content:
Context
În contextul crizei în desfășurare din Israel, rețelele sociale precum X și Facebook au fost invadate de știri false. O astfel de postare plasează în mod eronat imagini dintr-un clip video mai vechi, pentru a dezinforma și a crea panică.
Comparație între imaginea originală și cea preluată și folosită în știrea falsă. Se poate observa că este vorba despre același eveniment, al sosirii soldaților pe aeroportul Mihail Kogălniceanu
Videoclipul utilizat în postările cu informații false are rezoluție joasă și conține fragmente dintr-un videoclip mai lung, încărcat de Ministerul Apărării al Statelor Unite (DOD), care arată soldați ai Diviziei 101 Aeropurtate sosind pe aeroportul Mihail Kogălniceanu, în iunie 2022. Trupele americane au fost dislocate în România pentru a întări flancul estic al NATO, ca răspuns la invazia din Ucraina.
Narațiuni alimentate de astfel de conținuturi false/ înșelătoare:
„SUA dorește începerea unui război mondial.”
„SUA a mobilizat în secret trupe pentru a lupta în Israel.”
„SUA dorește escaladarea crizei din Orientul Mijlociu.”
„Criza din Orientul Mijlociu este creată de elitele globaliste din SUA.”
Evaluarea noastră:
Clip video și imagini scoase din context, atribuite în mod eronat evenimentelor din Israel. Clipul arată de fapt soldați ai armatei americane sosind în România, în iunie 2022, și nu în Israel, în octombrie 2023. Menționăm că știrile false sunt concepute pentru a manipula percepțiile și a distorsiona realitatea. În acest caz, dezinformarea, care se referă la o presupusă acțiune a SUA, poate deturna discuțiile constructive despre pace, amplificând narațiuni distorsionate, cu potențial de inflamare a opiniei publice.
Disclaimer!
Antifake scoate la suprafață și analizează conținuturi eronate, înșelătoare sau pur și simplu false, nu pentru a le amplifica sau a le oferi o vizibilitate nedorită în spațiul public, ci pentru a crește nivelul de conștientizare publică pe marginea lor.
Sursele noastre de fact-checking:
Apnews.com – Old video shows US Army arriving in Romania, not Marines landing in Israel
Reuters.com – Video shows US soldiers arriving in Romania in 2022, not Israel in 2023
Afp.com – Video from 2022 shows US troops landing in Romania, not Israel
Army.mil – 101st Airborne Division arrives in Europe to support NATO Allies
Translation:
Context
In the context of the ongoing crisis in Israel, social networks such as X and Facebook have been overrun with fake news. Such a post mistakenly places footage from an older video clip to misinform and create panic.
Comparison between the original image and the one taken and used in the fake news. It can be seen that it is about the same event, the arrival of the soldiers at the Mihail Kogălniceanu airport
The video used in the disinformation posts is low-resolution and contains fragments of a longer video uploaded by the United States Department of Defense (DOD) showing soldiers from the 101st Airborne Division arriving at Mihail Kogălniceanu Airport in June 2022. US troops were deployed in Romania to strengthen NATO's eastern flank, in response to the invasion from Ukraine.
Narratives fueled by such false/misleading content:
"The US wants to start a world war."
"US Secretly Mobilized Troops to Fight in Israel."
"The US wants to escalate the crisis in the Middle East."
"The Middle East crisis is being created by US globalist elites."
Our Rating:
Video clip and images taken out of context wrongly attributed to events in Israel. The clip actually shows US Army soldiers arriving in Romania in June 2022, not Israel in October 2023. We note that fake news is designed to manipulate perceptions and distort reality. In this case, disinformation, which refers to an alleged US action, can hijack constructive discussions about peace, amplifying distorted narratives with the potential to inflame public opinion.
Disclaimer!
Antifake surfaces and analyzes erroneous, misleading or simply fake content, not to amplify it or give it unwanted visibility in the public space, but to raise public awareness of it.
Our fact-checking sources:
Apnews.com – Old video shows US Army arriving in Romania, not Marines landing in Israel
Reuters.com – Video shows US soldiers arriving in Romania in 2022, not Israel in 2023
Afp.com – Video from 2022 shows US troops landing in Romania, not Israel
Army.mil – 101st Airborne Division arrives in Europe to support NATO Allies
false_claim: The US is sending troops in Israel.

content:
Правда ли, что к флагу ЛГБТ+ добавили цвета украинского флага?
В мае 2022 года в соцсетях стали публиковать одну из версий радужного флага, дополненную полосами жёлтого и синего цветов. Мы проверили, откуда взялась эта картинка.
Фотографию необычной модификации радужного флага в конце мая публиковали пользователи Facebook, «ВКонтакте», Twitter и других соцсетей. Обычно картинку сопровождали подписи вроде «Новый флаг ЛГБТ включает цвета украинского флага». Изображение опубликовал в своём Telegram-канале (116 000 подписчиков на момент написания этого разбора) политолог и регулярный участник стримов Владимира Соловьёва Сергей Карнаухов, уточнив, что «на Западе граждан Незалежной определили в секс-меньшинства». В других Telegram-каналах публикацию сопроводили комментарием советника руководителя офиса президента Украины Алексея Арестовича: «Включение цветов флага Украины в цвета флага мирового ЛГБТ-сообщества — признание наших доблестных ВСУ и беспрецедентная победа над мировым злом».
Радужный флаг ЛГБТ был разработан в конце 1970-х годов в Сан-Франциско — его придумал художник Гилберт Бейкер. Изначально на флаге было восемь полос, но впоследствии их число сократилось до шести. Всемирным символом ЛГБТ-сообщества, как утверждает энциклопедия Britannica, этот флаг стал уже в середине 1990-х годов.
Поскольку внешний вид флага ЛГБТ не закреплён в каких-либо документах, разные активисты регулярно предлагают дополненные и изменённые варианты. Например, основа заинтересовавшего нас изображения — версия под названием Progress Pride, разработанная в 2018 году американским дизайнером Даниэлем Куазаром. По его задумке, голубая, розовая и белая полосы репрезентируют трансгендерных и небинарных людей, а коричневая и чёрная — маргинализированные сообщества цветных людей. Чёрная полоса имеет двойное значение, поскольку она также напоминает о «тех, кто живёт со СПИДом, с окружающими их стигмой и предрассудками, а также тех, кто погиб из-за болезни».
Постоянно поступающие предложения по изменению и дополнению классического шестиполосного флага нередко вызывают дискуссии и даже насмешки. Как выяснили наши коллеги из Reuters, флаг Progress Pride с добавлением жёлтой и синей полос — тоже результат иронии над активистами, разрабатывающими, по их мнению, всё более инклюзивные версии.
22 мая канадский журналист Ким Сивер опубликовал в Twitter фотографию своего дома, окрашенного в цвета классического радужного флага. В ответ аккаунт @ProjectDroc напомнил Сиверу, что шестиполосный флаг устарел и «не подразумевает репрезентацию некоторых людей, например цветных», и призвал использовать версию, разработанную Куазаром. В свою очередь, пользователь @aryanfaggot высмеял этот ответ: его твит полностью повторяет запись @ProjectDroc, однако в нём слово «цветные» заменено на «украинцы». К твиту прикреплён и флаг с добавленными на него жёлтой и синей полосами.
Не все пользователи поняли, что комментарий @aryanfaggot носил иронический характер. Его даже опубликовала в Twitter член палаты представителей США Марджори Тейлор Грин. Представительница Республиканской партии сопроводила изображение подписью «Знают ли об этом нацисты в украинской армии?». Пользователь @aryanfaggot довольно быстро написал немало твитов, в которых удивился, что его шуточная картинка была воспринята всерьёз и стала столь популярной.
Нам не удалось найти комментарий о появлении цветов украинского флага на флаге ЛГБТ, который некоторые интернет-пользователи приписали Алексею Арестовичу. Мы не смогли обнаружить соответствующие записи ни в соцсетях политика, ни в его выступлениях в СМИ и на YouTube. Судя по данным сервиса TGStat, первоисточник этой цитаты — пост в Telegram-канале «Меркури» (72 000 подписчиков), появившийся днём 26 мая.
Reuters обращает внимание на то, что, хотя в Украине проходят гей-парады, их участники и активисты ещё совсем недавно подвергались нападениям. Как сообщают Pew Research Center и украинский правозащитный ЛГБТ-центр «Наш мир», уровень гомофобии в стране остаётся довольно высоким. Украинская конституция, как и российская, определяет брак исключительно как союз мужчины и женщины.
Итог: Сатирические новости
Translation:
Is it true that the colors of the Ukrainian flag were added to the LGBT+ flag?
In May 2022, one of the versions of the rainbow flag, supplemented with yellow and blue stripes, began to be published on social networks. We checked where this image came from.
A photo of an unusual modification of the rainbow flag was published at the end of May by users of Facebook, VKontakte, Twitter and other social networks. Usually, the image was accompanied by captions like “The new LGBT flag includes the colors of the Ukrainian flag.” The image was published on his Telegram channel (116,000 subscribers at the time of writing) by political scientist and regular participant in Vladimir Solovyov's streams Sergei Karnaukhov, who specified that “in the West, citizens of Nezalezhnaya were defined as sexual minorities.” In other Telegram channels, the publication was accompanied by a comment from the adviser to the head of the office of the President of Ukraine, Oleksiy Arestovych: “The inclusion of the colors of the Ukrainian flag in the colors of the flag of the world LGBT community is recognition of our valiant Armed Forces of Ukraine and an unprecedented victory over global evil.” The LGBT rainbow flag was developed in the late 1970s in San Francisco by artist Gilbert Baker. Initially, the flag had eight stripes, but their number was later reduced to six. According to the Britannica Encyclopedia, this flag became a global symbol of the LGBT community in the mid-1990s. Since the appearance of the LGBT flag is not fixed in any documents, various activists regularly offer supplemented and modified versions. For example, the basis of the image that interested us is a version called Progress Pride, developed in 2018 by American designer Daniel Coisard. According to his idea, the blue, pink and white stripes represent transgender and non-binary people, while the brown and black represent marginalized communities of color. The black stripe has a double meaning, as it also recalls “those living with AIDS, with the stigma and prejudice that surrounds them, as well as those who have died because of the disease.”
The constant proposals to change and supplement the classic six-striped flag often cause discussions and even ridicule. As our colleagues from Reuters found out, the Progress Pride flag with the addition of yellow and blue stripes is also the result of irony towards activists who are developing, in their opinion, increasingly inclusive versions.
On May 22, Canadian journalist Kim Seaver posted a photo on Twitter of his house painted in the colors of the classic rainbow flag. In response, @ProjectDroc reminded Seaver that the six-striped flag was outdated and “doesn’t represent certain people, like people of color,” and called for the version designed by Cuazar to be used. In turn, @aryanfaggot mocked this response: his tweet completely repeats @ProjectDroc’s post, but in it, the word “people of color” is replaced with “Ukrainians.” The tweet also includes a flag with yellow and blue stripes added to it.
Not all users realized that @aryanfaggot’s comment was ironic. It was even posted on Twitter by US Representative Marjorie Taylor Greene. The Republican representative accompanied the image with the caption “Do the Nazis in the Ukrainian army know this?” User @aryanfaggot quickly wrote a lot of tweets in which he expressed surprise that his joke image was taken seriously and became so popular. We were unable to find a comment about the appearance of the colors of the Ukrainian flag on the LGBT flag, which some Internet users attributed to Oleksiy Arestovych. We were unable to find any relevant posts either on the politician’s social networks or in his media appearances or on YouTube. According to the TGStat service, the original source of this quote is a post on the Telegram channel “Mercury” (72,000 subscribers), which appeared on the afternoon of May 26.
Reuters draws attention to the fact that, although gay parades are held in Ukraine, their participants and activists have recently been attacked. According to the Pew Research Center and the Ukrainian LGBT human rights center “Our World”, the level of homophobia in the country remains quite high. The Ukrainian constitution, like the Russian one, defines marriage exclusively as a union of a man and a woman.
Summary: Satirical news
false_claim: Ukraine flag’s colors have been added to the LGBTQ+ rainbow flag.

content:
El comunicado de Trump anunciando su vuelta a Twitter el 31 de octubre es falso
La imagen comenzó a circular tras formalizarse la compra de Twitter por parte de Elon Musk, pero no hay registros de que el expresidente de Estados Unidos haya publicado, a 2 de noviembre, un mensaje sobre su retorno a la plataforma
Circula en redes sociales una imagen de un supuesto comunicado del expresidente estadounidense Donald Trump en el que anuncia su vuelta a Twitter. La fotografía se ha compartido horas después de que Elon Musk finalizase la compra de esta red social el pasado 27 de octubre. La cuenta del expresidente fue suspendida en enero de 2021 tras sus comentarios sobre el asalto al Capitolio, los cuales fueron considerados una “incitación a la violencia” por parte de Twitter. Sin embargo, el comunicado que se ha difundido es falso.
“Trump anuncia que vuelve a Twitter. ‘Felicito a Elon Musk por la compra de Twitter, muchos dicen que el cambio era necesario, la directiva anterior tenía su agenda progre/woke… Me dijeron que mi cuenta volvería el Lunes. ¡Ya veremos!’”, dicen mensajes compartidos en Facebook y Twitter desde, al menos, el 28 de octubre. Están acompañados de una fotografía de lo que simula ser un comunicado emitido por Trump. Incluye la cabecera de “Save America” que aparece en los mensajes compartidos por el expresidente y, según la imagen, se habría difundido el 27 de octubre.
No obstante, no es cierto que Trump haya publicado dicho comunicado sobre su vuelta a Twitter. En la página web oficial del expresidente no hay registros de que una información igual o similar se haya publicado. Además, un antiguo asesor de su última campaña electoral afirmó que era “falso”.
El comunicado sobre Trump y su vuelta a Twitter es falso
La imagen viral indica que el supuesto mensaje del expresidente se emitió el pasado 27 de octubre. Este dice lo siguiente en inglés: “Enhorabuena a Elon Musk por su compra de Twitter. Mucha gente está diciendo que el cambio era necesario, dado que la antigua administración estaba demasiado preocupada por una agenda progresista. Se me ha notificado que mi cuenta volverá a estar activa el lunes [31], ya veremos. ¡Me alegro de poder interactuar con una empresa afroamericana!”
Una búsqueda en la página web oficial de Trump, donde comparte estos comunicados, no muestra ninguna publicación sobre su supuesta vuelta a Twitter. Tampoco hay rastro de ello en versiones archivadas de la web del 27 y 28 de octubre, cuando se habría emitido el mensaje.
Por otro lado, Brad Parscale, antiguo asesor de Trump que trabajó durante su última campaña electoral, desmintió el comunicado. “Esto es falso, obviamente. Si no proviene del sistema de prensa Campus Nucleus, es falso”. Además, el actual director de comunicaciones del expresidente, Taylor Budowich, retuiteó el mensaje.
Asimismo, el supuesto comunicado decía que la vuelta de Trump a Twitter sería el lunes 31 de octubre, pero esto tampoco ha ocurrido. A fecha de publicación de este artículo, la cuenta del expresidente sigue suspendida.
En cuanto a su posible retorno a la plataforma, Trump se refirió a ello en una entrevista en Fox News publicada el 28 de octubre. “Me gusta Elon [Musk], pero me quedo en Truth Social. Me gusta más, me gusta cómo funciona […] es como estar en casa”, declaró. En Truth Social, la red social que creó el expresidente, este volvió a remarcar que su plataforma “es mejor” que la recién adquirida por Musk y se alegró de que “Twitter esté ahora en manos sanas y dejará de estar dirigida por los maníacos y lunáticos radicales de izquierda que verdaderamente odian [Estados Unidos]”, según PolitiFact. Trump no hizo ninguna referencia a si iba a volver o no a Twitter.
[Elon Musk ya es el dueño Twitter, ¿y ahora qué?]
La compra de Twitter y la polémica sobre la verificación
La imagen viral del falso comunicado de Trump sobre una vuelta a Twitter se ha compartido horas después de que el multimillonario Elon Musk finalizase la compra de esta red social. Días más tarde de la adquisición, Musk anunció algunas de las novedades que incorporaría a la plataforma, algunas de ellas afectando al sistema de verificación de usuarios.
Actualmente, en algunos países se tiene la opción de pagar 4,99 dólares al mes por la suscripción de Twitter Blue que ofrece a los usuarios la posibilidad de leer artículos sin publicidad, editar tuits y customizar la barra de navegación, según The Verge. Este mismo medio informó de que, tras la compra de Musk, la suscripción a Twitter Blue pasaría a costar 19,99 dólares mensuales e incluiría el icono azul con un tic que sirve para indicar que la cuenta está verificada, aunque esta medida no ha sido aplicada todavía.
El hecho de tener que pagar hasta 240 dólares al año para mantener el símbolo de verificación, independientemente de querer beneficiarse o no de las herramientas que ofrece Twitter Blue, causó críticas entre numerosos usuarios de la red social. Es por ello por lo que el empresario anunció que rebajaría el precio de la suscripción a 8 dólares al mes en Estados Unidos, que “se ajustará a cada país en proporción a la paridad de su poder adquisitivo”, añadió The Verge.
Translation:
Trump's statement announcing his return to Twitter on October 31 is false
The image began to circulate after the purchase of Twitter by Elon Musk was formalized, but there are no records that the former president of the United States has published, on November 2, a message about his return to the platform
An image of an alleged statement from former US President Donald Trump is circulating on social networks in which he announces his return to Twitter. The photograph was shared hours after Elon Musk finalized the purchase of this social network on October 27. The former president's account was suspended in January 2021 after his comments about the assault on the Capitol, which were considered “incitement to violence” by Twitter. However, the statement that has been released is false.
“Trump announces that he is returning to Twitter. 'I congratulate Elon Musk for the purchase of Twitter, many say that the change was necessary, the previous board had its progressive/woke agenda... They told me that my account would return on Monday. We’ll see!’” read messages shared on Facebook and Twitter since at least October 28. They are accompanied by a photograph of what appears to be a statement issued by Trump. It includes the “Save America” header that appears in the messages shared by the former president and, according to the image, it would have been broadcast on October 27.
However, it is not true that Trump published such a statement about his return to Twitter. On the former president's official website there are no records that the same or similar information has been published. In addition, a former advisor to his last election campaign claimed that it was “false.”
The statement about Trump and his return to Twitter is false
The viral image indicates that the former president's supposed message was issued on October 27. It says the following in English: “Congratulations to Elon Musk for purchasing Twitter from him. Many people are saying that the change was necessary, since the old administration was too concerned with a progressive agenda. I've been notified that my account will be active again on Monday [31], we'll see. I’m glad I got to interact with an African American business!”
A search of Trump's official website, where he shares these statements, does not show any posts about his alleged return to Twitter. There is also no trace of it in archived versions of the website from October 27 and 28, when the message would have been issued.
On the other hand, Brad Parscale, a former Trump advisor who worked during his last election campaign, denied the statement. “This is false, obviously. If it doesn't come from the Campus Nucleus press system, it's fake.” Additionally, the former president's current communications director, Taylor Budowich, retweeted the message.
Likewise, the supposed statement said that Trump's return to Twitter would be on Monday, October 31, but this has not happened either. As of the publication of this article, the former president's account remains suspended.
Regarding his possible return to the platform, Trump referred to it in an interview on Fox News published on October 28. “I like Elon [Musk], but I'm sticking to Truth Social. I like it better, I like how it works […] it's like being at home,” he declared. In Truth Social, the social network created by the former president, he once again stressed that his platform “is better” than the one recently acquired by Musk and was glad that “Twitter is now in healthy hands and will no longer be run by maniacs and radical left-wing lunatics who truly hate [the United States],” according to PolitiFact. Trump made no reference to whether or not he would return to Twitter.
[Elon Musk already owns Twitter, what now?]
The purchase of Twitter and the controversy over verification
The viral image of Trump's false statement about a return to Twitter has been shared hours after billionaire Elon Musk finalized the purchase of this social network. Days after the acquisition, Musk announced some of the new features that he would incorporate into the platform, some of them affecting the user verification system.
Currently, in some countries you have the option of paying $4.99 per month for a Twitter Blue subscription that offers users the ability to read articles without advertising, edit tweets and customize the navigation bar, according to The Verge. This same medium reported that, after Musk's purchase, the Twitter Blue subscription would cost $19.99 per month and would include the blue icon with a tick that serves to indicate that the account is verified, although this measure has not been still applied.
The fact of having to pay up to $240 a year to maintain the verification symbol, regardless of whether or not you want to benefit from the tools offered by Twitter Blue, caused criticism among many users of the social network. This is why the businessman announced that he would lower the subscription price to $8 per month in the United States, which “will be adjusted to each country in proportion to the parity of its purchasing power,” added The Verge.
false_claim: Donald Trump's public statement congratulating Elon Musk on buying Twitter and announcing his readmission starting October 31st.

content:
Altes Foto zeigt mutmaßliche Giftgasopfer aus Syrien
20.10.2023, 16:56 (CEST)
Warnung: Manche der in diesem Artikel verlinkten Seiten zeigen Opfer von Gewalt.
Vom Angriff der Hamas auf Israel haben Nutzer sich grausame Bilder in sozialen Netzwerken verbreitet. Ähnlich ist es nun nach den darauf folgenden Angriffen der israelischen Streitkräfte auf den Gaza-Streifen. Darunter ist aber auch Material, das mit dem aktuellen Geschehen nichts zu tun hat. Ein Beispiel ist ein Foto mit mehreren in weiße Tücher gewickelten Kinderleichen. «Eins von vielen Bildern, die uns nicht gezeigt werden», steht in einem Facebookpost, der Hashtag «#FreePalestine» legt nahe, es seien Kinder, die im aktuellen Konflikt getötet wurden. Die «Quelle ist Gaza!», behaupten Nutzer entsprechend in den Kommentaren.
Bewertung
Das Foto ist von 2013 und zeigt zahlreichen Berichten zufolge Opfer eines Giftgaseinsatzes in Syrien.
Fakten
Das Foto ist bereits 2013 von zahlreichen Medien veröffentlicht worden, etwa hier, hier, hier und hier. Es soll Opfer von Giftgasangriffen zeigen, die damals in Syrien durchgeführt wurden. Das Foto ist also definitiv vor 2023 erschienen und zeigt keine Opfer im Zusammenhang mit dem aktuellen Gaza-Krieg.
Der syrische Konflikt hatte 2011 mit Protesten gegen die Regierung von Bashar al-Assad begonnen. Nach der gewalttätigen Niederschlagung der Proteste brach ein blutiger Bürgerkrieg aus. Eine Untersuchung der Vereinten Nationen hat bestätigt, dass es am 21. August 2013 eine Gas-Attacke mit dem Gift Sarin auf Bewohner in der Region Ghuta gegeben hat. Die Opposition lastete die Attacke der Regierung an, die bestreitet ihre Verantwortung.
(Stand:)
Links:
National Geographic (archiviert)
Radio Free Europe (archiviert)
Über dpa-Faktenchecks
Dieser Faktencheck wurde im Rahmen des Facebook/Meta-Programms für unabhängige Faktenprüfung erstellt. Ausführliche Informationen zu diesem Programm finden Sie hier.
Erläuterungen von Facebook/Meta zum Umgang mit Konten, die Falschinformationen verbreiten, finden Sie hier.
Wenn Sie inhaltliche Einwände oder Anmerkungen haben, schicken Sie diese bitte mit einem Link zu dem betroffenen Facebook-Post an faktencheck@dpa.com. Nutzen Sie hierfür bitte die entsprechenden Vorlagen. Hinweise zu Einsprüchen finden Sie hier.
Schon gewusst?
Wenn Sie Zweifel an einer Nachricht, einer Behauptung, einem Bild oder einem Video haben, können Sie den dpa-Faktencheck auch per WhatsApp kontaktieren. Weitere Informationen dazu finden Sie hier.
Translation:
Old photo shows suspected poison gas victims from Syria
Oct 20, 2023, 4:56 p.m. (CEST)
Warning: Some of the sites linked to in this article feature victims of violence.
Users have shared gruesome images of Hamas' attack on Israel on social networks. The situation is similar now after the subsequent attacks by the Israeli armed forces on the Gaza Strip. But this also includes material that has nothing to do with current events. An example is a photo with several children's corpses wrapped in white cloths. “One of many pictures that are not shown to us,” says a Facebook post, the hashtag “#FreePalestine” suggests that they are children who were killed in the current conflict. The “source is Gaza!”, users claim in the comments.
Evaluation
The photo is from 2013 and, according to numerous reports, shows victims of a poison gas operation in Syria.
Facts
The photo was published by numerous media outlets in 2013, including here, here, here and here. It is intended to show victims of poison gas attacks that were carried out in Syria at the time. The photo was definitely published before 2023 and does not show any victims in connection with the current Gaza war.
The Syrian conflict began in 2011 with protests against the government of Bashar al-Assad. After the violent suppression of the protests, a bloody civil war broke out. A United Nations investigation has confirmed that there was a gas attack with the poison sarin on residents in the Ghouta region on August 21, 2013. The opposition blamed the attack on the government, which denied responsibility.
(as of:)
Left:
National Geographic (archived)
Radio Free Europe (archived)
About dpa fact checks
This fact check was created as part of the Facebook/Meta independent fact-checking program. Detailed information about this program can be found here.
Facebook/Meta's explanation of how to deal with accounts that spread false information can be found here.
If you have any objections or comments regarding the content, please send them to faktencheck@dpa.com with a link to the affected Facebook post. Please use the relevant templates for this. Information on objections can be found here.
Did you know?
If you have doubts about a message, claim, image or video, you can also contact the dpa fact check via WhatsApp. Further information can be found here.
false_claim: Images and videos are showing current violence against civilians in Gaza, such as portraying Palestinian victims.

content:
“Deve absolutamente libertar Julian Assange.
É sensível ao tempo e urgente.
Ele não tem mais um ano para esperar atrás das grades enquanto as rodas da ‘justiça’ o esmagam lentamente.
Agora é o momento. Agora é quando fala, quando se levanta.”
O texto é o de uma publicação no Twitter que se tornou viral, essencialmente pela imagem que a acompanha: uma aparente fotografia de Julian Assange (51 anos), em que o fundador da WikiLeaks, que se encontra detido em Londres desde abril de 2019, aparece num estado bastante degradado.
O tweet tornou-se viral e acabou por despertar a curiosidade sobre a autenticidade da imagem apresentada. Mas esta é mesmo verdadeira?
Quando a imagem é aproximada/aumentada, pelo menos três pormenores levantam as maiores dúvidas sobre a veracidade da suposta fotografia do jornalista e programador informático sobre o qual impende um pedido de extradição emitido pela justiça dos Estados Unidos, conforme assinala a “Maldita.es”, plataforma espanhola de verificação de factos.
O primeiro é a sombra demasiado pronunciada da maçã do rosto. As outras características que apontam para a artificialidade da imagem são o cabelo e a pele da testa, que aparentam uma textura não humana.
As suspeitas de que podia, afinal, não tratar-se de uma fotografia levou o jornal alemão “Bild” a procurar o autor da publicação – “The Errant Friend”. Na entrevista que concedeu à publicação, reconheceu ser uma criação sua, através do recurso à inteligência artificial, mais propriamente ao programa “MidJourney V5”, que constrói imagens a partir de uma descrição de texto. O objetivo foi o de “criar algo que colocasse as pessoas em um dilema moral” e ao mesmo tempo que o público fosse “testemunha” do que está a ser feito a Assange, conforme confidenciou “The Errant Friend” ao jornal sediado em Berlim.
O autor desta manipulação é um ativista pró-Assange, como é visível na autodescrição inscrita na sua conta de Twitter: “Silent no more. Free Assange.”
É, assim, manipulada (através do recurso à inteligência artificial) a imagem de Julian Assange que se tornou viral, na qual o fundador da WikiLeaks aparece debilitado.
____________________________
Avaliação do Polígrafo:
Translation:
“You must absolutely free Julian Assange.
It is time sensitive and urgent.
He doesn’t have another year to wait behind bars while the wheels of ‘justice’ slowly crush him.
Now is the time. Now is when he speaks, when he stands up.”
The text is from a post on Twitter that went viral, essentially due to the image that accompanies it: an apparent photograph of Julian Assange (51 years old), in which the founder of WikiLeaks, who has been detained in London since April 2019, appears in a very degraded state.
The tweet went viral and ended up sparking curiosity about the authenticity of the image presented. But is this really true?
When the image is zoomed in/enlarged, at least three details raise major doubts about the veracity of the supposed photograph of the journalist and computer programmer, who is subject to an extradition request issued by the United States courts, as highlighted by “Maldita.es”. , Spanish fact-checking platform.
The first is the too pronounced shadow on the cheekbone. The other characteristics that point to the artificiality of the image are the hair and the skin on the forehead, which appear to have a non-human texture.
Suspicions that it might not be a photograph after all led the German newspaper “Bild” to look for the author of the publication – “The Errant Friend”. In the interview he gave to the publication, he acknowledged that it was his creation, using artificial intelligence, more specifically the “MidJourney V5” program, which builds images from a text description. The objective was to “create something that puts people in a moral dilemma” and at the same time for the public to be “witness” to what is being done to Assange, as “The Errant Friend” confided in the Berlin-based newspaper.
The author of this manipulation is a pro-Assange activist, as is visible in the self-description posted on his Twitter account: “Silent no more. Free Assange.”
Thus, the image of Julian Assange that went viral, in which the founder of WikiLeaks appears weakened, was manipulated (through the use of artificial intelligence).
____________________________
Polygraph Assessment:
false_claim: Image shows Julian Assange in jail.

content:
La portavoce della Casa Bianca non ha parlato di manifestazioni naziste in Ucraina
Il 9 maggio 2024 è stato pubblicato su Facebook un post contenente la presunta risposta che Karine Jean-Pierre, portavoce della Casa Bianca, avrebbe fornito alla domanda di un giornalista durante una conferenza stampa. Il giornalista avrebbe chiesto: «È noto che l’Ucraina ha opinioni contrastanti su questa ideologia [il nazismo]. Perché non condanniamo le manifestazioni del nazismo in Ucraina e continuiamo a sponsorizzarlo?». A questa domanda, Karine Jean-Pierre avrebbe risposto: «79 anni fa, gli Stati Uniti e i nostri alleati ucraini unirono le forze per combattere i regimi totalitari di Hitler e Stalin. Mentre Berlino è ora un alleato, la minaccia da est rimane. Pertanto, continueremo a sostenere l’Ucraina, daremo il nostro pieno appoggio con ogni mezzo disponibile».
Si tratta di una notizia falsa.
L’informazione infondata proviene da un video, diffuso su X l’8 maggio 2024, che sembra mostrare lo scambio tra il giornalista e la portavoce della Casa Bianca citato nel post oggetto di analisi. Il filmato ha sottotitoli in russo.
Analizzando il video in questione, tuttavia, si notano delle incongruenze che fanno dedurre che si tratta di un filmato modificato digitalmente. Ad esempio, il movimento delle labbra delle persone riprese non sempre corrisponde all’audio delle parole pronunciate.
Il video mostra un momento della conferenza stampa svoltasi alla Casa Bianca il 7 maggio 2024. Come si può verificare guardando l’intera conferenza stampa – o leggendo la trascrizione integrale dell’evento – lo scambio tra il giornalista e Karine Jean-Pierre presente nel post oggetto di analisi non è mai avvenuto.
Il giornalista ripreso non ha posto una domanda su Ucraina e nazismo, e la portavoce della Casa Bianca non ha mai risposto citando la seconda guerra mondiale e regimi totalitari di Hitler e Stalin. Nel video originale, invece, il giornalista, al minuto 18:31, parla della situazione estremamente difficile per la popolazione nella Striscia di Gaza e della chiusura continua da parte di Israele dei valichi, domandando se la Casa Bianca «ha qualche piano per convincere Israele affinché consenta un flusso costante di aiuti a Gaza». Karine Jean-Pierre risponde su questo tema, dichiarando che è inaccettabile che i valichi vengano chiusi e che per questo motivo il presidente degli Stati Uniti Joe Biden ha chiamato direttamente il premier israeliano Benjamin Netanyahu.
Questo tipo di disinformazione, rientra nel filone della propaganda russa che punta a dipingere il governo ucraino guidato da nazisti o da persone affascinate da questa ideologia.
Translation:
The White House spokeswoman did not mention Nazi demonstrations in Ukraine
On May 9, 2024, a post was published on Facebook containing the alleged answer that White House spokeswoman Karine Jean-Pierre gave to a journalist's question during a press conference. The journalist reportedly asked: «It is known that Ukraine has conflicting opinions on this ideology [Nazism]. Why don't we condemn the manifestations of Nazism in Ukraine and continue to sponsor it?". To this question, Karine Jean-Pierre would have responded: «79 years ago, the United States and our Ukrainian allies joined forces to fight the totalitarian regimes of Hitler and Stalin. While Berlin is now an ally, the threat from the east remains. Therefore, we will continue to support Ukraine, we will give our full support by all available means."
This is fake news.
The unfounded information comes from a video, released on X on May 8, 2024, which appears to show the exchange between the journalist and the White House spokeswoman cited in the post being analyzed. The film has Russian subtitles.
Analyzing the video in question, however, we notice some inconsistencies that lead us to deduce that it is a digitally modified film. For example, the movement of the lips of people filmed does not always correspond to the audio of the spoken words.
The video shows a moment of the press conference held at the White House on May 7, 2024. As can be verified by watching the entire press conference - or reading the full transcript of the event - the exchange between the journalist and Karine Jean-Pierre present in the post object of analysis never occurred.
The reprimanded journalist did not ask a question about Ukraine and Nazism, and the White House spokeswoman never responded by mentioning World War II and the totalitarian regimes of Hitler and Stalin. In the original video, however, the journalist, at minute 18:31, talks about the extremely difficult situation for the population in the Gaza Strip and Israel's continuous closure of the crossings, asking if the White House «has any plan to convince Israel to allow a constant flow of aid to Gaza." Karine Jean-Pierre responds on this issue, declaring that it is unacceptable that the crossings are closed and that for this reason United States President Joe Biden called Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu directly.
This type of disinformation falls within the trend of Russian propaganda which aims to portray the Ukrainian government as led by Nazis or people fascinated by this ideology.
false_claim: A White House spokesperson discussed why the US supports Nazism in Ukraine.

content:
Attention, cette vidéo n'a pas été tournée en banlieue parisienne mais en Ouzbékistan en mai 2023
- Cet article date de plus d'un an
- Publié le 03 juillet 2023 à 10:45
- Lecture : 3 min
- Par : Bénédicte REY, AFP France
Copyright AFP 2017-2024. Toute réutilisation commerciale du contenu est sujet à un abonnement. Cliquez ici pour en savoir plus.
"Explosion à Créteil", affirme cet internaute, dans une vidéo vue plus de 11.600 fois sur Tik Tok. La vidéo, virale, est diffusée par de nombreux autres utilisateurs de réseau social, qui ne précisent pas sa localisation mais la relie toujours aux émeutes en cours en France (ici, ici ou ici).
La même vidéo circule sur Twitter, dans un message retweeté 200 fois ou sur Facebook dont cet utilisateur localise cette fois l'explosion à Clichy.
Si de nombreuses images ont circulé sur les réseaux de heurts, incendies ou pillages dans plusieurs villes de France, celle-ci a néanmoins été décontextualisée.
Une explosion en mai 2023 en Ouzbékistan
Une recherche d'image inversée - procédé qui permet de retrouver les précédentes utilisations d'une image sur internet - montre que cette vidéo circulait déjà avant le début des émeutes qui ont suivi la mort de Nahel, le 27 juin 2023.
La vidéo a été publiée la première fois le 10 mai 2023 par plusieurs médias, dont la chaîne de télévision turque TRT (vidéo ci-dessous), qui explique qu'il s'agit de l'explosion d'une station de gaz naturel liquéfié en Ouzbékistan le 9 mai.
Plusieurs vidéos de la même explosion ont été postées sur la messagerie Telegram le 10 mai 2023 à 07H44 (ici et ici). Sur les captures d'écran ci-dessous, on reconnaît la même forme de boule de feu (encadrée en rouge) que dans les vidéos prétendument tournées en France le 29 juin, ainsi que le même bâtiment au premier plan (encadré en jaune).
Le 10 mai 2023, d'autres médias, dont le quotidien ouzbèke The Tashkent Times ou le média britannique Daily Express ont publié des articles reprenant des captures d'écran de cette vidéo.
"Un violent incendie s'est déclaré le soir du 9 mai dans une station de remplissage de gaz située près de l'entreprise d'approvisionnement en gaz dans le district de Pakhtachi de la province de Samarcande. Cela a entraîné une explosion, qui a été capturée dans de nombreuses vidéos circulant sur les réseaux sociaux", écrivait The Tashkent Times. Une personne a été blessée dans l'accident.
Plusieurs nuits de violences en France
Le gouvernement a annoncé (lien archivé ici) le 30 juin le déploiement de blindés de la gendarmerie pour tenter d'enrayer le cycle des violences, pillages et destructions qui agitent de nombreuses villes du pays depuis le décès quatre jours plut tôt du jeune Nahel, tué par un policier lors d'un contrôle routier.
Saisi par une vidéo amateur, le tir à bout portant d'un motard de la police sur l'adolescent de 17 ans lors d'un contrôle routier à Nanterre, a embrasé de nombreux quartiers populaires du pays.
Des écoles et des édifices publics ont été la cible de la colère de jeunes habitants des quartiers populaires et incendiés dans de multiples villes de France, rappelant les émeutes qui avaient embrasé la France en 2005 après la mort de deux adolescents poursuivis par la police.
Malgré l'arrestation de 875 personnes dans la nuit du 29 au 30 juin, 492 bâtiments ont été visés, 2.000 véhicules brûlés et des dizaines de magasins pillés, notamment en plein cœur de Paris.
Emmanuel Macron a appelé "tous les parents à la responsabilité", critiquant l'"instrumentalisation" de la mort de Nahel et demandant aux réseaux sociaux le "retrait" de contenus et l'identification d'utilisateurs liés à ces violences urbaines.
Translation:
Please note, this video was not filmed in the Paris suburbs but in Uzbekistan in May 2023
- This article is over a year old
- Published on July 3, 2023 at 10:45 a.m.
- Reading: 3 min
- By: Bénédicte REY, AFP France
Copyright AFP 2017-2024. Any commercial reuse of the content is subject to a subscription. Click here to learn more.
“Explosion in Créteil”, affirms this Internet user, in a video seen more than 11,600 times on Tik Tok. The viral video is broadcast by many other social network users, who do not specify its location but always link it to the ongoing riots in France (here, here or here).
The same video is circulating on Twitter, in a message retweeted 200 times or on Facebook, where this user this time locates the explosion in Clichy.
Although numerous images have circulated on the networks of clashes, fires or looting in several cities in France, they have nevertheless been decontextualized.
An explosion in May 2023 in Uzbekistan
A reverse image search - a process which allows you to find previous uses of an image on the internet - shows that this video was already circulating before the start of the riots which followed Nahel's death, on June 27, 2023.
The video was first published on May 10, 2023 by several media outlets, including Turkish television channel TRT (video below), which explains that it is an explosion at a liquefied natural gas station. in Uzbekistan on May 9.
Several videos of the same explosion were posted on Telegram messaging on May 10, 2023 at 7:44 a.m. (here and here). In the screenshots below, we recognize the same fireball shape (boxed in red) as in the videos allegedly filmed in France on June 29, as well as the same building in the foreground (boxed in yellow).
On May 10, 2023, other media, including the Uzbek daily The Tashkent Times and the British media Daily Express, published articles containing screenshots of this video.
"A severe fire broke out on the evening of May 9 at a gas filling station located near the gas supply enterprise in the Pakhtachi district of Samarkand province. This led to an explosion, which been captured in numerous videos circulating on social media,” wrote The Tashkent Times. One person was injured in the accident.
Several nights of violence in France
The government announced (archived link here) on June 30 the deployment of gendarmerie armored vehicles to try to stop the cycle of violence, looting and destruction which has shaken many cities in the country since the death four days earlier of young Nahel, killed by a police officer during a traffic stop.
Seized by an amateur video, the point-blank shooting of a police motorcyclist on the 17-year-old teenager during a road check in Nanterre, set many working-class neighborhoods in the country ablaze.
Schools and public buildings were the target of the anger of young residents of working-class neighborhoods and set on fire in multiple cities in France, recalling the riots which engulfed France in 2005 after the death of two teenagers pursued by the police.
Despite the arrest of 875 people on the night of June 29 to 30, 492 buildings were targeted, 2,000 vehicles burned and dozens of stores looted, particularly in the heart of Paris.
Emmanuel Macron called "all parents to responsibility", criticizing the "instrumentalization" of Nahel's death and asking social networks to "remove" content and identify users linked to this urban violence.
false_claim: Videos and images showing riots in France after the death of Nahel Merzouk.

content:
La fotografía de la bandera palestina proyectada en la Torre de El Cairo (Egipto) es un montaje
La fotografía original fue tomada en 2010, no muestra ninguna bandera y corresponde a un banco de imágenes
Circula por redes sociales una imagen de la Torre de El Cairo, en Egipto, supuestamente iluminada con la bandera de Palestina. La fotografía muestra el edificio con luces sobre un cielo nocturno. No obstante, se trata de un montaje. La enseña palestina ha sido superpuesta sobre una imagen publicada en un banco de imágenes en 2010.
La imagen manipulada circula en Facebook y X (antes Twitter) de distintas formas. La más difundida se trata de la bandera de Palestina proyectada en la Torre de El Cairo de forma vertical, con el triángulo rojo en la parte superior. Sin embargo, en X se han compartido fotos del edificio iluminado con la bandera palestina con menos intensidad y en horizontal.
Ambas fotos se han comenzado a difundir desde el 8 de octubre. Algunos mensajes apuntan a que se trata de una reacción de Egipto ante la agresión israelí en la Franja de Gaza. Sin embargo, la imagen editada circula por redes sociales desde al menos mayo de 2021.
La imagen de la Torre de El Cairo iluminada con la bandera palestina es un montaje
Una búsqueda inversa de la fotografía viral en Tineye arroja como resultado un archivo del banco de imágenes Wikimedia Commons que fue publicado en febrero de 2010. Este archivo se trata de la fotografía original que ha sido utilizada posteriormente en redes sociales para superponer la bandera de Palestina.
La luna situada a la derecha de la torre, la iluminación del edificio en tonos morados y la forma provocada por la sombra de los árboles en la zona inferior evidencia que la fotografía difundida se trata de una edición digital de la original, que fue tomada en 2010.
Además, la iluminación de la bandera de Palestina que supuestamente se ha proyectado en la Torre de El Cairo supone un alto contraste con el resto de la fotografía. Aunque el color verde de la bandera es transparente y deja ver de fondo el edificio, el color blanco se muestra opaco.
El bulo ya se difundió en mayo de 2021
No es la primera vez que se difunde esta imagen de la bandera palestina en la Torre de El Cairo. Como demuestra una búsqueda inversa en Google Imágenes, existen diversas publicaciones en Facebook y X desde mayo de 2021 que comparten la foto con mensajes de apoyo a Palestina.
Entonces, varios verificadores que forman parte de la red internacional IFCN, al igual que Newtral.es, ya advirtieron de que se trataba de una imagen manipulada, como es el caso de la agencia francesa AFP y el medio indio de verificación Factly.
En mayo de 2021, cuando comenzó a difundirse la imagen manipulada con la bandera de palestina proyectada sobre la Torre de El Cairo, hubo una escalada de las tensiones entre Israel y Palestina, lo que provocó mucha desinformación. A principios de este mes se desencadenaron distintos ataques de Israel sobre Gaza y de las milicias palestinas sobre Tel Aviv, la capital israelí. Este enfrentamiento finalizó con un alto al fuego tras once días de ataque aéreos
Fuentes
Verificaciones de AFP y Factly
Búsqueda inversa de Google Imágenes y Tineye
Artículo sobre el alto al fuego de mayo de 2021 del canal de televisión francés France24
Translation:
The photograph of the Palestinian flag projected on the Cairo Tower (Egypt) is a montage
The original photograph was taken in 2010, does not show any flag and corresponds to an image bank
An image of the Cairo Tower, in Egypt, supposedly illuminated with the flag of Palestine, is circulating on social networks. The photograph shows the building with lights against a night sky. However, it is a montage. The Palestinian flag has been superimposed on an image published in an image bank in 2010.
The manipulated image circulates on Facebook and X (formerly Twitter) in different ways. The most widespread is the flag of Palestine projected on the Cairo Tower vertically, with the red triangle at the top. However, in X, photos of the building illuminated with the Palestinian flag less intensely and horizontally have been shared.
Both photos have begun to be spread since October 8. Some messages suggest that this is Egypt's reaction to Israeli aggression in the Gaza Strip. However, the edited image has been circulating on social networks since at least May 2021.
The image of the Cairo Tower illuminated with the Palestinian flag is a montage
A reverse search for the viral photograph in Tineye results in a file from the Wikimedia Commons image bank that was published in February 2010. This file is the original photograph that has subsequently been used on social networks to superimpose the flag of Palestine .
The moon located to the right of the tower, the lighting of the building in purple tones and the shape caused by the shadow of the trees in the lower area show that the photograph distributed is a digital edition of the original, which was taken in 2010.
Furthermore, the lighting of the Palestinian flag that has supposedly been projected on the Cairo Tower represents a high contrast with the rest of the photograph. Although the green color of the flag is transparent and allows the building to be seen in the background, the white color appears opaque.
The hoax already spread in May 2021
It is not the first time that this image of the Palestinian flag on the Cairo Tower has been spread. As a reverse search on Google Images demonstrates, there are several posts on Facebook and X since May 2021 that share the photo with messages of support for Palestine.
So, several verifiers that are part of the international IFCN network, like Newtral.es, already warned that it was a manipulated image, as is the case of the French agency AFP and the Indian verification media Factly.
In May 2021, when the manipulated image with the Palestinian flag projected on the Cairo Tower began to spread, there was an escalation of tensions between Israel and Palestine, which caused a lot of misinformation. At the beginning of this month, various attacks by Israel on Gaza and by Palestinian militias on Tel Aviv, the Israeli capital, were unleashed. This confrontation ended with a ceasefire after eleven days of air attacks
Sources
AFP and Factly verifications
Google Images Reverse Search and Tineye
Article on the May 2021 ceasefire from the French television channel France24
false_claim: Images shows international support for Palestine, such as Palestinian flags on monuments and in stadiums.

content:
Τρεις φαινομενικά διαφορετικές φωτογραφίες του ίδιου κοριτσιού που ανασύρεται από τα ερείπια βομβαρδισμένου κτιρίου, συνοδεύεται από τον ισχυρισμό πως προέρχονται από την Παλαιστίνη και έχουν χρησιμοποιηθεί για να δώσουν την εντύπωση πως τα θύματα στη Λωρίδα της Γάζας, από τους ισραηλινούς βομβαρδισμούς είναι λιγότερα.
ΙΣΧΥΡΙΣΜΟΣ: Στις 3 “διασώσεις” παιδιού στην “παλαιστίνη”,η μια δώρο!!
ΣΥΜΠΕΡΑΣΜΑ: Οι φωτογραφίες είναι από το Χαλέπι της Συρίας και τραβήχτηκαν το 2016, έπειτα από βομβαρδισμό από δυνάμεις του καθεστώτος Άσαντ. Απεικονίζουν το ίδιο περιστατικό.
Ανάλυση
Αρχικά, αν προσέξουμε το σήμα στο κάτω δεξιά μέρος της φωτογραφίας που επισημαίνουμε με κόκκινο βέλος, διαπιστώνουμε ότι προέρχεται από την οργάνωση Λευκά Κράνη που δραστηριοποιείται στη Συρία.
Η ανθρωπιστική οργάνωση Λευκά Κράνη που δραστηριοποιείται από το 2014 στις ελεγχόμενες από τη συριακή αντιπολίτευση περιοχές. Τα Λευκά Κράνη κατηγορούνται ως τρομοκρατική οργάνωση από την κυβέρνηση του Μπασάρ αλ Άσαντ. Η δραστηριότητα τους στη Συρία περιλαμβάνει διασώσεις, απεγκλωβισμούς από βομβαρδισμένα κτίρια και εκκενώσεις αμάχων. Έχουν βρεθεί συχνά στο στόχαστρο της ρωσικής και συριακής προπαγάνδας και γίνονται προσπάθειες εξουδετέρωσής τους. Εκτός από τη διάσωση ζωών, έχουν πιστωθεί με την τεκμηρίωση εγκλημάτων πολέμου που έχει διαπράξει το καθεστώς Άσαντ.
Όσον αφορά τις 3 εικόνες που δήθεν προέρχονται από τη Γάζα, στην πραγματικότητα έχουν τραβηχτεί από φωτογράφο του Γαλλικού Πρακτορείου Ειδήσεων (AFP) το 2016 στη Συρία.
Πιο αναλυτικά, ο φωτογράφος Ameer Alhalbi, τράβηξε τις φωτογραφίες στις 27 Αυγούστου 2016 στο Χαλέπι της Συρίας. Δείχνουν διασώστες των Λευκών Κρανών, να απεγκλωβίζουν ένα κορίτσι από τα ερείπια κτιρίων που κατέρρευσε έπειτα από βομβαρδισμούς του καθεστώτος Άσαντ στην περιοχή.
Επιπλέον φωτογραφίες του ίδιου παιδιού από το ίδιο περιστατικό στο Χαλέπι το 2016.
Το 2018, είχαν κυκλοφορήσει ξανά οι ίδιες φωτογραφίες που εξετάζουμε με τον ισχυρισμό πως δείχνουν μια σκηνοθετημένη επίθεση εναντίον αμάχων στη Συρία και το “στήσιμο” της διάσωσης από τις δυνάμεις των αντικαθεστωτικών. Ο ισχυρισμός ωστόσο είχε καταρριφθεί από το AFP.
Συμπέρασμα
Οι υπό εξέταση φωτογραφίες δεν δείχνουν το ίδιο κορίτσι να χρησιμοποιείται για να παραστήσει 3 διαφορετικά θύματα στη Γάζα. Είναι από το Χαλέπι της Συρίας και τραβήχτηκαν το 2016, έπειτα από βομβαρδισμό από δυνάμεις του καθεστώτος Άσσαντ. Απεικονίζουν το ίδιο περιστατικό.
Translation:
Three seemingly different photographs of the same girl being pulled from the rubble of a bombed building, accompanied by the claim that they are from Palestine, have been used to give the impression that casualties in the Gaza Strip from Israeli bombing are fewer.
CLAIM: In the 3 "rescues" of a child in "Palestine", one is a gift!!
CONCLUSION: The photos are from Aleppo, Syria and were taken in 2016, after a bombardment by Assad regime forces. They depict the same incident.
Analysis
First, if we pay attention to the sign in the lower right part of the photo that we mark with a red arrow, we find that it comes from the White Helmets organization that is active in Syria.
The humanitarian organization Lefka Krani which has been active since 2014 in the areas controlled by the Syrian opposition. The White Helmets are accused of being a terrorist organization by the government of Bashar al-Assad. Their activity in Syria includes rescues, rescues from bombed buildings and civilian evacuations. They have often been the target of Russian and Syrian propaganda and efforts are being made to neutralize them. In addition to saving lives, they have been credited with documenting war crimes committed by the Assad regime.
As for the 3 images purportedly from Gaza, they were actually taken by an AFP photographer in 2016 in Syria.
In more detail, photographer Ameer Alhalbi took the photos on August 27, 2016 in Aleppo, Syria. They show White Helmets rescuers freeing a girl from the rubble of buildings that collapsed after the Assad regime bombed the area.
Additional photos of the same child from the same incident in Aleppo in 2016.
In 2018, the same photos we are looking at were released again with the claim that they show a staged attack on civilians in Syria and the "set-up" of the rescue by anti-regime forces. The claim was however dismissed by the AFP.
Conclusion
The photos in question do not show the same girl being used to represent 3 different victims in Gaza. They are from Aleppo, Syria and were taken in 2016, following a bombardment by Assad regime forces. They depict the same incident.
false_claim: Crisis actors are portrayed as interpreting Palestinian victims of Israeli violence showing staged rescues.

content:
Lo que sabemos del ataque al Hospital Infantil de Okhmatdyt en Kiev: evidencias apuntan a que fue un misil ruso
El Hospital Infantil de Okhmatdyt en Kiev fue alcanzado por un misil y, desde que se reportó el ataque, han circulado numerosas teorías sobre su autoría. Dos adultos murieron y otras 16 personas, entre ellas siete niños, resultaron heridas, según el gobierno ucraniano.
Qué dicen las partes. Desde que se produjo el pasado 8 de julio, Rusia ha negado su responsabilidad en el ataque y ha señalado a un error de la defensa militar de Ucrania.
- El presidente ucraniano, Volodímir Zelenski, aseguró que “cerca de 100 instalaciones resultaron dañadas, incluyendo un hospital infantil”.
- La ministra de Asuntos Exteriores rusa, Maria Zakharova, señaló que fue un misil ucraniano, parte de su sistema de defensa antiaérea, que se “desvió de su trayectoria” y cayó sobre el hospital infantil.
Desde la Organización de Naciones Unidas apuntan a que hay “una alta probabilidad” de que el ataque al hospital de Kiev haya sido consecuencia de “un impacto directo” de un misil de Rusia, en lugar de “un sistema de interceptación de armas”.
Imágenes del ataque. El periodista ucraniano Andriy Tsaplienko compartió un vídeo del ataque al hospital en su canal de Telegram. Las imágenes muestran un bloque acristalado —el Ministerio de Infraestructura ucraniano— y detrás de él cae un misil sobre un edificio con una fachada de mosaico.
- Este corresponde al Hospital Infantil de Okhmatdyt en Kiev, como muestran imágenes del ataque y la vista aérea del lugar en Google Earth.
Acusaciones contra Ucrania y EEUU. Algunas publicaciones en redes sociales afirman que el proyectil que cayó sobre el hospital ucraniano durante el ataque era un misil Patriot de los que Estados Unidos envió a Ucrania.
- Otros usuarios aseguran que el proyectil era un AIM-120 AMRAAM lanzado desde Ucrania —también procedente de un envío militar de EEUU.
Sin embargo, la apariencia de estos misiles no coincide con la del proyectil que aparece en las imágenes del ataque al hospital en Kiev.
- En el vídeo que compartió Tsaplienko se aprecia que el misil tiene la punta redonda y unas alas en la parte central y en la parte trasera, que también carga un pequeño motor.
- En cambio, como señalan los verificadores de Open y Les Observateurs, ni los Patriot ni los AIM-120 son de estas características, pues la parte frontal de ambos es puntiaguda y no llevan el motor en la cola.
Un misil ruso. Un análisis de Bellingcat muestra que los proyectiles estadounidenses tampoco coinciden con el que aparece en el vídeo del ataque al hospital ucraniano. En cambio, se aprecian varias semejanzas con el misil KH-101 usado exclusivamente por las fuerzas rusas.
- Este proyectil tiene la punta redonda, alas en el centro y en la cola, en la que carga un pequeño motor, coincidiendo con el misil que aparece en las imágenes del ataque.
El análisis de Bellingcat también incluye fotografías del Servicio de Seguridad de Ucrania de los restos del proyectil que cayó sobre el hospital de Kiev en el ataque.
- Los escombros se asemejan a los de un misil KH-101 que aparecen en el manual de identificación de las Fuerzas de Defensa Territorial de Ucrania de 2022, señalan los analistas.
- En algunas imágenes se distingue una inscripción numérica escrita sobre los restos del proyectil; Bellingcat destaca que este formato coincide con el que aparecía en los restos de un misil KH-101 supuestamente derribado por Ucrania en diciembre de 2023.
Fuentes
Comunicado de Médicos Sin Fronteras sobre el ataque al Hospital Infantil de Okhmatdyt en Kiev
Publicación en X de Volodímir Zelenski
Nota de prensa del Ministerio de Asuntos Exteriores de Rusia
Reuters
Publicación en Telegram de Andriy Tsaplienko
Página web del Ministerio de Infraestructura ucraniano
Google Earth
Agencia EFE
BBC
Air and Space Forces Magazine
Verificación de Open
Verificación de Les Observateurs
Bellingcat
Servicio de Seguridad de Ucrania
Translation:
What we know about the attack on the Okhmatdyt Children's Hospital in kyiv: evidence suggests it was a Russian missile
The Okhmatdyt Children's Hospital in kyiv was hit by a missile and, since the attack was reported, numerous theories have circulated about its responsibility. Two adults were killed and 16 other people, including seven children, were injured, according to the Ukrainian government.
What the parties say. Since it occurred on July 8, Russia has denied responsibility for the attack and has pointed to an error by Ukraine's military defense.
- Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky said that “about 100 facilities were damaged, including a children's hospital.”
- Russian Foreign Minister Maria Zakharova said it was a Ukrainian missile, part of its air defense system, that “deviated from its trajectory” and fell on the children's hospital.
The United Nations points out that there is "a high probability" that the attack on the Kiev hospital was the result of "a direct hit" by a Russian missile, rather than "a weapons interception system."
Images of the attack. Ukrainian journalist Andriy Tsaplienko shared a video of the hospital attack on his Telegram channel. The images show a glass block - the Ukrainian Ministry of Infrastructure - and behind it a missile falls on a building with a mosaic facade.
- This corresponds to the Okhmatdyt Children's Hospital in kyiv, as shown in images of the attack and the aerial view of the place on Google Earth.
Accusations against Ukraine and the US. Some posts on social media claim that the projectile that fell on the Ukrainian hospital during the attack was one of the Patriot missiles that the United States sent to Ukraine.
- Other users claim that the projectile was an AIM-120 AMRAAM launched from Ukraine—also from a US military shipment.
However, the appearance of these missiles does not match that of the projectile that appears in the images of the attack on the hospital in kyiv.
- In the video that Tsaplienko shared, you can see that the missile has a round tip and wings in the central part and in the rear part, which also carries a small engine.
- On the other hand, as the Open and Les Observateurs verifiers point out, neither the Patriot nor the AIM-120 have these characteristics, since the front of both is pointed and they do not have the engine in the tail.
A Russian missile. A Bellingcat analysis shows that the US projectiles also do not match the one seen in the video of the attack on the Ukrainian hospital. However, there are several similarities with the KH-101 missile used exclusively by Russian forces.
- This projectile has a round tip, wings in the center and in the tail, in which it carries a small motor, coinciding with the missile that appears in the images of the attack.
Bellingcat's analysis also includes photographs from the Ukrainian Security Service of the remains of the projectile that fell on the kyiv hospital in the attack.
- The debris resembles that of a KH-101 missile that appears in the identification manual of the Territorial Defense Forces of Ukraine for 2022, analysts say.
- In some images you can see a numerical inscription written on the remains of the projectile; Bellingcat highlights that this format coincides with the one that appeared on the remains of a KH-101 missile supposedly shot down by Ukraine in December 2023.
Sources
Statement from Doctors Without Borders on the attack on the Okhmatdyt Children's Hospital in kyiv
Publication in X by Volodymyr Zelensky
Press release from the Russian Ministry of Foreign Affairs
Reuters
Telegram post by Andriy Tsaplienko
Ukrainian Ministry of Infrastructure website
Google Earth
EFE Agency
BBC
Air and Space Forces Magazine
Open Verification
Les Observateurs verification
Bellingcat
Ukrainian Security Service
false_claim: The rocket that struck the Okhmatdyt hospital in Kiev was fired by Ukrainian anti-aircraft artillery.

content:
No, the discovery of bodies in Ukraine's Bucha was not 'staged' with 'actors'
- This article is more than one year old.
- Published on April 6, 2022 at 12:32
- Updated on April 6, 2022 at 18:34
- 11 min read
- By AFP France
Copyright © AFP 2017-2024. Any commercial use of this content requires a subscription. Click here to find out more.
On April 3 the Russian defence ministry shared on its Telegram feed -- which has nearly 200,000 followers -- a 21-second video of the scene alongside a comment that it was "fake".
"The video with the bodies is puzzling: here, at 12 seconds, the “corpse” on the right moves its hand. At 30 seconds in the rearview mirror, the "corpse" sits down. The bodies in the video seem to have been deliberately laid out in order to create a more dramatic picture," the Telegram post reads.
On its Twitter account, the Russian embassy in Canada also posted the video, alongside a claim that it was staged and showed "faked dead bodies".
"Slowed down version clearly shows a "corpse" moves his hand and then sits up after the car passes by (seen in the rear mirror)," it claims.
The claim that the footage had been manipulated spread quickly on social networks in several languages.
"After a car passes one of the bodies lying on the ground we see in the rearview mirror an actor getting up," reads a French-language Twitter post that shared the same video.
The same video was viewed more than 800,000 times after it was shared alongside a similar claim on China's Twitter-like social media platform Weibo here, here, and here.
Where is the video from?
Apparently filmed from a vehicle following a Ukrainian military convoy, the video shows several bodies lying on a war-damaged street in the town of Bucha, which is northwest of Kyiv.
AFP geolocated the video clip to Yablonska street.
The video was published on April 2 on the YouTube channel of Ukrainian channel Espreso.TV.
The journalist describes the images as proof of "atrocities committed by the Russian occupiers of Bucha".
A longer, higher-quality version of the video was published the same day on the Twitter feed of the Ukrainian defence ministry.
It claims: "Local civilians were being executed arbitrarily."
Bodies that move?
In the misleading posts, the video has been slowed down. The quality is also diminished in comparison with the video shared by the Ukrainian defence ministry.
But, as many social media users have spotted (1,2,3), if we look closely at the sequence in higher quality footage, the bodies do not move.
The first man on the right-hand side of the video does not raise his arm -- the moving object is actually a droplet of rain on the windshield of the vehicle where the video was filmed from:
Getting fed up of this “it’s a moving arm” bullsh….. it’s a raindrop on the windscreen, alongside an inverted channel version for more clarity. The whole arm moving thing is just ridiculous. pic.twitter.com/ZiuEX4rFWc
— Aurora Intel (@AuroraIntel) April 3, 2022
AFP team on the ground confirms the scene
AFP journalists entered Bucha on April 2 and confirmed the presence of about 20 bodies in civilian clothing. One of them has its hands tied, they said.
The team consisted of journalist Danny Kemp; photographer Ronaldo Schemidt; and video journalist Nicolas Garcia.
They arrived on the scene on April 2 at around 3.30pm local time, Kemp told AFP Factuel.
In an email, he said: "As soon as we arrived, we could see that the street was littered with bodies. We first saw a group of three and then noticed there were more in either direction.
"They were spaced out along the street at irregular intervals over a distance of around 400 metres, some alone and some in small groups of two or three. We walked along the entire length of the scene at least twice. We counted the bodies, noting that there were 20, photographed them, and filmed them. At no time did we see any of them move.
"During that time we noted that the bodies were all wearing civilian clothing. They had waxy, sallow skin, and had stiff-looking fingers, with some having discoloured fingernails. Some had limbs in awkward poses.
"Some had their eyes open, some had their mouths gaping open. They had clearly been dead for a number of days, if not longer."
We compared the images being shared in misleading posts with the photos taken by AFP at the scene.
There are several signs that show they show the same scene.
AFP has circled in red the body of the victim and in green the damaged vehicle, a signpost, and part of the pavement:
Content warning
Danny Kemp sent us two pictures that he took on April 2, the same day the bodies were found:
Content warning
Content warning
Two other AFP photographs -- taken a day later by a second team that arrived at the scene -- show a Bucha municipal worker about to put the same body in a mortuary bag:
Content warning
Content warning
The body that some posts claim moves appears twice in the video of April 2, firstly on the ground and two seconds later in the rearview mirror of the vehicle from which it was filmed:
It was also photographed by AFP on April 3 in the same position and the same location:
Content warning
"Witnesses in Bucha told us they saw a column of some 70 Russian armoured vehicles leaving the town on the evening of Tuesday March 29 but that Russian shelling continued heavily on Wednesday March 30, and that the last shelling they heard was on Thursday March 31," Kemp said.
"AFP journalists in the area around Irpin, next to Bucha, heard shelling on Thursday. It was impossible to access the area until Friday as Ukrainian authorities said it was not safe to enter. AFP entered Irpin on Friday, April 1 and Bucha on Saturday, April 2."
An investigation by the BBC also concluded that allegations the massacre was "staged" are unfounded.
According to the BBC report, a body that appears to rise up in the video -- from the perspective of the vehicle's rearview mirror -- has likely been distorted by the reflection.
What we know about the deaths in Bucha
The small town of Bucha was occupied by the Russian army on February 27 and remained inaccessible for more than one month.
The bombings stopped on March 31 and Ukrainian forces were only able to enter the whole town a few days ago.
Ukraine accused the Russians of being responsible for these deaths.
This was denied by Moscow which announced it would investigate what it said was a "heinous provocation" to blame Russian forces.
According to the mayor of Bucha, Anatoly Fedoruk, these people were killed by Russian soldiers with "a bullet in the neck".
The bodies of 57 people were also found in a mass grave, local rescue chief Sergei Kaplytchny said on Sunday, April 3, showing the site to an AFP team.
A dozen bodies were visible, some only partially buried, behind a church in the city centre.
Several were in black body bags and those that could be seen were wearing civilian clothes.
On April 2, Fedorouk said that "280 people" had been buried "in mass graves" because they could not be buried in the cemeteries of Bucha.
The exact number of victims is not yet known, the mayor of Kiev, Vitali Klitschko, told AFP after he visited Bucha on April 3. "We think that more than 300 civilians died," he said.
Matching satellite images and photographs
Satellite photographs released on April 4 also rebut Russian assertions that dead bodies in civilian clothing found in Bucha had appeared in the devastated town after Russian forces retreated.
The satellite imagery was taken in mid-March and appears to show several bodies of civilians lying dead in or just off the roadway.
"High-resolution Maxar satellite imagery collected over Bucha, Ukraine (northwest of Kyiv) verifies and corroborates recent social media videos and photos that reveal bodies lying in the streets and left out in the open for weeks," Maxar Technologies spokesman Stephen Wood said in a statement.
The New York Times published an analysis of close-ups of Bucha's Yablonska street and concluded -- after comparing it with video footage from April 1 and 2 of dead bodies along the street -- that many had been there for at least three weeks when Russian forces were in control of the town.
AFP cross-checked the satellite images from March 19 with its own photos from the scene taken on April 2.
The bodies appear in the same positions and same locations.
Number 5 in the image shows the body of the first victim AFP analysed in this story.
He can be seen lying on his back next to a damaged car, which further debunks the baseless claims about him moving.
International outcry
Several Western capitals and the UN expressed their indignation after the discovery of the bodies.
Michelle Bachelet, High Commissioner for Human Rights, said on April 4 she was "horrified" by the images of Bucha, which "raise serious and disturbing questions about possible war crimes".
The European Union, after the release of these images, condemned the "atrocities" on April 4 as it discussed a new round of sanctions against Moscow.
Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky visited Bucha on April 4 and urged the world to acknowledge "genocide".
April 6, 2022 This article was updated to correct the first name of an AFP photographer.
Is there content that you would like AFP to fact-check? Get in touch.
Contact us
Translation:
