false_claim: The horrific scenes recorded in Bucha were staged by Ukrainian forces.

content:
Nämä palomiehet osallistuivat hyväntekeväisyystapahtumaan Puolassa eivätkä osoittaneet mieltään alankomaalaisten maanviljelijöiden puolesta
- Artikkeli on yli vuoden vanha.
- Julkaistu 20. heinäkuuta 2022 13:58
- Lukuaika: 4 minuuttia
- Teksti: Ede ZABORSZKY, Maja CZARNECKA, AFP Unkari, AFP Puola
- Kääntänyt ja sovittanut suomeksi: Anna HOLLINGSWORTH
Tekijänoikeus © AFP 2017-2024. Sisältöjen kaupallinen käyttö vaatii tilauksen. Lue lisää täältä.
"Alankomaat: Palomiehet liittyvät maanviljelijöiden joukkoon solidaarisesti taistellakseen globalisteja vastaan", suomenkielisessä, heinäkuun alun jälkeen yli 300 kertaa jaetussa Facebook-päivityksessä sanotaan. Videolla näkyy useita sireenejään soittavia paloautoja ja ihmisiä palomiesten asuissa niiden päällä.
Facebookin-päivityksen teksti viittaa virheellisesti siihen, että videolla näkyisi tukimielenosoitus Alankomaissa, missä maanviljelijät järjestävät protesteja vastustaakseen hallituksen suunnitelmia typpipäästöjen vähentämiseksi.
Facebookin käyttäjät reagoivat päivitykseen myönteisesti. "Sydämeni saa oikean rytmin ja pääse puristuksesta kuin näen tämän kaltaisia uutisia", yksi käyttäjä kirjoitti.
Videolla ei kuitenkaan ole mitään tekemistä maanviljelijöiden protestien kanssa Alankomaissa: AFP tutki kuvamateriaalia ja puhui tapahtuman järjestäjille sekä videon kuvaajalle ja selvitti, että se kuvattiin Puolassa hyväntekeväisyystapahtumassa.
Video ja väärät väittämät ovat levinneet monilla kielillä, muun muassa kroatiaksi, puolaksi, englanniksi, ranskaksi, saksaksi ja unkariksi.
Videolla on hyväntekeväisyystapahtuma Puolassa
Videolla näkyy, että palomiehillä lukee selässä "straz", joka on lyhenne palomiehestä puolaksi.
Väärässä asiayhteydessä levitetyllä videolla on myös TikTok-tunniste, joka johtaa käyttäjänimi daniel998dxdx:n TikTok-kanavalle. Hän julkaisi saman videon 22.5.2022. Sen puolankielisessä kuvauksessa lukee "Pelastajien yöajelu Majalle", ja siinä mainitaan eri puolankielisiä tunnisteita kuten "palomies" ja "Krosno".
Käyttäjän muut videot ovat saaneet yleensä pari tuhatta katselukertaa, mutta tällä videolla on niitä yli 1,5 miljoonaa sekä satoja kommentteja englanniksi, saksaksi ja ranskaksi. Kommenteissa kirjoitetaan korruptoituneista poliitikoista ja maanviljelijöiden protesteista. Pienessä osassa kommentteja huomautetaan, että video kuvattiin itse asiassa Puolassa.
AFP teki sanahaun Googlella käyttäen TikTok-päivityksen tietoja. Tämä toi esiin puolalaisia uutisartikkeleita (kuten tämä ja tämä), joissa kerrotaan, että 21.5.2022 eteläpuolalaisen Krosnon kaupungin pelastuslaitokset järjestivät hyväntekeväisyystapahtuman kerätäkseen rahaa Maja-nimiselle, läheisessä Potokin kylässä asuvalle tytölle. Paikallinen media kertoi, että Majalla on CP-vamma ja että hän tarvitsi kuntoutusta.
"Pelastajien yöajelu on poikkeusellinen OSP Dobieszynun ja Krosno112.pl:n järjestämä hyväntekeväisyystapahtuma, johon osallistuu noin sata pelastuspalveluiden ajoneuvoa", paikallisessa sanomalehdessä kirjoitettiin.
OSP on lyhenne vapaaehtoispalokunnalle puolaksi, Dobieszyn on Potokin vieressä sijaitseva kylä, ja Krosno112 on paikallinen uutissivusto, joka "antaa tietoa ongelmista teillä ja pelastusoperaatioista".
Sivuston tiedoissa mainitaan myös, että "Krosno112.pl-portaali tunnetaan myös "Pelastajien yöajelu" -hyväntekeväisyystapahtumien järjestämisestä apua tarvitsevien ihmisten hyväksi sekä muiden hyväntekeväisyystapahtumien mainostamisesta". Tämä mainitaan myös TikTok-videon kuvauksessa.
Krosno112 julkaisi kuvagallerian Majan hyväksi järjestetystä tapahtumasta. Vertaamalla näitä kuvia ja TikTok-videota voi nähdä useita vihjeitä, jotka osoittavat, että kuvat ja video kuvattiin samassa paikassa samaan aikaan.
Sekä sosiaalisessa mediassa leviävällä videolla ja Krosno112:n kuvissa näkyy esimerkiksi samoja paloautoja samassa järjestyksessä. Paloautoissa on samat tunnukset.
Kuvissa ja videolla voi huomata samat siviilipukuiset ihmiset, jotka seisovat palomiesten keskellä. Esimerkiksi alla on merkitty vihreällä nainen, joka seisoo paloauton 347R24 päällä kummassakin kuvassa ja katsoo taakseen TikTok-videon kuvaajan suuntaan. Näkymän perusteella (merkitty keltaisella vasemmalla olevaan kuvaan) videon kuvaaja seisoo paloauton 347R64 päällä:
Paloauto 347R64 näkyy myös muilla TikTok-käyttäjä daniel998dxdx:n videoilla. Siinä lukee myös "Jedlicze", joka on kaupunki Krosnon piirikunnassa.
AFP otti yhteyttä Jedliczen paikalliseen palolaitokseen, joka tunnisti käyttäjän paikalliseksi palomieheksi Daniel Zająciksi 12.7.2022.
AFP:n onnistui saamaan yhteys Zającikseen, joka selitti: "Kyllä, kuvasin videon seistessäni Jedliczen palomiesyksikön auton päällä. Se ei ole tietenkään Alankomaista. Se oli hyväntekeväisyystapahtumassa Majan hyväksi."
AFP kysyi nauhoitteesta myös valtion palokunnan kunnalliselta päämajalta Krosnossa. "Video, jonka lähetitte meille, kuvattiin hyväntekeväisyystapahtumassa 'Nocna Jazda Ratowników' [Pelastajien yöajelu]. Palomiehemme eivät ole koskaan järjestäneet protesteja tukeakseen maanviljelijöitä Alankomaissa", he vastasivat 12.7.
Videon yksityiskohtien, kuten taustalla olevan talon ja ruohokentän, perusteella AFP selvitti, että se kuvattiin huoltoasema Orlenin parkkipaikalla Jedliczessä, joka on sama paikka kuin hyväntekeväisyystapahtuman Facebook-sivulla nimetty paikka.
Myös Krosno112-portaali vahvisti, että sosiaalisessa mediassa väärien väitteiden yhteydessä leviävä TikTok-video kuvattiin sen järjestämässä hyväntekeväisyystapahtumassa Puolassa. "Video kuvattiin ehdottomasti 'Nocna Jazda Ratownikówissa'. Se on vuosittainen hyväntekeväisyystapahtuma, jonka portaalimme järjestää yhdessä Dobieszynin palomiesten kanssa", he sanoivat 12.7.2022 ja vahvistivat, että video "ei kuvaa protesteja".
Todisteet siis osoittavat, että video kuvattiin Etelä-Puolassa paikallisessa "Nocna Jazda Ratowników" -nimisessä (Pelastajien yöajelu) tapahtumassa, jonka järjestävät paikalliset vapaaehtoiset palomiehet ja paikallinen uutissivusto Krosno112.
Maanviljelijöiden mielenosoitukset Alankomaissa
Toistuvat maanviljelijöiden protestit Alankomaissa alkoivat vuonna 2019, kun hallitus alkoi puhua ensimmäistä kertaa suunnitelmistaan rajoittaa maanviljelyä ja karjankasvatusta typpipäästöjen vähentämiseksi.
Alankomaalaiset maanviljelijät käyttävät traktoreita valtateiden liikenteen rajoittamiseen. Saksalaiset maanviljelijät ovat järjestäneet ainakin kerran tukimielenosoituksen alankomaalaisten kollegoidensa puolesta. AFP ei löytänyt mainintoja merkittävistä alankomaalaisten palomiesten protestista tukena maanviljelijöille.
Yksi viimeisimmistä suurista protesteista järjestettiin 22.6.2022. Siihen osallistui tuhansia traktoreilla ajavia maanviljelijöitä, jotka osoittivat mieltään Keski-Alankomaissa sen jälkeen, kun hallitus Haagissa julkisti suunnitelmansa, jotka voisivat johtaa karjan vähentämiseen 30 prosentilla.
Alankomaat on maailman toisiksi suurin maataloustuotteiden vientimaa sekä yksi suurimmista kasvihuonekaasujen, erityisesti typen, tuottajista Euroopassa. Tästä suuri osa johtuu karjan tuottamasta lannasta ja lannoitteesta. Maanviljelijät kuitenkin sanovat, että heihin kohdistetaan epäreiluja vaatimuksia suurten yritysten ja teollisuuden sijaan. Monet heistä ovat vannoneet vastustavansa suunnitelmia supistaa tai sulkea maatiloja.
Kuvia alankomaalaisten maanviljelijöiden protesteista vääristellään usein sosiaalisessa mediassa: esimerkiksi tämän vuonna 2019 otetun valokuvan väitettiin esittävän protestia pandemiarajoituksia vastaan vuonna 2022.
Ehdota meille faktantarkistusta.
Ota yhteyttä
Translation:
These firefighters were participating in a charity event in Poland and were not protesting on behalf of Dutch farmers
- The article is over a year old.
- Posted on July 20, 2022 1:58 p.m
- Reading time: 4 minutes
- Text: Ede ZABORSZKY, Maja CZARNECKA, AFP Hungary, AFP Poland
- Translated and adapted into Finnish by: Anna HOLLINGSWORTH
Copyright © AFP 2017-2024. Commercial use of the contents requires a subscription. Read more here.
"Netherlands: Firefighters join farmers in solidarity to fight globalists," reads a Facebook update in Finnish that has been shared more than 300 times since the beginning of July. The video shows several fire trucks sounding their sirens and people wearing firemen's uniforms on top of them.
The text of the Facebook update falsely suggests that the video shows a support rally in the Netherlands, where farmers are staging protests against government plans to reduce nitrogen emissions.
Facebook users reacted positively to the update. "My heart skips a beat when I see news like this," one user wrote.
However, the video has nothing to do with farmers' protests in the Netherlands: AFP examined the footage and spoke to the organizers of the event as well as the videographer, and found out that it was filmed in Poland at a charity event.
The video and false claims have spread in many languages, including Croatian, Polish, English, French, German and Hungarian.
The video shows a charity event in Poland
The video shows that the firemen have "straz" written on their backs, which is an abbreviation for fireman in Polish.
The miscontextualized video also has a TikTok tag that leads to the username daniel998dxdx's TikTok channel. He published the same video on May 22, 2022. Its description in Polish reads "Rescuers' night ride to Maja", and mentions various Polish identifiers such as "firefighter" and "Krosno".
The user's other videos usually get a couple of thousand views, but this video has more than 1.5 million and hundreds of comments in English, German and French. In the comments, they write about corrupt politicians and farmers' protests. A small number of comments point out that the video was actually shot in Poland.
AFP did a word search on Google using information from the TikTok update. This brought up Polish news articles (such as this one and this one ) reporting that on 5/21/2022, emergency services in the southern Polish town of Krosno organized a charity event to raise money for a girl named Maja, who lives in the nearby village of Potok. Local media reported that Maja has a CP disability and that she needed rehabilitation.
"The rescuers' night drive is an exceptional charity event organized by OSP Dobieszynu and Krosno112.pl, in which about a hundred rescue services vehicles participate," the local newspaper wrote.
OSP stands for Volunteer Fire Brigade in Polish, Dobieszyn is a village next to Potok, and Krosno112 is a local news site that "gives information about problems on the roads and rescue operations".
The information on the site also mentions that "Krosno112.pl portal is also known for organizing "Rescuer night ride" charity events for people in need, as well as promoting other charity events". This is also mentioned in the description of the TikTok video.
Krosno112 published a photo gallery of the event organized for Maja. By comparing these images and the TikTok video, several clues can be seen that indicate that the images and the video were shot in the same place at the same time.
Both the video circulating on social media and the photos of Krosno112 show, for example, the same fire engines in the same order. Fire engines have the same badges.
In the pictures and video, you can see the same people in civilian clothes standing among the firefighters. For example, the woman standing on top of a 347R24 fire engine in both images is marked in green below, looking back in the direction of the TikTok video's cameraman. Based on the view (marked in yellow in the picture on the left), the cameraman of the video is standing on top of the fire truck 347R64:
Fire truck 347R64 can also be seen in other videos of TikTok user daniel998dxdx. It also says "Jedlicze", which is a town in Krosno County.
AFP contacted the local fire department in Jedlice, which identified the user as local firefighter Daniel Zając on 12 July 2022.
AFP managed to get in touch with Zającis, who explained: "Yes, I filmed the video standing on top of the car of the Jedlicze fire department. It's not from the Netherlands, of course. It was at a charity event for Maja."
AFP also asked the municipal headquarters of the State Fire Service in Krosno about the recording. "The video you sent us was filmed at the charity event 'Nocna Jazda Ratowników' [Rescue Night Ride]. Our firefighters have never organized protests to support farmers in the Netherlands," they replied on 7/12.
Based on details of the video, such as a house and a grassy field in the background, AFP found that it was filmed in the parking lot of the gas station Orlen in Jedlicze, the same location as the one named on the charity event's Facebook page.
The Krosno112 portal also confirmed that the TikTok video circulating on social media in connection with false claims was filmed at a charity event organized by it in Poland. "The video was definitely filmed at 'Nocna Jazda Ratoników'. It's an annual charity event organized by our portal together with Dobieszyn firefighters," they said on 7/12/2022, confirming that the video "does not depict protests".
So the evidence shows that the video was shot in southern Poland at a local event called "Nocna Jazda Ratowników" (Night Ride of Rescuers) organized by local volunteer firefighters and local news site Krosno112.
Farmers' demonstrations in the Netherlands
Repeated farmer protests in the Netherlands began in 2019, when the government began talking for the first time about its plans to restrict farming and livestock raising to reduce nitrogen emissions.
Dutch farmers use tractors to limit traffic on highways. German farmers have organized at least one demonstration in support of their Dutch counterparts. AFP found no mention of any significant protest by Dutch firefighters in support of farmers.
One of the last large protests was organized on June 22, 2022. It involved thousands of tractor-driving farmers demonstrating in the central Netherlands after the government in The Hague unveiled plans that could lead to a 30 percent reduction in livestock.
The Netherlands is the world's second largest exporter of agricultural products and one of the largest producers of greenhouse gases, especially nitrogen, in Europe. A large part of this is due to the manure and fertilizer produced by livestock. However, farmers say that unfair demands are placed on them instead of large companies and industry. Many of them have vowed to oppose plans to downsize or close farms.
Images of Dutch farmers' protests are often distorted on social media: for example, this photo taken in 2019 was said to show a protest against pandemic restrictions in 2022.
Suggest us a fact check.
Contact us
false_claim: Videos and pictures shows the protests of anti-government farmers in the Netherlands.

content:
Organizations of the EDMO’s fact-checking network that contributed to this analysis: Pagella Politica – Facta.news, AFP, Delfi, Demagog.pl, Eesti Päevaleht, Ellinika Hoaxes, Faktabaari, Faktisk, Lakmusz, Maldita, Mimikama, Nieuwscheckers, Re:Baltica, Science Feedback, The Journal – FactCheck, TjekDet, Verificat.
On November 21st, 2022, a “documentary” titled “Died suddenly” about alleged Covid-19 vaccines’ side effects was released on the niche video-sharing platform Rumble, and began to spread online.
By the end of November, many organizations that are part of the EDMO’s fact-checking network detected and reported in their own countries a wide circulation of this video. From Spain to the Baltic States, from Scandinavia to Greece, passing through France, Italy, Germany, Austria, Hungary, Poland, Ireland and many others, basically all of Europe was interested by this disinformation content.
Various fact-checking organizations have published, or plan to publish in the next few days, their analyses of the false news spread by the video. Here we summarize the most relevant information about who published “Died suddenly,” which are the main allegations and thesis of the “documentary,” and why they are false or misleading.
The “Died Suddenly” film
The so-called documentary was produced by the Stew Peters Network (SPN), a media production company managed by Stew Peters, a widely popular U.S. based disinformation spreader. In February 2022, Peters’ personal podcast show was removed from Spotify for violating the platform’s guidelines about Covid-19 disinformation (but it’s still available on Google and Apple Podcast), and in April SPN produced the documentary “Watch the Water,” which claimed that coronavirus is not a virus, but a synthetic version of snake venom (needless to say, this was immediately debunked.
“Died Suddenly” was «written, produced, directed, filmed, and edited,» as the end credits state, by Matthew Miller Skow and Nicholas Stumphauzer. The two filmmakers had previously released “These Little Ones”, a Stew Peters Network’s documentary about child trafficking which supports, among other things, conspiracy theories about abortions and satanic rituals.
In “Died Suddenly”, which lasts about 1 hour and 10 minutes, «the filmmakers not only lie, but also try to create a feeling of anxiety and insecurity through manipulative language, music and visuals», Latvian fact-checkers from Re:Baltica stated in their analysis. The documentary, in fact, quotes several disinformation narratives about Covid-19 vaccines that have been circulating widely over the last couple of months and years.
Debunking old hoaxes
The film starts by claiming that embalmers and funeral directors have been finding unusually long blood clots in the bodies of vaccinated people. Images and vidoes of these supposed blood clots are profusely shown in the film. As explained by the French fact-checking outlet Health Feedback, part of the EDMO network, «without a pathological analysis that takes into account the clinical history of the person, images of blood clots alone don’t provide sufficient evidence of an association between these clots and Covid-19 vaccines.» Furthermore, the AFP fact-checking team stated that «experts have offered multiple other possibilities [for blood clots], including obesity, smoking or infection with Covid-19.» AFP also noticed that a video used in “Died Suddenly” to show a blood clot being removed actually comes from a YouTube video, uploaded in 2019 (therefore before the Covid-19 pandemic), showing a pulmonary embolism being removed from a living patient.
“Died Suddenly” goes on stating that Covid-19 vaccines often cause sever illnesses, such as cancer, and can lead to pregnacy problems such as miscarriages, abortions, or stillbirths. However, as highligted among others by AFP, experts have consistently said pregnant people should get vaccinated, and national and international health authorities, such as the CDC and the EMA, recommend Covid-19 vaccination to protect against severe illness and hospitalization. Fact-checkers at Re:Baltica also noted that several scientific studies concluded that neither Pfizer nor Moderna increased the risk of miscarriage or premature birth. Dutch fact-checkers from NieuwsCheckers dug deeper and proved that the images of babies with deformities that are shown in the film have nothing to do with Covid-19 vaccines.
Alleged connections with cancer have also widely been debunked, and NieuwsCheckers noted that the documentary uses data from the U.S. Department of Defense which turned out to contain an error and were later corrected. «There is no link between vaccination and cancer or neurological diseases,» NieuwsCheckers concluded in its analysis, which debunked the 12 core claims (all false) spread by “Died Suddenly.”
The film also shows several headlines and disturbing videos of people suddenly collapsing on the ground, allegedly because of the Covid-19 vaccine. Fact-checkers from Health Feeedback, however, noted that while the images are real, many of them are not related with Covid-19 vaccines, and some of the people are actually still alive. For instance, “Died Suddenly” shows «the Argentinian nutritionist Teresa Coccaro, who fainted during a TV show. Coccaro, who is well and alive, later explained that she fainted due to a fall in blood pressure», Health Feedback reported.
Overall, “Died Suddenly” claims that Covid-19 vaccines are «bioweapons» whose main goal is to depopulate the world. The film quotes several well-known conspiracy theories, such as the Great Reset; makes reference to the «global élite agenda»; and presentes in a misleading way Event 201, a virtual exercise hosted in October 2019 by the Johns Hopkins Center for Health Security, the World Economic Forum and the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation which simulated a potential global pandemic.
In order to support these baseless theories, the documentary exploits common disinformation narratives: the film claims, for instance, that Covid-19 vaccines haven’t been properly tested, or it uses data in a misleading manner in order to convey the idea that the vaccines might do more harm than good.
For example, as explained by the Greek fact-checking outlet Ellinika Hoaxes, part of the EDMO network, «the video refers to a previously debunked conspiracy that claims vaccine manufacturers are hiding information about vaccine side effects,» because the information leaflet contained in the boxes is left «intentionally blank.» Ellinika Hoaxes explained that, according to Reuters news agency, «it’s true that Johnson & Johnson’s vaccine package insert was left mostly blank,» but «the company used the flyer to direct readers, via a QR code, to an online newsletter that can be updated and reflects any FDA revisions.»
The documentary also claims that the general public is kept in the dark about the composition of vaccines, but our Greek colleagues noted that «after their approval at the end of 2020, the composition of the vaccines was never hidden.» Quite the contrary: «The EMA had made public a related document of 140 pages, which summarized and explained every part of the experimental, non-clinical and clinical data, which supported the approval of the vaccine as safe and effective.»
The documentary also uses the Vaccine Adverse Event Reporting System (VAERS)’s data to state that in the United States about 15,000 people died because of Covid-19 vaccines, and the number is «probably underreported.» Polish fact-checkers from Demagog clarified that VAERS data show the number of people who died and were vaccinated, but it does not imply a causal relationship between the two elements: «Vaccinated people can die for completely different reasons, unrelated to vaccines, just like unvaccinated people,» Demagog claimed in a debunking article about the “Died Suddenly” film.
Conclusion
“Died Suddenly” fits into a growing list of so-called “documentaries” that support misleading and distorted perspectives about the Covid-19 pandemic. The group already features films spreading false news, such as “Hold Up” and “Plandemic,” which circulated online during the last couple of months and years.
The Stew Peters Network’s documentary mixes correct information, manipulated interpretations of data, and popular conspiracy theories to provide a skewed view of Covid-19 vaccines which is not supported by scientific evidence. Beware of it and, if you happen to see it online, please help us curb disinformation and do not share it.
Laura Loguercio, Pagella Politica
Tommaso Canetta, Pagella Politica / Facta news

Laura Loguercio, Pagella Politica
Tommaso Canetta, Pagella Politica / Facta news
false_claim: The documentary “Died Suddenly” shows that COVID-19 vaccines increase mortality.

content:
Пользователи социальных сетей активно делятся видео, в котором некий российский блогер рассказывает, что ракетный удар по Краматорску якобы был совершен украинскими военными. Он это аргументирует тем, что Россия якобы не использует ракеты Точка-У, которыми было совершено нападение. Это неправда. Есть многочисленные свидетельства, что Россия по-прежнему применяет эти ракеты и что удар был со стороны российских войск.
Мужчина на видео — блогер Юрий Подоляка, родившийся в Украине. Сейчас он проживает в России и активно распространяет дезинформацию о вторжении России в Украину. Подоляка пользуется популярностью в социальных сетях. Например, в Telegram у него почти два миллиона подписчиков. У него также был популярный канал на YouTube, который был заблокирован за нарушение правил пользования.
В видео он рассказывает о ракетном ударе, который был совершен 8 апреля в городе Краматорск. Подоляка заявляет, что Киевские власти хотят доказать, что удар был совершен Россией, хотя такие ракеты якобы использует только сторона Украины. Он говорит:
“(..) самым убийственным аргументом, который их пригвоздил, стали серийные номера ракет. (..) И серийные номера вот этих разгромных блоков, они очень близко к серийным номерам тех ракет, которые падали на Донецкие города,”
и делает вывод:
“(..) это ракеты из одной партии, то есть той партии, которые были оставлены во времена Советского союза на территории Украины.”
Такой же версии придерживается Россия и сепаратисты Донбасса. Как заявило Минобороны России, российские войска не совершали нападение на Краматорск, а ракеты Точка-У применяются только украинскими вооруженными силами. Однако есть многочисленные свидетельства, что их также используют российские военные.
Группа расследователей Conflict Intelligence 6 марта сообщала (здесь), что Россия начала применять именно эти ракеты. А в ночь на 8 апреля (перед ударом) в одном из пророссийских телеграм-каналов появилось следующее сообщение:
“Гражданам эвакуирующимся сейчас из Славянска, Краматорска и близлежащих населённых пунктов советую покидать города не на жд транспорте.”
Также в социальных сетях было размещено видео, на котором видны эти ракетные установки, помеченные латинскими буквами V, сообщает Би-би-си (здесь). Как известно, V является одним из символов вторжения российских войск в Украину.
Серийный номер ракеты также не доказывает, что она принадлежит Вооруженным силам Украины (ВСУ). Этот миф подробно разобрали специалисты по проверке фактов из The Insider и StopFake. Они сообщали, что серийный номер «Ш91579» — это заводская маркировка, которую во времена СССР наносили на все снаряды, произведенные на Воткинском заводе, и что Точка-У числится на вооружении у восьми стран.
Украинские СМИ писали, что нападение произошло утром 8 апреля, когда на вокзале Краматорска находились мирные жители, ожидающие эвакуационного поезда. Президент Украины Владимир Зеленский сообщил, что удар был нанесен ракетой Точка-У и обвинил в нападении российские войска. На обломке ракеты видна надпись “За детей”. Как сообщали СМИ из разных стран, в результате этого удара погибли десятки людей.
Подоляка также заявляет, что украинский политик Алексей Арестович в одном из интервью якобы раскрыл схему обмана жителей Украины. Подоляка говорит:
“Это видео, (..) где Арестович украинскому корреспонденту объясняет схему обмана тех людей, которые ему доверились. Это стандартная схема, которая используется для оболванивания масс. И Лешенька Арестович открыто, не стесняясь, самовлюбленно хвастается перед всеми, как он обманывает народ Украины.”
Видео, о котором рассказывает Подоляка, это отрывок из интервью 2017 года (здесь). В нем советник главы Офиса президента Украины, психолог Алексей Арестович рассуждает на тему манипуляций обществом. В свою очередь отрывок, опубликованный Подолякой, длится всего полторы минуты; в нем ведущая задает Арестовичу вопрос, как нами манипулируют политики. В ответ Арестович рассказывает о так называемых кнопках, психологических приемах, которые используются политиками.
Фраза Арестовича вырвана из контекста. Тема этого интервью — психология и манипуляция сознанием человека и как не поддаваться этим манипуляциям, о чем ведущая программы сообщает в самом начале передачи.
Вывод: То, что ракетный удар по Краматорску был совершен ВСУ — миф, созданный Кремлем. Факты показывают, что нападение было со стороны российских войск. Фраза Арестовича о манипуляции обществом вырвана из контекста.
Эта статья является частью работы Re:Check по проверке потенциально ложных или полуправдивых записей Facebook, изображений и видео. Читайте о сотрудничество Re:Check с Facebook здесь.
О проекте: Re:Check — это виртуальная лаборатория по проверке фактов и исследованию социальных сетей, работающая под эгидой Балтийского центра журналистских расследований Re:Baltica.
При оценивании проверенных фактов мы используем пять возможных оценок: Правда – утверждение соответствует правде, высказывание точное и фактологически доказуемое. Близко к правде — утверждение преимущественно правдиво, однако, допущены мелкие неточности. Полуправда — утверждение содержит как правдивую, так и лживую информацию, часть фактов замолчана. Скорее неправда — в утверждении лишь малая доля правды, однако не принимаются во внимание важные факты и/или контекст, поэтому высказывание либо вводит в заблуждение, либо вне контекста. Неправда — утверждение не соответствует правде, у него нет доказательств, автор высказывания врет или несознательно обманывает. Если какая-то новость или утверждение тебе кажется фактологически сомнительным, пришли нам: recheck@rebaltica.com.
НЕЗАВИСИМОЙ ЖУРНАЛИСТИКЕ ТРЕБУЕТСЯ НЕЗАВИСИМОЕ ФИНАНСИРОВАНИЕ
Если вам нравится наша работа, поддержать нас!
LV38RIKO0001060112712
Translation:
Social media users are actively sharing a video in which a certain Russian blogger says that the missile attack on Kramatorsk was allegedly carried out by the Ukrainian military. He argues that Russia allegedly does not use Tochka-U missiles, which were used in the attack. This is not true. There is ample evidence that Russia continues to use these missiles and that the attack was carried out by Russian troops.
The man in the video is blogger Yuriy Podolyaka, who was born in Ukraine. He now lives in Russia and actively spreads disinformation about Russia's invasion of Ukraine. Podolyaka is popular on social media. For example, he has almost two million subscribers on Telegram. He also had a popular YouTube channel, which was blocked for violating the terms of use.
In the video, he talks about the missile attack that took place on April 8 in the city of Kramatorsk. Podolyaka claims that the Kyiv authorities want to prove that the attack was carried out by Russia, although such missiles are allegedly used only by the Ukrainian side. He says:
“(..) the most damning argument that nailed them was the serial numbers of the missiles. (..) And the serial numbers of these devastating blocks, they are very close to the serial numbers of those missiles that fell on Donetsk cities,”
and concludes:
“(..) these missiles are from the same batch, that is, the batch that was left on the territory of Ukraine during the Soviet Union.”
Russia and the Donbas separatists adhere to the same version. As the Russian Defense Ministry stated, Russian troops did not attack Kramatorsk, and Tochka-U missiles are used only by the Ukrainian armed forces. However, there is ample evidence that they are also used by the Russian military.
The Conflict Intelligence investigative group reported on March 6 (here) that Russia has begun using these missiles. And on the night of April 8 (before the strike), the following message appeared in one of the pro-Russian Telegram channels:
“I advise citizens currently evacuating from Slavyansk, Kramatorsk and nearby settlements to leave the cities not by rail.”
A video was also posted on social networks showing these missile launchers marked with the Latin letters V, the BBC reports (here). As is known, V is one of the symbols of the invasion of Russian troops into Ukraine.
The serial number of the missile also does not prove that it belongs to the Armed Forces of Ukraine (AFU). This myth was thoroughly analyzed by fact-checkers from The Insider and StopFake. They reported that the serial number “Ш91579” is a factory marking that was applied to all shells produced at the Votkinsk plant during the Soviet era, and that the Tochka-U is in service with eight countries.
Ukrainian media reported that the attack took place on the morning of April 8, when civilians were waiting for an evacuation train at the Kramatorsk train station. Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky reported that the strike was carried out by a Tochka-U missile and blamed Russian troops for the attack. The inscription “For children” is visible on the missile fragment. According to media reports from various countries, dozens of people were killed in the attack.
Podolyaka also claims that Ukrainian politician Oleksiy Arestovych allegedly revealed a scheme to deceive Ukrainian residents in an interview. Podolyaka says:
“This is a video (..) where Arestovych explains to a Ukrainian correspondent the scheme to deceive those people who trusted him. This is a standard scheme that is used to fool the masses. And Leshenka Arestovych openly, without embarrassment, narcissistically boasts to everyone how he deceives the people of Ukraine.”The video Podolyaka is talking about is an excerpt from an interview from 2017 (here). In it, psychologist Oleksiy Arestovych, an adviser to the head of the Office of the President of Ukraine, discusses the topic of manipulation of society. In turn, the excerpt published by Podolyaka is only one and a half minutes long; in it, the presenter asks Arestovych how politicians manipulate us. In response, Arestovych talks about the so-called buttons, psychological techniques used by politicians.
Arestovych’s phrase is taken out of context. The topic of this interview is psychology and manipulation of human consciousness and how not to succumb to this manipulation, which the presenter reports at the very beginning of the program.
Conclusion: The fact that the missile strike on Kramatorsk was carried out by the Ukrainian Armed Forces is a myth created by the Kremlin. The facts show that the attack was carried out by Russian troops. Arestovych’s phrase about manipulation of society is taken out of context.
This article is part of Re:Check’s work to fact-check potentially false or half-true Facebook posts, images, and videos. Read about Re:Check’s partnership with Facebook here.
About the project: Re:Check is a virtual fact-checking and social media research lab run by the Baltic Center for Investigative Journalism Re:Baltica.
We use five possible ratings when evaluating fact-checked facts: True – the statement is true, accurate, and factually verifiable. Nearly true – the statement is mostly true, but contains some minor inaccuracies. Half-true – the statement contains both true and false information, and some facts are omitted. Mostly untrue – the statement contains only a small amount of truth, but important facts and/or context are ignored, so the statement is either misleading or out of context. Untrue – the statement is not true, there is no evidence for it, the author of the statement is lying or intentionally deceiving. If you find any news or statement factually questionable, send it to us: recheck@rebaltica.com.

false_claim: The missile that hit Kramatorsk reflects Ukraine's responsibility.

content:
Descoperirea cadavrelor din Bucea, Ucraina, nu este o „punere în scenă” cu „actori”
- Acest articol este mai vechi de un an.
- Publicat pe 5 Aprilie 2022, la 17:59
- Actualizat pe 6 Aprilie 2022, la 16:34
- 13 minute de citit
- De: François D'ASTIER, AFP Franța
- Traducerea și adaptarea Paula CABESCU
Copyright © AFP 2017-2024. Orice utilizare comercială a acestui conținut necesită un abonament. Faceți clic aici pentru a afla mai multe informații.
Pe 3 aprilie, Ministerul rus al Apărării a distribuit pe canalul său de Telegram, care are aproape 200,000 de urmăritori, un videoclip de aproximativ 20 de secunde cu scena, alături de un comentariu potrivit căruia aceasta ar fi fost „falsă”. „Videoclipul cu cadavrele este derutant: aici, la secunda 0:12, «cadavrul» din dreapta își mișcă mâna. La secunda 0:30, în oglinda retrovizoare, «cadavrul» se așează. Cadavrele din videoclip par să fi fost așezate în mod deliberat pentru a crea o imagine mai dramatică”, susține ministerul.
Pe contul său de Twitter, ambasada Rusiei în Canada a postat, de asemenea, videoclipul, cu un comentariu potrivit căruia scena a fost regizată și arată „cadavre false”. „Versiunea încetinită arată clar că un «cadavru» își mișcă mâna și apoi se așează după ce mașina trece pe lângă el (se vede în oglinda retrovizoare)”, a scris ambasada.
Afirmații similare s-au răspândit rapid pe rețelele de socializare în mai multe limbi. „După ce o mașină trece pe lângă unul dintre cadavrele care zac pe jos, vedem în oglinda retrovizoare un actor care se ridică”, spune o postare pe Twitter în limba franceză, care a distribuit aceeași înregistrare video.
În România, videoclipul a fost publicat pe mai multe rețele de socializare, mai întâi pe Telegram de către un utilizator care a scris că într-o „filmare făcută de armata ucraineană care a preluat controlul Bucea, vedem că se scoală morții de la groapă. Adică civilii masacrați de ruși”. „Unu' dă din mânuță, altul se scoală efectiv de pe jos. Mi s-a părut bizar inițial că nu era nici o filmare de aproape, nu era sânge nicăieri, nu era nici un cadavru cu fața în sus, nu cunoșteam cauza deceselor”, mai spune postarea.
Postarea a început să se răspândească rapid și pe alte canale de Telegram (aici), precum și pe Facebook (aici, aici, aici) cu exact aceeași descriere. Videoclipul a fost distribuit, de asemenea, cu afirmații similare, și în germană și bulgară.
De unde provine videoclipul?
Aparent filmat dintr-un vehicul care urmărea un convoi militar ucrainean, videoclipul arată mai multe cadavre care zac pe o stradă distrusă de război din orașul Bucea, situat la nord-vest de Kiev. Am putut geolocaliza videoclipul aici, pe strada Yablonska.
Videoclipul a fost publicat pe 2 aprilie 2022 pe canalul de YouTube al postului de televiziune online ucrainean Espreso.TV. Jurnalistul descrie imaginile ca fiind o dovadă a „atrocităților comise de ocupanții ruși ai (orașului - n.r) Bucea”.
O versiune mai lungă, cu o calitate mai bună a imaginii, a fost publicată în aceeași zi pe canalul de Twitter al Ministerului ucrainean al Apărării. Aceasta susține că „civilii locali au fost executați în mod arbitrar”.
Corpuri care se mișcă?
În postările înșelătoare, videoclipul este încetinit și de calitate slabă. Dar, așa cum au observat mai multe surse (aici, aici, aici), dacă privim cu atenție secvența la o calitate mai bună, aceste corpuri nu se mișcă. Primul bărbat din colțul din dreapta al videoclipului nu ridică mâna; iluzia este dat[ de fapt o picătură de apă aflată pe parbrizul vehiculului din care se filmează scena:
Getting fed up of this “it’s a moving arm” bullsh….. it’s a raindrop on the windscreen, alongside an inverted channel version for more clarity. The whole arm moving thing is just ridiculous. pic.twitter.com/ZiuEX4rFWc
— Aurora Intel (@AuroraIntel) April 3, 2022
Echipa AFP aflată la fața locului confirmă scena
Jurnaliștii AFP au intrat în Bucea pe 2 aprilie și au confirmat prezența a aproximativ 20 de cadavre îmbrăcate în haine civile. Unul dintre ele avea mâinile legate la spate cu o cârpă albă, iar pașaportul ucrainean era lăsat deschis lângă cadavru.
Echipa formată din jurnalistul și șeful biroului AFP de la Haga, Danny Kemp, fotograful Ronaldo Schemidt și video-jurnalistul Nicolas Garcia a ajuns la fața locului pe 2 aprilie, în jurul orei locale 15:30, a declarat Kemp pentru AFP Franța.
„De îndată ce am ajuns, am putut vedea că strada era plină de cadavre. Am văzut mai întâi un grup de trei și apoi am observat că erau mai multe în ambele direcții. Erau răspândite de-a lungul străzii la intervale neregulate pe o distanță de aproximativ 400 de metri, unele singure, altele în grupuri mici de două sau trei persoane. Am parcurs întreaga lungime a locului cel puțin de două ori. Am numărat cadavrele, constatând că erau 20, le-am fotografiat și le-am filmat. În niciun moment nu am văzut vreunul dintre ele mișcându-se”, a spus Kemp într-un email.
„În acel timp am observat că toate cadavrele purtau haine civile. Aveau pielea cerată, palidă, și aveau degete cu aspect rigid, iar unele aveau unghiile decolorate. Unele aveau membrele în poziții ciudate. Unii aveau ochii deschiși, alții aveau gurile întredeschise. Era clar că erau morți de mai multe zile”, a mai completat jurnalistul.
Am comparat imaginile distribuite în postările înșelătoare cu fotografiile realizate de AFP la fața locului. Există mai multe indicii care arată că ele prezintă aceeași scenă. Am încercuit cu roșu cadavrul victimei și cu verde vehiculul avariat, un stâlp de semnalizare și partea de trotuar:
Avertisment privind conținutul
Danny Kemp ne-a trimis două fotografii pe care le-a făcut pe 2 aprilie, ziua în care au fost găsite cadavrele:
Avertisment privind conținutul
Avertisment privind conținutul
Alte două fotografii AFP, realizate o zi mai târziu de o a doua echipă sosită la fața locului, arată un muncitor municipal din Bucea, care se pregătește să pună același cadavru într-un sac mortuar.
Avertisment privind conținutul
Cadavrul despre care unele postări susțin că se mișcă apare de două ori în înregistrarea video din 2 aprilie, mai întâi întins pe jos și, două secunde mai târziu, în oglinda retrovizoare a vehiculului din care a fost filmat:
Avertisment privind conținutul
Avertisment privind conținutul
Acesta a fost de asemenea fotografiat de echipa AFP pe 3 aprilie, adică la 24 de ore distanță de la înregistrarea videoclipului distribuit pe rețelele de socializare, în aceeași poziție și în același loc:
Avertisment privind conținutul
„Martorii din Bucea ne-au spus că au văzut o coloană de aproximativ 70 de vehicule blindate rusești părăsind orașul în seara zilei de marți, 29 martie, dar că bombardamentele rusești au continuat intens miercuri, 30 martie, și că ultimul bombardament pe care l-au auzit a fost joi, 31 martie”, a mai spus Kemp.
„Jurnaliștii AFP aflați în zona din jurul localității Irpin, de lângă Bucea, au auzit bombardamente joi. A fost imposibil să aibă acces în zonă până vineri, deoarece autoritățile ucrainene au spus că nu este sigur să intre. AFP a intrat în Irpin vineri, pe 1 aprilie, și în Bucea sâmbătă, pe 2 aprilie”, a mai adăugat jurnalistul.
Ce se știe despre decesele din Bucea
Orășelul Bucea a fost ocupat de armata rusă pe 27 februarie 2022 și a rămas inaccesibil timp de mai mult de o lună. Bombardamentele au încetat pe 31 martie, iar forțele ucrainene au reușit să intre în totalitate în oraș abia în urmă cu câteva zile.
Ucraina i-a acuzat pe ruși că sunt responsabili pentru aceste decese. Acest lucru a fost negat de Moscova, care a anunțat că va investiga ceea ce a spus că este o „provocare odioasă” pentru a da vina pe forțele rusești.
Potrivit primarului din Bucea, Anatoli Fedoruk, aceste persoane au fost ucise de soldații ruși printr-un „glonț în zona gâtului”. Cadavrele a 57 de persoane au fost găsite, de asemenea, într-o groapă comună, a declarat pe 3 aprilie șeful serviciilor de salvare locale, Serghei Kaplytchny, care a arătat locul unei echipe AFP.
O duzină de cadavre erau vizibile, unele doar parțial îngropate, în spatele unei biserici din centrul orașului. Câteva dintre ele se aflau în saci mortuari negri, iar cele care puteau fi văzute purtau haine civile.
Pe 2 aprilie, Fedorouk a declarat că „280 de persoane” au fost îngropate „în gropi comune”, deoarece nu au putut fi înmormântate în cimitirele din Bucea. Numărul exact al victimelor nu este încă cunoscut, a declarat pentru AFP primarul Kievului, Vitali Klitschko, care a vizitat Bucea pe 3 aprilie. „Credem că au murit mai mult de 300 de civili”.
Imagini din satelit
Fotografii din satelit publicate pe 4 aprilie au părut, de asemenea, să infirme afirmațiile Rusiei potrivit cărora cadavrele îmbrăcate în haine civile găsite la Bucea au apărut acolo după ce forțele rusești s-au retras din orașul devastat.
Imaginile din satelit au fost realizate la jumătatea lunii martie și par să arate mai multe cadavre ale unor civili care zac morți pe carosabil sau chiar în afara acestuia. „Imaginile din satelit ale Maxar de înaltă rezoluție colectate deasupra orașului Bucea, Ucraina (la nord-vest de Kiev) verifică și coroborează videoclipurile și fotografiile recente de pe rețelele de socializare care dezvăluie cadavrele care zac pe străzi și sunt lăsate în văzul lumii de săptămâni întregi”, a declarat Stephen Wood, purtătorul de cuvânt al Maxar Technologies, pe 4 aprilie, într-un comunicat.
The New York Times a publicat o analiză a unor prim-planuri de pe strada Yablonska din Bucea și a concluzionat - după ce a comparat-o cu înregistrările video de pe 1 și 2 aprilie cu cadavrele aflate de-a lungul străzii - că multe dintre acestea se aflau acolo de cel puțin trei săptămâni, când forțele rusești controlau orașul.
AFP a comparat imaginile din satelit de pe 19 martie cu propriile sale fotografii de la fața locului, realizate pe 2 aprilie. Cadavrele apar în aceleași poziții și în aceleași locuri.
Bărbatul care „se presupune că își mișcă mâna”, după cum afirmă postările de pe rețelele de socializare, - întins lângă mașina avariată - este vizibil în imaginile de mai sus (a fost notat cu numărul 5 în graficul AFP), ceea ce dovedește încă o dată că afirmațiile despre mișcarea lui sunt nefondate. Multe alte cadavre prezente într-o imagine din satelit, furnizată de Maxar, din 19 martie, apar în aceeași poziție la pământ și în același loc ca în fotografiile AFP, realizate două săptămâni mai târziu.
În cadrul propriei sale investigații, BBC a constatat, de asemenea, că acuzațiile potrivit cărora masacrul a fost înscenat sunt nefondate. BBC explică faptul că ridicarea aparentă a unui corp, așa cum se vede în oglinda retrovizoare, este probabil efectul unei distorsiuni a reflexiei.
Revolta internațională
Mai multe capitale occidentale și ONU și-au exprimat indignarea după descoperirea cadavrelor. Michelle Bachelet, Înaltul Comisar pentru Drepturile Omului, s-a declarat pe 4 aprilie „îngrozită” de imaginile de la Bucea, care „ridică întrebări serioase și tulburătoare cu privire la posibile crime de război”.
După publicarea acestor imagini, Uniunea Europeană a discutat pe 4 aprilie în „regim de urgență” despre luarea unor noi sancțiuni împotriva Moscovei.
Președintele ucrainean Volodimir Zelenski a vizitat orașul Bucea pe 4 aprilie și a solicitat lumii să recunoască „genocidul”. Câteva ore mai târziu, Zelenski s-a adresat Parlamentului României într-un discurs în care a prezentat imagini explicite din orașul ucrainean.
De la începutul invaziei Rusiei, pe rețelele de socializare au fost distribuite numeroase imagini și videoclipuri care distorsionează evenimentele din Ucraina, războiul fiind însoțit de un puternic val de dezinformare online. Departamentul de fact-checking al AFP a demontat numeroase afirmații false despre război, inclusiv multe care spun că Ucraina înscenează victime și morți (aici, aici, aici).
6 aprilie 2022 Numele fotografului AFP Ronaldo Schemidt a fost corectat în paragraful 12.
Există un conținut pe care ai vrea ca AFP să îl verifice?
Contactează-ne
Translation:
The discovery of bodies in Bucea, Ukraine, is not a "staging" with "actors"
- This article is over a year old.
- Published on April 5, 2022, at 5:59 p.m
- Updated on April 6, 2022, at 4:34 p.m
- 13 minutes to read
- By: François D'ASTIER, AFP France
- Translation and adaptation by Paula CABESCU
Copyright © AFP 2017-2024. Any commercial use of this content requires a subscription. Click here to find out more information.
On April 3, the Russian Ministry of Defense shared a roughly 20-second video of the scene on its Telegram channel, which has nearly 200,000 followers, along with a comment saying it was "fake." "The corpse video is confusing: here, at 0:12, the "corpse" on the right is moving its hand. At 0:30, in the rear-view mirror, the "corpse" sits down. The bodies in the video appear to have been deliberately placed to create a more dramatic image," the ministry claims.
On its Twitter account, the Russian embassy in Canada also posted the video, with a comment that the scene was staged and showed "fake corpses". "The slow-motion version clearly shows a 'corpse' moving his hand and then sitting down after the car passes him (seen in the rear-view mirror)," the embassy wrote.
Similar claims quickly spread on social media in several languages. "After a car passes one of the bodies lying on the ground, we see in the rear-view mirror an actor standing up," said a French-language Twitter post, which shared the same video.
In Romania, the video was published on several social networks, first on Telegram by a user who wrote that in a "film made by the Ukrainian army that took control of Bucea, we see the dead being raised from the pit. I mean the civilians massacred by the Russians". "One' waves his hand, another actually gets up from the floor. It seemed bizarre to me at first that there was no close-up footage, there was no blood anywhere, there was no face-up body, I didn't know the cause of the deaths," the post says.
The post quickly started spreading on other Telegram channels (here) as well as on Facebook (here, here, here) with the exact same description. The video was also shared with similar claims in German and Bulgarian.
Where is the video from?
Apparently shot from a vehicle following a Ukrainian military convoy, the video shows several bodies lying on a war-torn street in the town of Bucea, northwest of Kiev. I was able to geolocate the video here on Yablonska Street.
The video was published on April 2, 2022 on the YouTube channel of the Ukrainian online television station Espreso.TV. The journalist describes the images as proof of the "atrocities committed by the Russian occupiers of Bucea".
A longer version with better image quality was published the same day on the Ukrainian Defense Ministry's Twitter feed. It claims that "local civilians were arbitrarily executed".
Moving bodies?
In the deceptive posts, the video is slowed down and of poor quality. But as several sources have noted (here, here, here), if we look carefully at the sequence in better quality, these bodies do not move. The first man in the right corner of the video does not raise his hand; the illusion is actually a drop of water on the windshield of the vehicle from which the scene is filmed:
Getting fed up of this "it's a moving arm" bullsh.... it's a raindrop on the windscreen, alongside an inverted channel version for more clarity. The whole arm moving thing is just ridiculous. pic.twitter.com/ZiuEX4rFWc
— Aurora Intel (@AuroraIntel) April 3, 2022
The AFP team at the scene confirms the scene
AFP journalists entered Bucea on April 2 and confirmed the presence of approximately 20 corpses dressed in civilian clothes. One of them had his hands tied behind his back with a white cloth, and the Ukrainian passport was left open next to the body.
The team of journalist and AFP Hague bureau chief Danny Kemp, photographer Ronaldo Schemidt and video journalist Nicolas Garcia arrived at the scene on April 2 at around 15:30 local time, Kemp told AFP France.
"As soon as I arrived, I could see that the street was full of dead bodies. I first saw a group of three and then noticed that there were more in both directions. They were spread along the street at irregular intervals for a distance of about 400 yards, some alone, others in small groups of two or three. I walked the entire length of the place at least twice. I counted the bodies, finding that there were 20, photographed and filmed them. At no time did I see any of them move,” Kemp said in an email.
"At that time I noticed that all the bodies were wearing civilian clothes. They had pale, waxy skin and stiff-looking fingers, and some had discolored nails. Some had their limbs in strange positions. Some had their eyes open, others had their mouths agape. It was clear that they had been dead for several days", added the journalist.
We compared the images shared in the hoax posts with the photos taken by AFP at the scene. There are several indications that they depict the same scene. I have circled the victim's body in red and the damaged vehicle, a signal pole and the side of the pavement in green:
Content warning
Danny Kemp sent us two photos he took on April 2, the day the bodies were found:
Content warning
Content warning
Two other AFP photos, taken a day later by a second team that arrived on the scene, show a municipal worker from Bucea preparing to put the same body in a body bag.
Content warning
The body that some posts claim is moving appears twice in the April 2 video, first lying on the ground and two seconds later in the rearview mirror of the vehicle from which it was filmed:
Content warning
Content warning
He was also photographed by the AFP team on April 3, that is, 24 hours after the recording of the video shared on social networks, in the same position and in the same place:
Content warning
"Witnesses in Bucea told us that they saw a convoy of about 70 Russian armored vehicles leaving the city on the evening of Tuesday, March 29, but that Russian shelling continued intensely on Wednesday, March 30, and that the last shelling that - they heard it was Thursday, March 31," Kemp said.
"AFP journalists in the area around the town of Irpin, near Bucea, heard shelling on Thursday. It was impossible to gain access to the area until Friday, as Ukrainian authorities said it was unsafe to enter. AFP entered Irpin on Friday, April 1, and Bucea on Saturday, April 2," the journalist added.
What is known about the deaths in Bucea
The town of Bucea was occupied by the Russian army on February 27, 2022 and remained inaccessible for more than a month. The shelling stopped on March 31, and Ukrainian forces were able to fully enter the city only a few days ago.
Ukraine has accused the Russians of being responsible for the deaths. This was denied by Moscow, which announced it would investigate what it said was a "heinous provocation" to blame Russian forces.
According to the mayor of Bucea, Anatoli Fedoruk, these people were killed by Russian soldiers with a "bullet in the neck". The bodies of 57 people were also found in a mass grave, the head of local rescue services, Serghei Kaplytchny, said on April 3, showing the site to an AFP team.
A dozen bodies were visible, some only partially buried, behind a downtown church. A few of them were in black body bags, and those that could be seen were wearing civilian clothes.
On April 2, Fedorouk stated that "280 people" were buried "in mass graves" because they could not be buried in the Bucea cemeteries. The exact number of victims is not yet known, Kyiv mayor Vitali Klitschko, who visited Bucea on April 3, told AFP. "We believe more than 300 civilians died."
Satellite images
Satellite photos released on April 4 also appeared to disprove Russian claims that the plainclothes bodies found in Bucea appeared there after Russian forces withdrew from the devastated city.
The satellite images were taken in mid-March and appear to show several bodies of civilians lying dead on or off the roadway. "High-resolution Maxar satellite imagery collected over the city of Bucea, Ukraine (northwest of Kyiv) verifies and corroborates recent videos and photos on social media revealing corpses lying in the streets and left for the world to see for weeks whole," Maxar Technologies spokesman Stephen Wood said in a statement on April 4.
The New York Times published an analysis of close-ups on Yablonska Street in Bucea and concluded - after comparing it with the video footage from April 1 and 2 of the bodies lying along the street - that many of they had been there for at least three weeks when Russian forces controlled the city.
AFP compared the March 19 satellite images with its own on-site photos taken on April 2. The corpses appear in the same positions and in the same places.
The man who is "supposed to be moving his hand", as the social media posts state, - lying next to the damaged car - is visible in the images above (he was marked number 5 in the AFP graphic), which further proves once the claims about his movement are unfounded. Many other bodies in a satellite image provided by Maxar on March 19 appear in the same position on the ground and in the same place as in AFP photos taken two weeks later.
In its own investigation, the BBC also found allegations that the massacre was staged to be unfounded. The BBC explains that the apparent lifting of a body, as seen in the rear-view mirror, is probably the effect of a distortion of the reflection.
International revolt
Several Western capitals and the UN expressed outrage after the bodies were discovered. Michelle Bachelet, the High Commissioner for Human Rights, said on April 4 she was "horrified" by the images from Bucea, which "raise serious and disturbing questions about possible war crimes".
After the publication of these images, the European Union discussed on April 4 in an "emergency regime" about taking new sanctions against Moscow.
Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky visited the city of Bucea on April 4 and called on the world to recognize the "genocide". A few hours later, Zelenski addressed the Romanian Parliament in a speech in which he presented explicit images from the Ukrainian city.
Since the beginning of the Russian invasion, numerous images and videos have been shared on social media that distort the events in Ukraine, and the war has been accompanied by a strong wave of online disinformation. AFP's fact-checking department has debunked numerous false claims about the war, including many that Ukraine is faking casualties and deaths (here, here, here).
6 April 2022 Name of AFP photographer Ronaldo Schemidt corrected in paragraph 12.
Is there content you would like AFP to check?
Contact us
false_claim: Ukrainian forces were involved in the Rohyric scenes recorded in Bucha.

content:
Informații de context
O temă constantă de la declanșarea invaziei militare din Ucraina este aceea că mass media, în special mass media internaționale „mint”, „fabrică războiul”, „amplifică războiul”. În acest sens, pe rețelele sociale au circulat multe video-uri sau fotografii trucate atribuite acestor mass media cu caracter de simbol pentru spațiul public occidental (CNN, BBC, The Guardian). Aceste video-uri sau fotografii au fost puse în circulație pentru a consolida această temă, a „mass media care mint”, a „sistemului care minte” (mass media fiind portretizate ca „parte a sistemului”, ca „unelte ale sistemului”).
Care sunt faptele?
O astfel de fotografie este și cea de mai sus, atribuită în mod eronat ca aparținând/ fiind pusă în circulație de către BBC. Fotografia prezintă două clădiri în flăcări și este însoțită de descrierea: „Breaking News: Forțele ruse au bombardat două blocuri de apartamente în Ucraina”. Faptul că fotografia conține sigla BBC induce ideea că ar fi vorba despre un reportaj recent despre războiul din Ucraina realizat de postul britanic de televiziune.
Postările de pe rețelele sociale care au pus în circulație această fotografie subliniază caracterul ei contrafăcut, dar atribuie, în mod eronat, responsabilitatea pentru trucarea ei postului britanic de televiziune, îndemnând utilizatorii să nu mai creadă „propaganda occidentală a posturilor de televiziune”. În unele situații, conținutul postărilor nu precizează alte detalii, iar sursa de proveniență a fotografiei nu este indicată. Postarea a fost distribuită și pe unele pagini care se prezintă drept „pagini de amuzament”, însă fără a se indica în mod clar dacă postarea reprezintă un conținut de satiră.
O căutare a imaginii cu ajutorul Google Images arată că fotografia nu are legătură cu evenimentele de astăzi din Ucraina. Potrivit rezultatelor căutării, imaginile au fost suprinse în timpul atentatelor teroriste din 11 septembrie 2001, asupra turnurilor gemene World Trade Center din New York, SUA.
Rezultatele de căutare Google a presupusului titlu din limba engleză „Breaking News: Russian Forces Bomb 2 Blocks of Flats in Ukraine” indică faptul că o asemenea știre, însoțită de fotografia din postări, nu a fost publicată de postul BBC sau de alte surse de știri. Mai mult, o căutare pe site-ul BBC nu conduce la nici un rezultat corespunzător pentru știrea menționată în imagine.
Aceeași imagine înșelătoare a circulat recent pe rețelele sociale și în Lituania.
Evaluarea noastră: imagine trucată
Evenimentele surprinse în imagine prezintă atentatele din 11 septembrie 2001, din New York, și nu au legătură cu războiul din Ucraina. În baza analizei noastre, apreciem că fotografia a fost editată/ fabricată pentru a include sigla postului BBC News.
Narațiuni alimentate de astfel de postări:
- „presa mainstream minte/ ascunde adevărul/ manipulează”;
- „presa mainstrea publică informații fabricate despre războiul din Ucraina”;
- „războiul din Ucraina este fabricat/ o farsă/ invenție”.
Disclaimer!
Antifake scoate la suprafață și analizează conținuturi eronate, înșelătoare sau pur și simplu false nu pentru a le amplifica sau a le oferi o vizibilitate nedorită în spațiul public, ci pentru a crește nivelul de conștientizare publică pe marginea lor.
Sursele noastre de fact-checking:
google.com – Rezultatele căutarii imaginii cu ajutorul Google Images
bbc.com – Rezultatele căutării titlului pe site-ul BBC
delfi.lt – Plinta suklastota nuotrauka: 2001 m. rugsėjo 11 d. kadrą susiejo su karu Ukrainoje
antifake.ro – Imagini fabricate și atribuite în mod fals CNN
Translation:
Context information
A constant theme since the start of the military invasion of Ukraine is that the media, especially the international media "lies", "manufactures war", "amplifies war". In this sense, many fake videos or photos have circulated on social networks attributed to these mass media with a symbolic character for the Western public space (CNN, BBC, The Guardian). These videos or photos were circulated to reinforce this theme, of the "lying media", the "lying system" (the media being portrayed as "part of the system", as "tools of the system") .
What are the facts?
One such photo is the one above, wrongly attributed to/circulated by the BBC. The photo shows two burning buildings and is accompanied by the description: "Breaking News: Russian forces bombed two apartment blocks in Ukraine." The fact that the photo contains the BBC logo leads to the idea that it is a recent report on the war in Ukraine made by the British television station.
The social media posts that circulated the photo emphasized its fake nature, but wrongly attributed responsibility for its manipulation to the British TV station, urging users to stop believing "Western TV propaganda". In some cases, the content of the posts does not specify other details, and the source of the photo is not indicated. The post was also shared on some pages that present themselves as "funny pages", but without clearly indicating whether the post is satirical content.
A search of the image using Google Images shows that the photo is unrelated to today's events in Ukraine. According to the search results, the images were captured during the terrorist attacks of September 11, 2001, on the twin towers of the World Trade Center in New York, USA.
Google search results for the supposed English title "Breaking News: Russian Forces Bomb 2 Blocks of Flats in Ukraine" indicate that such news, accompanied by the photo in the posts, was not published by the BBC or other news sources . Furthermore, a search on the BBC website does not return any relevant results for the news item mentioned in the image.
The same misleading image recently circulated on social networks in Lithuania as well.
Our rating: rigged image
The events captured in the image depict the attacks of September 11, 2001, in New York, and are not related to the war in Ukraine. Based on our analysis, we believe the photo has been edited/fabricated to include the BBC News station logo.
Narratives fueled by posts like these:
- "the mainstream media lies/ hides the truth/ manipulates";
- "mainstream press publishes fabricated information about the war in Ukraine";
- "the war in Ukraine is fabricated/ a hoax/ invention".
Disclaimer!
Antifake surfaces and analyzes erroneous, misleading or simply fake content not to amplify it or give it unwanted visibility in the public space, but to raise public awareness of it.
Our fact-checking sources:
google.com – Image search results using Google Images
bbc.com – Search results for the title on the BBC website
delfi.lt – Plinta suklastota photo: 2001 m. September 11 d. kadrą susiejo su karu Ukrainoje
antifake.ro – Images fabricated and falsely attributed to CNN
false_claim: Western media are spreading false news and images regarding the war.

content:
Obalamy fałszywe informacje pojawiające się w mediach społecznościowych oraz na portalach internetowych. Odwołując się do wiarygodnych źródeł, weryfikujemy najbardziej szkodliwe przykłady dezinformacji.
Ostrzał szpitala w Mariupolu był ustawką? Fake news!
Kobieta była w zaawansowanej ciąży jeszcze przed wybuchem wojny.
Ostrzał szpitala w Mariupolu był ustawką? Fake news!
Kobieta była w zaawansowanej ciąży jeszcze przed wybuchem wojny.
Zwolennicy teorii spiskowych nieustannie zaskakują. Wojna w Ukrainie stała się dla nich wielkim teatrem, lecz nie działań wojennych, lecz… takim na „serio”. Nie minął miesiąc od rozpoczęcia inwazji, a w sieci funkcjonuje już szerokie grono osób, które uważają, że wojna w Ukrainie została zmyślona lub wyolbrzymiona przez media, by wywołać strach.
Przykładowo na podstawie kilku zdjęć ze zbombardowanego szpitala w Mariupolu część osób wysnuła wniosek, że „ukraińscy fałszywi mistrzowie fabryki wykorzystali modelkę Mariannę z Mariupola”. Tym samym kobietę w zaawansowanej ciąży posądzono o udział w spisku.
Teorie spiskowe były dodatkowo legitymizowane przez rosyjską ambasadę w Wielkiej Brytanii. Na Twitterze rosyjska instytucja podawała, że ciężarna kobieta odgrywała „rolę” dwóch poszkodowanych kobiet widocznych na zdjęciach. Nie przedstawiono na to żadnych wiarygodnych dowodów — jakby wystarczyć miała jej tożsamość jako influncerki beauty.
Zniszczenia szpitala zostały wytłumaczone słowami rosyjskiego ministra spraw zagranicznych Siergieja Ławrowa, który stwierdził, że szpital od dawna nie działał i bym obsadzony siłami „neonazistowskiego” Batalionu Azow (o czym Rosja miała ostrzec ONZ kilka dni wcześniej). Sugeruje w ten sposób, że obiekt należy rozpatrywać w kategoriach budynku wojskowego, a nie cywilnego.
W bombardowaniu zginęły 3 osoby (w tym jedno dziecko), a 17 zostało rannych. Rosjanie przyznali się do ataku, jednak utrzymują, że szpital był okupowany przez radykalny pułk „Azow”.
Kobieta była w zaawansowanej ciąży przed inwazją. Nic więc dziwnego, że mogła znajdować się w szpitalu
Kobieta widoczna na zdjęciach to Marianna Podgurskaya. Jeżeli zajrzymy na konto gixie_beauty, które prowadzi na Instagramie, to dowiemy się, że zdjęcie z prezentacją kosmetyków, które rozeszło się w sieci, pojawiło się tam w październiku 2021 roku.
Kobieta mieszka w Mariupolu, a ostatnie zdjęcia zamieszczała 28 lutego 2022 roku. Widać na nich, że jest w zaawansowanej ciąży, a więc mogła trafić do szpitala, który w tej miejscowości został później zbombardowany przez rosyjskie wojska.
Rosyjska Ambasada twierdzi, jakoby blogerka modowa była podstawioną do zdjęć modelką w celu mistyfikacji ataku na szpital położniczy w Mariupolu.
❌To #FakeNews
✅ Pochodząca z Mariupola Marianna Podgurskaya wielokrotnie na swoim IG dokumentowała, że jest w zaawansowanej ciąży. https://t.co/dnB9ttPoA5 pic.twitter.com/xkbDfykpEd
— 🔎 DEMAGOG (@DemagogPL) March 10, 2022
Trudno mówić o tym, by bombardowanie budynku miało skoordynowany charakter, wymierzony w rzekomo przebywające tam oddziały radykalnego pułku „Azow” – jak to stwierdziła strona rosyjska – kiedy ucierpieli na tym niewinni cywile przebywający w szpitalu.
✔️W wyniku ostrzału szpitala położniczego w Mariupolu zginęły 3 osoby, w tym jedno dziecko. 17 osób zostało rannych.
A na nagraniu poniżej, jak zapewne za Rosyjską Ambasadą w UK stwierdzą trolle i spiskowcy — żołnierze pułku Azow.
Źródło: @CBSNews pic.twitter.com/nVexpFeKNv
— 🔎 DEMAGOG (@DemagogPL) March 10, 2022
Co więcej, należy zaznaczyć, że zdjęcie kobiety na noszach nie przedstawia modowej influencerki. To inna osoba, co można dostrzec już po przybliżeniu zdjęcia. Wskazują na to przede wszystkim inne rysy twarzy i inny kolor włosów.
Uwagę na ten fakt zwracał jeden z dziennikarzy BBC Sahayan Sardarizadeh, który zajmuje się problemem dezinformacji.
[Aktualizacja 14.03.2022]
Wieczorem 13 marca dziennikarze poinformowali o śmierci jednej z kobiet widocznych na fotorelacji z bombardowania szpitala. Razem z matką zmarło dziecko. Marianna Podgurskaya przeżyła atak i urodziła córkę.
Podsumowanie
Wojna i tragedie wielu rodzin to nie mistyfikacja. To dzieje się naprawdę i odpowiadają za to rosyjskie wojska. Zdjęcia rannej ukraińskiej influencerki w ciąży, które zamieszczono w sieci, w żaden sposób nie dowodzą tego, by została ona wykorzystana w medialnej propagandzie zachodnich mediów.
[AKTUALIZACJA 14.03.22]
Jeden z fotografów współpracujących z agencją Associated Press, którzy byli na miejscu zdarzenia, Mstyslav Chernov, udostępnił na swoim Instagramie materiały wideo. Widzimy na nich ewakuację z ostrzelanego szpitala. W pomieszczeniach znajduje się porozrzucamy sprzęt szpitalny. Nie widać natomiast sprzętu, który jednoznacznie wskazywałby na to, że w placówce znajdowała się jednostka wojskowa.
9 marca ambasada rosyjska w Izraelu opublikowała rzekomy dowód na to, że w szpitalu stacjonował Batalion Azow, którym miało być zdjęcie stojącego pod budynkiem pojazdu wojskowego. Jeden z użytkowników Twittera (@digitaljonah) zwrócił uwagę, że budynek na zdjęciu znajduje się ponad 10 km od szpitala, o czym poinformował serwis Bellingcat zajmujący się białym wywiadem.
11 marca agencja Associated Press podała, że jedna z bohaterek zdjęć, influencerka Marianna Wiszegirskaja urodziła córkę.
Druga kobieta, która na zdjęciach leży na noszach, nie przeżyła.
*Jeśli znajdziesz błąd, zaznacz go i wciśnij Ctrl + Enter
Translation:
We debunk false information appearing on social media and websites. By referring to reliable sources, we verify the most harmful examples of disinformation.
Was the shelling of the hospital in Mariupol a set-up? Fake news!
The woman was in an advanced stage of pregnancy even before the war broke out.
Was the shelling of the hospital in Mariupol a set-up? Fake news!
The woman was in an advanced stage of pregnancy even before the war broke out.
Conspiracy theorists are constantly surprising. The war in Ukraine became a great theater for them, not of military action, but... in a "serious" way. Less than a month has passed since the invasion began, and there is already a large group of people online who believe that the war in Ukraine was made up or exaggerated by the media to cause fear.
For example, based on several photos from the bombed hospital in Mariupol, some people concluded that "Ukrainian fake factory masters used the model Marianna from Mariupol." Thus, the heavily pregnant woman was accused of participating in the conspiracy.
Conspiracy theories were further legitimized by the Russian embassy in the UK. On Twitter, the Russian institution said that the pregnant woman played the "role" of the two injured women visible in the photos. No credible evidence has been provided for this - as if her identity as a beauty influencer were enough.
The destruction of the hospital was explained by the words of Russian Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov, who stated that the hospital had not been operational for a long time and that it would be staffed by the forces of the "neo-Nazi" Azov Battalion (about which Russia had warned the UN a few days earlier). It thus suggests that the facility should be considered as a military building, not a civilian one.
3 people were killed in the bombing (including one child) and 17 were injured. The Russians admitted to the attack, but maintain that the hospital was occupied by the radical "Azov" regiment.
The woman was heavily pregnant before the invasion. No wonder she could be in hospital
The woman in the photos is Marianna Podgurskaya. If we look at the gixie_beauty account she runs on Instagram, we will learn that the photo with the cosmetics presentation that went viral online appeared there in October 2021.
The woman lives in Mariupol and posted her last photos on February 28, 2022. They show that she is in an advanced stage of pregnancy, so she could have been taken to a hospital that was later bombed by Russian troops.
The Russian Embassy claims that the fashion blogger was a model used for photos in order to hoax the attack on the maternity hospital in Mariupol.
❌It's #FakeNews
✅ Marianna Podgurskaya from Mariupol has documented many times on her IG that she is in an advanced stage of pregnancy. https://t.co/dnB9ttPoA5 pic.twitter.com/xkbDfykpEd
— 🔎 DEMAGOG (@DemagogPL) March 10, 2022
It is difficult to say that the bombing of the building was coordinated, aimed at the units of the radical "Azov" regiment allegedly located there - as stated by the Russian side - when innocent civilians in the hospital suffered.
✔️As a result of the shelling of the maternity hospital in Mariupol, 3 people died, including one child. 17 people were injured.
And in the recording below, trolls and conspirators - soldiers of the Azov regiment - will probably say that behind the Russian Embassy in the UK.
Source: @CBSNews pic.twitter.com/nVexpFeKNv
— 🔎 DEMAGOG (@DemagogPL) March 10, 2022
Moreover, it should be noted that the photo of the woman on a stretcher does not depict a fashion influencer. This is a different person, which can be seen just by zooming in on the photo. This is indicated primarily by different facial features and different hair color.
One of the BBC journalists, Sahayan Sardarizadeh, who deals with the problem of disinformation, drew attention to this fact.
[Update 14/03/2022]
On the evening of March 13, journalists reported the death of one of the women visible in the photo report from the hospital bombing. The child died along with his mother. Marianna Podgurskaya survived the attack and gave birth to a daughter.
Summary
The war and the tragedies of many families are not a hoax. This is real and the Russian troops are responsible for it. The photos of the injured, pregnant Ukrainian influencer posted online do not prove in any way that she was used in media propaganda by Western media.
[UPDATE 14/03/22]
One of the Associated Press photographers at the scene, Mstyslav Chernov, shared video footage on his Instagram. We see an evacuation from a hospital under fire. There are hospital equipment scattered throughout the rooms. However, there is no equipment visible that would clearly indicate that a military unit was located in the facility.
On March 9, the Russian embassy in Israel published alleged evidence that the Azov Battalion was stationed in the hospital, which was allegedly a photo of a military vehicle standing in front of the building. One Twitter user (@digitaljonah) pointed out that the building in the photo is more than 10 km from the hospital, as reported by the white intelligence website Bellingcat.
On March 11, the Associated Press reported that one of the subjects of the photos, influencer Marianna Wiszegirskaja, gave birth to a daughter.
The second woman, who is lying on a stretcher in the photos, did not survive.
*If you find an error, select it and press Ctrl + Enter
false_claim: Mariupol’s hospital was not bombed by Russia; the attack was staged by Ukrainian forces.

content:
Įrašą ištrynė
Įspūdingu vaizdo įrašu, kuriame esą įamžintas Rusijos ir Suomijos pasienis, trečiadienio popietę paskelbė nepriklausomu laisvai samdomu žurnalistu prisistatantis „Twitter“ vartotojas. Kaip žinoma, tos dienos rytą V.Putinas paskelbė dalinę mobilizaciją.
„Svarbi žinia: ką tik – spūstis prie Rusijos / Suomijos sienos jau 35 km ir ilgėja kas valandą, tai – vienintelė siena, kuri vis dar atvira Rusijos civiliams piliečiams su Šengeno vizomis, kai V.Putinas paskelbė, kad į Ukrainą pasiųs 300 tūkst. naujų karių“, – pakomentavo jis.
Beveik pusės minutės trukmės įraše išties pažymėta, kad rodomas Rusijos ir Suomijos pasienis.
Nufilmuoti dviem eilėmis sustoję automobiliai, aplink vaikštantys jų vairuotojai ir keleiviai. Parodoma, kad eilės driekiasi tolyn, jų galo nematyti. „Visur, visur žmonės“, – paaiškinta įraše.
Per pusantros paros jis buvo peržiūrėtas 2,8 mln. kartų. Daugiau nei 25 tūkst. žmonių paspaudė „patinka“, daugiau nei 13 tūkst. perpublikavo savo paskyrose. Netrukus įrašas buvo ištrintas, bet galima pamatyti jo suarchyvuotą versiją.
Tas pats įrašas (su angliškais arba rusiškais komentarais, be jų) pasirodė ir kituose socialiniuose tinkluose (pavyzdžiui, čia, čia, čia, čia). Apie situaciją pasienyje, remdamiesi įrašu, pranešė ir įvairūs tinklalapiai (Indijoje, Graikijoje čia, čia).
Demaskavo pagal orą
Bet žinia apie didžiulę eilę prie Suomijos sienos, kuri užfiksuota vaizdo įraše, yra klaidinanti. Į tai dėmesį atkreipė net žurnalisto įrašo „Twitter“ komentatoriai. Anot jų, kad platinama melagiena, galima suprasti jau iš pirmo žvilgsnio – rodomas pernelyg vasariškas oras.
„Čia ne šiandiena. Dabar – rugsėjis ir Suomijoje jau rudeniškos spalvos!“, – po poros valandų žurnalistui replikavo viena suomė ir pridėjo jau kiek parudavusių medžių ir ne taip skaisčiai žalios žolės nuotrauką iš sienos kirtimo punkto.
Oro sąlygos užkliuvo ir kitai komentatorei (anot jos, Suomijoje jau prasidėjo šaltas ruduo). Dar vienas „Twitter“ vartotojas atkreipė dėmesį, kad daugiau vairuotojų norėjo patekti iš Suomijos į Rusiją, ne atvirkščiai. Tai esą rodė tiesioginė transliacija iš vieno sienos kirtimo punkto.
Žinią apie kilometrinę eilę paneigė Suomijos sienos apsaugos tarnyba: „Rusijoje paskelbus (dalinę) mobilizaciją, situacija prie Suomijos sienų nepasikeitė.
Socialiniuose tinkluose cirkuliuoja vaizdo įrašai, iš kurių bent kai kurie buvo nufilmuoti anksčiau ir dabar, ištraukti iš konteksto. Platinama neteisinga informacija.“
Tą patį savo paskyroje „Twitter“ (čia, čia) pažymėjo ir tarnybos Tarptautinių reikalų direktorato vadovas Matti Pitkäniitty.
Anot jo, situacija prie Suomijos-Rusijos sienos trečiadienį iki vakaro buvo normali, eilės nebuvo ilgesnės nei įprastai pastaruoju metu.
Pietryčių Suomijos sieną saugantys pareigūnai informavo, kad trečiadienio popietę driekėsi vos 250 metrų ilgio automobilių eilė.
Savaitgalį buvo pranešta, kad penktadienį sieną norėjo kirsti gerus du kartus daugiau Rusijos piliečių nei savaite anksčiau, bet jų esą vis tiek mažiau nei priešpandeminiais metais.
Panašius skaičius Suomija paskelbė ir pirmadienį. Praėjęs savaitgalis buvęs rekordinis šiais metais, kalbant apie į šalį atvykstančius rusus.
„Praėjusį savaitgalį eismas prie rytinės sienos buvo intensyviausias šiais metais“, – naujienų agentūrai AFP sakė Mertas Sasioglu iš Suomijos sienos apsaugos tarnybos.
Šeštadienį, kirsdami sausumos sieną į Suomiją, atvyko kone 8,6 tūkst. rusų, o beveik 4,2 tūkst. per sieną išvyko į Rusiją. Sekmadienį skaičiai siekė atitinkamai 8,3 tūkst. ir 5,1 tūkst.
„Atvykstančiųjų skaičius yra maždaug dvigubai didesnis nei prieš savaitę, – sakė M.Sasioglu. – Pagrindinė priežastis yra mobilizacija, bet iš dalies tai galima paaiškinti ir tuo, kad Suomija bei Rusija vasarą atšaukė suvaržymus dėl COVID-19.“
Iki V.Putino kalbos buvo likusios 3 savaitės
Minėtas žurnalistas graikišku vardu ir pavarde (beje, jau anksčiau platinęs melagienas, buvęs cituojamas anoniminės kraštutinės dešiniosios pakraipos žiniasklaidos) nėra vaizdo įrašo autorius.
