But it is false that Biden is trying to sit in a “chair that does not exist.” The video cuts to just before the American president sits down.
-The images, lasting 13 seconds, show that Biden is in a ceremony with the president of France, Emmanuel Macron, and his respective wives.
The event from which the viral video was taken is from the celebration of the 80th anniversary of the Normandy landings, as reported on the YouTube channel of the British media The Guardian (min. 26:40). It was celebrated on June 6, 2024.
By consulting the full video of Biden and the chair, and not just the clipping that is spread on social networks and which has also been echoed by some media outlets, we can see that Biden bends down to grab the armrests of the chair he he has prepared, and, finally, he ends up sitting down.
A global hoax. Misinformation about Biden and the supposed chair that does not exist has circulated in different languages ​​and countries. In the United States it has also been denied by fact-checkers such as Snopes or USA Today.
Sources
Full video in The Guardian
Snopes
USA Today
false_claim: Joe Biden attempted to sit on an invisible chair during the D-Day anniversary celebration.

content:
Context
Postările false și videoclipul fac referire la vizita președintelui Zelenski în SUA, la Adunarea Generală a ONU și la Consiliul de Securitate al ONU pe 19 și, respectiv, 20 septembrie 2023.
Videoclipul de pe Facebook include sigla USA TODAY în colțul din dreapta sus și arată o compilație de clipuri cu președintele ucrainean Volodimir Zelenski, poliția orașului New York și lupte de stradă. Videoclipul a fost distribuit de peste 40 de ori în mai puțin de o zi. Un videoclip similar a fost vizionat, pe Telegram, de peste 130.000 de ori.
Narațiuni alimentate de astfel de conținuturi false/ înșelătoare:
„Ucrainenii sunt violenți.”
„Statul ucrainean și conducerea lui sunt lipsite de orice etică.”
„Atât conducerea, cât și cultura Ucrainei sunt impregnate de elemente naziste.”
Evaluarea noastră:
Videoclip fabricat și atribuit în mod fals USA Today, despre un membru al delegației ucrainene la Adunarea Generala a ONU. USA Today nu a publicat un astfel de videoclip. Poliția din New York a confirmat că nu a existat nicio raportare a unui astfel de eveniment care să corespundă informațiilor din videoclip. Fragmentele din videoclip în care apar oameni neidentificați implicați într-o încăierare au fost geolocalizate la aproximativ 20 km distanță de barul din Manhattan unde ar fi avut loc incidentul incriminat.
Disclaimer!
Antifake scoate la suprafață și analizează conținuturi eronate, înșelătoare sau pur și simplu false, nu pentru a le amplifica sau a le oferi o vizibilitate nedorită în spațiul public, ci pentru a crește nivelul de conștientizare publică pe marginea lor.
Sursele noastre de fact-checking:
Reuters.com – Fact Check: USA Today report on Ukraine delegate’s New York bar fight is fake
Usatoday.com – Video about a ‘drunken brawl’ tied to Ukraine isn’t from USA TODAY | Fact check
Apnews.com – Fabricated video spreads false report that a member of Ukraine’s UN delegation got into a bar fight
Translation:
Context
The fake posts and video refer to President Zelenskiy's visit to the US, the UN General Assembly and the UN Security Council on September 19 and 20, 2023, respectively.
The Facebook video includes the USA TODAY logo in the upper right corner and shows a compilation of clips of Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky, New York City police and street fights. The video has been shared over 40 times in less than a day. A similar video has been viewed over 130,000 times on Telegram.
Narratives fueled by such false/misleading content:
"Ukrainians are violent."
"The Ukrainian state and its leadership are unethical."
"Both the leadership and the culture of Ukraine are permeated with Nazi elements."
Our Rating:
Video fabricated and falsely attributed to USA Today, about a member of the Ukrainian delegation to the UN General Assembly. USA Today did not publish such a video. The NYPD confirmed that there had been no report of such an event matching the information in the video. Clips of the video showing unidentified people involved in a brawl were geolocated about 20km away from the Manhattan bar where the alleged incident took place.
Disclaimer!
Antifake surfaces and analyzes erroneous, misleading or simply fake content, not to amplify it or give it unwanted visibility in the public space, but to raise public awareness of it.
Our fact-checking sources:
Reuters.com – Fact Check: USA Today report on Ukraine delegate's New York bar fight is fake
Usatoday.com – Video about a 'drunken brawl' tied to Ukraine isn't from USA TODAY | Fact check
Apnews.com – Fabricated video spreads false report that a member of Ukraine's UN delegation got into a bar fight
false_claim: USA Today reported a fight involving the Ukrainian delegation in New York.

content:
In Australia non sarà rilasciato un vaccino in cielo tramite «scie chimiche»
L’11 giugno 2022 su Facebook è stato pubblicato un post in cui si afferma che l’Australia avrebbe approvato «la richiesta di licenza della società Big Pharma PaxVax che consentirà loro di rilasciare intenzionalmente un vaccino OGM costituito da batteri vivi nel Queensland, tramite scie chimiche».
Si tratta di una notizia falsa.
Come hanno ricostruito i colleghi australiani Aap FactCheck non esiste alcun riscontro secondo cui l’Australia abbia approvato un vaccino da somministrare tramite le cosiddette «scie chimiche».
L’approvazione a cui si fa riferimento nel post oggetto di analisi è stata data nel 2014 dalle autorità australiane e riguardava la sperimentazione di un vaccino Vaxchora contro il colera che aveva coinvolto circa 1.000 partecipanti. In quell’occasione la somministrazione del farmaco era avvenuta per via orale.
Contattato dai fact-checker australiani, Wilbur Chen – scienziato che ha lavorato allo sviluppo del vaccino Vaxchora – ha smentito la notizia infondata, affermando di non conoscere piani «per disperdere il vaccino per via aerea; non vi è alcuna ragione scientificamente plausibile per farlo».
Michelle McIntosh, un’esperta di somministrazione di farmaci presso la Monash University (Australia) che ha lavorato a progetti che tentano di determinare la fattibilità dei vaccini spray, ha spiegato che la vaccinazione con aerosol di massa tramite un aereo non è né fattibile né sensata. «Una considerazione importante nei programmi di vaccinazione è garantire che ogni paziente riceva la dose corretta, che non potrebbe essere raggiunta con una spruzzata aerea di polvere di vaccino», ha detto McIntosh.
Iniltre, un portavoce del Dipartimento della Salute del governo australiano ha chiarito sempre ad Aap FactCheck di non aver mai approvato, né di aver ricevuto la richiesta di approvare, la distribuzione aerea di un vaccino.
Passiamo infine alla teoria del complotto priva di fondamento delle scie chimiche. Si tratta di una teoria, nata nella seconda metà degli anni ’90, che sostiene che i governi starebbero modificando il clima globale o avvelenando la popolazione tramite le scie di condensazione formate da agenti chimici e create da aerei su cui sono montati particolari strumenti. In realtà si tratta di scie costituite da prodotti di condensazione e solidificazione del vapore acqueo. Su Facta ci siamo già occupati di un caso di disinformazione legato alle scie chimiche.
Translation:
Australia won't release a vaccine into the sky via 'chemtrails'
On June 11, 2022, a post was published on Facebook stating that Australia would approve "Big Pharma company PaxVax's application for a license that will allow them to intentionally release a GMO vaccine made from live bacteria in Queensland, via trails chemicals".
This is fake news.
As our Australian colleagues at AAP FactCheck have reconstructed, there is no evidence that Australia has approved a vaccine to be administered via so-called "chemtrails".
The approval referred to in the post under analysis was given in 2014 by the Australian authorities and concerned the testing of a Vaxchora vaccine against cholera which involved approximately 1,000 participants. On that occasion the drug was administered orally.
Contacted by Australian fact-checkers, Wilbur Chen – a scientist who worked on the development of the Vaxchora vaccine – denied the unfounded news, stating that he knew of no plans «to disperse the vaccine by air; there is no scientifically plausible reason to do so."
Michelle McIntosh, a drug delivery expert at Monash University (Australia) who has worked on projects trying to determine the feasibility of spray vaccines, explained that mass aerosol vaccination via a plane is neither feasible nor sensible . “An important consideration in vaccination programs is ensuring that each patient receives the correct dose, which could not be achieved with an aerial spray of vaccine powder,” McIntosh said.
Furthermore, a spokesperson for the Australian Government's Department of Health also clarified to AAP FactCheck that it has never approved, nor received a request to approve, the aerial distribution of a vaccine.
Finally, let's move on to the baseless chemtrail conspiracy theory. This is a theory, born in the second half of the 1990s, which claims that governments are modifying the global climate or poisoning the population through contrails formed by chemical agents and created by airplanes on which particular instruments are mounted. In reality these are trails made up of condensation and solidification products of water vapor. On Facta we have already dealt with a case of misinformation linked to chemtrails.
false_claim: Chemtrails have been used/will be used in different countries to spread vaccines from the sky.

content:
Esta e outras publicações com teor semelhante, efetuadas já este mês de dezembro, mereceram milhares de partilhas e a verificação de vários jornais da International Fact-Checking Network (na qual o Polígrafo está também integrado).
Para comprovar o que é referido, algumas destas publicações são acompanhadas pela captura de ecrã da manchete de um órgão de informação (El Español) com esse conteúdo, que acaba por ser decisiva para perceber o tempo e os contornos desta polémica semântica.
Uma pesquisa pelas palavras exatas da manchete citada e pelo jornal permite, desde logo, perceber três factos: 1) a notícia é de 30 de novembro de 2021 (cerca das 12.40); 2) houve uma atualização da mesma notícia (cerca das 17.00); 3) a notícia original foi retirada do site do jornal e manteve-se somente na rede social (na altura, Twitter). A atualização da informação foi efetuada nos dois canais e apontava para a suspensão da medida que tinha sido objeto da primeira notícia. Na rede X/Twitter, estes horários assumem a hora portuguesa (menos 1 hora).
E o que aconteceu afinal?
A 26 de outubro de 2021 a Comissária para a Igualdade na Comissão Europeia (CE), Helena Dalli, anunciou a criação de um guia interno, de 30 páginas, dirigido aos funcionários da CE, com instruções concretas de como utilizar uma linguagem mais neutral, que não enviesasse a mensagem, designadamente em relação ao género ou às minorias em território europeu (orientação sexual, etnia ou religião).
Neste documento, a comissária maltesa propunha o seguinte: “Há que evitar assumir que todos são cristãos. Nem todos celebram as festas natalícias e nem todos os cristãos celebram-na nas mesmas datas. Há que ser sensível ao direito das pessoas terem tradições religiosas diferentes”. Nesse sentido, Helena Dalli passou a diretriz de que seria de evitar formulações como “a época de Natal pode ser stressante” e substituí-las por “a época de festas pode ser stressante” ou “para os que celebram o Natal (…)”.
Mas a partir de dia 28 de novembro, algumas medidas foram conhecidas e esta estilização da linguagem gerou bastantes críticas, nomeadamente de diversos setores políticos italianos e do Vaticano (este no dia 30).
A CE tentou estancar a contestação e, nesse mesmo 30 de novembro de 2021, às 12.10, emitiu uma nota de informação, assinada pela comissária Helena Dalli, na qual informava que aquele guia tinha sido suspenso:
“(…) não é um documento maduro e não atende a todos os padrões de qualidade da Comissão. As Guidelines claramente precisam de mais trabalho. Portanto, retiro as Guidelines e trabalharei mais neste documento.”
Assim, e apesar de ter havido uma diretriz interna no sentido do uso de uma linguagem neutral relativamente a alguns aspetos da referência à época de Natal (que suscitaram grande polémica), em outubro/novembro de 2021, esta orientação nem foi formulada nos termos precisos em que se apresenta na publicação aqui verificada, nem tão pouco está em vigor. A CE retirou-a 35 dias depois de a anunciar, devido à contestação que gerou.
_______________________________
Este artigo foi desenvolvido pelo Polígrafo no âmbito do projeto “EUROPA”. O projeto foi cofinanciado pela União Europeia no âmbito do programa de subvenções do Parlamento Europeu no domínio da comunicação. O Parlamento Europeu não foi associado à sua preparação e não é de modo algum responsável pelos dados, informações ou pontos de vista expressos no contexto do projeto, nem está por eles vinculado, cabendo a responsabilidade dos mesmos, nos termos do direito aplicável, unicamente aos autores, às pessoas entrevistadas, aos editores ou aos difusores do programa. O Parlamento Europeu não pode, além disso, ser considerado responsável pelos prejuízos, diretos ou indiretos, que a realização do projeto possa causar.
_______________________________
Avaliação do Polígrafo:
Translation:
This and other publications with similar content, published this December, received thousands of shares and verification by several newspapers in the International Fact-Checking Network (in which Polígrafo is also integrated).
To prove what is being said, some of these publications are accompanied by a screenshot of the headline from an information organization (El Español) with this content, which ends up being decisive in understanding the time and contours of this semantic controversy.
A search for the exact words in the headline cited and the newspaper allows you to immediately understand three facts: 1) the news is from November 30, 2021 (around 12:40); 2) there was an update of the same news (around 5pm); 3) the original news was removed from the newspaper's website and remained only on the social network (at the time, Twitter). The information was updated on both channels and pointed to the suspension of the measure that had been the subject of the first news. On the X/Twitter network, these times assume Portuguese time (minus 1 hour).
And what happened after all?
On October 26, 2021, the Commissioner for Equality at the European Commission (EC), Helena Dalli, announced the creation of a 30-page internal guide, aimed at EC employees, with concrete instructions on how to use more neutral language, that did not send the message, particularly in relation to gender or minorities in European territory (sexual orientation, ethnicity or religion).
In this document, the Maltese Commissioner proposed the following: “We must avoid assuming that everyone is Christian. Not everyone celebrates the holidays and not all Christians celebrate them on the same dates. We must be sensitive to people’s right to have different religious traditions.” In this sense, Helena Dalli gave the guideline that we should avoid formulations such as “Christmas time can be stressful” and replace them with “festive season can be stressful” or “for those who celebrate Christmas (…)” .
But as of November 28th, some measures became known and this stylization of language generated a lot of criticism, particularly from various Italian political sectors and the Vatican (this one on the 30th).
The EC tried to stop the challenge and, on that same November 30, 2021, at 12.10, it issued an information note, signed by Commissioner Helena Dalli, in which she informed that that guide had been suspended:
“(…) it is not a mature document and does not meet all of the Commission’s quality standards. The Guidelines clearly need more work. Therefore, I withdraw the Guidelines and will work further on this document.”
Therefore, despite there having been an internal guideline to use neutral language regarding some aspects of the reference to the Christmas season (which aroused great controversy), in October/November 2021, this guideline was not even formulated in the precise terms as presented in the publication verified here, is not even in force. The EC withdrew it 35 days after announcing it, due to the outcry it generated.
_______________________________
This article was developed by Polígrafo within the scope of the “EUROPA” project. The project was co-financed by the European Union under the European Parliament's communications grants programme. The European Parliament was not involved in its preparation and is in no way responsible for the data, information or views expressed in the context of the project, nor is it bound by them, with their responsibility, in accordance with applicable law, solely to the authors, people interviewed, editors or broadcasters of the program. Furthermore, the European Parliament cannot be held responsible for any direct or indirect damage that carrying out the project may cause.
_______________________________
Polygraph Assessment:
false_claim: The EU Commission prohibited the use of the term 'Christmas'.

content:
¿Qué verificamos?
Uno de los terroristas detenidos por el atentado de Moscú es un checheno que lucha a favor de Ucrania.
Conclusión
Falso, no es el ciudadano ucraniano de origen checheno Rustam Azhiev sino el ciudadano Dalerjon Mirzoev, de Tayikistán.
EFE Madrid |
El checheno Rustam Azhiev no es uno de los cuatro detenidos en Moscú como autores del atentado del pasado 22 de marzo que costó la vida a más de 130 personas en la capital rusa, como afirman mensajes en redes sociales. Se trata de Dalerjon Mirzoev, identificado como ciudadano de Tayikistán, según muestra una comparación visual de las fotografías tras su detención y las del verdadero Rustam Azhiev.
Mensajes compartidos en redes sociales afirman que uno de los supuestos terroristas detenidos por las autoridades rusas como responsables de los atentados de Moscú es Rustam Azhiev, también conocido como Abdul Hakim Al-Shishani, un combatiente checheno que luchó en Siria antes de unirse a Ucrania en su lucha contra Rusia.
«El nexo entre Ucrania y los yihadistas: ¿quién es Abdul-Hakim Shishani? «, dice uno de los mensajes compartidos en Facebook que viene acompañado de una fotografía de grupo de una reunión del Frente Central de Ichkeria, un grupo checheno enfrentado a Moscú.
En la red social X podemos leer: «Uno de los terroristas, Rustam Azhiyev, es ciudadano ucraniano y luchó en las Fuerzas Armadas de Ucrania en 2022. ¿Viene 3ra Guerra Mundial? ¿Qué hará Putin?«. En este caso la entrada de X está ilustrada con una fotografía del supuesto terrorista detenido junto a lo que dicen es el pasaporte de Azhiev.
El detenido por los atentados de Moscú no es Rustam Azhiev
El supuesto terrorista detenido por las autoridades rusas no es el checheno Rustam Azhiev, que luchó en Siria contra el régimen del presidente al-Ashad y posteriormente contra Rusia en Ucrania, se trata de Dalerjon Mirzoev, como muestra un análisis visual de las fotografías tras su detención y las del verdadero Rustam Azhiev.
La búsqueda en Google de las imágenes de Rustam Azhiev nos devuelve varias fotografías en las que se le puede observar en una reunión con la cúpula de una organización guerrillera chechena y otras en las que aparece mirando a la cámara armado con un rifle de asalto.
En una observación detallada de las imágenes podemos ver cómo faltan varios dedos de la mano izquierda de Azhiev, como puede observarse claramente en las fotografías encontradas, la más antigua de las cuales data del año 2019.
No coincide con la persona de los atentados
En la televisión pública británica BBC encontramos fotografías en las que se identifica con sus nombres a los cuatro supuestos integrantes del comando que atacó el centro comercial de Moscú, incluido Dalerjon Mirzoev, quien según los mensajes habría sido uno de los terroristas que irrumpió en el asalto.
Las fotografías tomadas por la Agencia EFE en Moscú del supuesto terrorista durante su comparecencia en una audiencia preliminar en un juzgado de la capital rusa dos días después de los ataques nos permite compararlas con las de Azhiev.
En ellas queda claro que las manos del acusado, Dalerjon Mirzoev, tienen todos su dedos a diferencia de todas las imágenes encontradas de Rustam Azhiev en las que aparece con los dedos amputados en su mano izquierda.
La desinformación rusa en Ucrania
Esta es la segunda vez que en Efe Verifica ha investigado mensajes falsos que relacionaban el atentado de Moscú del 22 de marzo con el Gobierno de Ucrania. Hace unos días, la unidad de verificación de EFE publicó una investigación que desmentía que una furgoneta sospechosa de haber sido utilizado por los terroristas fuese de matrícula ucraniana.
Además, se emitió en televisiones rusas un vídeo manipulado con inteligencia artificial (deepfake o ultrafalso) en el que el principal funcionario de seguridad de Ucrania, Oleksiy Danilov, admitía la participación de su país en el atentado de Moscú. En realidad el vídeo combinaba imágenes grabadas con anterioridad al ataque con una pista de audio manipulada y fue desacreditado por los principales medios de comunicación que no le dieron credibilidad.
Estas desinformaciones se enmarcan en el contexto de la invasión rusa de Ucrania de 2022. Desde entonces los usuarios de redes sociales han compartir decenas de imágenes, supuestamente reales, que reflejan cómo se desarrolla el conflicto, aunque, en realidad, en muchos casos se trata de vídeos y fotografías manipulados o descontextualizados.
Por tanto no es cierto que el cheheno Rustam Azhiev sea uno de los detenidos por su supuesta participación en el atentado de Moscú. En realidad es Dalerjon Mirzoev, que se identificó tras su detención como ciudadano de Tayikistán.
Fuentes:
Búsqueda en Google.
Televisión pública británica BBC.
Canal de televisión France24.
Información de EFE.
Translation:
What do we verify?
One of the terrorists arrested for the Moscow attack is a Chechen who fights for Ukraine.
Conclusion
False, it is not the Ukrainian citizen of Chechen origin Rustam Azhiev but the citizen Dalerjon Mirzoev, from Tajikistan.
EFE Madrid |
The Chechen Rustam Azhiev is not one of the four detained in Moscow as perpetrators of the attack on March 22 that cost the lives of more than 130 people in the Russian capital, as messages on social networks claim. This is Dalerjon Mirzoev, identified as a citizen of Tajikistan, as shown by a visual comparison of the photographs after his arrest and those of the real Rustam Azhiev.
Messages shared on social media claim that one of the alleged terrorists detained by Russian authorities as responsible for the Moscow attacks is Rustam Azhiev, also known as Abdul Hakim Al-Shishani, a Chechen fighter who fought in Syria before joining Ukraine in his fight against Russia.
«The link between Ukraine and jihadists: who is Abdul-Hakim Shishani? «says one of the messages shared on Facebook that is accompanied by a group photograph of a meeting of the Central Front of Ichkeria, a Chechen group opposed to Moscow.
On the social network What will Putin do?«. In this case, X's entry is illustrated with a photograph of the alleged terrorist detained along with what they say is Azhiev's passport.
The person arrested for the Moscow attacks is not Rustam Azhiev
The alleged terrorist detained by the Russian authorities is not the Chechen Rustam Azhiev, who fought in Syria against the regime of President al-Ashad and later against Russia in Ukraine, it is Dalerjon Mirzoev, as shown by a visual analysis of the photographs after his arrest and those of the real Rustam Azhiev.
A Google search for images of Rustam Azhiev returns several photographs in which he can be seen in a meeting with the leadership of a Chechen guerrilla organization and others in which he appears looking at the camera armed with an assault rifle.
In a detailed observation of the images we can see how several fingers are missing from Azhiev's left hand, as can be clearly seen in the photographs found, the oldest of which dates from 2019.
Does not match the person of the attacks
On British public television BBC we found photographs in which the four alleged members of the commando that attacked the Moscow shopping center are identified by name, including Dalerjon Mirzoev, who according to the messages would have been one of the terrorists who broke into the assault. .
The photographs taken by the EFE Agency in Moscow of the alleged terrorist during his appearance at a preliminary hearing in a court in the Russian capital two days after the attacks allow us to compare them with those of Azhiev.
In them it is clear that the hands of the accused, Dalerjon Mirzoev, have all his fingers, unlike all the images found of Rustam Azhiev in which he appears with the fingers amputated on his left hand.
Russian disinformation in Ukraine
This is the second time that Efe Verifica has investigated false messages that linked the Moscow attack on March 22 to the Government of Ukraine. A few days ago, the EFE verification unit published an investigation that denied that a van suspected of having been used by terrorists had a Ukrainian license plate.
In addition, a video manipulated with artificial intelligence (deepfake or deepfake) was broadcast on Russian television in which Ukraine's top security official, Oleksiy Danilov, admitted his country's participation in the Moscow attack. In reality, the video combined images recorded before the attack with a manipulated audio track and was discredited by the main media, which did not give it credibility.
This misinformation is framed in the context of the Russian invasion of Ukraine in 2022. Since then, social media users have shared dozens of images, supposedly real, that reflect how the conflict develops, although, in reality, in many cases they are of manipulated or decontextualized videos and photographs.
Therefore, it is not true that the Chehenonian Rustam Azhiev is one of those detained for his alleged participation in the Moscow attack. He is actually Dalerjon Mirzoev, who identified himself after his arrest as a citizen of Tajikistan.
Sources:
Google Search.
British public television BBC.
France24 television channel.
Information from EFE.
false_claim: One of the terrorists arrested for the Moscow attack is a Chechen commander who fought against Russia in Ukraine.

content:
Desmentimos las falsedades sobre la ola de calor en España
- Envíanos consultas al 659 800 555 o a verificartve@rtve.es
- Suscríbete a nuestros desmentidos por RSS y practica con la Caja básica de herramientas
La segunda ola de calor del verano, en la segunda y tercera semanas de julio, ha causado estragos en España. Hemos vivido una serie de incendios de gran magnitud en la Península y más de un millar de personas han fallecido en los primeros seis días de este fenómeno meteorológico. En VerificaRTVE desmentimos las falsedades, inexactitudes y bulos difundidos por Internet en estos días de máximas en los termómetros.
Es falso que las muertes por calor hayan subido un 13.250% en tres años
En redes hemos visto un mensaje que dice que las muertes por calor en España han aumentado “un 13.250%” en tres años. Es un bulo. El mensaje utiliza datos falsos de defunciones por exceso de temperatura. El mensaje en cuestión dice que en 2016 murieron en España siete personas por calor, el mismo número en 2017, nueve en 2019, 714 en junio de 2022 y “360 en 6 días de julio”. “¿Han aumentado los fallecidos por calor un 13.250% en sólo 3 años?”, expone el tuit, con más de 5.900 ‘me gusta’ y 3.400 retuits.
De acuerdo con el sistema de Monitorización de la Mortalidad Diaria (MoMo) del Instituto Carlos III de Madrid, en 2016 en España murieron por exceso de temperatura 1.937 personas (pág.18). Las defunciones por calor en 2017 fueron 2.406 y en 2019 la cifra fue de 1.409 fallecidos. El dato de 714 muertos por calor en junio es incorrecto. Aparece en este informe del MoMo pero solo muestra la situación hasta el 22 de junio (pág.2). La cifra actualizada de junio se eleva a 829 defunciones (pág.2). El dato de 360 muertos en seis días de julio que aporta el tuit es el único cierto. Corresponde al periodo del 10 al 15 de julio, como puedes ver en la siguiente tabla del Instituto Carlos III. Salvo este último registro, todos los datos que menciona el tuit son falsos, incluido el aumento del 13.250% de muertes por calor en tres años.
No existen registros de que en 1957 se alcanzaran los 50 grados en España
Mensajes de redes aseguran que España vivió en 1957 “el verano más caluroso del siglo”, alcanzando los 50 grados, y muestran la portada de un semanario de ese verano como prueba. Es falso. No hay registros que certifiquen que España alcanzara los 50 grados en 1957. La temperatura máxima avalada por la Agencia Estatal de Meteorología (AEMET) es de 47,4 grados.
Los mensajes muestran una portada del semanario ‘El Español’ que habla de “el verano más caluroso del siglo” y en páginas interiores refiere “temperaturas de 50 grados en algún lugar de la Mancha”. La portada es real pero la información publicada es incorrecta (aquí puedes ver varias páginas del ejemplar del 17 de agosto de 1957). La Agencia Estatal de Meteorología (AEMET) no tiene registros de que en España se hayan alcanzado los 50 grados de temperatura.
El récord histórico de temperatura es de 47,4 y se registró el 14 de agosto de 2021 en la localidad de Montoro (Córdoba). El portavoz de la AEMET, Rubén del Campo, confirmó el registro histórico en un mensaje publicado en Twitter. La AEMET insiste en su blog en que esto no significa que nunca se haya medido una temperatura superior en España, sino que “no se ha medido una temperatura superior en una estación sometida a los estándares y controles de calidad reconocidos internacionalmente”. Desde el equipo de El Tiempo de TVE nos aclaran que las estaciones meteorológicas “tienen que cumplir varias condiciones para tomarse como referencia”, como por ejemplo “que los instrumentos metereológicos estén ubicados en una garita pintada de blanco, que se encuentre bien ventilada, orientada al norte y alejada de árboles y edificios”. Además, insisten en que “una vez registrado un récord de temperatura este se verifica en los siguientes días para evitar errores como puede ser el recalentamiento de un termómetro o que la estación esté en malas condiciones”. En VerificaRTVE hemos comprobado que la imagen de la portada de ‘El Español’ se difunde por redes al menos desde 2021 con mensajes que buscan desinformar sobre el cambio climático. Por lo tanto, se trata de mensajes engañosos que niegan el calentamiento global bajo el contexto de la ola de calor que experimenta España.
Los mapas del tiempo no exageran los colores rojos durante las olas de calor
Cada vez que hay un episodio extremo en el mundo de la climatología vemos en redes mensajes que afirman que en los espacios del tiempo se modifican los colores con los que se pintan las temperaturas para exagerar la situación. Este es el caso del eurodiputado de Vox Hermann Tertsch: “La ridiculez de pintar España como una brasa porque haga calor no es inocente. Se trata de crear una alarma que lleve a la población a aceptarlo todo para combatir el supuesto fin del mundo que sugieren. Impuestos, intervención y servidumbre incondicional a la ingeniería social”. “Hartos de mentiras, calentólogas”, añade otro tuitero.
Hemos consultado sobre esta cuestión al responsable del área de meteorología de TVE, Albert Barniol. Él nos confirma que en los mapas del tiempo de Radiotelevisión Española los colores de las temperaturas se mantienen constantes a lo largo del año. Añade que “lo que sí cambia es la escala lateral de la horquilla de temperaturas” En verano aparecen las temperaturas más cálidas y en invierno las más frías. Lo puedes comprobar en varias capturas de El tiempo de TVE donde vemos que se mantiene la misma paleta de colores para las mismas temperaturas haga más calor o más fresco. Como puedes comprobar el rojo que equivale a 30 grados siempre es el mismo (Cículo negro) y cuando hay 22 grados siempre se pinta el mismo amarillo-verdoso (flecha naranja).
Manipulando con la comparación de dos mapas de distintas variables
Mensajes de redes muestran la imagen de un presentador ante dos mapas de España con datos de altas temperaturas y dos gamas de colores distintas. Los presentan como si ilustraran una misma variable. “Julio de 2017. Verano”, dice una anotación en el primer mapa. “Julio de 2022. Ola de calor por el cambio climático”, señala la referencia del segundo. “No me explico cómo puede haber negacionistas del “cambio cromático””, señala un tuit con más de 1.000 retuits que difunde la imagen de los mapas. “Manipulación?”, plantea otro mensaje con más de 6.000 retuits. La comparativa es un bulo. Los dos mapas ilustran dos variables distintas y, por tanto, no se pueden comparar.
El propio presentador del servicio de información meteorológica aludido ha desmentido la falsa comparativa difundida en Twitter. “Este tuit compara 2 mapas de distinta índole:(uno es de avisos y el otro es de temperatura)”, ha asegurado Roberto Brasero, de El Tiempo de Antena 3 Televisión. El primer mapa difundido en redes muestra los avisos meteorológicos adversos, con una gama de colores que va del verde al rojo. El segundo mapa ilustra las temperaturas máximas, con una escala que usa el naranja a partir de 30 grados y el rojo y colores más oscuros para valores superiores.
Translation:
We deny the falsehoods about the heat wave in Spain
- Send us inquiries to 659 800 555 or to verificationtve@rtve.es
- Subscribe to our RSS debunkings and practice with the Basic Toolkit
The second heat wave of the summer, in the second and third weeks of July, has wreaked havoc in Spain. We have experienced a series of large fires on the Peninsula and more than a thousand people have died in the first six days of this meteorological phenomenon. At VerificaRTVE we deny the falsehoods, inaccuracies and hoaxes spread on the Internet in these days of maximum thermometers.
It is false that heat deaths have increased by 13,250% in three years
On networks we have seen a message that says that deaths due to heat in Spain have increased “13,250%” in three years. It's a hoax. The message uses false data on deaths due to excess temperature. The message in question says that in 2016 seven people died in Spain due to heat, the same number in 2017, nine in 2019, 714 in June 2022 and “360 in 6 days in July.” “Have deaths from heat increased by 13,250% in just 3 years?” states the tweet, with more than 5,900 likes and 3,400 retweets.
According to the Daily Mortality Monitoring system (MoMo) of the Carlos III Institute of Madrid, in 2016 in Spain 1,937 people died due to excess temperature (page 18). Deaths due to heat in 2017 were 2,406 and in 2019 the figure was 1,409 deaths. The figure of 714 deaths due to heat in June is incorrect. It appears in this MoMo report but only shows the situation until June 22 (page 2). The updated figure for June rises to 829 deaths (page 2). The figure of 360 deaths in six days of July provided by the tweet is the only true one. It corresponds to the period from July 10 to 15, as you can see in the following table from the Carlos III Institute. Except for this last record, all the data mentioned in the tweet are false, including the 13,250% increase in heat deaths in three years.
There are no records that in 1957 50 degrees were reached in Spain
Network messages claim that Spain experienced “the hottest summer of the century” in 1957, reaching 50 degrees, and show the cover of a weekly newspaper from that summer as proof. It's false. There are no records that certify that Spain reached 50 degrees in 1957. The maximum temperature endorsed by the State Meteorological Agency (AEMET) is 47.4 degrees.
The messages show a cover of the weekly 'El Español' that talks about "the hottest summer of the century" and on the inside pages it refers to "temperatures of 50 degrees somewhere in La Mancha." The cover is real but the information published is incorrect (here you can see several pages from the August 17, 1957 issue). The State Meteorological Agency (AEMET) has no records that temperatures of 50 degrees have been reached in Spain.
The historical temperature record is 47.4 and was recorded on August 14, 2021 in the town of Montoro (Córdoba). The AEMET spokesperson, Rubén del Campo, confirmed the historical record in a message published on Twitter. The AEMET insists in its blog that this does not mean that a higher temperature has never been measured in Spain, but rather that "a higher temperature has not been measured in a station subject to internationally recognized standards and quality controls." The El Tiempo de TVE team clarifies that meteorological stations “have to meet several conditions to be used as a reference”, such as “that the meteorological instruments are located in a sentry box painted white, that is well ventilated, oriented to the north and away from trees and buildings.” Furthermore, they insist that "once a temperature record is recorded, it is verified in the following days to avoid errors such as a thermometer overheating or the station being in poor condition." At VerificaRTVE we have verified that the image of the cover of 'El Español' has been spread through networks at least since 2021 with messages that seek to misinform about climate change. Therefore, these are misleading messages that deny global warming in the context of the heat wave that Spain is experiencing.
Weather maps don't exaggerate red colors during heat waves
Every time there is an extreme episode in the world of climatology we see messages on social networks that claim that in the spaces of time the colors with which temperatures are painted are modified to exaggerate the situation. This is the case of Vox MEP Hermann Tertsch: “The ridiculousness of painting Spain as an ember because it is hot is not innocent. It is about creating an alarm that leads the population to accept everything to combat the supposed end of the world that they suggest. Taxes, intervention and unconditional servitude to social engineering.” “Fed up with lies, heatologists,” adds another tweeter.
We have consulted the head of TVE's meteorology area, Albert Barniol, on this issue. He confirms that in the Spanish Radiotelevision weather maps the colors of the temperatures remain constant throughout the year. He adds that “what does change is the lateral scale of the temperature range.” In summer the warmest temperatures appear and in winter the coldest. You can see this in several screenshots from TVE's El tiempo where we see that the same color palette is maintained for the same temperatures, whether hotter or cooler. As you can see, the red that is equivalent to 30 degrees is always the same (black circle) and when there are 22 degrees the same yellow-green is always painted (orange arrow).
Manipulating with the comparison of two maps of different variables
Network messages show the image of a presenter in front of two maps of Spain with high temperature data and two different color ranges. They present them as if they illustrate the same variable. “July 2017. Summer,” says a notation on the first map. “July 2022. Heat wave due to climate change,” says the reference of the second. “I don't understand how there can be deniers of the “chromatic change”,” says a tweet with more than 1,000 retweets that spreads the image of the maps. “Manipulation?”, raises another message with more than 6,000 retweets. The comparison is a hoax. The two maps illustrate two different variables and therefore cannot be compared.
The presenter of the aforementioned meteorological information service has denied the false comparison spread on Twitter. “This tweet compares 2 maps of different types: (one is for warnings and the other is for temperature),” said Roberto Brasero, from El Tiempo on Antena 3 Television. The first map disseminated on networks shows adverse weather warnings, with a range of colors that goes from green to red. The second map illustrates the maximum temperatures, with a scale that uses orange from 30 degrees and red and darker colors for higher values.
false_claim: Weather maps are being manipulated to exaggerate climate change.

content:
Obalamy fałszywe informacje pojawiające się w mediach społecznościowych oraz na portalach internetowych. Odwołując się do wiarygodnych źródeł, weryfikujemy najbardziej szkodliwe przykłady dezinformacji.
Directed Energy Weapon podpaliła wyspę na Hawajach? Fałsz
Wokół katastrofy tworzą się kolejne teorie spiskowe.
fot. James Wheeler / Pexels / Modyfikacje: Demagog
Directed Energy Weapon podpaliła wyspę na Hawajach? Fałsz
Wokół katastrofy tworzą się kolejne teorie spiskowe.
Fake news w pigułce
W związku z pożarem na wyspie Maui w mediach społecznościowych pojawiają się kolejne teorie spiskowe. Popularność zyskują tezy (1, 2, 3, 4) o tym, że podpalono ją przy pomocy Directed Energy Weapon (DEW), którą w postach nazywa się „bezpośrednią bronią energetyczną”, choć zapewne chodzi o broń o energii skierowanej. Dowodem na to ma być np. to, że „spaliły się domy, a drzew już ogień nie ruszył” (czas nagrania 1:34). Nagrania i zdjęcia rzekomo przedstawiają moment użycia tej broni na Hawajach.
W jednym z filmów spekuluje się, że motywacją do podpalenia wyspy miała być chęć utworzenia „pierwszej inteligentnej wyspy, zarządzanej przez sztuczną inteligencję” (czas nagrania 1:35). Podano też, że w historycznym mieście i byłej stolicy Królestwa Hawajów Lahainie planowano wybudować kompleksy biznesowe, na co nie chcieli się zgodzić rdzenni mieszkańcy wyspy (czas nagrania 2:15).
Posty (1, 2, 3, 4) zyskały spore zasięgi: jeden z nich udostępniło ponad 1,2 tys. użytkowników i skomentowano go ponad 200 razy.
Jakie są przyczyny pożarów na wyspie Maui? Nie ma dowodów, że to działanie celowe
Krótko po wybuchu pożarów na hawajskiej wyspie Maui w sierpniu 2023 roku w internecie pojawiły się doniesienia, jakoby podpalono ją celowo. W jednym z omawianych przez nas filmów wysunięto tezę, że stało się tak, by stworzyć infrastrukturę dla „pierwszej inteligentnej wyspy, zarządzanej przez sztuczną inteligencję” (czas nagrania 1:35). Motywacją miało być też wybudowanie w Lahainie, byłej hawajskiej stolicy, kompleksów biznesowych, na co nie chcieli się zgodzić rdzenni mieszkańcy wyspy (czas nagrania 2:15).
Bezpośrednia przyczyna pożarów nadal jest przedmiotem dochodzenia. Jak donosi „The Washington Post”, istnieją dowody, które wskazują, że przyczyną może być uszkodzona przez wiatr infrastruktura zakładu energetycznego Hawaiian Electric. Hipoteza mówi, że iskry ze słupów i linii energetycznych miały spadać na suche rośliny i rozniecić ogień.
Eksperci podkreślają, że do skali i dotkliwości żywiołu przyczyniło się kilka ważnych czynników, m.in. pogoda, bardzo mocne wiatry i występowanie łatwopalnych nierodzimych traw na obszarach dawnych pól uprawnych i lasów.
Doniesienia o celowym podpaleniu wyspy skomentował Gubernator Hawajów Josh Green, który w oświadczeniu przesłanym dla prasy powiedział: „Nie ma prawdy w straszliwym twierdzeniu, że pożary zostały celowo wzniecone, aby zrównać z ziemią historyczne miasto Lahaina, które było pierwszą stolicą Królestwa Hawajów”.
Plany przekształcenia Maui w „inteligentną wyspę” omawia się na konferencjach? Tematu nie ma w agendzie
Przedstawiona w jednym z filmów teoria o celowym podpaleniu opiera się na rzekomych planach przekształcenia Maui w „inteligentną wyspę”, rządzoną przez sztuczną inteligencję. Na czym swoje przekonanie opierają zwolennicy tej teorii? W nagraniu słyszymy: „Jest to opisane w cyfrowym szczycie rządowym Hawajów w 2023 roku, który planują zorganizować w przyszłym miesiącu – 25 września 2023 na Maui” (czas nagrania 1:35). Dodatkowo wspomniano w nim, że „w styczniu 2023 roku na Maui odbyła się konferencja Smart City, która miała na celu przekształcenie Maui w wyspę Smart City, wprowadzając wszystko elektroniczne […]” (czas nagrania 2:01).
Jak donosi redakcja AP, Hawaii International Conference on System Sciences (HICSS) to konferencja informatyczna. W tym roku odbyła się jej 56. edycja. Zgłoszono na nią prawie 1,5 tys. artykułów naukowych z różnych zagadnień, a kilka z nich dotyczyło koncepcji inteligentnych miast, ale żadna nie dotyczyła wyłącznie Maui.
Podobnie jest ze szczytem Hawaii Digital Government Summit (który nie odbędzie się na Maui). Agenda dostępna jest na stronie. Pośród wielu wystąpień nie znajdziemy takiego, które ma omówić zamianę jakiegokolwiek miejsca w „inteligentną wyspę” czy w „inteligentne miasto”, zarządzane sztuczną inteligencją.
Na stronie znajdziemy też komentarz organizatorów w tej sprawie. Jednoznacznie określają te doniesienia jako fałszywe:
„Uwaga: w mediach społecznościowych krążyły posty wprowadzające w błąd, w których fałszywie się twierdzi, że Hawaii Digital Government Summit, który odbywa się co roku w Honolulu, ma na celu przekształcenie Maui w pierwszą inteligentną wyspę. Twierdzenia te są błędne i nie pokrywają się z corocznym celem szczytu”.
Czy broń DEW istnieje? Tak, ale to nie dowód, że użyto ją na Maui
Według innej teorii przyczyną pożarów na hawajskiej wyspie Maui jest celowe podpalenie przy pomocy tzw. Directed Energy Weapons (DEW). Odwołują się do nich posty omawiane przez nas w tym artykule (1, 2, 3, 4). Nie ma żadnych wiarygodnych dowodów na potwierdzenie tezy, że pożar został wywołany przy użyciu tej broni.
DEW, czyli directed energy weapons, istnieje i jest rozwijana od dziesięcioleci. Nad takim typem broni pracują m.in. Stany Zjednoczone. Wykorzystuje ona „skoncentrowaną energię elektromagnetyczną”, „lasery wysokoenergetyczne i inne urządzenia elektromagnetyczne dużej mocy, takie jak fale milimetrowe i mikrofale dużej mocy”. Jej istnienie nie jest dowodem na to, że została użyta na Hawajach, aby zrównać z ziemią miejsce historyczne i wybudować w tym miejscu kompleksy biznesowe.
Fact-checkerzy z serwisu PolitiFact przeanalizowali informacje o rzekomym użyciu broni na Hawajach. Po przeprowadzonych konsultacjach z ekspertami, m.in. z adiunktem nauk atmosferycznych na Uniwersytecie Howarda Josephem Wilkinsem czy z przewodniczącym wydziału inżynierii ochrony przeciwpożarowej na Uniwersytecie Maryland Arnaudem Trouvé, stwierdzono, że doniesienia te są nieprawdziwe. Nie ma żadnych dowodów mogących potwierdzić teorię o laserach powodujących pożary.
Skoro to nie DEW, to co widzimy na załączonych filmach?
Dowodem na potwierdzenie teorii o tym, że przyczyną pożarów na Maui było DEW, mają być liczne filmiki i zdjęcia rzekomo przedstawiające to wydarzenie (1, 2, 3, 4). W mediach społecznościowych pojawiło się ich sporo, a część była sprawdzona przez wiele redakcji. Okazało się, że część z nich była wykorzystywana w ubiegłych latach do szerzenia fałszywych treści na temat innych pożarów.
Zdjęcia opublikowane w poście (część z nich pojawiła się również w filmach: czas nagrania 1:30 lub 0:14) nie zostały zrobione w ostatnim czasie na Maui. Jedno pochodzi ze Stanów Zjednoczonych, z Canton Township w stanie Ohio, a zrobiono je w 2018 roku i przedstawia rafinerię ropy naftowej.
Drugie pojawiło się w sieci w 2018 roku i widzimy na nim start rakiety SpaceX. Trzecią fotografię w 2018 roku opublikowała na swoim profilu Służba Leśna Klamath National Forest i przedstawia pożar w Kalifornii. Kwestię smugi wyjaśniono w innej wiadomości: to odblask obiektywu aparatu.
Good Morning. Here is a photo of the Noland Fire, discovered earlier this morning near Carter Summit on the Salmon/Scott Ranger District. Fire suppression resources are currently walking in to this incident. pic.twitter.com/KN77eJkPK0
— Klamath NF (@Klamath_NF) May 24, 2018
W filmach (1, 2, 3) również użyto kilku powyższych zdjęć oraz innych materiałów, które nie mają związku z pożarami na Maui.
- W jednym z filmów (czas nagrania 1:55) pojawia się nagranie wybuchu transformatora w Chile, spowodowanego silnym wiatrem.
- W innym pokazano materiał wideo z 2018 roku, na którym widzimy eksplozje elektryczne w Kenner, w stanie Luizjana, o czym donosi m.in. WWL-TV.
Incredible video captures several electrical explosions in Kenner this morning. Thousands of people are without power. https://t.co/2ODl383ZUR pic.twitter.com/k7QVoSjres
— WWL-TV (@WWLTV) December 27, 2018
Dlaczego drzewa stoją, a auta są spalone?
Dowodem na to, że przyczyną pożarów jest DEW, ma być materiał wideo, na którym widać, że spalone są wyłącznie budynki, a drzewa – nie (czas nagrania 1:40). Chwilę później, w tym samym nagraniu, pokazano już obrazy, w na których widać już spalone drzewa, ale nie skomentowano tego. Materiały opublikowane w mediach pokazują, że na Maui spłonęło wiele drzew.
Inż. Erica C. Fischer z Oregon State University powiedziała redakcji Full Fact, że w pogorzelisku mogą ostać się drzewa, po części dlatego, że zawierają wodę, która zabezpiecza je przed całkowitym spaleniem.
W innym nagraniu podano temperatury topnienia stali, aluminium i drewna (czas nagrania 0:30), co ma być dowodem na użycie broni DEW. W innych materiałach pojawiały się teorie, że pożary nie mogą osiągnąć temperatury, która topi szkło czy aluminium, dlatego rzekomo bardziej prawdopodobne jest użycie potężnego lasera. W obu przypadkach to fałszywe założenie: takie pożary nie wymagają wcale DEW, by osiągać temperaturę do 1 200 stopni Celsjusza, która jest w stanie stopić aluminium i wiele innych metali.
*Jeśli znajdziesz błąd, zaznacz go i wciśnij Ctrl + Enter
Translation:
We debunk false information appearing on social media and websites. By referring to reliable sources, we verify the most harmful examples of disinformation.
Directed Energy Weapon set fire to an island in Hawaii? Falsehood
More conspiracy theories are emerging around the disaster.
photo: James Wheeler / Pexels / Modifications: Demagogue
Directed Energy Weapon set fire to an island in Hawaii? Falsehood
More conspiracy theories are emerging around the disaster.
Fake news in a nutshell
Due to the fire on the island of Maui, more conspiracy theories are appearing on social media. Theses (1, 2, 3, 4) are gaining popularity that it was set on fire using a Directed Energy Weapon (DEW), which in the posts is called a "direct energy weapon", although it is probably a directed energy weapon. The proof of this is, for example, the fact that "the houses burned down, but the fire did not burn the trees" (recording time 1:34). The videos and photos allegedly show the moment the weapon was used in Hawaii.
In one of the videos, it is speculated that the motivation for setting the island on fire was the desire to create "the first intelligent island, managed by artificial intelligence" (recording time 1:35). It was also reported that there were plans to build business complexes in the historic city and former capital of the Kingdom of Hawaii, Lahaina, which the indigenous inhabitants of the island did not want to agree to (recording time 2:15).
Posts (1, 2, 3, 4) gained considerable reach: one of them was shared by over 1.2 thousand people. users and commented on it over 200 times.
What are the causes of fires on the island of Maui? There is no evidence that this was intentional
Shortly after the fires broke out on the Hawaiian island of Maui in August 2023, reports appeared on the Internet that it had been set on fire on purpose. In one of the videos we discussed, it was put forward that this was done to create infrastructure for "the first intelligent island, managed by artificial intelligence" (recording time 1:35). The motivation was also supposed to be the construction of business complexes in Lahaina, the former capital of Hawaii, which the indigenous inhabitants of the island did not want to agree to (recording time 2:15).
The immediate cause of the fires is still under investigation. As reported by The Washington Post, there is evidence that the cause may be wind-damaged infrastructure at Hawaiian Electric. The hypothesis is that sparks from poles and power lines were supposed to fall on dry plants and start a fire.
Experts emphasize that several important factors contributed to the scale and severity of the disaster, including: weather, very strong winds and the presence of flammable non-native grasses in areas of former farmland and forests.
Hawaii Governor Josh Green commented on the reports that the island was intentionally set on fire, saying in a statement sent to the press: "There is no truth in the terrible claim that the fires were deliberately started to raze the historic city of Lahaina, which was the first capital of the Kingdom of Hawaii."
Plans to transform Maui into a "smart island" discussed at conferences? The topic is not on the agenda
The theory of deliberate arson presented in one of the films is based on alleged plans to transform Maui into a "smart island" ruled by artificial intelligence. What do the supporters of this theory base their beliefs on? In the recording we can hear: "This is described in the 2023 Hawaii Digital Summit that they plan to host next month - September 25, 2023 on Maui" (recording time 1:35). Additionally, it mentioned that "in January 2023, a Smart City conference was held on Maui, which aimed to transform Maui into a Smart City island by making everything electronic [...]" (recording time 2:01).
As reported by AP, the Hawaii International Conference on System Sciences (HICSS) is an IT conference. This year was its 56th edition. Almost 1.5 thousand applications were submitted. research articles on a variety of topics, and several of them focused on the concept of smart cities, but none were specific to Maui.
The same applies to the Hawaii Digital Government Summit (which will not take place on Maui). The agenda is available on the website. Among the many speeches, we will not find one that discusses turning any place into a "smart island" or a "smart city" managed by artificial intelligence.
The website also contains the organizers' comments on this matter. They clearly label these reports as false:
“Note: Misleading posts have circulated on social media falsely claiming that the Hawaii Digital Government Summit, held annually in Honolulu, is intended to transform Maui into the first smart island. These claims are false and do not align with the annual purpose of the summit.”
Do DEW weapons exist? Yes, but that doesn't prove it was used on Maui
According to another theory, the cause of the fires on the Hawaiian island of Maui is deliberate arson using the so-called Directed Energy Weapons (DEW). They are referenced in the posts we discuss in this article (1, 2, 3, 4). There is no credible evidence to support the claim that the fire was started using this weapon.
DEW, or directed energy weapons, has existed and been developed for decades. They are working on this type of weapon, among others: United States. It uses "concentrated electromagnetic energy", "high-energy lasers and other high-power electromagnetic devices such as millimeter waves and high-power microwaves". Its existence is not proof that it was used in Hawaii to raze a historic site and build business complexes there.
Fact-checkers from the PolitiFact website analyzed information about the alleged use of weapons in Hawaii. After consultations with experts, including: Joseph Wilkins, assistant professor of atmospheric sciences at Howard University, and Arnaud Trouvé, chairman of the department of fire protection engineering at the University of Maryland, found these reports to be untrue. There is no evidence to support the theory of lasers causing fires.
If it's not DEW, what do we see in the attached videos?
Evidence to confirm the theory that DEW was the cause of the fires on Maui is provided by numerous videos and photos allegedly showing this event (1, 2, 3, 4). A lot of them appeared on social media, and some of them were checked by many editorial offices. It turned out that some of them had been used in previous years to spread false information about other fires.
The photos published in the post (some of them also appeared in the videos: recording time 1:30 or 0:14) were not taken recently on Maui. One comes from the United States, from Canton Township, Ohio, and was taken in 2018 and shows an oil refinery.
The second one appeared on the Internet in 2018 and shows the launch of a SpaceX rocket. The third photo in 2018 was published on its profile by the Klamath National Forest Service and shows a fire in California. The streak issue was explained in another post: it's a camera lens flare.
Good Morning. Here is a photo of the Noland Fire, discovered earlier this morning near Carter Summit on the Salmon/Scott Ranger District. Fire suppression resources are currently walking in to this incident. pic.twitter.com/KN77eJkPK0
— Klamath NF (@Klamath_NF) May 24, 2018
Videos (1, 2, 3) also use several of the above photos and other materials that are unrelated to the Maui fires.
- In one of the videos (recording time 1:55) there is a recording of a transformer explosion in Chile, caused by strong winds.
- Another shows video footage from 2018 showing electrical explosions in Kenner, Louisiana, as reported by, among others, WWL-TV.
Incredible video captures several electrical explosions in Kenner this morning. Thousands of people are without power. https://t.co/2ODl383ZUR pic.twitter.com/k7QVoSjres
— WWL-TV (@WWLTV) December 27, 2018
Why are the trees standing and the cars burning?
The proof that the cause of the fires is DEW is the video material, which shows that only the buildings are burned, and not the trees (recording time 1:40). A moment later, in the same video, images were shown showing already burnt trees, but no comment was made. Materials published in the media show that many trees have burned on Maui.
Engineer Erica C. Fischer from Oregon State University told Full Fact that trees may survive in the fire, partly because they contain water, which protects them from burning completely.
Another recording shows the melting points of steel, aluminum and wood (recording time 0:30), which is supposed to be evidence of the use of DEW weapons. There have been theories elsewhere that fires cannot reach temperatures that melt glass or aluminum, so a powerful laser is allegedly more likely to be used. In both cases, this is a false assumption: such fires require no DEW at all to reach temperatures of up to 1,200 degrees Celsius, which can melt aluminum and many other metals.
*If you find an error, select it and press Ctrl + Enter
false_claim: Maui wildfires in Hawaii were caused by Directed Energy Weapons.

content:
FAKTIKONTROLL | Andmed ei näita radioaktiivsuse kasvu - väited tuumapommi kohta Ukrainas on valed
(52)Eesti sotsiaalmeedias läks möödunud nädalal ringlema info, et Ukrainas plahvatas tuumarelv ning hoiatati kasvava radiatsiooni eest. See ei vasta tõele.
Nädalatagused postitused näitavad videot plahvatusest Ukrainas ning väidavad, et peale seda tõusis Ukrainas kiirgustase. Järelikult on Ukrainal tuumapomm, mille venelased hävitasid, väidavad postitused. See sobib täpselt juba pikaaegse Kremli narratiiviga, et Ukraina on ohtlik riik, sest viimane taaskasvatab oma tuumajõudu, kuigi selle väite tõestuseks ühtegi fakti pole.
Ühe sellise postituse tegi Harry Raudvere, kes on avalikkusele tuntud Nõmme raadio omaniku ja endise Isamaa erakonna liikmena. Tähelepanu hakkas aga postitus koguma sellega, et kasutajad jagasid seda Nursipaluga seotud gruppi ning hirmutasid, et varsti-varsti algab tuumasõda.
Raudvere postitusel on tänaseks 117 jagamist ja 160 kommentaari. Kokku on postitust näinud pea 30 000 Facebooki kasutajat.
Mida väidetakse?
Postituses on video plahvatusest ning videol on ajatempel, mis näitab, et plahvatus toimus 13. mail. „Esimesed arglikud sammud tuumasõja suunas,“ kirjutas Raudvere ning lisas, et piirkonnas on radiatsioon oluliselt suurenenud. Põhjuseks see, et Venemaa lasi õhku Ukrainas oleva relvalao, mida ka postitusse lisatud video näitama peaks.
Kuidas on tegelikult?
Esmalt, ei ole tõendeid, et Ukrainal on tuumarelvi. Vastupidist on väitnud ja selle eest mitmetpidi hoiatanud Kremli-meelne meedia. Kõige populaarsemalt ka Vladimr Putin ise, kes hoiatas 2022. aasta 9. mai kõnes, kuidas Venemaa ei talu, et nende kõrval on Ukraina näol kasvav tuumajõud.
Raudvere postitatud video on tõepoolest venelaste põhjustatud rünnak Ukrainas, Hmelnõtski linnas. Piirkonna linnapea Oleksandr Simchyshyn kirjutas, et rünnakus on kannatada saanud õppeasutused, meditsiiniasutused, administratiivhooned, tööstusrajatised, mitmekorruselised hooned ja eramajad.
Valeinfo postituse väide on, et plahvatuse järel tõusis piirkonnas radioaktiivsuse tase. See aga ei vasta tõele.
Euroopa kiirgustaset on võimalik vaadata vastaval veebileheküljel. Selleks on Euroopa kiirgusandmete vahetusplatvorm (EURDEP), mis koosneb andmetest, mida 39 osalevat riiki reaalajas jagavad. Andmed pärinevad umbes 5000 jaamast üle Euroopa.
Vaadates Ida-Euroopat üldiselt, siis ei ole märgata kiirgustaseme märkimisväärset tõusu üheski piirkonnas:
Hmelnõtski linnas, kus plahvatus toimus, on ka oma seirejaam, mida samalt kaardilt uurida saab. See näitab, et perioodil 12. - 19. mai muutus radioaktiivsuse tase marginaalselt - tase kõikus 148 - 157 nSv/h vahel. Eesti Kiirgusseirebüroo juhataja Uko Randi sõnul võivad sellist muutust põhjustada ka sademed, mis toovad endaga atmosfäärist kaasa mitmeid looduses esinevaid radionukliide. „Nende tagajärjel võib maapinna lähistelt mõõdetav gammakiirguse tase kerkida lühiajaliselt mitmekordseks. Midagi ohtlikku selles ei ole,“ ütles ta.
„Millal siis ohtlikuks läheb? Ütleme, et see 150 nSv/h ja ka Narvas näiteks max 130 nSv/h ei ole midagi tähelepanuväärset,“ selgitas Rand.
„Võtame kasvõi Soomes asuva Hamina seirejaama: 250 nSv/h ja seda täiesti looduslikest põhjustest – peamiselt just nende graniitkivipaljandite tõttu (sisaldavad rohkelt erinevaid looduslikke radionukliide: K-40, U-238 ja Th-232 on lagunemisridadest pärinevad radionukliidid).“
Randi sõnul saaksime ohust rääkida siis, kui need numbrid (võtame näiteks väärtuseks 100 nSv/h) korrutada vähemalt 100-ga, erandlikes olukorras 1000 või isegi 10000-ga. „Oht ei ole alati number, vaid ohuolukorras mängib rolli ka ohus viibitud aeg ja teatud olukorras on aktsepteeritavad ka kõrgemad numbrid, kuid siis ollakse ohualas vähem aega,“ lisas ta. „Samal ajal arvutatakse aga kogunevat doosi. Doosikiirus tähendabki doosi kiirust ajas ehk kui korrutame doosikiiruse näiteks tundide ajaga, saame kogu keha doosi.“
Narratiivi võttis üle Kreml
19. mail kirjutas Kremli väljaanne TASS, kuidas Lääs on Ukrainale tarninud uraaniga lahingumoona, mille hävitamine on põhjustanud radioaktiivse pilve, mis triivib Euroopa poole. Nõnda ütles Venemaa julgeolekunõukogu sekretär Nikolai Patrušev reedel Sõktõvkaris toimunud konverentsil.
Tasnim News Agency kirjutas, et kõrgendatud radiokatiivsust on märgatud Poolas, kuhu Ukrainast tulnud „tuumapilv“ esmalt liikus. Sputnik kirjutas, et ohus on terve Euroopa, sest kiirguse tase on niivõrd kõrge. Mitte ühelegi neist väidetest ei ole faktilisi tõendeid ning seirejaamad ei ole tavapärasest kõrgemat radioaktiivsuse taset õhus fikseerinud.
Otsus: Vale. Numbrid näitavad, et radioaktiivsuse tase Ukrainas, selle ümbruses ning ka mujal Euroopas pole kasvanud. vastupidise alusel arvata, et Ukrainas plahvatas tuumarelv, on vale. Sel puhul oleks seirejaamades fikseeritud numbrid kordades suuremad.
Translation:
FACT CHECK | The data does not show an increase in radioactivity - claims about a nuclear bomb in Ukraine are false
(52) Information circulated on Estonian social media last week that a nuclear weapon had exploded in Ukraine and warnings were issued against increasing radiation. This is not true.
Posts from a week ago show a video of an explosion in Ukraine and claim that radiation levels in Ukraine increased after that. Consequently, Ukraine has a nuclear bomb that was destroyed by the Russians, the posts claim. This fits perfectly with the Kremlin's long-standing narrative that Ukraine is a dangerous country because it is rebuilding its nuclear power, even though there are no facts to support this claim.
One such post was made by Harry Raudvere, who is known to the public as the owner of Nõmme Radio and a former member of the Isamaa political party. However, the post started to gain attention when users shared this group related to Nursipalu and threatened that a nuclear war would start very soon.
Raudvere's post has 117 shares and 160 comments to date. In total, almost 30,000 Facebook users have seen the post.
What is claimed?
The post includes a video of the explosion, and the video has a time stamp indicating that the explosion took place on May 13. "The first timid steps towards a nuclear war," wrote Raudvere and added that radiation has increased significantly in the region. The reason is that Russia blew up a weapons depot in Ukraine, which the video attached to the post should also show.
How is it really?
First, there is no evidence that Ukraine has nuclear weapons. The pro-Kremlin media has claimed the opposite and warned against it in many ways. Most popularly, Vladimr Putin himself, who warned in a speech on May 9, 2022, how Russia will not tolerate having a growing nuclear power in the form of Ukraine on their side.
The video posted by Raudvere is indeed an attack by Russians in the city of Khmelnytsk, Ukraine. Oleksandr Simchyshyn, the mayor of the region, wrote that educational institutions, medical institutions, administrative buildings, industrial facilities, multi-storey buildings and private houses were damaged in the attack.
The disinformation post claims that radioactivity levels in the area rose after the explosion. However, this is not true.
The European radiation level can be viewed on the corresponding website. This is done by the European Radiation Data Exchange Platform (EURDEP), which consists of data shared in real time by the 39 participating countries. The data comes from around 5,000 stations across Europe.
Looking at Eastern Europe in general, there is no noticeable increase in radiation levels in any region:
The city of Khmelnytsk, where the explosion took place, also has its own monitoring station, which can be explored on the same map. This shows that during the period 12 - 19 May, the level of radioactivity changed marginally - the level fluctuated between 148 - 157 nSv/h. According to Uko Randi, head of the Estonian Radiation Monitoring Bureau, such a change can also be caused by precipitation, which brings with it several naturally occurring radionuclides from the atmosphere. "As a result of them, the level of gamma radiation measured near the ground can increase several times in the short term. There is nothing dangerous about it," he said.
"So when does it become dangerous? Let's say that this 150 nSv/h and also the maximum 130 nSv/h in Narva, for example, is nothing remarkable," explained Rand.
"Let's even take the Hamina monitoring station in Finland: 250 nSv/h, and this is due to completely natural causes - mainly because of these granite rock outcrops (they contain a lot of different natural radionuclides: K-40, U-238 and Th-232 are radionuclides originating from decay lines)."
According to Rand, we could talk about the danger if these numbers (for example, let's take the value 100 nSv/h) are multiplied by at least 100, in exceptional cases by 1000 or even 10000. "Danger is not always a number, but in a dangerous situation, the time spent in danger also plays a role, and in certain situations higher numbers are also acceptable, but then there is less time in the danger area," he added. "At the same time, however, the cumulative dose is calculated. The dose rate means the dose rate in time, i.e. if we multiply the dose rate by hours, for example, we get the dose of the whole body."
The Kremlin took over the narrative
On May 19, the Kremlin publication TASS wrote how the West has supplied Ukraine with uranium munitions, the destruction of which has caused a radioactive cloud drifting toward Europe. This is what Nikolai Patrushev, the secretary of the Russian Security Council, said at a conference in Sõktivkari on Friday.
Tasnim News Agency wrote that increased radioactivity has been noticed in Poland, where the "nuclear cloud" from Ukraine first moved. Sputnik wrote that the whole of Europe is at risk because the level of radiation is so high. There is no factual evidence for any of these claims, and monitoring stations have not recorded higher than normal levels of radioactivity in the air.
Verdict: Wrong. The numbers show that the level of radioactivity in Ukraine, its surroundings and elsewhere in Europe has not increased. to believe on the contrary that a nuclear weapon exploded in Ukraine is wrong. In this case, the numbers fixed at the monitoring stations would be many times higher.
false_claim: A radioactive cloud is moving toward Western Europe after Russia struck a shipment of ammunition containing depleted uranium supplied by the UK to Ukraine.

content:
Questo video non mostra dei brogli elettorali in un seggio degli Stati Uniti
L’8 novembre 2022 è stato pubblicato su Facebook un video di 25 secondi che mostra la ripresa di una televisione in cui è trasmesso un programma di notizie; viene mostrato un uomo che, in un seggio elettorale, scrive su delle schede utilizzate per il voto. In sottofondo si sentono dei commenti in lingua inglese nei quali la persona che ha condiviso il filmato con la trasmissione televisiva chiede «cosa sta segnando?» e «Cosa sta facendo sfogliando le schede elettorali? Guarda la telecamera. Segna. Si guarda intorno. Che diavolo sta facendo?».
Il filmato è accompagnato da un commento, scritto da chi ha condiviso il post, che recita: «Elezioni USA: Al seggio c’è chi segna le schede elettorali pure in diretta TV».
Si tratta di un contenuto circolato senza il contesto necessario alla sua comprensione, che veicola una notizia falsa.
Il riferimento è alle elezioni di metà mandato che si sono tenute negli Stati Uniti l’8 novembre 2022. Dopo due anni da ogni elezione presidenziale, infatti, i cittadini statunitensi sono chiamati a eleggere i nuovi membri del Congresso, cioè l’organo legislativo del Governo federale del Paese. Queste elezioni sono considerate un’indicazione dell’operato del Presidente in carica.
La diretta tv del filmato oggetto della nostra analisi è autentica, ma non mostra un uomo mentre «fa affari loschi» con le schede elettorali. Si tratta di uno spezzone estratto da una trasmissione andata in onda l’8 novembre 2022 su Fox News (come si può verificare qui dal minuto 00:49) in cui la conduttrice Harris Faulkner annunciava l’inizio della giornata elettorale negli Stati Uniti.
Attraverso una ricerca inversa per immagini è stato possibile verificare che il video dell’uomo all’interno del seggio è stato girato nei Giardini botanici Olbrich, nella città di Madison, nel Wisconsin, che erano stati adibiti a sede elettorale.
Passiamo ora al contenuto del filmato che stiamo analizzando. Scott McDonell, cancelliere della contea di Dane, che comprende la città di Madison, il 9 novembre 2022 ha smentito su Twitter la notizia secondo cui l’uomo nel video sarebbe coinvolto in dei brogli elettorali. McDonell aveva specificato che quello che si vede nel video è un addetto alle urne che «sta facendo il noioso lavoro di routine di siglare le schede e cerchiare il numero della circoscrizione da consegnare agli elettori perché possano votare» e non si tratta di alcuno scandalo.
Secondo lo statuto del Wisconsin che regola le elezioni, infatti, durante questi eventi due ispettori sono incaricati di occuparsi delle schede nei seggi elettorali, scrivendo «le loro iniziali sul retro di ogni scheda» che verrà consegnata a tutti gli elettori quando entrano nella cabina elettorale e una «scheda elettorale correttamente vidimata da ciascuno di loro».
Contattato dai colleghi di Afp, McDonell ha condiviso un’immagine che mostra lo spazio in cui gli operatori elettorali devono apporre le loro iniziali, in cui è presente la formula «scheda rilasciata da».
Anche il cancelliere della città di Madison ha smentito la falsa notizia dei brogli precisando su Twitter che quello nel video è un ispettore elettorale previsto dallo statuto del Wisconsin.
Clicca qui per iscriverti alla newsletter gratuita di Facta
Ogni sabato mattina riceverai il meglio del nostro lavoro
Translation:
This video does not show voter fraud at a polling station in the United States
On November 8, 2022, a 25-second video showing footage of a television broadcasting a news program was posted on Facebook; a man is shown who, in a polling station, writes on cards used for voting. In the background we hear comments in English in which the person who shared the video with the television program asks "what are you marking?" and “What is he doing flipping through ballots? Look at the camera. Score. He looks around. What the hell is he doing?"
The video is accompanied by a comment, written by the person who shared the post, which reads: «US elections: At the polling station there are those who mark the ballot papers even live on TV».
This is content circulated without the context necessary for its understanding, which conveys false news.
The reference is to the mid-term elections which were held in the United States on 8 November 2022. In fact, after two years from each presidential election, US citizens are called to elect new members of Congress, i.e. the legislative body of Federal government of the country. These elections are considered an indication of the performance of the incumbent President.
The live TV footage of the video being analyzed is authentic, but it does not show a man "doing shady deals" with ballot papers. This is a clip taken from a broadcast aired on November 8, 2022 on Fox News (as can be seen here from minute 00:49) in which the host Harris Faulkner announced the start of election day in the United States.
Through a reverse image search it was possible to verify that the video of the man inside the polling station was shot in the Olbrich Botanical Gardens, in the city of Madison, Wisconsin, which had been used as an electoral headquarters.
Let's now move on to the content of the video we are analyzing. Scott McDonell, clerk of Dane County, which includes the city of Madison, on November 9, 2022 denied on Twitter the news that the man in the video was involved in election fraud. McDonell had specified that what you see in the video is a poll worker who "is doing the boring routine job of initialing the ballots and circling the precinct number to give to voters so they can vote" and there is no question of any scandal.
According to the Wisconsin statute that regulates elections, in fact, during these events two inspectors are responsible for handling the ballots at the polling stations, writing "their initials on the back of each ballot" which will be given to all voters when they enter the voting booth and a "ballot card correctly endorsed by each of them".
Contacted by AFP colleagues, McDonell shared an image showing the space where election workers must place their initials, which contains the formula "ballot issued by".
Even the chancellor of the city of Madison denied the false news of fraud, specifying on Twitter that the one in the video is an election inspector required by Wisconsin statute.
Click here to subscribe to Facta's free newsletter
Every Saturday morning you will receive the best of our work
false_claim: False information alleging electoral scams in the U.S. midterm elections.

content:
Nei, Russland angriper ikke amerikanske laboratorier i Ukraina
Påstand
Russland angriper amerikanske biolaboratorier i Ukraina.
Konklusjon
Dette stemmer ikke. Påstanden kan spores tilbake til en russisk desinformasjonskampanje fra 2018. USA driver ingen laboratorier i Ukraina, men har i årevis gitt Ukraina støtte til bygging og oppgradering av deres statlige laboratorier.
Putin ødelegger de sataniske bio-laboratoriene i Ukraina. Han ødelegger de underjordiske gjemmestedene, næringsvirksomheten, barnehandel-hiene og basene deres. Ikke tro på det Main Stream Media rapporterer. Putin sloss for friheten til den menneskelige rase.
Slik beskriver Facebook-brukeren Raphael Angel den russiske krigføringen i Ukraina. Et skjermbilde av Angels innlegg deles nå av nordmenn, og brukes til å legitimere Russlands angrep på Ukraina som en redningsaksjon for hele verden.
Påstanden spiller også på QAnon-bevegelsen, som tror at verden er styrt av djeveldyrkende barneovergripere. En vanlig konspirasjonsteori blant QAnon-tilhengere er at barn holdes fanget under jorda, hvor de misbrukes av en skjult elite.
Dette er QAnon i Norge
Flere varianter av samme påstand
Påstander om at amerikanske laboratorier er det egentlige målet for krigen i Ukraina, spres i flere ulike innlegg her til lands. To kart som skal vise henholdsvis hvor disse laboratoriene ligger, og hvor de russiske luftangrepene har truffet mål i Ukraina, har også blitt delt i Norge.
Faktisk.no har også sett kartet delt i denne versjonen og i denne versjonen. Her er budskapet at russerne bomber flyplasser eller militære installasjoner, noe som også skal omfatte de amerikanske laboratoriene.
Bak ligger en oppfatning om at det foregår produksjon av biologiske våpen i disse laboratoriene.
«Folk blir ledet til å tro at det er flyplassene og ikke deep state biovåpen labs som blir destruert. Der forsvant den neste planlagte pandemien som svt informerte skulle komme den 20. mars. Hvitvasking, korrupsjon og bankkontoer neste», skriver en av nordmennene som har kommentert.
«Tilsluttes. Det bombes ikke uten grunn…», skriver en annen norsk Facebook-bruker.
Slik vurderer du informasjon om krigen i Ukraina
Desinformasjon fra 2018
Stemmer det at USA har biolaboratorier i Ukraina, og at Russland angriper Ukraina for å ødelegge dem? Det korte svaret er nei.
Allerede i ukene før Russland invaderte nabolandet, begynte statskontrollerte russiske medier å spre desinformasjon om amerikanske laboratorier som produserte biologiske våpen. Dette er ikke noe nytt, og har ifølge medienettstedet Coda vært en del av en russisk desinformasjonskampanje siden 2018.
Allerede da ble det avdekket at russiske myndigheter spredte desinformasjon om USA-støttede laboratorier i Ukraina og Georgia. Laboratoriene produserte ikke biologiske våpen, slik statsstøttede russiske medier påsto. Tvert imot jobbet de med å oppdage og håndtere utbrudd av smittsomme sykdommer.
Ifølge nettstedet The Daily Beast fikk desinformasjonskampanjen en ny vår i 2021. Russland og Kina skal da ha gått sammen om å beskylde USA for å stå bak koronapandemien. De USA-støttede laboratoriene i Ukraina ble beskyldt for å ha en sentral rolle i spredningen av covid-19-viruset.
Russlands invasjon av Ukraina har gjenopplivet desinformasjonen nok en gang. Den siste tiden har påstander om de påståtte amerikanske laboratoriene i Ukraina blitt faktasjekket til feil av blant andre Politifact, USA Today og Snopes.
Russland sprer desinformasjon ved hjelp av store nettverk
USA bistår Ukraina
Det er altså ikke riktig at USA har biolaboratorier i Ukraina. Men de to landene har siden 2005 hatt en avtale om å forebygge spredning av teknologi, patogener og ekspertise som kan brukes i utviklingen av biologiske våpen i Ukraina.
