Den amerikanske ambassaden i landet kom i april 2020 med en lengre uttalelse om avtalen, som de kaller «Biologial threath reduction program». Der kommer det fram at avtalen har bidratt til bygging av to og oppgradering av flere laboratorier i Ukraina. Ingen av disse er imidlertid drevet av USA.
Avtalen med Ukraina er en del av det amerikanske forsvarsdepartementets «Cooperative Threat Reduction Program». Dette ble startet etter den kalde krigen, da flere av de tidligere sovjetstatene satt på kjemiske, biologiske og kjernefysiske våpen.
Målet var å sikre at disse ble håndtert på en trygg måte for verden i forbindelse med oppløsningen og etableringen av nye stater. Programmet har fortsatt fram til i dag, og tanken bak fra USA sin side er fortsatt å bistå andre nasjoner med å håndtere biologiske trusler. Dermed sikrer de også seg selv, ved at truslene ikke når USA eller deres allierte.
Translation:
No, Russia is not attacking US laboratories in Ukraine
Assertion
Russia attacks US biolabs in Ukraine.
Conclusion
This is not true. The claim can be traced back to a Russian disinformation campaign from 2018. The US does not operate any laboratories in Ukraine, but has for years provided Ukraine with support for the construction and upgrading of its state laboratories.
Putin destroys the satanic bio-laboratories in Ukraine. He destroys their underground hideouts, businesses, child trafficking dens and bases. Don't believe what the Main Stream Media reports. Putin fought for the freedom of the human race.
This is how Facebook user Raphael Angel describes the Russian warfare in Ukraine. A screenshot of Angel's post is now being shared by Norwegians, and is being used to legitimize Russia's attack on Ukraine as a rescue operation for the whole world.
The claim also plays on the QAnon movement, which believes the world is ruled by devil-worshiping child molesters. A common conspiracy theory among QAnon followers is that children are held captive underground, where they are abused by a hidden elite.
This is QAnon in Norway
Several variations of the same claim
Claims that American laboratories are the real target of the war in Ukraine are spread in several different posts in this country. Two maps which will show respectively where these laboratories are located, and where the Russian airstrikes have hit targets in Ukraine, have also been shared in Norway.
Faktisk.no has also seen the map divided in this version and in this version. Here the message is that the Russians are bombing airports or military installations, which should also include the American laboratories.
Behind it lies a perception that the production of biological weapons takes place in these laboratories.
"People are being led to believe that it is the airports and not the deep state bioweapons labs that are being destroyed. There, the next planned pandemic, which swt was informed would come on 20 March, disappeared. Money laundering, corruption and bank accounts next," writes one of the Norwegians who commented.
"Connecting. It is not bombed for no reason...," writes another Norwegian Facebook user.
This is how you rate information about the war in Ukraine
Disinformation from 2018
Is it true that the US has biolaboratories in Ukraine, and that Russia is attacking Ukraine to destroy them? The short answer is no.
Already in the weeks before Russia invaded the neighboring country, state-controlled Russian media began spreading disinformation about American laboratories producing biological weapons. This is nothing new and, according to the media website Coda, has been part of a Russian disinformation campaign since 2018.
Already then, it was revealed that Russian authorities were spreading disinformation about US-backed laboratories in Ukraine and Georgia. The laboratories did not produce biological weapons, as state-backed Russian media claimed. On the contrary, they worked to detect and deal with outbreaks of infectious diseases.
According to the website The Daily Beast, the disinformation campaign got a new spring in 2021. Russia and China will then have joined forces to accuse the United States of being behind the corona pandemic. The US-backed laboratories in Ukraine were accused of having a central role in the spread of the covid-19 virus.
Russia's invasion of Ukraine has revived disinformation once again. Recently, claims about the alleged US laboratories in Ukraine have been fact-checked to error by, among others, Politifact, USA Today and Snopes.
Russia spreads disinformation using large networks
The US is assisting Ukraine
It is therefore not true that the USA has biolaboratories in Ukraine. But the two countries have had an agreement since 2005 to prevent the spread of technology, pathogens and expertise that could be used in the development of biological weapons in Ukraine.
In April 2020, the US embassy in the country issued a longer statement about the agreement, which they call the "Biological threat reduction program". There it emerges that the agreement has contributed to the construction of two and the upgrading of several laboratories in Ukraine. However, none of these are operated by the United States.
The agreement with Ukraine is part of the US Department of Defense's "Cooperative Threat Reduction Program". This was started after the Cold War, when several of the former Soviet states were using chemical, biological and nuclear weapons.
The aim was to ensure that these were handled in a safe way for the world in connection with the dissolution and establishment of new states. The program has continued to this day, and the idea behind it from the US side is still to assist other nations in dealing with biological threats. In this way, they also secure themselves, in that the threats do not reach the United States or its allies.
false_claim: Ukraine hosts secret US bio-labs

content:
Obalamy fałszywe informacje pojawiające się w mediach społecznościowych oraz na portalach internetowych. Odwołując się do wiarygodnych źródeł, weryfikujemy najbardziej szkodliwe przykłady dezinformacji.
Zamach na Trumpa to „ustawka”? Brak dowodów na spisek
Teorie spiskowe na temat zamachu na Donalda Trumpa przybierają różne oblicza. Jedna z nich głosi, że zdarzenie to „ustawka”, a nawet, że polityk sam zaplanował atak, by wykorzystywać to w swojej kampanii.
fot. Pixabay i Facebook / Modyfikacje: Demagog
Zamach na Trumpa to „ustawka”? Brak dowodów na spisek
Teorie spiskowe na temat zamachu na Donalda Trumpa przybierają różne oblicza. Jedna z nich głosi, że zdarzenie to „ustawka”, a nawet, że polityk sam zaplanował atak, by wykorzystywać to w swojej kampanii.
Analiza w pigułce
- W mediach społecznościowych pojawiły się informacje o tym, że Donald Trump sam uknuł zamach (1, 2) w Butler w Pensylwanii. Jednym z powodów miała być próba zwiększenia poparcia w nadchodzących wyborach prezydenckich.
- Zdaniem amerykańskich służb odpowiedzialność za zdarzenie ponosi Thomas Matthew Crooks i obecnie nie ma argumentów, które świadczyłyby o tym, że działał on w większej grupie czy też w ramach skoordynowanej akcji.
- Nie ma podstaw do tego, by zakładać, że Donald Trump zaplanował zamach na samego siebie we współpracy z osobą z zewnątrz, by umocnić swoje poparcie. Wyniki badań sondażowych opublikowane przez „New York Times” na początku lipca wskazywały na to, że Donald Trump (49 proc.) ma poparcie większe o 6 punktów procentowych niż Joe Biden (43 proc.).
Na politycznym wiecu 13 lipca 2024 roku w Butler w Pensylwanii doszło do nieudanego zamachu na Donalda Trumpa. Zdarzenie wywołało chaos informacyjny, któremu towarzyszyły spekulacje, plotki, fałszywe informacje oraz teorie spiskowe (1, 2). Jedna z nich pojawiła się na Threads oraz na Facebooku, gdzie napisano, że wydarzenie to „ustawka”. Jak podano w facebookowym wpisie [pisownia oryginalna]: „będzie teraz męczennikiem, ma teraz swój »smoleńsk«” – co oznaczałoby, że kandydat sam zorganizował zdarzenie.
Na wpis na Facebooku zareagowało ponad 200 osób, a w sekcji komentarzy pojawiły się wypowiedzi osób, które popierały narrację spiskową. Jeden z użytkowników napisał [pisownia oryginalna]: Tak, stać go na wszystko. Inny podawał [pisownia oryginalna]: Popieram , tak to wyglada”.
Co wydarzyło się na wiecu Donalda Trumpa w Butler w Pensylwanii?
Po oficjalnym rozpoczęciu wiecu w Butler w Pensylwanii o godzinie 18:05 czasu lokalnego Donald Trump wszedł na scenę. Niedługo później – o 18:11 – w jego stronę padły strzały. Funkcjonariusze Secret Service wbiegli na scenę i osłonili Donalda Trumpa. Jedna z kul zraniła kandydata na prezydenta w ucho. Według informacji przekazanych przez władze zginął mężczyzna siedzący na widowni, a dwie inne osoby zostały ciężko ranne.
Organy ścigania rozpoczęły śledztwo, by wyjaśnić wszelkie szczegóły związane ze zdarzeniem, a władze USA oficjalnie potępiły atak na kandydata (1, 2). Prezydent Joe Biden w oświadczeniu z 13 lipca podał, że „w Ameryce nie ma miejsca na tego rodzaju przemoc. Musimy zjednoczyć się jako jeden naród, aby ją potępić”.
Czy Donald Trump i jego otoczenie uknuli zamach na wiecu w Butler?
Zdaniem służb odpowiedzialność za zdarzenie ponosi Thomas Matthew Crooks i nie ma argumentów, które świadczyłyby o tym, że działał on w większej grupie czy też w ramach skoordynowanej akcji. Obecnie nie są znane jego motywacje. Wiadomo, że miał 20 lat, pracował w domu opieki i był zarejestrowanym republikaninem (choć w 2021 roku przekazał też kwotę 15 dolarów na rzecz komitetu demokratów) oraz członkiem lokalnego klubu strzeleckiego.
Nie ma podstaw do tego, by zakładać, że Donald Trump zaplanował zamach na samego siebie we współpracy z osobą z zewnątrz, by umocnić swoje poparcie. Wyniki badań sondażowych opublikowane przez „New York Times” na początku lipca wskazywały na to, że Donald Trump (49 proc.) ma poparcie większe o 6 punktów procentowych niż Joe Biden (43 proc.). Redakcja zauważa, że w USA pogłębiają się też obawy związane z wpływem wieku Joe Bidena na stan jego zdrowia, który może wpłynąć na prezydenturę.
Teza o zaplanowaniu zamachu przez samego kandydata w obliczu dostępnych dowodów wydaje się nieprawdopodobna, ponieważ frekwencję i poparcie w wyborach można budować bez bezpośredniego narażania swojego zdrowia lub życia. Trudno też przewidzieć, jak zdarzenie przełoży się na rzeczywisty wynik w wyborach, które odbędą się dopiero 5 listopada 2024 roku. W dodatku nawet jeżeli w przyszłości polityk będzie wykorzystywał fakt zamachu w swojej kampanii politycznej, to nie świadczy to o związku przyczynowo-skutkowym między zaplanowaniem zamachu a planem na polepszenie wyniku w wyborach.
*Jeśli znajdziesz błąd, zaznacz go i wciśnij Ctrl + Enter
Translation:
We debunk false information appearing on social media and websites. By referring to reliable sources, we verify the most harmful examples of disinformation.
Is the attack on Trump a "set up"? No evidence of conspiracy
Conspiracy theories about the assassination of Donald Trump take many forms. One of them claims that the event was a "set up" and even that the politician planned the attack himself to use it in his campaign.
photo: Pixabay and Facebook / Modifications: Demagogue
Is the attack on Trump a "set up"? No evidence of conspiracy
Conspiracy theories about the assassination of Donald Trump take many forms. One of them claims that the event was a "set up" and even that the politician planned the attack himself to use it in his campaign.
Analysis in a nutshell
- Information appeared on social media that Donald Trump himself had plotted the attack (1, 2) in Butler, Pennsylvania. One of the reasons was to be an attempt to increase support in the upcoming presidential elections.
- According to the American services, Thomas Matthew Crooks is responsible for the incident and there are currently no arguments that would prove that he acted in a larger group or as part of a coordinated action.
- There are no grounds to assume that Donald Trump planned the attack on himself in cooperation with an outsider to strengthen his support. Poll results published by the New York Times in early July indicated that Donald Trump (49%) has 6 percentage points more support than Joe Biden (43%).
There was an unsuccessful attack on Donald Trump at a political rally on July 13, 2024 in Butler, Pennsylvania. The event caused information chaos, accompanied by speculations, rumors, false information and conspiracy theories (1, 2). One of them appeared on Threads and Facebook, where it was written that the event was a "set up". As stated in the Facebook post [original spelling]: "he will now be a martyr, he now has his own 'Smolensk'" - which would mean that the candidate organized the event himself.
More than 200 people reacted to the post on Facebook, and the comments section included statements from people who supported the conspiracy narrative. One user wrote [original spelling]: Yes, he can afford anything. Another said [original spelling]: I support it, that's what it looks like.
What happened at Donald Trump's rally in Butler, Pennsylvania?
After the official start of the rally in Butler, Pennsylvania at 6:05 p.m. local time, Donald Trump took the stage. Shortly later - at 6:11 p.m. - shots were fired at him. Secret Service officers ran onto the stage and protected Donald Trump. One of the bullets injured the presidential candidate in the ear. According to information provided by the authorities, a man sitting in the audience was killed and two other people were seriously injured.
Law enforcement authorities began an investigation to clarify all details related to the incident, and the US authorities officially condemned the attack on the candidate (1, 2). President Joe Biden said in a statement on July 13 that “this type of violence has no place in America. We must unite as one nation to condemn it.”
Did Donald Trump and his entourage plot an attack on the rally in Butler?
According to the services, Thomas Matthew Crooks was responsible for the incident and there are no arguments that he acted in a larger group or as part of a coordinated action. His motivations are currently unknown. It is known that he was 20 years old, worked in a nursing home and was a registered Republican (though he also donated $15 to the Democratic committee in 2021) and a member of a local gun club.
There is no reason to assume that Donald Trump planned the assassination attempt in cooperation with an outsider to strengthen his support. Poll results published by the New York Times in early July indicated that Donald Trump (49%) has 6 percentage points more support than Joe Biden (43%). The editors note that in the US there are also growing concerns about the impact of Joe Biden's age on his health, which may affect his presidency.
The thesis that the attack was planned by the candidate himself seems unlikely in the face of available evidence, because turnout and support in the elections can be built without directly endangering one's health or life. It is also difficult to predict how the event will translate into the actual result in the elections, which will take place only on November 5, 2024. In addition, even if in the future a politician uses the fact of the attack in his political campaign, this does not prove a cause-and-effect relationship between planning the attack and the plan to improve the election result.
*If you find an error, select it and press Ctrl + Enter
false_claim: The attack on Donald Trump in Pennsylvania was staged.

content:
Kalbėjo S.Berlusconi televizijoje
Ministras apie A.Hitlerio kilmę prabilo sekmadienį. Maždaug 40 min. trukmės interviu su juo transliavo konservatyvaus kanalo „Rete 4“ laida „Zona Bianca“ („Baltoji zona“). Visą laidą galima pamatyti paspaudus šią nuorodą.
Šis kanalas priklauso didžiausiai Italijoje privačiai TV kompanijai „Mediaset“, kurią įkūrė tuomet dar tik būsimasis politikas ir premjeras Silvio Berlusconi. Anksčiau garsėjęs gana draugiškais santykiais su Rusijos prezidentu Vladimiru Putinu, neseniai jis pasmerkė agresiją prieš Ukrainą.
Laidos vedėjo paklaustas, kaip Maskva gali siekti Ukrainos denacifikacijos, kai šios šalies prezidentas Volodymyras Zelenskis yra žydų kilmės, pašnekovas iš Maskvos atkirto: „Ir ką, jei V.Zelenskis yra žydas? Šis faktas nepaneigia nacistinių elementų Ukrainoje.
Galiu klysti, bet Hitleris taip pat turėjo žydiško kraujo. [Tai, kad V.Zelenskis yra žydų kilmės], visiškai nieko nereiškia. Išmintingi žydai sako, kad aršiausi antisemitai paprastai yra žydai. Kaip mes sakome, kiekviena šeima turi savo juodą avelę.“
Izraelio užsienio reikalų ministras Yairas Lapidas tokius komentarus pavadino „neatleistinais, skandalingais ir baisia istorine klaida“.
Holokausto muziejus „Yad Vashem“ savo ruožtu S.Lavrovo komentarus įvertino kaip „absurdiškus, klaidinančius, pavojingus ir smerktinus“.
Bandydama perrašyti istoriją, Maskva paprasčiausiai ieško argumentų masiniam ukrainiečių žudymui pateisinti.
Panašiai sureagavo ir Ukraina. Ukrainos užsienio reikalų ministro Dmytro Kulebos žodžiais, šios pastabos parodė „giliai įsišaknijusį Rusijos elito antisemitizmą“.
„Bandydama perrašyti istoriją, Maskva paprasčiausiai ieško argumentų masiniam ukrainiečių žudymui pateisinti“, – pakomentavo prezidento patarėjas Mychailo Podoliakas.
Izraelio premjero Naftalio Bennetto kanceliarija ketvirtadienį paskelbė, kad Rusijos prezidentas Vladimiras Putinas atsiprašė už ministro žodžius.
Mįslinga vėlyva motinystė
Antrasis pasaulinis karas, per kurį SSRS neteko maždaug 27 mln. žmonių ir padėjo nugalėti nacių Vokietiją, yra Rusijos nacionalinio identiteto šerdis. Istorinis šalies gelbėtojos nuo blogio jėgų naratyvas padeda Kremliui telkti rusų paramą karui.
O štai Izraeliui vienas svarbiausių nacionalinio etoso elementų yra Holokaustas. Šalis skelbia esanti pasaulio pastangų išsaugoti jo atminimą ir kovoti su antisemitizmu centre.
Todėl ir vienos, ir kitos šalies istorijoje nacių lyderiui A.Hitleriui tenka reikšmingas vaidmuo.
Kalbos, esą jis turėjęs žydų kraujo ir kaip tik todėl tariamai buvo apimtas antisemitizmo, netyla dešimtmečius. Šių menkai pagrįstų gandų šaltinis – nežinia, kas buvo A.Hitlerio senelis iš tėvo pusės. Atsakymą su savimi į kapus amžiams nusinešė jo senelė.
Būsimasis nacių lyderis gimė 1889 m. balandžio 20 d. Braunau am Inn mieste tuometėje Austrijos-Vengrijos imperijoje (dabar šis maždaug 17 tūkst. gyventojų turintis miestas yra Austrijoje prie sienos su Vokietija). Berniukas buvo ketvirtas iš šešių vaikų Aloiso Hitlerio ir jo trečios žmonos Klaros Pölzl šeimoje.
Archyvuose užfiksuota, kad ji atsisakė įvardyti vaiko tėvą, todėl kunigas kūdikį pakrikštijo kaip kataliką ir įregistravo Schicklgruberio pavarde.
Ne iki galo aiški vyresniojo A.Hitlerio kilmė paskatino kalbas, esą fiureris gali turėti žydų kraujo. Aloiso motina ir Adolfo senelė buvo neturtingo ūkininko dukra Maria Anna Schicklgruber. Kadangi buvo katalikė, visos žinios apie ją paremtos bažnyčios ir kitais viešaisiais įrašais.
1837 m., būdama 42-ejų, vis dar netekėjusi moteris susilaukė vienintelio vaiko Aloiso. Archyvuose užfiksuota, kad motina atsisakė įvardyti vaiko tėvą, todėl kunigas kūdikį pakrikštijo kaip kataliką ir įregistravo Schicklgruberio pavarde, o grafoje „tėvas“ nurodė „neteisėtas“. Istorikai mini tris galimus kandidatus į mažylio tėvus.
Vienas iš jų – keliaujantis malūnininkas Johannas Georgas Hiedleris. Vyras vedė jau 5-erių sulaukusio Aloiso mamą ir suteikė jam savo pavardę. Kaip tik šis vyras nacių buvo pripažįstamas kaip lyderio senelis.
Vaikas augo jo brolio ūkininko Johanno Nepomuko (kurio pavardė kartais buvo rašoma kaip Huettleris) šeimoje. Šis vyras, kuris mirdamas paliko globotiniui nemažą dalį savo santaupų, taip pat laikomas galimu Aloiso tėvu.
Sulaukęs 39-erių, pastarasis tapo „teisėtu vaiku“, o krikšto įrašuose tėvu buvo nurodytas jį įsivaikinęs J.N.Hiedleris. Kaip tik tuomet vyras pasikeitė pavardę į Hitleris, ją gavo ir Aloisas.
Tėvas – darbdavio žydo sūnus?
Trečias pretendentas į A.Hitlerio senelius – Leopoldas Frankenbergeris, kurio šeimoje M.A.Schicklgruber dirbo virėja. Apie šį žydą Niurnbergo tribunole užsiminė fiurerio advokatas, nacių okupuotos Lenkijos vyriausybės vadovas Hansas Frankas.
Pastarasis buvo nuteistas mirties bausme, egzekucija įvykdyta 1946 m. pabaigoje. Prieš mirtį vyras parašė memuarus, kurie buvo išleisti gerokai vėliau – tik 1956-aisiais – pavadinimu „Kartuvių akivaizdoje“ (vok. „Im Angesicht des Galgens“).
A.Hitlerio kilmę memuaruose nacis nagrinėjo išsamiau, bet jo tekstas laikomas nepatikimu. Spėjama, kad, jausdamas galą, H.Frankas norėjo atkreipti į save dėmesį arba galvojo, jog nebeturi, ką prarasti, todėl gali kalbėti bet ką.
H.Frankas tvirtino fiurerio protėviais domėjęsis jo paties prašymu, gautu 4-ojo dešimtmečio pabaigoje. Šis esą skundęsis, kad sūnėnas Williamas Patrickas dėl to jį šantažuojantis, net rodęs laišką su grasinimu atskleisti žydišką kilmę. Tiesa, jokio patvirtinimo, kad tokio šantažo būta, nėra.
Teisininkui tariamai pavyko sužinoti, kad A.Hitlerio senelė dirbo virėja pas pasiturinčius žydus Frankenbergerius, kurie tuo metu gyveno Graco mieste (Austrija). Darbdavys esą mokėjo už vaiko išlaikymą (tariamai iš baimės, kad nesulauktų teismo ir viešumo), kol Aloisui sukako 14 metų.
Tai esą patvirtino šios šeimos ir moters siųsti laiškai. Anot H.Franko kaip tik tuo metu ji pastojo, galimai nuo 19-mečio sūnaus Leopoldo (nors teigiama, kad iš tiesų tuomet berniukui tebuvo dešimt metų).
Istorikai šią teoriją (kuri tebuvo H.Franko spekuliacijos) atmeta kaip neturinčią pagrindo.
Kaip biografijoje „Hitleris 1889–1936 m.: Arogancija“ (angl. „Hitler 1889–1936: Hubris“) pažymėjo Jungtinės Karalystės istorikas Ianas Kershaw, Grace gyveno Frankenreiterių šeima, bet jie buvo ne žydai. „Nėra įrodymų, kad Maria Anna kada nors lankėsi Grace, jau nekalbant apie darbą mėsininkui Leopoldui Frankenreiteriui“, – rašė istorikas.
Grace tuo metu negyveno ne tik Frankenbergeriai, bet ir apskritai jokie žydai. Dar praėjusio amžiaus viduryje tai patvirtino austrų istorikas Nikolaus von Preradovichius. Šios tautos atstovams dar XVI a. buvo uždrausta gyventi Štirijoje, kurios sostinė yra Gracas, ir Aloiso gimimo metu šioje žemėje jie dar nebuvo laukiami.
2010 m. žiniasklaida rašė apie A.Hitlerio giminaičių seilių tyrimą. Išanalizavus šių žmonių DNR, nustatyta, kad jis galėjo būti žydų kilmės.
Beje, pats A.Hitleris, anot H.Franko, pasakojo, esą jo senelė su Aloiso tėvu buvo tokie neturtingi, kad nusprendė įtikinti žydų šeimą, esą virėja pastojo būtent nuo jų sūnaus. Taip pora tariamai užsitikrino tam tikras pajamas. Tačiau fiureris vargiai galėjo šią istoriją girdėti iš senelės, nes ji mirė iki gimstant anūkui.
Gandai plito nuo tarpukario
Tačiau viešumoje vis randasi šios teorijos apie A.Hitlerio protėvius patvirtinimų. 2010 m. žiniasklaida rašė apie 39 žinomų jo giminaičių seilių tyrimą. Išanalizavus šių žmonių DNR, nustatyta, kad jis galėjo būti žydų kilmės.
Mat ėminiuose buvo rasta chromosoma Haplogroup E1b1b1, kuri retai aptinkama Vakarų Europoje, bet kurią turi nemažai Maroko, Alžyro ir Tuniso berberų, taip pat – aškenaziai (viduramžiais abipus Reino slėnio gyvenę žydai) ir sefardai (viduramžiais Ispanijoje ir Portugalijoje gyvenę žydai bei jų palikuoniai).
2019 m. žydų psichologas, gydytojas dr. Leonardas Saxas paskelbė turintis informacijos, kad A.Hitlerio tėvo gimimo laiku Grace gyveno nedidelė žydų bendruomenė. Taip jis tvirtino analizėje, kuri buvo publikuota „Journal of European Studies“.
L.Saxas rėmėsi XIX a. gyvenusio Vienos tarybos nario Emanuelio Mendelio Baumgarteno teiginiais, kad 1856 m. jau buvo kalbama apie jo tautiečių bendruomenę Grace, vadinasi, žydai pradėjo ten kurtis anksčiau.
O minėtas N.von Preradovichius, anot kurio, mieste žydų negalėjo būti, simpatizavęs naciams, todėl esą įžeidimu laikė faktą, kad A.Hitleris buvo galėjo būti Vierteljude (vok. ketvirtadaliu žydas).
Tačiau net jei A.Hitlerio senelis tikrai buvo žydas, tai nieko nereiškė. Pagal tradicinį žydų įstatymą, tautybė paveldima per motinos liniją. Nėra duomenų, kad kuri nors moteris iš jo protėvių buvo žydė. Jei žydų tautybė buvo perduota per vyriškąją liniją, būtų reikėję atlikti ritualinį atsivertimą, o apie tokį informacijos taip pat nėra.
Beje, A.Hitleris išties buvo paprašęs SS patikrinti gandus apie jo kilmę. Šie žydiškumo pėdsakų neradę. Tuomet fiureris paprašė genealogo Rudolfo Koppensteinerio paskelbti didelį genealoginį medį, iš kurio būtų aiškūs jo protėviai.
Remiantis šiuo medžiu, 1937 m. buvo išleista knyga „Lyderio kilmės dokumentas“ („Die Ahnentafel des Führers“) ir padaryta išvada, kad A.Hitleris buvo austrų-vokiečių bei nesuteptos arijų kilmės.
To prireikė, nes jau nuo praėjusio amžiaus 3-iojo dešimtmečio Miuncheno kavinėse sklandė gandai, esą A.Hitlerio senelis buvo žydas. Kiek vėliau, kai jis perėmė Vokietijos kontrolę, tokios kalbos pagarsėjo. Žurnalistai ieškojo sensacingų istorijų apie nacių lyderį, tokias kalbas skatino ir politiniai oponentai.
Nepaisant sąmokslo teorijos apie fiurerio žydišką kilmę ilgaamžiškumo, ji yra menkai pagrįsta, todėl ir S.Lavrovo teiginius galima laikyti jos dalimi. Juoba kad Rusija turi ilgą stipraus antisemitizmo istoriją.
Išvedžiojimai, esą A.Hitleris buvo šios tautybės, yra antisemitinis įsitikinimas, kad dėl Holokausto buvo kalti ir patys žydai, kurių anuomet buvo nužudyta 6 mln. Taip bandoma sumenkinti tikrųjų žudikų atsakomybę.
Publikacija parengta 15min bendradarbiaujant su „Facebook“, kuria siekiama stabdyti klaidinančių naujienų plitimą socialiniame tinkle. Daugiau apie programą ir jos taisykles – čia.
Translation:
S. Berlusconi spoke on television
The minister spoke about A. Hitler's origin on Sunday. About 40 min. a long interview with him was broadcast by the "Zona Bianca" ("White Zone") program of the conservative Rete 4 channel. The entire show can be seen by clicking this link.
This channel belongs to the largest private TV company in Italy, Mediaset, which was founded by Silvio Berlusconi, the future politician and prime minister. Previously known for his rather friendly relations with Russian President Vladimir Putin, he recently condemned the aggression against Ukraine.
When asked by the host of the show, how Moscow can seek the denazification of Ukraine, when the president of this country, Volodymyr Zelensky, is of Jewish origin, the interviewer from Moscow retorted: "And what if V. Zelensky is a Jew?" This fact does not negate the Nazi elements in Ukraine.
I could be wrong, but Hitler also had Jewish blood. [The fact that V. Zelensky is of Jewish origin] means absolutely nothing. Wise Jews say that the most virulent anti-Semites are usually Jews. As we say, every family has its black sheep."
Israeli Foreign Minister Yair Lapid called such comments "unforgivable, scandalous and a terrible historical mistake."
The Yad Vashem Holocaust Museum, for its part, evaluated S. Lavrov's comments as "absurd, misleading, dangerous and reprehensible".
Trying to rewrite history, Moscow is simply looking for arguments to justify the mass killing of Ukrainians.
Ukraine reacted similarly. In the words of Ukraine's foreign minister, Dmytro Kuleba, these remarks showed "the deep-rooted anti-Semitism of the Russian elite."
"Trying to rewrite history, Moscow is simply looking for arguments to justify the mass killing of Ukrainians," commented presidential adviser Mychailo Podoliak.
The office of Israeli Prime Minister Naftali Bennett announced on Thursday that Russian President Vladimir Putin had apologized for the minister's words.
Mysterious late motherhood
World War II, during which the USSR lost approximately 27 million people and helped defeat Nazi Germany, is the core of Russian national identity. The historical narrative of the country's savior from evil forces helps the Kremlin mobilize Russian support for the war.
And for Israel, one of the most important elements of the national ethos is the Holocaust. The country claims to be at the center of global efforts to preserve his memory and fight anti-Semitism.
Therefore, the Nazi leader A. Hitler has a significant role in the history of both countries.
Rumors that he had Jewish blood and that is precisely why he was allegedly surrounded by anti-Semitism have been silent for decades. The source of these ill-founded rumors is that it is not known who A. Hitler's paternal grandfather was. His grandmother took the answer with her to the grave forever.
The future Nazi leader was born in 1889. April 20 Braunau am Inn in the then Austro-Hungarian Empire (now this city with approximately 17,000 inhabitants is located in Austria on the border with Germany). The boy was the fourth of six children in the family of Alois Hitler and his third wife Klara Pölzl.
Archives record that she refused to name the child's father, so a priest baptized the baby as a Catholic and registered it with the surname Schicklgruber.
The not entirely clear parentage of the elder A. Hitler led to rumors that the Führer might have Jewish blood. Alois' mother and Adolf's grandmother were Maria Anna Schicklgruber, the daughter of a poor farmer. Because she was Catholic, all information about her is based on church and other public records.
In 1837, at the age of 42, the still unmarried woman gave birth to her only child, Alois. Archives record that the mother refused to name the child's father, so the priest baptized the baby as a Catholic and registered it under the surname Schicklgruber, with the count "father" indicating "illegitimate". Historians mention three possible candidates for the baby's parents.
One of them is the traveling miller Johann Georg Hiedler. The man married the mother of 5-year-old Alois and gave him his last name. This man was recognized by the Nazis as the leader's grandfather.
The child grew up in the family of his brother, farmer Johann Nepomuk (whose surname was sometimes written as Huettler). This man, who left a significant portion of his savings to his ward when he died, is also considered a possible father of Alois.
At the age of 39, the latter became a "legitimate child", and in the baptism records, the father was indicated as J.N. Hiedler, who adopted him. Just then, the man changed his surname to Hitler, and Alois got it too.
The father is the son of a Jewish employer?
The third contender for A. Hitler's grandparents is Leopold Frankenberger, in whose family M. A. Schicklgruber worked as a cook. This Jew was mentioned at the Nuremberg Tribunal by the Führer's lawyer, Hans Frank, the head of the government of Nazi-occupied Poland.
The latter was sentenced to death and executed in 1946. at the end Before his death, the man wrote a memoir, which was published much later - only in 1956 - under the title "In front of the gallows" (German: "Im Angesicht des Galgens").
A. Hitler's origin was examined in more detail by the Nazis in his memoirs, but his text is considered unreliable. It is assumed that, sensing the end, H. Frank wanted to draw attention to himself or thought that he had nothing to lose, so he could say anything.
H. Frank claimed that he was interested in the Führer's ancestors at his own request, received at the end of the 1940s. The latter complained that his nephew William Patrick was blackmailing him for this, even showing a letter threatening to reveal his Jewish origin. True, there is no confirmation that such blackmail took place.
The lawyer allegedly managed to find out that A. Hitler's grandmother worked as a cook for the wealthy Frankenberger Jews, who lived in the city of Graz (Austria) at that time. The employer allegedly paid child support (allegedly out of fear of a lawsuit and publicity) until Alois was 14 years old.
This was confirmed by the letters sent by this family and the woman. According to H. Frank, it was at that time that she became pregnant, possibly with her 19-year-old son Leopold (although it is claimed that the boy was actually only ten years old at the time).
Historians reject this theory (which was only H. Frank's speculation) as baseless.
As British historian Ian Kershaw noted in his biography Hitler 1889-1936: Hubris, the Frankenreiter family lived in Grace, but they were not Jewish. "There is no evidence that Maria Anna ever visited Grace, let alone worked for the butcher Leopold Frankenreiter," the historian wrote.
Not only the Frankenbergers, but also no Jews in general lived in Grace at that time. This was confirmed by the Austrian historian Nikolaus von Preradovich in the middle of the last century. Representatives of this nation as early as the 16th century. were forbidden to live in Styria, whose capital is Graz, and at the time of Alois' birth they were not yet welcome in this land.
in 2010 The media wrote about the saliva test of A. Hitler's relatives. After analyzing the DNA of these people, it was found that he could be of Jewish origin.
By the way, A. Hitler himself, according to H. Frank, said that his grandmother and Alois's father were so poor that they decided to convince the Jewish family that the cook became pregnant with their son. In this way, the couple allegedly secured some income. However, the Führer could hardly hear this story from his grandmother, because she died before the grandson was born.
Rumors have been circulating since the interwar period
However, confirmations of this theory about A. Hitler's ancestors are still being found in public. in 2010 the media wrote about the examination of the saliva of 39 known relatives of his. After analyzing the DNA of these people, it was found that he could be of Jewish origin.
Because the chromosome Haplogroup E1b1b1 was found in the samples, which is rarely found in Western Europe, but which a number of Berbers in Morocco, Algeria and Tunisia have, as well as Ashkenazis (Jews who lived on both sides of the Rhine Valley in the Middle Ages) and Sephardim (Jews who lived in Spain and Portugal in the Middle Ages and their descendants). .
in 2019 Jewish psychologist, doctor dr. Leonard Sax announced that he had information that a small Jewish community lived in Graz at the time of Hitler's father's birth. This is what he claimed in an analysis published in the Journal of European Studies.
L. Saxas relied on the 19th century. according to the statements of Emanuel Mendels Baumgarten, a member of the Vienna council, that in 1856 the community of his compatriots in Grace has already been mentioned, which means that Jews began to settle there earlier.
And the aforementioned N. von Preradovichius, according to whom there could not be any Jews in the city, sympathized with the Nazis, so he considered it an insult that A. Hitler could have been a Vierteljude (a quarter Jew in German).
However, even if A. Hitler's grandfather was really Jewish, it did not mean anything. According to traditional Jewish law, nationality is inherited through the maternal line. There is no record that any of his female ancestors were Jewish. If Jewish nationality was transmitted through the male line, a ritual conversion would have been required, and there is no information about this either.
By the way, A. Hitler had really asked the SS to check the rumors about his origin. They found no traces of Jewishness. The Führer then asked the genealogist Rudolf Koppensteiner to publish a large genealogical tree that would clarify his ancestry.
Based on this tree, in 1937 the book "Leader's pedigree" ("Die Ahnentafel des Führers") was published and it was concluded that A. Hitler was of Austrian-German and pure Aryan origin.
This was necessary because since the 1930s there were rumors in Munich cafes that A. Hitler's grandfather was Jewish. Somewhat later, when he took control of Germany, such talk became famous. Journalists looked for sensational stories about the Nazi leader, and political opponents encouraged such talk.
Despite the longevity of the conspiracy theory about the Führer's Jewish origin, it is poorly founded, so S. Lavrov's statements can be considered part of it. Ironically, Russia has a long history of strong anti-Semitism.
The conclusion that A. Hitler was of this nationality is an anti-Semitic belief that the Jews themselves were to blame for the Holocaust, 6 million of whom were killed at that time. This is an attempt to diminish the responsibility of the real killers.
The publication was prepared by 15min in cooperation with Facebook, which aims to stop the spread of misleading news on the social network. More about the program and its rules - here.
false_claim: Hitler had Jewish origins, a claim made by Lavrov.

content:
As the war in Ukraine rumbles on but fades from dominating daily news headlines, disinformation topics have followed suit.
False content has started to diversify as news outlets have begun to refocus coverage back to other events.
Outlets are still reporting on the Ukrainian conflict but not as front page news as they did almost every day at the start of the invasion.
A school shooting in Uvalde, Texas which killed 19 primary school students and two teachers became a ubiquitous global story last week. It contained all the elements of a story which grab the world's attention - the tragic deaths of children, speculation over the suspect (who would do such a thing and why?), politics, and of course, a chance to revisit America’s gun policy debate.
Gun control and the US constitution is a divisive topic, making news since 1999 when the word Columbine became shorthand for a massacre and the phrase ‘school shooting’ entered the lexicon.
Disinformation loves a divisive topic in a news cycle.
A piece of false content has a better chance of going wider, faster if it contains certain words people are searching for, if details are still emerging and if people feel strong emotions about the event.
The Uvalde tragedy held all three elements and within minutes of initial reports of a shooting at a primary school, disinformation about the school shooter commenced circulating online, according to the BBC.
One in particular took hold. Posts on 4Chan (yes, the forum that started ‘Pizzagate’) claimed the shooter was a trans woman and soon photos of a trans woman with the shooter’s dark hair started spreading across other social media platforms.
‘Sam’, one of the women whose images were used, told NBC that her photos were taken from Reddit and Instagram. They were reposted countless times and labelled her as the killer, with some posts linking back to the 20-year-old's personal accounts.
It culminated with an Arizona Congressman tweeting that Uvalde’s shooter was “a transsexual leftist illegal alien named Salvatore Ramos.”
The tweet has since been deleted and Salvatore Ramos? Well, the shooter has been indentified as Salvador Ramos, a cis man born in America.
Rep Paul Grosar has not apologised for or explained his false accusations yet.
Another Congressman claimed in an interview that Ramos "wore dresses", while photos of another trans woman named Sabrina were superimposed into photo collages alongside a real photo of the actual gunman alongside false claims about her.
So far, fact-checkers have been unable to point to a source of the false theory outside the original 4Chan posts - meaning anonymous posts using someone’s stolen photos were likely to be only ‘evidence’ of a rumour accusing innocent people of murder, causing harm to a marginalised community and getting a US Congressman to spread false news.
|
Translation:

Gun control and the US constitution is a divisive topic, making news since 1999 when the word Columbine became shorthand for a massacre and the phrase ‘school shooting’ entered the lexicon.
Disinformation loves a divisive topic in a news cycle.
A piece of false content has a better chance of going wider, faster if it contains certain words people are searching for, if details are still emerging and if people feel strong emotions about the event.
The Uvalde tragedy held all three elements and within minutes of initial reports of a shooting at a primary school, disinformation about the school shooter commenced circulating online, according to the BBC.
One in particular took hold. Posts on 4Chan (yes, the forum that started ‘Pizzagate’) claimed the shooter was a trans woman and soon photos of a trans woman with the shooter’s dark hair started spreading across other social media platforms.
‘Sam’, one of the women whose images were used, told NBC that her photos were taken from Reddit and Instagram. They were reposted countless times and labelled her as the killer, with some posts linking back to the 20-year-old's personal accounts.
It culminated with an Arizona Congressman tweeting that Uvalde’s shooter was “a transsexual leftist illegal alien named Salvatore Ramos.”
The tweet has since been deleted and Salvatore Ramos? Well, the shooter has been indentified as Salvador Ramos, a cis man born in America.
Rep Paul Grosar has not apologised for or explained his false accusations yet.
Another Congressman claimed in an interview that Ramos "wore dresses", while photos of another trans woman named Sabrina were superimposed into photo collages alongside a real photo of the actual gunman alongside false claims about her.
So far, fact-checkers have been unable to point to a source of the false theory outside the original 4Chan posts - meaning anonymous posts using someone’s stolen photos were likely to be only ‘evidence’ of a rumour accusing innocent people of murder, causing harm to a marginalised community and getting a US Congressman to spread false news.
|
false_claim: The massacre in Uvalde, Texas, was carried out by a transgender woman.

content:
Des fermiers italiens mobilisés contre l'inflation ? Non, cette vidéo immortalise une fête dans le Piémont
- Cet article date de plus d'un an
- Publié le 10 août 2022 à 11:30
- Mis à jour le 12 août 2022 à 19:30
- Lecture : 8 min
- Par : Emilie BERAUD, Eva WACKENREUTHER, AFP France, AFP Autriche
Copyright AFP 2017-2024. Toute réutilisation commerciale du contenu est sujet à un abonnement. Cliquez ici pour en savoir plus.
Sur la vidéo relayée sur Facebook, des dizaines de tracteurs, gyrophares allumés et klaxons retentissant à l'unisson, stationnent les uns à côté des autres.
"Les fermiers italiens de la région du Piémont protestent contre l'inflation, les prix élevés du carburant, les engrais, les coûts de la vie élevés, les prix d'achat bas des produits... !!!", est-il affirmé dans la légende qui accompagne la publication, partagée près de 3.000 fois depuis le 30 juillet 2022.
"Belgique, puis Italie, la colère gagne et gronde...", peut-on lire parmi les quelque 238 commentaires qui appellent, pour la plupart, au "réveil" des Français et des Européens : "Bravo l'Italie ! Tous les Européens devraient en faire de même ! La solidarité des peuples s'avère nécessaire face aux profiteurs de crise qui nous broient !"
Cette publication, diffusée également en Roumanie ou en République Tchèque, suscite de vives réactions sur les réseaux sociaux à l'heure où le taux d'inflation dans la zone euro bat des records, atteignant 8,9% en juillet, sur un an.
L'Italie n'est pas épargnée par cette augmentation brutale du coût de la vie : le gouvernement italien a d'ailleurs adopté, jeudi 4 août, un nouveau paquet de mesures de 17 milliards d'euros destinées en grande partie à amortir le choc de la flambée des prix de l'énergie pour les ménages et entreprises.
Sur la vidéo publiée sur Facebook, un drapeau italien est bien identifiable, à la sixième seconde.
Cependant, d'après les recherches de l'AFP, ces véhicules étaient rassemblés à l'occasion d'une "fête de la bière et du tracteur" organisée dans une petite ville du Nord-Ouest de l'Italie, qui n'avait aucun lien avec une mobilisation contre l'inflation.
Des tracteurs rassemblés... à l'occasion d'une fête
Visionnée plus de 50.000 fois sur la page d'un groupe Facebook qui se fait le relai d'images de mobilisations populaires, la publication prétend dévoiler les images d'agriculteurs italiens, mobilisés en nombre contre la baisse du pouvoir d'achat.
Toutefois, une recherche par mots clés effectuée sur Google ne nous a pas permis de retrouver un tel événement décrit dans la presse italienne.
En revanche, le média en ligne Torino Oggi a publié un article, le 20 juillet 2022, titré de la manière suivante : "Villafranca Piemonte vise haut avec son Tractor Beer Fest". Dans le détail, l'article indique que l'objectif de cette première "fête de la bière et du tracteur" est de programmer "le plus grand rassemblement de tracteurs jamais organisé dans le Piémont", pour "souligner l'importance de l'agriculture" dans cette région du Nord-Ouest de l'Italie.
De nombreux festivaliers accompagnés de leurs tracteurs se sont donc rendus, le 23 juillet 2022, dans la petite ville de Villafranca Piemonte. Sur son site, la commune a effectivement communiqué autour de l'événement, et même partagé l'affiche qui lui est consacrée. Elle explique que la fête est organisée notamment par le "Pro loco" de la ville, une association touristique locale.
Après plusieurs posts annonçant le festival publiés sur sa page Facebook le 18 puis le 23 juillet 2022, cette association touristique a diffusé le 25 juillet une vidéo qui contient certaines des images que nous vérifions. Cette vidéo n'a pas de légende mais débute par un gros plan sur le t-shirt "Tractor Beer fest" d'un participant.
Contactée par l'AFP, la présidente de l'association touristique locale, Franca Alciato, a indiqué le 12 août 2022 que "la vidéo montre le festival de la bière et du tracteur et rien d'autre".
Nous avons comparé les images de la vidéo diffusée par l'association touristique, avec les six premières secondes de la vidéo diffusée sur Facebook, filmées en plan aérien : plusieurs éléments, identifiés ci-dessous, sont reconnaissables.
A partir de la sixième seconde, les images publiées sur Facebook ne sont plus filmées en plan aérien, mais au sol. Elles ne sont pas visibles dans la vidéo relayée par l'association italienne. Cependant, nous avons pu établir qu'elles ont également été prises lors du Tractor Beer Fest, le 23 juillet 2022.
En effet, nous avons retrouvé ces images sur Twitter : elles figurent en meilleure qualité dans une vidéo virale, publiée le 29 juillet 2022 et partagée plus de 3.000 fois sur le réseau social.
Sur ces images, un bâtiment rectangulaire de couleur claire est visible à la seizième secondes, en arrière-plan. Et sur l'affiche officielle du festival, mise en ligne sur le site de la ville Villafranca Piemonte, nous apprenons que le rendez-vous avait été donné au Prezzo Il Palazzetto Polivalente.
Cette salle polyvalente, que nous avons géolocalisée sur Google Maps, est le bâtiment rectangulaire et de couleur claire identifié sur la vidéo que nous vérifions.
Sur Google Street View, nous reconnaissons sa forme géographique, sa façade et les supports de sa toiture.
La partie de la vidéo filmée au sol partagée sur Facebook a donc bien été tournée sur le parking du Prezzo Il Palazzetto Polivalente.
Par ailleurs, à la dixième seconde de la vidéo en meilleur qualité diffusée sur Twitter on observe, de droite à gauche, un tracteur vert, un tracteur rouge et un tracteur bleu encadrés par deux lampadaires.
Sur la vidéo publiée par l'association italienne qui organisait l’événement, nous avons identifié ces trois mêmes tracteurs, à 2 minutes et 14 secondes. Ils sont visibles ci-dessous, cerclés de vert.
Le lampadaire visible sur la vidéo Twitter est également identifiable, encadré en bleu.
Enfin, la zone où sont garés les tracteurs est visible ci-dessous, encadrée en rouge :
Des versions plus longues de la vidéo circulent sur Facebook, comme par exemple ici. En plus des images nocturnes, elles comportent des images de tracteurs filmées de jour qui proviennent elles aussi de la vidéo du festival publiée par l'association touristique (à 0'33).
Des médias locaux ou des passants (comme ici) ont également publié des images du festival qui correspondent à celles publiées par l'association "Pro Loco".
A l'origine du détournement : une page Facebook serbe
Un logo (situé en haut à droite des images vidéo) ainsi qu'une inscription en alphabet latin serbe (en haut à gauche), nous ont par ailleurs mis sur la piste de l'origine du détournement d'images.
Une recherche par mots-clés sur Google nous a ainsi permis de retrouver la page Facebook à l'origine de la manipulation, basée dans la capitale de la Serbie, Belgrade.
Elle se présente comme un "magazine politique" et publie de nombreuses vidéos de manifestations et de mobilisations populaires, en y accolant leur logo ou des inscriptions.
Des manifestations d'agriculteurs dans le Sud de l'Italie
Des manifestations d'agriculteurs ont toutefois bien eu lieu en Italie ces dernières semaines. Le 21 juillet 2022, par exemple, plus de 300 tracteurs ont bloqué la circulation sur une route d'accès au siège de la région de Calabre (sud-ouest). Selon la presse locale, environ 600 agriculteurs ont manifesté contre l'augmentation des coûts des matières premières.
Le même jour, toujours selon des médias locaux italiens, des agriculteurs venus de la campagne proche de la ville de Caserta sont entrés dans Naples avec des tracteurs pour protester contre les mesures sanitaires prises par les autorités régionales pour endiguer la brucellose et la tuberculose chez les bovins.
Le 6 juillet 2022, une autre manifestation d'agriculteurs en difficulté avait aussi eu lieu à Lamezia Terme, dans le sud du pays.
Cette vidéo circule aussi dans un contexte de manifestations massives aux Pays-Bas : depuis plusieurs semaines, des agriculteurs bloquent les autoroutes du pays, déversant du fumier et des déchets, incendiant des bottes de paille et se rassemblant devant le domicile de plusieurs responsables politiques.
En cause : le plan gouvernemental de réduction de 50% des émissions d'azote, envisagé d'ici à 2030, qui pourrait provoquer des expropriations.
Deuxième exportateur agricole au monde après les Etats-Unis, les Pays-Bas connaissent régulièrement de fortes mobilisations agricoles. Les images de ces manifestations ont déjà été décontextualisées à plusieurs reprises, comme expliqué dans cet article de vérification, ou encore dans celui-ci.
12 août 2022 Ajoute paragraphes et images de géolocalisation du 15ème au 22ème paragraphe
12 août 2022 Ajoute détails, citation de la présidente de l'association touristique locale
10 août 2022 Remplace "alphabet cyrillique" par "alphabet latin serbe" au 14ème paragraphe
Translation:
Italian farmers mobilized against inflation? No, this video immortalizes a party in Piedmont
- This article is over a year old
- Published on August 10, 2022 at 11:30 a.m.
- Updated August 12, 2022 at 7:30 p.m.
- Reading: 8 min
- By: Emilie BERAUD, Eva WACKENREUTHER, AFP France, AFP Austria
Copyright AFP 2017-2024. Any commercial reuse of the content is subject to a subscription. Click here to learn more.
In the video relayed on Facebook, dozens of tractors, flashing lights on and horns blaring in unison, parked next to each other.
"Italian farmers in the Piedmont region are protesting against inflation, high fuel prices, fertilizers, high living costs, low purchasing prices of products...!!!", it is said affirmed in the caption which accompanies the publication, shared nearly 3,000 times since July 30, 2022.
"Belgium, then Italy, anger wins and grows...", we can read among the some 238 comments which call, for the most part, for the "awakening" of the French and Europeans: "Bravo Italy! All Europeans should do the same! The solidarity of the people is necessary in the face of the crisis profiteers who are crushing us!”
This publication, also distributed in Romania or the Czech Republic, arouses strong reactions on social networks at a time when the inflation rate in the euro zone is breaking records, reaching 8.9% in July, over one year.
Italy is not spared from this sudden increase in the cost of living: the Italian government adopted, on Thursday August 4, a new package of measures worth 17 billion euros intended largely to cushion the shock. of the surge in energy prices for households and businesses.
In the video published on Facebook, an Italian flag is clearly identifiable, at the sixth second.
However, according to AFP research, these vehicles were gathered on the occasion of a "beer and tractor festival" organized in a small town in northwest Italy, which had not no link with mobilization against inflation.
Tractors gathered... for a party
Viewed more than 50,000 times on the page of a Facebook group which relays images of popular mobilizations, the publication claims to reveal images of Italian farmers, mobilized in numbers against the decline in purchasing power.
However, a keyword search carried out on Google did not allow us to find such an event described in the Italian press.
On the other hand, the online media Torino Oggi published an article on July 20, 2022, titled as follows: “Villafranca Piemonte aims high with its Tractor Beer Fest”. In detail, the article indicates that the objective of this first "beer and tractor festival" is to program "the largest gathering of tractors ever organized in Piedmont", to "highlight the importance of agriculture" in this region of north-west Italy.
Many festival-goers accompanied by their tractors therefore went, on July 23, 2022, to the small town of Villafranca Piemonte. On its website, the municipality effectively communicated about the event, and even shared the poster dedicated to it. She explains that the party is organized in particular by the city's "Pro loco", a local tourist association.
After several posts announcing the festival published on its Facebook page on July 18 and then on July 23, 2022, this tourist association broadcast a video on July 25 which contains some of the images that we are verifying. This video has no caption but begins with a close-up of an attendee's "Tractor Beer fest" t-shirt.
Contacted by AFP, the president of the local tourist association, Franca Alciato, indicated on August 12, 2022 that “the video shows the beer and tractor festival and nothing else”.
We compared the images of the video broadcast by the tourist association, with the first six seconds of the video broadcast on Facebook, filmed from an aerial shot: several elements, identified below, are recognizable.
From the sixth second, the images published on Facebook are no longer filmed in an aerial shot, but on the ground. They are not visible in the video relayed by the Italian association. However, we were able to establish that they were also taken during Tractor Beer Fest on July 23, 2022.
Indeed, we found these images on Twitter: they appear in better quality in a viral video, published on July 29, 2022 and shared more than 3,000 times on the social network.
In these images, a light-colored rectangular building is visible at the sixteenth second mark, in the background. And on the official poster of the festival, posted online on the website of the town Villafranca Piemonte, we learn that the meeting had been given at the Prezzo Il Palazzetto Polivalente.
This multipurpose room, which we geolocated on Google Maps, is the rectangular, light-colored building identified in the video we are checking.
On Google Street View, we recognize its geographical shape, its facade and the supports of its roof.
The part of the video filmed on the ground shared on Facebook was therefore filmed in the parking lot of the Prezzo Il Palazzetto Polivalente.
Furthermore, at the tenth second of the best quality video posted on Twitter we see, from right to left, a green tractor, a red tractor and a blue tractor framed by two lampposts.
In the video published by the Italian association which organized the event, we identified these same three tractors, at 2 minutes and 14 seconds. They are visible below, circled in green.
The lamppost visible in the Twitter video is also identifiable, framed in blue.
Finally, the area where the tractors are parked is visible below, framed in red:
Longer versions of the video are circulating on Facebook, such as here. In addition to nighttime images, they include images of tractors filmed during the day which also come from the festival video published by the tourist association (at 0'33).
Local media or passers-by (like here) have also published images of the festival which correspond to those published by the "Pro Loco" association.
At the origin of the diversion: a Serbian Facebook page
A logo (located at the top right of the video images) as well as an inscription in the Serbian Latin alphabet (at the top left) also put us on the trail of the origin of the misappropriation of images.
A keyword search on Google allowed us to find the Facebook page behind the manipulation, based in the capital of Serbia, Belgrade.
It presents itself as a "political magazine" and publishes numerous videos of demonstrations and popular mobilizations, attaching their logo or inscriptions.
Farmers' protests in southern Italy
However, farmers' demonstrations have taken place in Italy in recent weeks. On July 21, 2022, for example, more than 300 tractors blocked traffic on an access road to the headquarters of the Calabria region (southwest). According to the local press, around 600 farmers demonstrated against the increase in raw material costs.
The same day, still according to local Italian media, farmers from the countryside near the town of Caserta entered Naples with tractors to protest against the health measures taken by regional authorities to stem brucellosis and tuberculosis among farmers. cattle.
On July 6, 2022, another demonstration by farmers in difficulty also took place in Lamezia Terme, in the south of the country.
This video is also circulating in the context of massive demonstrations in the Netherlands: for several weeks, farmers have been blocking the country's highways, dumping manure and waste, burning bales of straw and gathering in front of the homes of several political leaders.
At issue: the government plan to reduce nitrogen emissions by 50%, envisaged by 2030, which could cause expropriations.
The second largest agricultural exporter in the world after the United States, the Netherlands regularly experiences strong agricultural mobilizations. The images of these demonstrations have already been decontextualized several times, as explained in this verification article, or in this one.
August 12, 2022 Adds paragraphs and geolocation images from the 15th to the 22nd paragraph
August 12, 2022 Adds details, quote from the president of the local tourist association
August 10, 2022 Replaces “Cyrillic alphabet” with “Serbian Latin alphabet” in the 14th paragraph
false_claim: Videos show Italian farmers in Piedmont protesting against the government.

content:
Mariupol: Nein, diese Fotos verletzter Frauen belegen keinen inszenierten Angriff
In Sozialen Netzwerken wird einer schwangeren Bloggerin unterstellt, sie habe mehrere verletzte Frauen bei einem „angeblichen“ Bombenangriff in Mariupol gespielt. Doch Journalisten vor Ort haben den Einschlag dokumentiert – die Bloggerin war eine von mehreren Patienten.
Triggerwarnung: In diesem Beitrag ist Bildmaterial zu sehen, das die Folgen von Gewalt zeigt.
Am 9. März wurde ein Krankenhaus mit Entbindungsstation in Mariupol in der Südost-Ukraine bombardiert. Bilder in den Medien zeigten verletzte, schwangere Frauen. Die russische Botschaft in London verbreitete daraufhin auf Twitter die Behauptung, bei den „Verletzten“ handele es sich um Schauspielerinnen, die Szenen seien gestellt. Twitter hat die Tweets der Botschaft inzwischen gelöscht.
In Deutschland griff die Webseite Anti-Spiegel die russischen Behauptungen auf und behauptete, die schwangere Beauty-Bloggerin „Marianna aus Mariupol“ habe mehrere verletzte Frauen gespielt, sie habe sich dafür sogar umgezogen.
Die Aufnahmen der verletzten Frauen stammen von der Nachrichtenagentur Associated Press (AP). Die freien Fotografen Mstyslav Chernov und Evgeny Maloletka fotografierten und filmten für AP im Treppenhaus der Klinik und vor dem Gebäude.
Die Bilder zeigen zwei verschiedene Frauen in Mariupol
Anti-Spiegel fragt: „Warum erklärt mir kein ‚Qualitätsjournalist‘, warum das kein Fake war und wie Marianna als ‚bemitleidenswertes Opfer‘ des russischen Luftangriffs gleich dreimal in verschiedenen Rollen in dem Video auftaucht (…)?“ Angeblich zeigten Bild 1, Bild 2 und Bild 3 dieselbe Frau, die aber unterschiedliche Opfer darstellen soll.
Tatsächlich handelt es sich laut Fotograf Chernov um zwei verschiedene Frauen, die beide schwanger waren. Das konnten wir anhand eines Videos, das Anti-Spiegel selbst verlinkt hat, bestätigen.
Auf einigen Aufnahmen ist eine blonde Frau in einem hellen Pyjama mit schwarzen Punkten zu sehen – ihr Gesicht ist an mehreren Stellen blutig, doch sie kann laufen. In der Hand hält sie eine Decke, die sie sich später um die Schultern legte. Die anderen Bilder zeigen dagegen eine Frau in einem hellen Oberteil, die verletzt auf einer Bahre liegt. Sie hat andere Gesichtszüge und etwas Blut an der linken Augenbraue.
Wie Recherchen der Nachrichtenagentur AP ergaben, sind die Frau auf der Bahre und ihr ungeborenes Kind in ein anderes Krankenhaus gebracht worden, dort aber gestorben.
Die Frau mit dem gepunkteten Pyjama ist Beauty-Bloggerin
Es stimmt, dass die blonde Frau eine Beauty-Bloggerin aus Mariupol ist.
Eine kurze Google-Recherche führt zu vielen Medienberichten, die bestätigen, dass die Instagram-Bloggerin als Patientin in der Klinik war. Dass sie hochschwanger war, zeigt ein Foto auf ihrem Instagram-Profil vom 28. Februar. AP berichtete zudem am 11. März über die Geburt des Kindes.
Staatsnahe Medien in Russland berichten, das Krankenhaus sei zum Zeitpunkt des Angriffs leer gewesen – doch die Angaben sind widersprüchlich
Laut Anti-Spiegel seien im Inneren des Krankenhauses „nirgends“ Blut, Tote oder Verletzte zu sehen. Das Bildmaterial der Journalisten bestätigt aber, dass in und vor dem Krankenhaus verletzte Menschen und Blutspuren zu sehen sind (hier, hier und hier). Laut Angaben der Ukraine wurden mindestens 17 Personen bei dem Angriff verletzt, mindestens drei Menschen starben.
Nach Angaben des russischen Außenministers Sergei Lawrow habe das Krankenhaus in Mariupol als Stützpunkt des nationalistischen Asow-Bataillons gedient, nicht als Krankenhaus. Die Rede ist aber von „Entbindungskrankenhaus Nr. 1“, das anders aussieht, als das in den Aufnahmen. In Mariupol gibt es mehrere Geburtsstationen.
Laut Recherchen des russischen Exil-Mediums Meduza, einer zweisprachigen Internetzeitung mit Sitz in Lettland, zeigen die Bilder von dem Angriff die „Entbindungsabteilung von Krankenhaus Nr. 3“ in Mariupol. Bellingcat hat die Klinikstandorte mithilfe von Satellitenbildern lokalisiert (hier und hier), demnach liegen sie mehr als zehn Kilometer voneinander entfernt.
Chernov, einer der AP-Fotografen, die bei dem Angriff vor Ort waren, schrieb am 11. März in einem Artikel: „AP-Reporter in Mariupol, die den Angriff in Videos und Fotos dokumentierten, sahen die Opfer und Schäden aus erster Hand – und nichts, was darauf hindeutet, dass das Krankenhaus als etwas anderes als ein Krankenhaus genutzt wurde.“
Einen Überblick mit allen Faktenchecks von uns zum Russland-Ukraine-Krieg finden Sie hier.
Redigatur: Steffen Kutzner, Tania Röttger
Translation:
Mariupol: No, these photos of injured women do not prove a staged attack
On social networks, a pregnant blogger is being accused of playing the role of several injured women in an “alleged” bomb attack in Mariupol. But journalists on site documented the impact - the blogger was one of several patients.
Trigger warning: This post contains images that show the consequences of violence.
On March 9, a hospital and maternity ward in Mariupol, southeastern Ukraine, was bombed. Images in the media showed injured, pregnant women. The Russian embassy in London then spread the claim on Twitter that the “injured people” were actresses and that the scenes were staged. Twitter has since deleted the embassy's tweets.
In Germany, the website Anti-Spiegel took up the Russian claims and claimed that the pregnant beauty blogger “Marianna from Mariupol” had played several injured women and that she had even changed her clothes to do so.
The images of the injured women came from the Associated Press (AP) news agency. Freelance photographers Mstyslav Chernov and Evgeny Maloletka took photos and filmed for AP in the clinic's stairwell and in front of the building.
The pictures show two different women in Mariupol
Anti-Spiegel asks: "Why doesn't a 'quality journalist' explain to me why it wasn't a fake and how Marianna, as a 'pitiful victim' of the Russian air raid, appears three times in different roles in the video (…)?" Apparently picture 1, picture 2 and picture 3 are the same woman, but are supposed to represent different victims.
In fact, according to photographer Chernov, these are two different women, both of whom were pregnant. We were able to confirm this based on a video that Anti-Spiegel itself linked.
In some photos, a blonde woman can be seen wearing light-colored pajamas with black dots - her face is bloodied in several places, but she can walk. She holds a blanket in her hand, which she later puts around her shoulders. The other pictures, on the other hand, show a woman in a light-colored top who is lying injured on a stretcher. She has different facial features and some blood on her left eyebrow.
According to research by the AP news agency, the woman on the stretcher and her unborn child were taken to another hospital, but died there.
The woman in the polka dot pajamas is a beauty blogger
It's true that the blonde woman is a beauty blogger from Mariupol.
A quick Google search leads to many media reports confirming that the Instagram blogger was a patient at the clinic. A photo on her Instagram profile from February 28 shows that she was heavily pregnant. AP also reported on the birth of the child on March 11.
State-affiliated media in Russia report that the hospital was empty at the time of the attack - but the information is contradictory
According to Anti-Spiegel, there was “nowhere” to see blood, dead or injured people inside the hospital. However, the journalists' images confirm that injured people and traces of blood can be seen in and in front of the hospital (here, here and here). According to Ukraine, at least 17 people were injured in the attack and at least three people died.
According to Russian Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov, the hospital in Mariupol served as a base for the nationalist Azov Battalion, not as a hospital. But we're talking about "Maternity Hospital No. 1", which looks different than the one in the photos. There are several maternity wards in Mariupol.
According to research by the Russian exile media Meduza, a bilingual online newspaper based in Latvia, the images from the attack show the “maternity ward of Hospital No. 3” in Mariupol. Bellingcat has located the clinic locations using satellite images (here and here), so they are more than ten kilometers apart.
Chernov, one of the AP photographers on the scene of the attack, wrote in a March 11 article: "AP reporters in Mariupol who documented the attack in videos and photos saw the casualties and damage firsthand - and nothing to suggest that the hospital was used as anything other than a hospital.”
You can find an overview of all of our fact checks on the Russia-Ukraine war here.
Editing: Steffen Kutzner, Tania Röttger
false_claim: The attack in Ukraine was staged by Ukrainian forces.

content:
Nem, nem esett orosz fogságba a NATO parancsnoka Ukrajnában
- Ez a cikk több mint egy éves.
- Megjelent: 2022. április 20., 14:56
- 5 perces olvasmány
- Szerző: AFP Franciaország, AFP Románia
- Fordítás és adaptáció: Ede ZABORSZKY
Szerzői jog © AFP 2017–2024. A tartalom kereskedelmi célú felhasználásához előfizetés szükséges. Kattintson ide, ha többet szeretne megtudni.
"Mariupolban orosz fogságba esett az USA altábornagya Roger L. Cloutier" – olvasható egy Facebookon terjedő képen, amit már több mint 2400 ember osztott meg 2022. április 14-e óta.
Egy magyar cikk szintén terjedni kezdett az interneten azzal a hamis állítással, hogy Cloutier altábornagyot elfogták az ostrom alatt álló Mariupol városában. A cikkben szereplő videón egy kitakart arcú férfit látni, akit megbilincselve vezetnek el az orosz Szövetségi Biztonsági Szolgálat (FSZB) emberei. A videón a bal felső sarokban Roger L. Cloutier amerikai altábornagy fotója látható, a jobb alsó sarokban pedig az orosz állami hátterű RIA Novosztyi hírügynökség vízjelét látni.
A Facebookon hozzászóló felhasználók, úgy tűnik, azt hiszik: ez a bizonyíték arra az (egyébként téves) állításra, hogy a NATO közvetlenül is részt vesz az Ukrajnában dúló harcokban. "A NATO katonák is bent vannak", írta például valaki. "Bíróság elé vele, majd vagy életfogytig vagy főbelövés, mint Nürnbergben" – írta egy másik felhasználó a Facebookon megosztott kép alatt.
Ugyanez a hamis állítás már román, bolgár, thai, francia és szerb nyelven is terjedni kezdett az interneten. De a NATO megerősítette az AFP kérdésére, hogy a szárazföldi erők főparancsnoka, Roger L. Cloutier nem esett orosz fogságba, és nem is tartózkodik Ukrajnában.
A NATO cáfolja, hogy Cloutier fogságba esett volna Ukrajnában
2022. április 8-án – miután a hamis állítás több nyelven is terjedni kezdett – az AFP megkeresésére a NATO Szövetséges Erők Európai Főparancsnoksága (SHAPE) cáfolta, hogy az altábornagy orosz fogságba esett volna.
"Terjedni kezdett az interneten egy állítás, miszerint Roger Cloutier altábornagy, a szárazföldi erők főparancsnoka katonai tevékenység során fogságba esett Mariupolban. Ezek az állítások teljességgel hamisak" – mondta a SHAPE egy szóvivője, aki hozzátette, hogy Cloutier utoljára 2021 júliusában járt Ukrajnában.
Cloutier a közösségi médiában továbbra is aktív
Több jel is arra utal, hogy a NATO-főparancsnok nem Ukrajnában tartózkodik, hanem a törökországi Izmirben, ahol a NATO Szövetséges Műveleti Parancsnoksága (ACO) található. Cloutier 2022. április 5-én egy videót is feltöltött magáról a LinkedIn-oldalára, amin azt látni, ahogyan Izmirben beszédet tart. Ez már azután történt, hogy először terjedni kezdtek a hírek az állítólagos elfogásáról (például itt.)
A rákövetkező napon egy felhasználó az elfogásáról szóló pletykákról kérdezte Cloutier-t, aki a közösségi oldalán azt válaszolta, hogy ezek a hírek "teljességgel hamisak".
A tábornok a hivatalos NATO ACO Facebook-oldal egyik 2022. április 5-i bejegyzésében is látható:
Ezek mellett egy 2022. április 13-án a LinkedIn-oldalára feltöltött bejegyzés szerint Cloutier részt vett egy ünnepségen, ahol "27 a NATO Szövetséges Műveleti Parancsnokság kötelékében dolgozó katona és civil részesült elismerésben". A Törökországban megrendezett ünnepségről készült videó elérhető a NATO-parancsnokság hivatalos Youtube-csatornáján is. Az egyik kitüntetett katona, a kanadai Alexander Landry szintén felöltött egy közös képet az altábornaggyal a LinkedIn-profiljára 2022. április 13-án.
2022. április 14-én Cloutier egy másik videót is megosztott, amin azt látni, ahogyan a főparancsnokságon fogadja a Északkeleti Többnemzeti Hadtestparancsnokság parancsnokát, Dragoş-Dumitru Iacob vezérőrnagyot Izmirben.
Az AFP nem talált a TASZSZ orosz állami hírügynökség oldalán hírt az állítólagos elfogásról. A TASZSZ utoljára 2021 márciusában írt Cloutier-ről. Ramzan Kadirov csecsen vezér hivatalos Telegram-csatornáján szintén nincs említés Cloutier-ről, pedig Kadirov csapatai Mariupolnál harcolnak, ahol az állítólagos elfogás történt.
A videóban szereplő férfi nem Cloutier
Az AFP egy fordított képkereséssel kiderítette, hogy a hamis cikkben található videó több április 7-i orosz újságcikkben is feltűnik (itt, itt, itt és itt). A cikkek mind egy férfiról írnak, akit az FSZB a Krím félszigeten tartóztatott le, amiért állítólag egy illegális fegyveres csoport tagja volt.
A videót a TASZSZ hírügynökség, valamint az orosz védelmi minisztérium csatornája is megosztotta, mindkét oldal a Krímen elfogott férfiról szóló leírással.
Az eredeti videón nem szerepel Cloutier fényképe, azt feltehetően utólag adták hozzá a közösségi médiában terjedő hamis változathoz.
A hamis kontextusban terjedő változaton a RIA Novosztyi hírügynökség logója is látható. Az AFP megtalálta a RIA cikkét a videóval, de ott szintén a "Krími Tatár Zászlóalj egy harcosát elfogják Krímben" leírással szerepel a felvétel.
Az összes fenti hírforrás egyöntetűen azt írja az FSZB sajtóközleményére hivatkozva, hogy a videón azt látni, ahogyan letartóztatnak egy ukrán állampolgárt a Krím félszigeten, aki a gyanú szerint az oroszok által illegálisnak tekintett Krími Tatár Önkéntes Zászlóalj fegyveres csoportosulás tagja volt.
A NATO és Ukrajna kapcsolata
Bár a NATO "erőteljesen elítélte" az Ukrajna ellen indított orosz támadást, a katonai szövetség közvetlenül nem vesz részt a konfliktusban. A szövetség tagjai saját hatáskörükben küldtek harcászati felszereléseket az ukrán hadseregnek.
A NATO és Ukrajna kapcsolata hivatalosan az ország függetlenedése után, a 90-es években kezdődött, de Ukrajna nem NATO-tag, és nem esik a szövetség védelmi megállapodása alá, olvasható a NATO honlapján. Kijev próbálkozásai, hogy közelebb kerüljön az EU-hoz és a NATO-hoz, rendre heves tiltakozást váltottak ki Moszkva részéről, ugyanis az oroszok szerint fenyegetést jelentene Ukrajna csatlakozása a nyugati szövetségekhez.
Van olyan tartalom, amelyet szeretne ellenőrizni az AFP tényellenőrzésén keresztül?
Lépjen kapcsolatba velünk
Translation:
No, the NATO commander in Ukraine was not captured by Russia
- This article is over a year old.
- Published: April 20, 2022, 2:56 p.m
- 5 minute reading
- Author: AFP France, AFP Romania
- Translation and adaptation: Ede ZABORSZKY
Copyright © AFP 2017-2024. Commercial use of the content requires a subscription. Click here to learn more.
"U.S. Lieutenant General Roger L. Cloutier was taken prisoner by the Russians in Mariupol," reads a picture circulating on Facebook, which has already been shared by more than 2,400 people since April 14, 2022.
A Hungarian article also began to spread on the Internet with the false claim that Lieutenant General Cloutier had been captured in the besieged city of Mariupol. In the video in the article, you can see a man with a covered face being led away in handcuffs by the Russian Federal Security Service (FSB). In the video, in the upper left corner, you can see the photo of US Lieutenant General Roger L. Cloutier, and in the lower right corner, you can see the watermark of the Russian state-owned news agency RIA Novostyi.
Users commenting on Facebook seem to think that this is proof of the (otherwise false) claim that NATO is directly involved in the fighting in Ukraine. "The NATO soldiers are also inside," someone wrote, for example. "In front of the court with him, then either for life or shot, like in Nuremberg," another user wrote under the photo shared on Facebook.
The same false claim has already started to spread on the Internet in Romanian, Bulgarian, Thai, French and Serbian. But NATO confirmed to AFP that the commander-in-chief of ground forces, Roger L. Cloutier, had not been captured by Russia and was not in Ukraine.
NATO denies that Cloutier was captured in Ukraine
On April 8, 2022, after the false claim began to spread in several languages, the NATO High Command of Allied Forces Europe (SHAPE) denied to AFP that the lieutenant general had been captured by Russia.
"A claim has begun to circulate online that Lt. Gen. Roger Cloutier, the Commander-in-Chief of the Ground Forces, was captured during military operations in Mariupol. These claims are completely false," said a SHAPE spokesperson, adding that Cloutier last visited Ukraine in July 2021.
Cloutier remains active on social media
There are several indications that the NATO Commander-in-Chief is not in Ukraine, but in Izmir, Turkey, where NATO's Allied Operations Command (ACO) is located. Cloutier also uploaded a video of himself on his LinkedIn page on April 5, 2022, showing him giving a speech in Izmir. This happened after news of his alleged capture first began to spread (for example, here.)
The following day, a user asked Cloutier about the rumors of his capture, and Cloutier replied on his social media that these reports were "completely false".
The general can also be seen in a post from the official NATO ACO Facebook page on April 5, 2022:
In addition, according to a post uploaded to his LinkedIn page on April 13, 2022, Cloutier participated in a ceremony where "27 soldiers and civilians working under the NATO Allied Command were recognized." The video of the ceremony held in Turkey is also available on the official YouTube channel of the NATO headquarters. One of the honored soldiers, Canadian Alexander Landry, also posted a joint picture with the lieutenant general on his LinkedIn profile on April 13, 2022.
On April 14, 2022, Cloutier shared another video showing him receiving the commander of the Multinational Forces Command Northeast, Major General Dragoş-Dumitru Iacob at the headquarters in Izmir.
AFP found no news about the alleged capture on the website of the Russian state news agency TASSSZ. TASZSZ last wrote about Cloutier in March 2021. There is also no mention of Cloutier on Chechen leader Ramzan Kadyrov's official Telegram channel, even though Kadyrov's troops are fighting near Mariupol, where the alleged capture took place.
The man in the video is not Cloutier
AFP found through a reverse image search that the video in the fake article appears in several Russian newspaper articles from April 7 ( here , here , here and here ). The articles are all about a man who was arrested by the FSB in Crimea for allegedly being a member of an illegal armed group.
The video was shared by the TASZSZ news agency and the channel of the Russian Ministry of Defense, with both sides describing the man captured in Crimea.
The original video does not include Cloutier's photo, which is believed to have been added after the fact to the fake version circulating on social media.
The logo of the RIA Novosztyi news agency can also be seen on the version spreading in a false context. AFP found the RIA article with the video, but it also includes the recording with the description "A fighter of the Crimean Tatar Battalion is captured in Crimea".
All of the above news sources unanimously write, referring to the FSB press release, that the video shows the arrest of a Ukrainian citizen on the Crimean peninsula, who is suspected of being a member of the Crimean Tatar Volunteer Battalion, an armed group considered illegal by the Russians.
The relationship between NATO and Ukraine
Although NATO "strongly condemned" the Russian attack on Ukraine, the military alliance is not directly involved in the conflict. The members of the alliance sent military equipment to the Ukrainian army within their competence.
The relationship between NATO and Ukraine officially began after the country's independence in the 1990s, but Ukraine is not a NATO member and does not fall under the alliance's defense agreement, according to NATO's website. Kiev's attempts to get closer to the EU and NATO have often provoked fierce protests from Moscow, because according to the Russians, Ukraine's accession to Western alliances would pose a threat.
Got content you'd like to check with AFP fact-checking?
Contact us
false_claim: Russia's invasion of Ukraine is portrayed as a 'proxy war' with NATO aggression.

content:
Obalamy fałszywe informacje pojawiające się w mediach społecznościowych oraz na portalach internetowych. Odwołując się do wiarygodnych źródeł, weryfikujemy najbardziej szkodliwe przykłady dezinformacji.
Hamowanie transmisji – czy Pfizer musiał to sprawdzić w badaniu?
W badaniu klinicznym głównym celem jest sprawdzenie bezpieczeństwa i skuteczności w ochronie przed chorobą.
Fot. Mat Napo / Unsplash / Modyfikacje: Demagog
Hamowanie transmisji – czy Pfizer musiał to sprawdzić w badaniu?
