Päivityksissä väitetään myös, että Unkarin lähtö EU:sta valmistuisi toukokuuhun 2023 mennessä, mutta tosiasiassa EU:sta lähteminen niin lyhyellä aikataululla olisi erittäin vaikeaa.
Ensinnäkin EU-jäsenyys on kirjattu Unkarin perustuslakiin, jossa kielletään myös kansainvälisiä sopimuksia koskevat kansanäänestykset. Orbánin hallitus voisi kuitenkin teoriassa käyttää kahden kolmanneksen enemmistöään parlamentissa ja muuttaa perustuslakia raivaten tietä mahdolliselle "Huxitille".
Päivityksissä väitetään myös, että Unkarin parlamentin olisi tarkoitus aloittaa asian käsittely 2.1., mutta parlamentin kevätistuntokausi vuonna 2023 alkaa vasta 1.2. Vastaavaa aloitetta ei ole parlamentin tietokannassa.
Jos Unkari todella päättäisi lähteä EU:sta, se tehtäisiin seuraamalla Lissabonin sopimuksen 50. artiklaa. Näin on tapahtunut vain kerran, kun Britannia ero EU:sta, ja prosessi kesti useita vuosia.
Median-instituutin joulukuussa 2022 tekemän kyselyn mukaan 78% unkarilaista kannattivat EU-jäsenyyttä joko täysin (43%) tai jokseenkin (35%). Instituutin mukaan kannatus laski 10 prosenttiyksikköä Venäjän hyökättyä Ukrainaan. Sodan aikana Unkarin hallitus on syyttänyt EU:ta toistuvasti korkeista energian hinnoista.
Yksikään Unkarin suurista puolueista ei tällä hetkellä tue avoimesti EU-eroa. Vuonna 2022 oikeistopolitiikko János Volner ilmoitti "Huxit-puolueen" perustamisesta, mutta se ei osallistunut vuoden 2022 vaaleihin eikä ole saanut merkittävää huomiota tämän jälkeen.
16. tammikuuta 2023 Korjattu kirjoitusvirhe otsikossa
Ehdota meille faktantarkistusta.
Ota yhteyttä
Translation:
Prime Minister Viktor Orbán has not given a public speech in which he would have announced Hungary's departure from the EU
- The article is over a year old.
- Posted on January 16, 2023 11:18 am
- Updated January 16, 2023 11:43 AM
- Reading time: 5 minutes
- Text: Ede ZABORSZKY, AFP Hungary
- Translated and adapted into Finnish by: Anna HOLLINGSWORTH
Copyright © AFP 2017-2024. Commercial use of the contents requires a subscription. Read more here.
At the beginning of January 2023, a text started circulating on social media claiming that "Hungary decided to leave the European Union. Prime Minister Viktor Orban announced this in his New Year's address to the citizens." The text was distributed in several European languages, including Finnish, Hungarian, French, Greek, Slovak, Czech, Croatian and German. Updates in Finnish were shared almost a hundred times on Facebook. The claim has been shared relatively little in Hungary itself, but it is quite popular in other languages ​​and, for example, updates in Czech and Croatian have been shared more than a thousand times.
The text was also shared in Bulgarian, but these updates used the Russian word "Евросоюз" instead of the Bulgarian "Эвросъюз", suggesting that the text was copied from a Russian source.
A word search on the Russian Yandex search engine and Telegram brought up a Telegram update published on January 1, 2023 at 02:00 CET (01:00 GMT) on the Telegram channel of the Russian satire site Panorama. The text was also published on Panorama's website. The article was archived on 1.1. at 01:17 GMT.
The Finnish version also has unnatural-sounding formatting, which suggests that the text has been translated using a translation program.
The updates make several false internal claims, including that Viktor Orbán has announced that Hungary will begin the process of leaving the EU immediately; that he would have done so in his "New Year's speech"; and that the Hungarian Parliament would start the divorce process on 2.1. The updates say that Hungary will have left the EU by May 2023.
In Hungary, the president, not the prime minister, gives the New Year's speech
Although the updates claim that Orbán made his supposed announcement in a "New Year's speech", there is no evidence that he made such a speech this year. Word searches on Google and prominent Hungarian media (here and here) yielded no results. Such an extreme and important public announcement would have been widely reported in Hungary and beyond.
The Hungarian Prime Minister's public speeches and interviews are available online, and there is no "New Year's speech" among them either. At the time of publication of the article, the latest update is the statement from the press conference on 21 December 2022. Orbán does not mention anything about plans to leave the EU.
In Hungary, it is usually the president, not the prime minister, who gives the New Year's speech. President Katalin Novák gave a speech on New Year's Day, which can be read here. In his speech, Novák spoke about the importance of solidarity and did not say anything that resembled the quotes of the erroneous updates. He actually did not refer to the EU at all.
Orbán's statements about the EU
Orbán's government has had several disputes with EU institutions in recent years amid concerns in Brussels that the government has undermined the rule of law and allowed corruption. The EU has frozen Hungary's subsidies for billions of euros until reforms addressing the concerns have been implemented.
In an interview published on 24 December 2022, Orbán said that Brussels' position is based on "Hungaryphobia" and that the EU's rule of law process is a "significant nail in the EU's coffin". Orbán regularly uses warlike metaphors when talking about the EU, often referring to summits and negotiations as "battles". His government has argued that the EU threatens the independence of its members and that it "must be stopped". Orbán has also said he wants the European Parliament to be abolished in its current form and replaced by representatives of national parliaments.
However, Orbán and his government have always publicly assured that they are committed to EU membership. Viktor Orbán's leading political advisor, Balázs Orbán (no relation), was asked in an interview on January 8, 2023, whether Viktor Orbán wants to leave NATO and the EU. Balázs Orbán replied that "the question is absurd and malicious".
Viktor Orbán's representative, Zoltán Kovács, confirmed to AFP by email on January 10 that the "accusation" that Hungary is leaving the EU is "completely untrue".
In September 2022, Viktor Orbán himself told Hungarian MPs: "I confirm that, despite our disputes with Brussels, we see our future as a member of the Union."
A search in the archive of Orbán's speeches for the past two years also did not yield results that mentioned plans for Hungary's EU exit. In a speech in 2021, he said: "We have no intention of leaving [the EU]. It's not that easy to get rid of us." In an interview on October 24, 2022, he referred to Britain's decision to leave the EU as "regrettable".
Gender and sexual minorities and anti-Western rhetoric
According to false updates, Orbán would have said in his alleged New Year's speech that part of the reason for Hungary's departure from the EU is that "we were part of a European family that turned out to be an LGBT family, where the parents were forced into the child instead of the father and mother, numbered in a concentration camp."
AFP could not find the quote in question in Orbán's public statements, but it is true that he often uses language and imagery against gender and sexual minorities in his speeches, for example when he taunts so-called "HLBTQ propaganda" and when he uses the slogan "father is a man, mother is a woman".
The law, which banned the so-called "promotion of homosexuality" to under-18s, has also been criticized internationally. EU Commission President Ursula von der Leyen called it "shameful".
According to another part of the false updates, Orbán wants Hungary to leave the EU because it restricts trade with countries such as China, India, Russia, Iran and Serbia. It is true that Orban often criticizes the West and talks about seeking new connections in the East. However, during Orbán's reign, Hungary has promoted closer relations with countries such as Russia and China while part of the EU. An example of this is the agreement signed with Russia on the expansion of the Paks nuclear power plant and the agreement on the opening of the first European office of the Chinese Fudan University in Budapest.
Obstacles to Hungary's departure from the EU
The updates also claim that Hungary's departure from the EU would be completed by May 2023, but in reality leaving the EU in such a short time frame would be very difficult.
First of all, EU membership is enshrined in the Hungarian constitution, which also prohibits referendums on international agreements. However, Orbán's government could theoretically use its two-thirds majority in parliament and amend the constitution, paving the way for a possible "Huxit".
The updates also claim that the Hungarian parliament is supposed to start hearing the case on January 2, but the spring session of the parliament in 2023 doesn't start until February 1. There is no similar initiative in the parliament's database.
If Hungary really decided to leave the EU, it would be done by following Article 50 of the Treaty of Lisbon. This has only happened once, when Britain left the EU, and the process took several years.
According to a survey conducted by the Median Institute in December 2022, 78% of Hungarians supported EU membership either completely (43%) or somewhat (35%). According to the institute, support fell by 10 percentage points after Russia invaded Ukraine. During the war, the Hungarian government has repeatedly accused the EU of high energy prices.
None of Hungary's major parties currently openly supports leaving the EU. In 2022, right-wing politician János Volner announced the formation of the "Huxit Party", but it did not participate in the 2022 elections and has not received significant attention since.
January 16, 2023 Fixed a typo in the title
Suggest us a fact check.
Contact us
false_claim: Hungarian Prime Minister Viktor Orban announced in a New Year’s speech that Hungary will exit the European Union.

content:
Questa foto di Putin in ginocchio davanti al presidente cinese è falsa
Il 20 marzo 2023 è stata pubblicata su Facebook una foto che sembra mostrare il presidente russo Vladimir Putin mentre, inginocchiato, bacia la mano del presidente cinese Xi Jinping. L’immagine è accompagnata da un commento, scritto da chi ha pubblicato il post su Facebook, che recita: «Povero PUTIN, povera Russia come si sono ridotti male Ora fanno il baciamano, in ginocchio, alla CINA».
Il riferimento è al meeting iniziato il 20 marzo 2023 e terminato il 22 marzo tra il leader cinese e il presidente russo a Mosca.
Il contenuto oggetto di verifica è infondato e veicola una notizia falsa.
La foto non trova riscontro in nessuna delle foto e dei video ufficiali dell’incontro e in nessun resoconto di testate internazionali.
Inoltre, analizzando nel dettaglio l’immagine si possono notare diverse imperfezioni. Ad esempio, la testa del presidente russo è sproporzionata rispetto al corpo e i capelli del leader cinese non corrispondono a quelli di Xi Jinping nelle foto scattate durante il meeting. Infine, dietro ai due leader compare una persona con le mani deformate.
Tutti questi elementi sembrano indicare che l’immagine analizzata sia stata in realtà realizzata con l’intelligenza artificiale. Su Twitter Amanda Florian, giornalista specializzata in tecnologia e relazioni sino-americane, ha spiegato di aver inserito l’immagine in uno strumento che permette di rilevare immagini realizzate con l’intelligenza artificiale. «Secondo il rilevatore di immagini, la foto è artificiale», ha scritto Florian. Altri esperti consultati dal sito di fact-checking spagnolo Newtral sono giunti alla stessa conclusione.
Translation:
This photo of Putin kneeling before the Chinese president is fake
On March 20, 2023, a photo was published on Facebook that appears to show Russian President Vladimir Putin kneeling and kissing the hand of Chinese President Xi Jinping. The image is accompanied by a comment, written by the person who published the post on Facebook, which reads: «Poor PUTIN, poor Russia, how badly they have made themselves miserable. Now they are kissing the hand, on their knees, of CHINA».
The reference is to the meeting that began on March 20, 2023 and ended on March 22 between the Chinese leader and the Russian president in Moscow.
The content being verified is unfounded and conveys false news.
The photo is not reflected in any of the official photos and videos of the meeting or in any international newspaper reports.
Furthermore, analyzing the image in detail you can notice various imperfections. For example, the Russian president's head is disproportionate to his body and the Chinese leader's hair does not match Xi Jinping's in photos taken during the meeting. Finally, a person with deformed hands appears behind the two leaders.
All these elements seem to indicate that the analyzed image was actually created with artificial intelligence. On Twitter Amanda Florian, a journalist specializing in technology and Sino-American relations, explained that she had inserted the image into a tool that allows the detection of images created with artificial intelligence. “According to the image detector, the photo is artificial,” Florian wrote. Other experts consulted by the Spanish fact-checking site Newtral came to the same conclusion.
false_claim: AI-generated images portray Putin on his knees kissing the hand of Xi Jinping.

content:
“Nas últimas 18 horas, um vídeo publicado por internautas de Tampere, na Finlândia Ocidental, mostra que as Forças Armadas finlandesas começaram a movimentar e transportar uma enorme quantidade de equipamento militar para a fronteira oriental com a Rússia, nomeadamente a região de Carélia.
Segundo os observadores, além de dezenas de tanques Leopard, uma enorme quantidade de equipamentos militares soviéticos BMP, MTLB, KSHM-1V16 pode ser vista por moradores locais sendo movidos por ferrovias para as fronteiras com a Rússia, já que o país está prestes a candidatar-se à adesão à NATO em alguns dias”, escreve o autor de uma publicação no Facebook, de 4 de maio.
No vídeo, com menos de um minuto, podem ver-se várias dezenas de tanques a serem transportados num comboio de carga. Será o vídeo autêntico?
O vídeo é verdadeiro mas está a ser partilhado de forma enganadora. Com a adesão da Finlândia e da Suécia à NATO cada vez mais perto de se tornar uma realidade, a Rússia tem feito ameaças e até invasões do espaço aéreo dos dois países.
A Finlândia, que partilha com a Rússia 1340 quilómetros de fronteira, tem estado atenta às movimentações do gigante país vizinho. Contudo, as Forças Armadas do país emitiram um comunicado a explicar o que é visto no vídeo que tem sido amplamente partilhado.
De acordo com a nota, os tanques estavam a ser transferidos para exercícios militares para a vila de Niinisalo e para a cidade de Säkylä, ambas localizadas no lado oeste do país. Ora, a fronteira com a Rússia é no lado oposto, a este.
O exercício, conhecido como “Arrow 22” decorre, todos os anos, entre o fim de abril e início de maio e desta vez juntou mais de três mil soldados finlandeses. O evento abre as portas a participantes internacionais e, desta vez, fizeram parte forças militares do Reino Unido, Estados Unidos, Letónia e Estónia.
_________________________
Avaliação do Polígrafo:
Translation:
“In the last 18 hours, a video published by Internet users from Tampere, Western Finland, shows that the Finnish Armed Forces began moving and transporting a huge amount of military equipment to the eastern border with Russia, namely the Karelia region.
According to observers, in addition to dozens of Leopard tanks, a huge amount of Soviet military equipment BMP, MTLB, KSHM-1V16 can be seen by local residents being moved by rail to the borders with Russia, as the country is about to apply for join NATO in a few days”, writes the author of a Facebook post on May 4th.
In the video, less than a minute long, several dozen tanks can be seen being transported on a cargo train. Is the video authentic?
The video is true but is being shared in a misleading way. With the accession of Finland and Sweden to NATO increasingly close to becoming a reality, Russia has made threats and even invaded the airspace of the two countries.
Finland, which shares 1,340 kilometers of border with Russia, has been attentive to the movements of the giant neighboring country. However, the country's Armed Forces issued a statement explaining what is seen in the video that has been widely shared.
According to the note, the tanks were being transferred for military exercises to the town of Niinisalo and the city of Säkylä, both located on the western side of the country. Now, the border with Russia is on the opposite side, to the east.
The exercise, known as “Arrow 22”, takes place every year between the end of April and the beginning of May and this time brought together more than three thousand Finnish soldiers. The event opens its doors to international participants and, this time, military forces from the United Kingdom, United States, Latvia and Estonia took part.
_________________________
Polygraph Assessment:
false_claim: Finland is moving military equipment to its Eastern border with Russia.

content:
Bauernprotest in Berlin: Nein, die russische Botschaft schaltete keine Sirene ein, um Solidarität zu zeigen
Ein Video soll zeigen, wie die russische Botschaft in Berlin eine Sirene einschaltete, um die Bauernproteste zu unterstützen. Das stimmt jedoch nicht, die Botschaft dementiert.
Während der Bauernproteste in Berlin Mitte Januar 2024 soll die russische Botschaft eine Warnsirene eingeschaltet haben, um Solidarität zu zeigen. Das behaupteten Beiträge auf X, Tiktok, Facebook und Telegram zu einem Video, das hunderttausende Menschen erreichte.
Im Video ist hinter einigen Traktoren die russische Botschaft zu sehen, die sich in Berlin in unmittelbarer Nähe zum Brandenburger Tor befindet.
Russische Botschaft in Berlin dementiert Behauptung über eingeschaltete Sirene
Die Pressestelle der Botschaft schreibt uns auf Anfrage „Die in den sozialen Medien verbreiteten Informationen darüber, dass die Botschaft der Russischen Föderation in Deutschland ‚eine Sirene‘ eingeschaltet habe, um sich mit den Demonstrationen am 15. Januar 2024 in Berlin ‚zu solidarisieren‘, entsprechen nicht der Wirklichkeit.“ Die Botschaft mische sich nicht in die inneren Angelegenheiten Deutschlands ein und nehme auch an zivilen Demonstrationen nicht teil, heißt es in der Antwort weiter. Es gibt auch keine Medienberichte über die angebliche Sirenen-Aktion der russischen Botschaft.
Dass sich demonstrierende Landwirte bei Protesten Sirenen auf ihre Traktoren bauen, ist nicht neu, wie etwa dieses Video aus dem Jahr 2019 zeigt. Auch bei der Demo 2024 berichteten einige Medien von Sirenengeheul während der Sternfahrt. „In der Nacht sowie am Montagmittag [15. Januar 2024, Anm. d. Red.] waren zudem Sirenen zu hören, die den Signaltönen des Katastrophenschutzes oder gar einem Fliegeralarm ähneln“, schrieb etwa der Tagesspiegel. Laut dem Sender NTV heulten „ausrangierte Feuerwehrsirenen aus DDR-Beständen von den Traktoren weit über den Regierungsbezirk hinaus“. Diese klingen tatsächlich so wie die Sirene im Video.
Auch mehrere Nutzerinnen und Nutzer schrieben in den Kommentaren, die Sirene stammte nicht von der russischen Botschaft, sondern von Traktoren. Ob der Ton des Videos nachträglich hinzugefügt oder bearbeitet wurde, lässt sich nicht abschließend klären.
Rund um die Bauernproteste kursierten in Sozialen Netzwerken mehrere Falschbehauptungen. So sollten einige Videos zeigen, dass solidarische Unterstützung auch aus Österreich, Ungarn und Polen komme. Das stimmte jedoch nicht, wie wir hier und hier berichteten.
Redigatur: Gabriele Scherndl, Paulina Thom
Translation:
Farmers' protest in Berlin: No, the Russian embassy did not turn on a siren to show solidarity
A video purports to show how the Russian embassy in Berlin turned on a siren to support the farmers' protests. However, that is not true, the embassy denies it.
During the farmers' protests in Berlin in mid-January 2024, the Russian embassy is said to have turned on a warning siren to show solidarity. This is what posts on X, Tiktok, Facebook and Telegram claimed about a video that reached hundreds of thousands of people.
In the video, the Russian embassy, ​​which is located in Berlin in the immediate vicinity of the Brandenburg Gate, can be seen behind some tractors.
Russian embassy in Berlin denies claim that siren was switched on
The embassy's press office writes to us upon request: "The information spread on social media about the fact that the Embassy of the Russian Federation in Germany turned on 'a siren' to 'show solidarity' with the demonstrations on January 15, 2024 in Berlin, do not correspond to reality.” The embassy does not interfere in Germany’s internal affairs and does not take part in civil demonstrations, the answer continues. There are also no media reports about the alleged siren campaign by the Russian embassy.
The fact that demonstrating farmers install sirens on their tractors during protests is not new, as this video from 2019 shows. At the 2024 demo, some media also reported sirens wailing during the rally. “At night and on Monday afternoon [15. January 2024, note d. Red.] Sirens could also be heard that resembled the beeps of civil protection or even an air raid alarm,” wrote the Tagesspiegel. According to the broadcaster NTV, “discarded fire brigade sirens from GDR stocks wailed from the tractors far beyond the administrative district”. These actually sound like the siren in the video.
Several users also wrote in the comments that the siren did not come from the Russian embassy, ​​but from tractors. It cannot be conclusively clarified whether the audio in the video was added or edited later.
There were several false claims circulating on social networks surrounding the farmers' protests. Some videos were intended to show that solidarity support also comes from Austria, Hungary and Poland. However, that was not true, as we reported here and here.
Editing: Gabriele Scherndl, Paulina Thom
false_claim: The Russian Embassy in Berlin turned on a siren to show solidarity with the farmers' protest.

content:
Eesti sotsiaalmeediasse on jõudnud kuulus valeväide, et Euroopa Liit teeb ettepaneku keelata üle 15 aastat vanade sõidukite remontimise. Tegelikult on Euroopa Nõukogu seaduseelnõu eesmärk soodustada taaskasutust, vähendada ebaseaduslikku romude müüki ja käidelda jätkusuutlikult kasutuskõlbmatuid sõidukeid.
“Euroopa Liit esitab vastuolulise õigusakti ettepaneku, mis keelaks remondiõiguse vanematele kui 15-aastastele sõidukitele. Euroopa Komisjoni sõnul on eelnõu eesmärk “uuendada autoparki ja julgustada eurooplasi ostma uusi keskkonnasõbralikke sõidukeid” ehk sundima üksikisikuid ostma uuemaid autosid ja sagedamini, samas kui paljud jäävad paraku siis hoopis ilma autota, mis rahuldab seaduse väidetava tegeliku eesmärgi – inimeste kavandatud liikumisvõimetuks muutmise,” kirjutas portaal Telegram 28. veebruaril.
Sarnase teksti avaldas ka Targo Pärnametsa blogi. Mõlemad artiklid on tõlgitud portaalist The Exposé. Tegu on 2020. aastal loodud vandenõuteooriaid ja valeinfot levitava Briti portaaliga, mille väiteid on Faktikontroll on varemgi ümber lükanud.
2023. aasta juulis esitas Euroopa Komisjon ettepaneku, et tõhusamalt reguleerida autode disainimist, valmistamist ja käitlemist. Eelnõu eesmärk on “hõlbustada autotööstuse üleminekut ringmajandusele sõiduki olelusringi kõigis etappides, alates konstrueerimisest kuni töötlemiseni olelusringi lõpus”. Plaanitav määrus peaks looma “kaasaegse reeglistiku, mis parandab kasutuselt kõrvaldatud sõidukite utiliseerimist, stimuleerib taaskasutamist ja kasutab väärtuslikke ressursse kõige tõhusamalt”.
Komisjoni esitatud “kasutuselt kõrvaldatavate sõidukite” ehk “end-of-life vehicles” seaduseelnõu terviktekst on leitav eesti keeles siit, selgitavad tekstid on siin ja siin. Komisjoni esitatud eelnõuga plaanitakse asendada praegu kehtivad romusõidukeid, korduvkasutamist, ringlussevõetavust ja taaskasutamist käsitlevad direktiivid.
Autod, mida ei saa enam parandada ehk mis tunnistatakse kasutuskõlbmatuks, peab eelnõu järgi toimetama spetsiaalsesse töötlemiskohta ja utiliseerima. See peaks vähendama romude jätmist näiteks loodusesse või garaaži, ohtlike ainete lekkimist ja väärtuslike ressursside raiskamist. Eesmärk on võimalikult palju materjale taaskasutada ja ohtlikud jäätmed jätkusuutlikult utiliseerida. Määruse ettepanek sisaldab detailseid kriteeriume, mille järgi hakkavad ametiasutused otsustama, kas rikkis auto on veel remonditav või tuleb see kuulutada “kasutuselt kõrvaldatavaks sõidukiks”.
Kuigi kriteeriumid on detailsed ja täpsed, pole seaduseelnõu tekstis midagi kirjas mis tahes vanuses autode remontimise keelu kohta. Ettepanekus ja selgitavates tekstides pole ka kordagi mainitud “rohkem kui 15 aastat vanu autosid” või midagi sarnast. Eelnõu järgi saab mis tahes autosid edaspidigi remontida, kui need on seaduse järgi “remondikõlblikud”.
Kriteeriumid, mille alusel määratletakse, kas tegu on “kasutuselt kõrvaldatava sõidukiga”, ei sea sõidukile mingeid nõudeid selle vanuse, tüübi, margi, mudeli, päritolu või omandiõiguse alusel. Kui sõiduk vajab remonti, võib seda teha, kui sõiduk vastab tehnoülevaatuse nõuetele ja sel on jätkuvalt luba sõita ELi teedel.
Määruse eesmärkide seas on ka lõpetada romude seadusvastane müük kolmandatesse riikidesse ja muud sarnased pettused. Igal aastal “kaob” ELi liikmesriikide statistikast 3-4 miljonit vana autot. Paljud neist eksporditakse ja müüakse ebaseaduslikult “kasutatud autodena”, et vältida ELi jäätmealaseid õigusakte, mis kohustavad ettevõtteid romusid nõuetekohaselt kõrvaldama. Sellised “kasutatud autod” satuvad enamasti prügilatesse ja saastavad loodust.
Otsus: vale. Euroopa Liit ei plaani keelustada üle 15 aasta vanuste autode remondi. Euroopa Nõukogu esitatud seaduseelnõu ei maini kordagi autode remondikeeldu või “rohkem kui 15 aastat vanu autosid”. Seaduseelnõu eesmärk on muuta autode elutsükkel jätkusuutlikumaks ja täpsustada autode tootmise ja utiliseerimise nõudeid. Vastupidiselt väidetule on eelnõu üks eesmärk hõlbustada autode parandamist ja taaskasutust.
Translation:
The famous false claim that the European Union proposes to ban the repair of vehicles over 15 years old has reached Estonian social media. In fact, the Council of Europe draft law aims to encourage recycling, reduce the illegal sale of scrap metal and sustainably handle end-of-life vehicles.
"The European Union presents a controversial legislative proposal that would prohibit the right to repair for vehicles older than 15 years. According to the European Commission, the purpose of the bill is to "renovate the car fleet and encourage Europeans to buy new environmentally friendly vehicles", i.e. to force individuals to buy newer cars and more often, while unfortunately many will be left without a car instead, which satisfies the alleged real purpose of the law - the intended immobilization of people," wrote portal Telegram on February 28.
A similar text was also published by the Targo Pärnametsa blog. Both articles are translated from The Exposé portal. It is a British portal created in 2020 that spreads conspiracy theories and false information, the claims of which have been refuted by Faktikontrol in the past.
In July 2023, the European Commission presented a proposal to more effectively regulate the design, manufacture and handling of cars. The aim of the bill is to "facilitate the automotive industry's transition to a circular economy in all stages of the vehicle's life cycle, from design to processing at the end of the life cycle". The planned regulation should create "a modern set of rules that improves the disposal of end-of-life vehicles, stimulates recycling and makes the most efficient use of valuable resources."
The full text of the draft law on end-of-life vehicles submitted by the commission can be found in Estonian here, explanatory texts are here and here. The draft presented by the Commission plans to replace the current directives on end-of-life vehicles, reuse, recyclability and recovery.
According to the bill, cars that can no longer be repaired or are declared unusable must be transported to a special treatment facility and disposed of. This should reduce leaving scrap in nature or the garage, for example, the leakage of hazardous substances and the waste of valuable resources. The goal is to recycle as many materials as possible and dispose of hazardous waste sustainably. The proposal of the regulation contains detailed criteria according to which the authorities will decide whether a broken down car can still be repaired or whether it must be declared an "end-of-life vehicle".
Although the criteria are detailed and precise, there is nothing in the text of the bill about a ban on repairing cars of any age. In the proposal and explanatory texts, "cars more than 15 years old" or something similar are never mentioned. According to the bill, any cars can still be repaired if they are "repairable" according to the law.
The criteria used to determine whether it is an "end-of-life vehicle" do not impose any requirements on the vehicle based on its age, type, make, model, origin or ownership. If the vehicle needs repairs, this can be done as long as the vehicle meets the MOT requirements and is still authorized to drive on EU roads.
Among the goals of the regulation is to stop the illegal sale of scrap metal to third countries and other similar frauds. Every year, 3-4 million old cars "disappear" from the statistics of EU member states. Many are exported and sold illegally as "used cars" to avoid EU waste legislation, which obliges companies to properly dispose of scrap. Such "used cars" mostly end up in landfills and pollute nature.
Verdict: False. The European Union does not plan to ban the repair of cars over 15 years old. The draft law submitted by the Council of Europe never mentions the ban on car repairs or "cars that are more than 15 years old". The purpose of the draft law is to make the life cycle of cars more sustainable and to specify the requirements for the production and disposal of cars. Contrary to what has been said, one of the aims of the bill is to facilitate the repair and recycling of cars.
false_claim: The European Commission is considering a ban on repairing vehicles over 15 years old.

content:
No, Bill Gates non vuole abbattere 70 milioni di acri di alberi
Il 12 settembre 2023 è stato pubblicato su Facebook lo screenshot di un presunto articolo intitolato “Bill Gates promuove il piano per abbattere 70 milioni di acri di alberi per ‘combattere il riscaldamento globale’”. Come si legge nel commento dell’autore del post, gli alberi abbattuti verrebbero sepolti perché alcuni scienziati avrebbero dimostrato che «seppellire gli alberi può ridurre il riscaldamento globale». Un contenuto simile circola anche su TikTok.
Si tratta di una notizia falsa.
La notizia che l’imprenditore e filantropo americano Bill Gates sostenga l’abbattimento di milioni di acri di foresta è priva di qualsiasi riscontro. Gates, invece, tramite il suo fondo Break Through Energy dedicato alle scoperte scientifiche in materia di energia pulita a basso costo, nel 2022 ha finanziato Kodama Systems. Si tratta di una startup che, come si legge sul sito web ufficiale dell’azienda, si occupa del diradamento degli alberi per ristabilire equilibrio alle foreste nell’area occidentale degli Stati Uniti d’America. Tagliare gli alberi in maniera selettiva, infatti, viene spiegato sul sito di Kodama Systems, consente di ridurre la densità delle foreste così che gli arbusti possano avere più risorse nutrienti per crescere meglio, ma anche di diminuire gli incendi boschivi. Molte foreste dell’area occidentale degli Stati Uniti d’America, infatti, sono vulnerabili e soggette a forti incendi.
La biomassa derivante dal taglio degli alberi che non può essere destinata al commercio verrà poi effettivamente seppellita perché in questo modo, si legga ancora sul sito della startup, si riduce al minimo l’emissione di anidride carbonica nell’aria. Come ha dichiarato ai fact-checker di Associated Press Alex Reid, portavoce di Bill Gates, la startup Kodama Systems «ha sviluppato sistemi di gestione forestale progettati per aumentare la produttività delle foreste, prevenire incendi catastrofici e aumentare l’imprigionamento di carbonio seppellendo gli alberi morti per immagazzinare in modo permanente il carbonio che hanno assorbito nel corso della loro vita». Reid ha poi aggiunto che le affermazioni per cui Bill Gates ha in progetto di abbattere 70 milioni di acri di alberi «sono false».
Infine, l’informazione dei 70 milioni di acri è stata ripresa e travisata da un articolo di Forbes sulla startup Kodama Systems pubblicato il 28 luglio 2023. Forbes, infatti, attribuisce quella cifra alla quantità di foresta densamente popolata che il servizio forestale (FS) degli Stati Uniti d’America avrebbe in programma di diradare nei prossimi dieci anni per mitigare il rischio di incendi boschivi. James Sedlak, portavoce di Kodama, ha sottolineato ad Associated Press che «ciò non significa abbattere tutti gli alberi in quei acri di terra», e dunque quanto riportato da Forbes «è stato frainteso, portando probabilmente alla narrazione» disinformativa analizzata.
Sedlak ha spiegato infatti che l’obiettivo del servizio forestale e di Kodama è un «diradamento ecologico delle foreste», per cui alcuni alberi a rischio vengono diradati per permettere a quelli sani di crescere. «Anche se può sembrare controintuitivo», il diradamento degli alberi è importante non solo per diminuire la probabilità di incendi boschivi, ma anche per migliorare la salute delle foreste, ha concluso il portavoce della startup.
Translation:
No, Bill Gates doesn't want to cut down 70 million acres of trees
On September 12, 2023, a screenshot of an alleged article titled “Bill Gates Promotes Plan to Cut Down 70 Million Acres of Trees to ‘Fight Global Warming’” was posted on Facebook. As stated in the comment by the author of the post, the felled trees would be buried because some scientists have demonstrated that "burying trees can reduce global warming". Similar content is also circulating on TikTok.
This is fake news.
The news that the American entrepreneur and philanthropist Bill Gates supports the felling of millions of acres of forest is without any corroboration. Gates, however, through his Break Through Energy fund dedicated to scientific discoveries in low-cost clean energy, financed Kodama Systems in 2022. It is a startup which, as stated on the company's official website, deals with thinning trees to restore balance to forests in the western area of ​​the United States of America. Cutting trees selectively, in fact, as explained on the Kodama Systems website, allows you to reduce the density of forests so that shrubs can have more nutrient resources to grow better, but also to reduce forest fires. Many forests in the western United States of America, in fact, are vulnerable and subject to heavy fires.
The biomass resulting from the cutting of trees that cannot be used for trade will then actually be buried because in this way, as can be read on the startup's website, the emission of carbon dioxide into the air is reduced to a minimum. As Alex Reid, a spokesperson for Bill Gates, told Associated Press fact-checkers, the startup Kodama Systems "has developed forest management systems designed to increase forest productivity, prevent catastrophic fires and increase carbon sequestration by burying trees dead to permanently store the carbon they have absorbed throughout their lives." Reid then added that claims that Bill Gates plans to clear 70 million acres of trees "are false."
Finally, the information of the 70 million acres was taken and misrepresented from a Forbes article on the startup Kodama Systems published on July 28, 2023. Forbes, in fact, attributes that figure to the amount of densely populated forest that the Forest Service (FS) of the United States of America plans to thin out over the next ten years to mitigate the risk of forest fires. James Sedlak, spokesman for Kodama, stressed to the Associated Press that "this does not mean cutting down all the trees in those acres of land", and therefore what was reported by Forbes "has been misunderstood, probably leading to the disinformative narrative analyzed".
In fact, Sedlak explained that the objective of the forestry service and Kodama is an "ecological thinning of forests", whereby some at-risk trees are thinned to allow healthy ones to grow. “Although it may seem counterintuitive,” tree thinning is important not only to decrease the likelihood of forest fires, but also to improve the health of forests, concluded the startup spokesperson.
false_claim: Bill Gates promoted a controversial plan to cut 70 million acres of trees to combat climate change.

content:
Las fotos falsas de Donald Trump siendo arrestado en Washington D.C. fueron generadas con inteligencia artificial
Por el momento, el expresidente de Estados Unidos no ha sido arrestado por la investigación de los supuestos sobornos a la actriz Stormy Daniels
Circulan por Twitter y Facebook unas imágenes que supuestamente muestran a Donald Trump siendo arrestado en Washington D.C. por los presuntos sobornos a la actriz porno Stormy Daniels, por los que el expresidente estadounidense está siendo investigado. Pero son fotografías falsas.
Las imágenes muestran a Trump forcejeando con varios policías, que le rodean, e incluso tratando de huir. Sin embargo, estas imágenes han sido generadas por inteligencia artificial por un usuario de Twitter, tal y como ha reconocido el autor en una publicación. A fecha de la publicación de este artículo Trump no ha sido detenido.
Las falsas fotos de Trump arrestado en Washington, generadas por inteligencia artificial
“Donald Trump ha sido arrestado en Washington D.C.”, publica en inglés una usuaria en Twitter junto a las imágenes que estamos verificando. “¡Trump huyendo!”, escribe otro usuario en español en Facebook. Pero la realidad es que estas fotos son falsas.
Haciendo una búsqueda en Twitter con palabras clave como ‘picture’ (foto), ‘Trump’ y ‘arrested’ (arrestado) aparece un tuit del periodista Eliot Higgins, fundador del sitio web de periodismo de investigación Bellingcat, donde reconoce la autoría de las fotos.
“Haciendo fotos de Trump siendo arrestado mientras espero al arresto de Trump”, publicó Higgins en su cuenta de Twitter el pasado 20 de marzo, fecha anterior al resto de publicaciones que comparten las imágenes. En otro tuit aclara que lo ha hecho a través de la herramienta de inteligencia artificial Midjourney (versión 5) para crearla.
Making pictures of Trump getting arrested while waiting for Trump’s arrest. pic.twitter.com/4D2QQfUpLZ
— Eliot Higgins (@EliotHiggins) March 20, 2023
De hecho, uno de los tuits más virales que comparten las imágenes está acompañado de una nota de la propia red social donde aclara que el expresidente no ha sido arrestado y enlaza al tuit de Higgins donde reconoce su autoría.
Las fotografías contienen detalles extraños que muestran que son falsas
En las falsas fotos del supuesto arresto de Trump en Washington que están circulando también se pueden apreciar detalles extraños que dan pistas de que han sido generadas por inteligencia artificial. Por ejemplo, en la imagen de la izquierda se observa que el expresidente estadounidense lleva una porra y un arma propia de los policías. También se observa que el pelo de Trump tiene una textura artificial y no encaja con el resto del cuerpo.
En la foto de la derecha se puede ver que las manos de los policías presentan formas extrañas o, directamente, no están definidas, algo habitual en las imágenes generadas por inteligencia artificial.
Sin registros de que Trump haya sido arrestado en Washington
A la fecha de publicación de este artículo, no hay registro de que Trump haya sido arrestado. El expresidente está siendo investigado por unos presuntos sobornos a la estrella del porno Stormy Daniels en la campaña electoral de las presidenciales de 2016. El presunto objetivo era comprar su silencio y que esta no hablase sobre unos encuentros sexuales que mantuvieron en 2006.
Trump anunció en su cuenta de Truth Social que iba a ser detenido y urgía a sus seguidores a protestar y “recuperar la nación”. Pero, por el momento, no ha sido arrestado.
Por tanto, no es cierto que Trump haya sido detenido en Washington y las imágenes que se comparten han sido generadas por inteligencia artificial. También han circulado otras fotografías donde supuestamente el republicano es arrestado tras una redada del FBI en su resort en Mar-A-Lago, estado de Florida. Sin embargo, como verificamos en Newtral.es, también se trataban de imágenes hechas a través de inteligencia artificial.
Fuentes
Tuit original con las imágenes generadas por inteligencia artificial
Búsqueda de Twitter
Translation:
The fake photos of Donald Trump being arrested in Washington D.C. were generated with artificial intelligence
At the moment, the former president of the United States has not been arrested for the investigation of alleged bribes to actress Stormy Daniels
Images circulating on Twitter and Facebook that supposedly show Donald Trump being arrested in Washington D.C. for alleged bribes to porn actress Stormy Daniels, for which the former US president is being investigated. But they are fake photographs.
The images show Trump struggling with several police officers, who surround him, and even trying to flee. However, these images have been generated by artificial intelligence by a Twitter user, as the author has acknowledged in a publication. As of the publication of this article, Trump has not been arrested.
The fake photos of Trump arrested in Washington, generated by artificial intelligence
“Donald Trump has been arrested in Washington D.C.”, a user publishes in English on Twitter along with the images that we are verifying. “Trump fleeing!” writes another user in Spanish on Facebook. But the reality is that these photos are fake.
Doing a search on Twitter with keywords such as 'picture' (photo), 'Trump' and 'arrested', a tweet from journalist Eliot Higgins, founder of the investigative journalism website Bellingcat, appears, where he acknowledges the authorship of the photos.
“Taking photos of Trump being arrested while I wait for Trump's arrest,” Higgins posted on his Twitter account on March 20, a date before the rest of the publications that share the images. In another tweet he clarifies that he has done it through the artificial intelligence tool Midjourney (version 5) to create it.
Making pictures of Trump getting arrested while waiting for Trump's arrest. pic.twitter.com/4D2QQfUpLZ
— Eliot Higgins (@EliotHiggins) March 20, 2023
In fact, one of the most viral tweets that share the images is accompanied by a note from the social network itself where it clarifies that the former president has not been arrested and links to Higgins' tweet where he acknowledges his authorship.
The photographs contain strange details that show that they are fake
In the fake photos of Trump's alleged arrest in Washington that are circulating, you can also see strange details that give clues that they have been generated by artificial intelligence. For example, in the image on the left you can see that the former US president is carrying a baton and a police weapon. It is also noted that Trump's hair has an artificial texture and does not fit with the rest of his body.
In the photo on the right you can see that the police officers' hands have strange shapes or are not clearly defined, something common in images generated by artificial intelligence.
No record of Trump being arrested in Washington
As of this article's publication, there is no record of Trump being arrested. The former president is being investigated for alleged bribes to porn star Stormy Daniels in the 2016 presidential election campaign. The alleged objective was to buy her silence and keep her from talking about sexual encounters they had in 2006.
Trump announced on his Truth Social account that he was going to be arrested and urged his followers to protest and “take back the nation.” But, at the moment, he has not been arrested.
Therefore, it is not true that Trump has been detained in Washington and the images that are shared have been generated by artificial intelligence. Other photographs have also circulated where the Republican is supposedly arrested after an FBI raid on his resort in Mar-A-Lago, Florida. However, as we verified at Newtral.es, they were also images made through artificial intelligence.
Sources
Original tweet with images generated by artificial intelligence
Twitter Search
false_claim: Images showing Trump being arrested.

content:
Propaganda über angebliche ukrainische Nazis
26. November 2022Spätestens seit Beginn des russischen Angriffskriegs auf die Ukraine verbreitet sich die Erzählung, dass viele Ukrainer dem Nationalsozialismus zugetan sind. In bekannten Propaganda-Kanälen wie beispielsweise der Telegram-Gruppe "Neues aus Russland", die von der angeblich unabhängigen Journalistin Alina Lipp betrieben wird, findet man Behauptungen zu ukrainischen Nazis en masse. Solche Postings haben Einfluss - alleine Lipps Kanal abonnieren immerhin über 183.000 Menschen (Stand 25. November).
Eine einfache Suchanfrage darin ergibt, dass das Wort "Nazi" 285 Mal vorkommt, "Nationalsozialismus" 22 Mal und "Hakenkreuz" 17 Mal (Stand 25. November).
Doch was hat es mit dem Narrativ ukrainischer Nazis auf sich? Und was ist mit den angeblichen Beweisen, die prorussische Accounts in den Sozialen Medien verbreiten?
1. Behauptung: Ein in einem Tweet verbreitetes Video, das angeblich vom arabischen Nachrichtensender Al Jazeera stammt, handelt davon, dass drei betrunkene Ukrainer Nazi-Symbole bei der Fußballweltmeisterschaft in Katar verbreitet haben.
DW-Faktencheck: Falsch
Auch der russische Propagandist und Journalist Vladimir Solovyov verbreitet das Video auf seinem Telegram-Kanal , allein dort wird es fast 400.000 Mal angeschaut (Stand 25. November 2022). Im Stil des Mediums Al Jazeera wird in dem Video darüber berichtet, dass drei Ukrainer einen Hitlerbart auf ein Graffiti des Maskottchens der FIFA-Fußball-WM gemalt und einen Hitlergruß daneben geschrieben hätten. Zudem hätten die drei Ukrainer zehn Poster in der Umgebung des Fußballstadions Al Bayt zerstört, heißt es in dem Video. Sie seien dann festgenommen worden, ohne sich zu wehren.
Bei dem Video und handelt es sich um eine Fälschung, wie unsere Recherche zeigt und Al Jazeera selbst in einem eigenen Faktencheck erklärt.
In dem Clip sind das Logo von Al Jazeera zu sehen sowie Schriftarten, die denen der originalen Videos des Mediums (ein Beispiel hier) sehr ähnlich sehen. In dem Video selbst werden die drei angeblichen ukrainischen Fans nicht gezeigt, sondern nur Beispielbilder von ukrainischen Fans. Im Journalismus ist das teilweise zwar üblich, interessant ist aber, dass keine näheren Details zu den Männern gemacht werden - was stutzig machen kann, denn seit der Generalmobilmachung dürfen Männer zwischen 18 und 60 Jahren gar nicht aus der Ukraine ausreisen. Zudem hat sich die ukrainische Mannschaft gar nicht für die WM qualifiziert.
Auffällig ist zudem, dass das Stadion Al Bayt in dem Video falsch geschrieben wurde, nämlich El Beit. Bilder von den angeblich zerstörten Postern sind auch nicht zu sehen. Es wird auch eine Szene gezeigt, wie die ukrainischen Fans angeblich festgenommen werden - die Kleidung der Polizisten entspricht aber nicht der Kleidung der Ordnungshüter, die laut katarischem Innenministerium für die Fußball-WM eingesetzt wird.
Lädt man das Abzeichen, das auf dem Arm eines der angeblichen Polizisten zu sehen ist, in einer Bilderrückwärtssuche hoch, gelangt man auf verschiedene Webseiten, die darauf hinweisen, dass es sich um ein Militär-Abzeichen handelt. Aus welchem Land, ist aber nicht klar.
Fazit: Das Video wurde von diversen Faktencheckern überprüft und ist falsch. Auch Al Jazeera als angeblicher Urheber bestätigt die Fälschung.
2. Behauptung: "Einige ukrainische Kämpfer tragen als Zeichen ihres Engagements für den Neonazismus den Slogan 'Jedem das seine' auf ihrem Helm", schreibt die bereits erwähnte Alina Lipp in ihrem Telegram-Kanal und veröffentlicht dazu ein Foto, das als Beweis dienen soll.
DW-Faktencheck: Falsch
Das Foto ist klar manipuliert, wie unsere Recherche zeigt. Der Spruch "Jedem das Seine"prangte am Haupttor des Konzentrationslagers Buchenwald und ist seitdem nationalsozialistisch belastet. Er deutet die rechtsextreme und nationalsozialistische Auffassung an, dass jeder angeblich bekomme, was er verdiene.
Die Aufschrift wurde mit einer Bildbearbeitungssoftware auf den Helm des Soldaten draufgesetzt, wie eine Bilderrückwärtssuche zeigt. Zudem wurde das Originalfoto gespiegelt.
Und die Männer auf dem Foto sind nicht unbekannt: Es handelt sich um die ukrainische Band Antytila, die mittlerweile nicht mehr nur singt, sondern auch im russischen Angriffskrieg die Ukraine verteidigt. International bekannt wurde die Band, da sie während des Kriegs zusammen mit dem Musiker Ed Sheeran einen Remix des Songs "2 Step" aufnahmen. Dabei verwendeten internationale Medien wie die Washington Post das Foto als Titelbild, auf dem die Bandmitglieder Soldatenuniform tragen.
3. Behauptung: In einer ukrainischen Shoppingmall gebe es eine Treppe mit einem großen Hakenkreuz darauf - das impliziert ein Video, das unter anderem von diesem Twitter-Nutzer verbreitet wird.
DW-Faktencheck: Irreführend
In einem Einkaufszentrum namens Gorodok in Kiew leuchtet anscheinend ein riesiges LED-Hakenkreuz auf einer Treppe und weiter oben ein großes rotes Herz, wie das immer wieder in sozialen Netzwerken geteilte Video zeigt.
Tatsächlich ist das Video authentisch - aber irreführend. Laut einem Statement des Einkaufszentrums, das drei Tage später auf Facebook veröffentlicht wurde, ereignete sich der Vorfall schon am 16. Februar 2019, gegen 13.30 Uhr. Hacker sollen für das LED-Hakenkreuz verantwortlich sein. Ein Wachmann habe führende Stellen direkt benachrichtigt, nachdem ihm das Nazi-Symbol auf der Leuchttreppe aufgefallen sei. Dann habe das Einkaufszentrum die Beleuchtung sofort ausgemacht.
Der Fall ist damals an Ermittlungsbehörden weitergegeben worden. Am 29. Juli 2019 teilte die Staatsanwaltschaft Kiew in einer Pressemitteilung mit, dass ein 17-Jähriger mit der Software "TeamViewer" auf das Computersystem zugegriffen hätte. Das Symbol der Software ist auf dem Video zu sehen.
Das Passwort des Systems ist laut Staatsanwaltschaft kurzzeitig zu sehen gewesen, was der Jugendliche ausgenutzt hat, um sich einzuwählen und das Hakenkreuz einzublenden. In der Ukraine ist es verboten, nationalsozialistische Symbole öffentlich zu verbreiten. Zu dem kursierenden Video wurden schon zahlreiche Faktenchecks veröffentlicht.
Fazit: Tatsächlich wurde in dem Einkaufszentrum in Kiew für wenige Minuten ein Hakenkreuz eingeblendet. Bei dem Vorfall handelt es sich aber um einen Hackerangriff und keine Langzeit-LED-Beleuchtung.
Auch Putin verbreitet das Narrativ der ukrainischen Nazis
Fakt ist also: Viele der Behauptungen über angebliche ukrainische Nazis sind erfunden oder irreführend. Das Narrativ hält sich dennoch, weil Wladimir Putin und russische Propagandisten immer wieder Falschinformationen darüber verbreiten.
Schon in seiner Rede (hier im DW-Faktencheck) kurz vor dem Angriff auf die Ukraine Ende Februar sprach Wladimir Putin davon, dass Russland die Ukraine "entnazifizieren" müsse. Die sogenannte Entnazifizierung ist ein historischer Begriff, der auf die Politik der alliierten Siegermächte für Nazi-Deutschland nach dem Zweiten Weltkrieg verweist. Sie wollten das Land von nationalsozialistischen Einflüssen befreien und entsprechend belastete Personen aus ihren Ämtern entfernen.
Der Vergleich zur Ukraine ist jedoch falsch, sagte Andreas Umland schon im Februar im DW-Interview: "Dieses Gerede über Nazismus in der Ukraine ist völlig fehl am Platz." Umland ist Analyst am Stockholm Centre for Eastern European Studies (SCEEUS). "Der Präsident der Ukraine ist ein russischsprachiger Jude, der mit einem Riesenergebnis die letzten Präsidentschaftswahlen gegen einen nicht-jüdischen ukrainischen Kandidaten gewonnen hat."
Zwar gebe es auch in der Ukraine rechtsextreme Gruppierungen, diese seien aber im Vergleich zu vielen europäischen Ländern relativ schwach: "Wir hatten eine Einheitsfront aller rechtsradikalen Parteien bei den letzten Parlamentswahlen 2019 und da hat diese Einheitsfront 2,15 Prozent bekommen."
Was hat es mit dem Asow-Regiment auf sich?
Kritisiert wurden in der Vergangenheit auch rechte ukrainische Kampfverbände, die gegen die Separatisten im Osten der Ukraine kämpfen - vor allem das Regiment Asow. Dieses sei zwar von einer rechtsextremen Gruppierung gegründet, im Herbst 2014 aber in die Truppen des Innenministeriums, die Nationalgarde, eingegliedert worden, sagt Andreas Umland. Danach sei eine Trennung von Bewegung und Regiment erfolgt - letzteres verwende zwar noch entsprechende Symbole, werde aber nicht mehr dem Rechtsextremismus zugeordnet. Bei Ausbildungskursen für Militärs seien hin und wieder rechtsextreme Soldaten aufgefallen, so Umland, aber: "Das ist dann aufgedeckt und skandalisiert worden."
Translation:
Propaganda about alleged Ukrainian Nazis
November 26, 2022Since the beginning of the Russian war of aggression on Ukraine, the narrative has been spreading that many Ukrainians are loyal to National Socialism. In well-known propaganda channels such as the Telegram group "News from Russia", which is run by the supposedly independent journalist Alina Lipp, you can find allegations about Ukrainian Nazis en masse. Such postings have an influence - over 183,000 people subscribe to Lipp's channel alone (as of November 25th).
A simple search query shows that the word "Nazi" appears 285 times, "National Socialism" 22 times and "swastika" 17 times (as of November 25th).
But what is the narrative of Ukrainian Nazis all about? And what about the alleged evidence that pro-Russian social media accounts are spreading?
Claim 1: A video shared in a tweet purporting to be from Arabic news channel Al Jazeera shows three drunk Ukrainians spreading Nazi symbols at the World Cup in Qatar.
DW Fact Check: False
The Russian propagandist and journalist Vladimir Solovyov also spread the video on his Telegram channel, where it alone has been viewed almost 400,000 times (as of November 25, 2022). In the style of the media Al Jazeera, the video reports that three Ukrainians painted a Hitler beard on graffiti of the FIFA World Cup mascot and wrote a Hitler salute next to it. The three Ukrainians also destroyed ten posters in the area around the Al Bayt football stadium, the video says. They were then arrested without resisting.
The video is a fake, as our research shows and Al Jazeera itself explains in its own fact check.
The clip features Al Jazeera's logo and fonts that look very similar to those in the medium's original videos (an example here). The three alleged Ukrainian fans are not shown in the video itself, only sample images of Ukrainian fans. This is sometimes common in journalism, but what is interesting is that no further details are given about the men - which can be suspicious, because since the general mobilization, men between the ages of 18 and 60 are not allowed to leave Ukraine. In addition, the Ukrainian team did not qualify for the World Cup at all.
It is also noticeable that the Al Bayt stadium was misspelled in the video, namely El Beit. Pictures of the allegedly destroyed posters cannot be seen either. A scene is also shown of the Ukrainian fans allegedly being arrested - but the police officers' clothing does not correspond to the clothing of the law enforcement officers that, according to the Qatari Interior Ministry, will be used for the World Cup.
If you upload the badge that can be seen on the arm of one of the alleged police officers into a reverse image search, you will be taken to various websites that indicate that it is a military badge. But it is not clear from which country.
Conclusion: The video has been checked by various fact checkers and is incorrect. Al Jazeera, as the alleged author, also confirms the fake.
2. Claim: "Some Ukrainian fighters wear the slogan 'To each his own' on their helmets as a sign of their commitment to neo-Nazism," writes the aforementioned Alina Lipp in her Telegram channel and publishes a photo that is intended to serve as evidence .
DW Fact Check: False
The photo is clearly manipulated, as our research shows. The motto "To each his own" was emblazoned on the main gate of the Buchenwald concentration camp and has been under Nazi influence ever since. He hints at the right-wing extremist and National Socialist view that everyone supposedly gets what they deserve.
The inscription was placed on the soldier's helmet using image editing software, as a reverse image search shows. In addition, the original photo was mirrored.
And the men in the photo are not unknown: they are the Ukrainian band Antytila, which no longer only sings, but also defends Ukraine in the Russian war of aggression. The band became internationally known because they recorded a remix of the song "2 Step" with the musician Ed Sheeran during the war. International media such as the Washington Post used the photo as a cover photo, in which the band members are wearing soldiers' uniforms.
3. Claim: In a Ukrainian shopping mall there is a staircase with a large swastika on it - this is implied by a video that was distributed by this Twitter user, among others.
DW fact check: misleading
In a shopping center called Gorodok in Kiev, a huge LED swastika appears to be glowing on a staircase and, further up, a large red heart, as the video repeatedly shared on social networks shows.
In fact, the video is authentic - but misleading. According to a statement from the shopping center that was published on Facebook three days later, the incident occurred on February 16, 2019, around 1:30 p.m. Hackers are said to be responsible for the LED swastika. A security guard notified leading authorities directly after he noticed the Nazi symbol on the illuminated staircase. Then the shopping center immediately turned off the lights.
The case was then passed on to the investigating authorities. On July 29, 2019, the Kiev public prosecutor's office announced in a press release that a 17-year-old had accessed the computer system using the "TeamViewer" software. The software icon can be seen in the video.
According to the public prosecutor's office, the system's password was briefly visible, which the teenager took advantage of to log in and display the swastika. In Ukraine it is forbidden to publicly distribute Nazi symbols. Numerous fact checks have already been published about the circulating video.
Conclusion: A swastika was actually displayed in the shopping center in Kiev for a few minutes. However, the incident was a hacker attack and not long-term LED lighting.
Putin also spreads the Ukrainian Nazi narrative
The fact is: many of the claims about alleged Ukrainian Nazis are fabricated or misleading. The narrative still persists because Vladimir Putin and Russian propagandists continue to spread misinformation about it.
In his speech (here in the DW fact check) shortly before the attack on Ukraine at the end of February, Vladimir Putin spoke of Russia having to "denazify" Ukraine. The so-called denazification is a historical term that refers to the policy of the Allied victorious powers for Nazi Germany after the Second World War. They wanted to free the country from National Socialist influences and remove people with corresponding burdens from their offices.
However, the comparison to Ukraine is wrong, Andreas Umland said in an interview with DW in February: "This talk about Nazism in Ukraine is completely out of place." Umland is an analyst at the Stockholm Center for Eastern European Studies (SCEEUS). "The President of Ukraine is a Russian-speaking Jew who won the last presidential election by a huge margin against a non-Jewish Ukrainian candidate."
Although there are also right-wing extremist groups in Ukraine, they are relatively weak compared to many European countries: "We had a united front of all right-wing radical parties in the last parliamentary elections in 2019 and this united front got 2.15 percent."
What is the Azov Regiment all about?
Right-wing Ukrainian combat units fighting against the separatists in eastern Ukraine have also been criticized in the past - especially the Azov Regiment. This was founded by a right-wing extremist group, but was integrated into the Interior Ministry's troops, the National Guard, in autumn 2014, says Andreas Umland. After that, the movement and the regiment were separated - the latter still uses corresponding symbols, but is no longer associated with right-wing extremism. According to Umland, right-wing extremist soldiers were occasionally noticed during training courses for military personnel, but: "It was then discovered and scandalized."
false_claim: Claims of Ukrainian supporters displaying Nazi symbols during the Qatar World Championship.

content:
Jorge Ocaña y Jesús Montanero
¿Qué verificamos?
La UE autoriza agregar cualquier insecto a los alimentos y sin informar en el etiquetado.
Conclusión
La Comisión Europea ha autorizado a dos empresas la comercialización de dos especies de insectos y obliga a un correcto etiquetado de los productos.
EFE Madrid |
La Unión Europea (UE) no ha autorizado añadir cualquier insecto a alimentos de forma generalizada y sin que se advierta en el etiquetado, como aseguran mensajes en redes sociales que tergiversan la autorización de la Comisión Europea a un par de empresas para comercializar dos especies de insectos.
Publicaciones en redes sociales, principalmente en Twitter, Facebook, Telegram y TikTok, advierten que la Unión Europea ha autorizado la «inclusión de insectos» en los alimentos «sin indicarlo», por lo que la población los comerá «en pizzas, galletas, panes y pasteles».
Los insectos autorizados serían el grillo doméstico y larvas del escarabajo del estiércol, según los mensajes, que alertan de que el bloque comunitario tampoco «ve necesario registrar requisitos específicos de etiquetado sobre posibles reacciones alérgicas». Por ello, aseguran que toda la población va a «comer insectos sin saberlo a partir de ahora».
Este contenido, que ha circulado también en inglés, francés y alemán, se difunde en la misma línea que otras publicaciones que aseguran que la Agenda 2030 busca prohibir la carne e imponer una dieta alimentaria basada en el consumo de insectos.
La UE no ha autorizado añadir cualquier insecto a los alimentos
La Comisión Europea no permite agregar insectos a cualquier alimento. Recientemente autorizó a dos empresas la comercialización de larvas del escarabajo del estiércol y grillos comunes en polvo, que se suman a otros dos insectos permitidos. El reglamento comunitario obliga a informar en el etiquetado si un alimento los contiene para prevenir reacciones alérgicas.
El Ejecutivo comunitario dio luz verde el 3 de enero a la comercialización de la «Acheta domesticus» (grillo doméstico) en forma de polvo parcialmente desgrasado como ingrediente alimentario. De hecho, ampliaba así una autorización previa de febrero de 2022 que permitía la venta de este insecto congelado, en seco y en polvo.
El reglamento comunitario especifica que la autorización se limita exclusivamente a la empresa vietnamita Cricket One Co, aunque señala que otras empresas podrán «solicitar que se les permita la venta de este nuevo alimento».
Del mismo modo, la CE autorizó el 5 de enero a la empresa francesa Ynsect NL B.V. comercializar de forma congelada, en pasta, desecada y en polvo las larvas de «Alphitobius diaperinus» (escarabajo del estiércol) para consumo humano.
Pese a lo que afirman los mensajes engañosos, ambos reglamentos obligan a las empresas a etiquetar debidamente los alimentos que contengan cualquiera de estos insectos para informar de su presencia y sus posibles reacciones alérgicas.
Fuentes de la Comisión Europea recalcan a EFE Verifica que la «información sobre alérgenos debe estar siempre a disposición del consumidor» y que la aplicación de estas normas «es responsabilidad de los Estados miembros».
Las dos empresas podrán agregar los insectos -siempre etiquetándolos- a alimentos como panes, barritas de cereales, sopas, etc., recogidos en el reglamento comunitario, el cual especifica además cuántos gramos pueden emplearse como ingrediente.
Organismos y expertos avalan su seguridad
Hasta la fecha, la Comisión Europea ha autorizado la comercialización de cuatro insectos para consumo humano dentro del territorio de la Unión Europea (larvas del escarabajo del estiércol, gusano de la harina, la langosta migratoria y el grillo doméstico).
Para aprobarlos, los nuevos alimentos son sometidos a una estricta evaluación científica de seguridad por parte de la Autoridad Europea de Seguridad Alimentaria (EFSA, en inglés), una agencia de la Unión Europea que asesora sobre posibles riesgos alimentarios.
De hecho, este organismo emitió sendas resoluciones certificando la seguridad de esos insectos para el consumo humano.
Victorio Teruel, subdirector General de Gestión de la Seguridad Alimentaria de la Agencia Española de Seguridad Alimentaria y Nutrición (AESAN), explica a EFE Verifica que los recientes permisos significan «que los insectos actualmente autorizados son seguros».
Asimismo, señala que «en Europa se está empezando a introducir» el consumo de insectos porque los aprobados «tienen un alto valor nutritivo, aportan proteínas de alta calidad, otros micronutrientes (vitaminas y minerales) y fibra alimentaria (quitina)».
La quitina no produce cáncer
Precisamente, numerosos mensajes en redes aseguran que el consumo de quitina puede producir cáncer. Pero, como explica Teruel, este compuesto «no supone ningún riesgo para el consumidor».
«En las evaluaciones del riesgo de la EFSA se valoran estudios toxicológicos, en concreto sobre genotoxicidad (el posible daño a material genético), no habiendo indicios sobre las afirmaciones que se mencionan para la quitina», agrega.
Richard Locksley, médico inmunólogo e investigador del Instituto Médico Howard Hughes, coincide en que el consumo de quitina no supone un riesgo para la población, puesto que el ser humano dispone de enzimas capaces de descomponerlo «tanto en el intestino como en las vías respiratorias».
Solo en el caso de personas con enfermedades pulmonares crónicas graves «la quitina inhalada podría causar inflamación», subraya a EFE Verifica.
En definitiva, la UE no ha autorizado añadir cualquier insecto a los alimentos; el reglamento europeo permite a dos empresas la comercialización de dos especies de insectos y obliga a un correcto etiquetado de los productos, mientras que su consumo es seguro.
Fuentes:
Comisión Europea.
Victorio Teruel, subdirector General de Gestión de la Seguridad Alimentaria de la Agencia Española de Seguridad Alimentaria y Nutrición (AESAN).
Richard Locksley, médico inmunólogo e investigador del Instituto Médico Howard Hughes.
Reglamento de Ejecución (UE) 2023/5 de la Comisión de 3 de enero de 2023.
Reglamento de Ejecución (UE) 2023/58 de la Comisión de 5 de enero de 2023.
Translation:
Jorge Ocaña and Jesús Montanero
What do we verify?
The EU authorizes adding any insect to food without informing it on the label.
Conclusion
The European Commission has authorized two companies to market two species of insects and requires correct labeling of the products.
EFE Madrid |
The European Union (EU) has not authorized adding any insect to foods in a general way and without warning on the labeling, as claimed by messages on social networks that misrepresent the authorization of the European Commission to a couple of companies to market two species of insects.
Publications on social networks, mainly on Twitter, Facebook, Telegram and TikTok, warn that the European Union has authorized the "inclusion of insects" in food "without indicating it", so the population will eat them "on pizzas, cookies, breads and cakes.
The authorized insects would be the house cricket and larvae of the dung beetle, according to the messages, which warn that the community block also "does not see it necessary to register specific labeling requirements on possible allergic reactions." For this reason, they assure that the entire population will "eat insects without knowing it from now on."
This content, which has also circulated in English, French and German, is disseminated in the same vein as other publications that claim that the 2030 Agenda seeks to ban meat and impose a diet based on the consumption of insects.
The EU has not authorized adding any insects to food
The European Commission does not allow insects to be added to any food. It recently authorized two companies to market dung beetle larvae and common crickets in powder form, in addition to two other permitted insects. Community regulations require information on the labeling if a food contains them to prevent allergic reactions.
The Community Executive gave the green light on January 3 to the marketing of "Acheta domesticus" (domestic cricket) in the form of a partially defatted powder as a food ingredient. In fact, it thus extended a prior authorization from February 2022 that allowed the sale of this frozen, dry and powdered insect.
The community regulation specifies that the authorization is limited exclusively to the Vietnamese company Cricket One Co, although it notes that other companies may "request to be allowed to sell this new food."
Similarly, on January 5, the EC authorized the French company Ynsect NL B.V. market frozen, paste, dried and powdered larvae of "Alphitobius diaperinus" (dung beetle) for human consumption.
Despite what the misleading messages claim, both regulations require companies to properly label foods that contain any of these insects to report their presence and possible allergic reactions.
Sources from the European Commission emphasize to EFE Verifies that "information on allergens must always be available to the consumer" and that the application of these standards "is the responsibility of the Member States."
The two companies will be able to add the insects - always labeling them - to foods such as breads, cereal bars, soups, etc., included in the community regulation, which also specifies how many grams can be used as an ingredient.
Organizations and experts guarantee its safety
To date, the European Commission has authorized the marketing of four insects for human consumption within the territory of the European Union (larvae of the dung beetle, mealworm, migratory locust and house cricket).
To be approved, new foods are subjected to a strict scientific safety evaluation by the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA), an agency of the European Union that advises on possible food risks.
In fact, this organization issued resolutions certifying the safety of these insects for human consumption.
Victorio Teruel, Deputy Director General of Food Safety Management of the Spanish Agency for Food Safety and Nutrition (AESAN), explains to EFE Verifica that the recent permits mean "that the currently authorized insects are safe."
Likewise, he points out that "in Europe the consumption of insects is beginning to be introduced" because those approved "have a high nutritional value, provide high-quality proteins, other micronutrients (vitamins and minerals) and dietary fiber (chitin)."
Chitin does not cause cancer
Precisely, numerous messages on networks claim that the consumption of chitin can cause cancer. But, as Teruel explains, this compound "does not pose any risk to the consumer."
"In the EFSA risk assessments, toxicological studies are assessed, specifically on genotoxicity (possible damage to genetic material), there being no evidence on the claims mentioned for chitin," he adds.
Richard Locksley, an immunologist and researcher at the Howard Hughes Medical Institute, agrees that the consumption of chitin does not pose a risk to the population, since humans have enzymes capable of breaking it down "both in the intestine and in the respiratory tract." .
Only in the case of people with severe chronic lung diseases "inhaled chitin could cause inflammation," Verifica points out to EFE.
In short, the EU has not authorized adding any insect to food; The European regulation allows two companies to market two species of insects and requires correct labeling of the products, while their consumption is safe.
Sources:
European Commission.
Victorio Teruel, Deputy Director General of Food Safety Management of the Spanish Agency for Food Safety and Nutrition (AESAN).
Richard Locksley, immunologist and researcher at the Howard Hughes Medical Institute.
Commission Implementing Regulation (EU) 2023/5 of 3 January 2023.
Commission Implementing Regulation (EU) 2023/58 of 5 January 2023.
false_claim: The EU intends to mandate its citizens to consume insects as food.

content:
Príspevok na Facebooku tvrdí, že vo Švajčiarsku zakázali mamografiu, ktorá vraj spôsobuje rakovinu prsníka a viac ako polovica výsledkov vyšetrenia je nesprávnych. Švajčiarsko však mamografické skríningy nezakázalo, stále sú súčasťou prevencie voči rakovine. Nepravdivé sú taktiež tvrdenia, že vyšetrenie spôsobuje vznik rakoviny a šírenie metastáz. Štúdia, na ktorú sa príspevok odvoláva, hovorí o detekcii rakoviny, nie o jej vzniku. Výsledky mamografického vyšetrenia sú správne identifikované u asi 87 % žien, ktoré majú rakovinu prsníka, diagnózu určia lekári aj na základe ďalších testov.
Príspevok šíriaci sa na sociálnej sieti Facebook tvrdí, že vo Švajčiarsku zakázali mamografiu. V príspevku sa uvádza, že až 50-60 % pozitívnych výsledkov z mamografického vyšetrenia je nesprávnych, a že vyšetrenie stimuluje rast nádoru a šírenie metastáz. Príspevok sa taktiež odvoláva na štúdiu, ktorá vraj na 690 000 “záznamoch” ukázala, že u zdravých žien sa po mamografickom vyšetrení vo veľkom počte prípadov vyvinula rakovina prsníka.
Príspevok neuvádza žiadne zdroje, ani konkrétnych autorov, v našom texte preto budeme vychádzať z nami vyhľadaných verejne dostupných dát a štúdií.
Mamografia
Mamografia je lekárske vyšetrenie, ktoré pomáha odhaliť mnohé prípady rakoviny prsníka v ranom štádiu, vďaka čomu zvyšuje šancu na vyliečenie.
Skríning rakoviny prsníka predstavuje medzinárodný štandard pre včasnú detekciu rakoviny. Mamografia dokáže odhaliť príznaky rakoviny 2 alebo 3 roky predtým, ako ju dokáže rozpoznať pacient alebo lekár. Na Slovensku sa odporúča, aby každá žena vo veku nad 40 rokov absolvovala toto vyšetrenie aspoň raz za dva roky.
Švajčiarsko nezakázalo mamografiu
Pri vyhľadávaní na spravodajských weboch, či na oficiálnej stránke švajčiarskeho Federálneho úradu verejného zdravotníctva nie je možné dohľadať žiadnu informácie o tom, že by Švajčiarsko mamografiu zakázalo, Pravidelné absolvovanie tohto vyšetrenia je naopak stále odporúčané ako vo Švajčiarsku tak aj u nás.
Vo väčšine švajčiarskych kantónov, je zavedený program skríningu rakoviny prsníka, na ktorom sa môžu zúčastniť všetky ženy vo veku od 50 rokov. Účasť na vyšetrení je dobrovoľná a pozvané ženy sa na ňom zúčastniť nemusia, ak nechcú. Vyšetrenie je väčšinovo hradené zo základného zdravotného poistenia.
Doktorka Michelle Wrightová, riaditeľka švajčiarskej spoločnosti HealthFirst Sàrl, ktorá poskytuje školenia prvej pomoci vysvetľuje, že každá žena, ktorá žije v kantóne s programom skríningu, dostane písomnú pozvánku na účasť, keď dosiahne 50 rokov. Tieto pozvánky žena obdrží každé 2 roky až do veku 70 rokov v niektorých kantónoch 74 rokov.
Nezisková organizácia Swiss cancer screening, ktorá robí osvetu v oblasti prevencie rakoviny, na našu otázku k situácii vo Švajčiarsku ohľadom mamografických vyšetrení uviedla: „Organizovaný skríning rakoviny prsníka sa vo Švajčiarsku stále odporúča a nemáme žiadne poznatky o zrušení mamografického skríningu vo Švajčiarsku.“
Správa Švajčiarskej lekárskej rady
Tvrdenia v príspevku pravdepodobne vychádzajú zo staršej správy Švajčiarskej lekárskej rady, ktorá dospela k záveru, že systematické skríningy mamografom neodporúča. Švajčiarska lekárska rada je mimovládna organizácia a jej odporúčania nie sú právne záväzné. Správa bolo skritizovaná ostatnými odborníkmi a jej závery neboli nikdy implementované.
Švajčiarska lekárska rada vydala v roku 2013 správu, v ktorej sa uvádza, že systematické mamografické skríningové programy na včasnú detekciu rakoviny prsníka neodporúča. Rada dospela k záveru, že účinnosť mamografie je stále neistá a nadmerná diagnostika a falošne pozitívne testy spôsobujú škody a skríningové programy majú nepriaznivý pomer nákladovej efektívnosti (.pdf, str. 52–53).
V reakcii na tieto nové odporúčania sa viaceré významné švajčiarske osobnosti, odborníci a organizácie vyjadrili, že správu považujú za „chybnú a zavádzajúcu“ a že by mohla zmiasť ženy a stáť ich život. Navyše, štúdia publikovaná v podobnom čase ako správa Švajčiarskej lekárskej rady, predložila úplne opačný pohľad na skríning rakoviny prsníka, keď vyhlásila, že jeho prínosy prevažujú nad škodami, ktoré by mohol spôsobiť.
„Existujú skutočné nezhody o nadmernej diagnóze, ale metódy, ktoré zohľadňujú čas prípravy a základné trendy incidencie, poskytujú odhady nadmernej diagnózy, ktoré sú nízke a sú vyvážené prínosom úmrtnosti,“ píše sa v správe.
Odborný časopis JAMA Internal Medicine, ktorý vydáva Americká lekárska asociácia, reagoval na správu Švajčiarskej lekárskej článkom o systematickom skríningu. Autori článku konštatujú, že neexistuje dostatok dôkazov na zrušenie skríningových programov.
Výsledky mamografie sú spoľahlivé
Tvrdenia, že 50 až 60 % pozitívnych výsledkov mamografie je nesprávnych, sú značne nepresné. V skutočnosti je senzitivita mamografie okolo 87 %. To znamená, že výsledky mamografie sú správne identifikované u asi 87 % žien, ktoré majú rakovinu prsníka.
Mamografické vyšetrenie sa odporúča opakovať v pravidelných intervaloch. Podľa štúdií je tak po desiatich ročných mamografiách, aj pri vysokej spoľahlivosti, šanca obdržať aspoň jeden falošne pozitívny výsledok z desiatich asi 50 až 60 %.
Štúdia vedená Kalifornskou univerzitou v Davise zistila, že takmer polovica všetkých žien zažije aspoň jeden falošne pozitívny mamograf za desaťročie každoročného skríningu rakoviny prsníka pomocou digitálnej tomosyntézy. Štúdia však zároveň uznáva, že včasné odhalenie rakoviny prsníka pomocou skríningovej mamografie je kľúčovou stratégiou na zníženie rizika pokročilého karcinómu a úmrtia na toto ochorenie.
Navyše, prvý pozitívny mamografický výsledok automaticky neznamená, že pacientke je diagnostikovaná rakovina prsníka. Pozitívny skríning vedie k ďalšiemu diagnostickému spracovaniu, kedy je pacientka je zavolaná na prešetrenie a aj ďalšie testy. Keď rádiológovia interpretujú výsledky mamografie, snažia sa včas identifikovať potenciálny nádor a následne sa vykonajú ďalšie cielené mamografické snímky a testy.
Švajčiarska mimovládna organizácia Swiss cancer screening uvádza, že výsledky mamografie posudzujú oddelene dvaja rádiológovia, ktorí prešli špecifickým školením a pravidelným sústavným vzdelávaním. Ak sa zistí zmena alebo abnormalita, rádiológovia o snímkach medzi sebou diskutujú a až následne príjmu záver.
Rádiológička Dr. Amy Conners z Mayo Clinic, ktorá patrí k najlepším klinikám v oblasti liečby rakoviny v USA, hovorí, že falošne pozitívne mamografy sú bežnou a očakávanou súčasťou skríningového procesu.
Tlak na prsník a ožarovanie tkaniva
