Príspevok taktiež tvrdí, že pri vyšetrení je prsník stlačený veľkou hmotnosťou a potom je „zdravé, veľmi citlivé tkanivo mliečnej žľazy bombardované rádioaktívnym žiarením“.
Vyšetrenie mamografom zahŕňa ožarovanie prsníka röntgenovými lúčmi, množstvo lúčov je ale v tomto prípade minimálne. Röntgenové lúče, ktoré prenikajú tkanivom, sú oslabené. Mamografia využíva veľmi malé dávky žiarenia – približne na úrovni radiácie, ktorú prijmeme v bežnom živote za šesť mesiacov. Riziko poškodenia z tohto množstva žiarenia je veľmi nízke a podľa odborníkov prínosy prevažujú nad rizikami. Okrem toho ešte nikdy nebol zistený prípad rakoviny prsníka, ktorý by bol spôsobený ožiarením počas mamografie.
Každý prsník sa röntgenuje dvakrát z rôznych uhlov. Na získanie kvalitných snímok a minimalizovanie žiarenia sa prsník krátko stlačí medzi dve platničky, čo môže byť nepríjemné alebo dokonca bolestivé. Odborníci odporúčajú použiť tlak približne 10 kPa, ktorý pomáha pri získavaní kvalitných röntgenových snímok a znižovaní bolesti. Neexistujú žiadne vedecké dôkazy o tom, že stláčanie prsníka spôsobuje rakovinu alebo že by mohlo spôsobiť šírenie rakoviny.
Dezinterpretovaná štúdia
Príspevok taktiež spomína údajnú štúdiu vykonanú na 690 000 záznamoch, ktorá ukázala, že po mamografickom vyšetrení sa u zdravých žien sa vo veľkom počte prípadov vyvinula rakovina prsníka. Príspevok pravdepodobne odkazuje na štúdiu z roku 2000, ktorej závery však značne dezinterpretuje. Štúdia skúmala 690 993 žien vo veku 66 až 79 rokov a jej cieľom bolo zistiť, či staršie ženy, ktoré sa podrobia skríningu, majú nižšie riziko metastázujúceho karcinómu prsníka.
Štúdia konštatuje, že u žien, ktoré podstúpili mamografické vyšetrenie, bola väčšia šanca na odhalenie rakoviny prsníka, nie, že samotné vyšetrenie mohlo rakovinu spôsobiť. Tieto výsledky sa zhodujú s odporúčaniami, že mamografia je jedinou odporúčanou skríningovou metódou na odhalenie včasného štádia rakoviny prsníka. Vo výsledkoch štúdie sa taktiež píše, že skríningová mamografia je spojená so zníženým rizikom detekcie metastatického karcinómu prsníka u starších žien.
Záver
Švajčiarsko mamografické vyšetrenia nezakázalo. Žiarenie pri vyšetrení nie je nebezpečné, nespôsobuje vznik rakoviny, ani šírenie metastáz. Príspevok tiež výrazne zveličuje mieru falošne pozitívnych testov. Štúdia, na ktorú sa príspevok pravdepodobne odvoláva, hovorí o zvýšenej diagnostike rakoviny vďaka mamografickým skríningom, nie o vzniku rakoviny spôsobenej vyšetrením. Príspevok preto v rámci našej spolupráce so spoločnosťou Facebook označujeme ako nepravdivý.
Translation:
A Facebook post claims that mammography has been banned in Switzerland because it is said to cause breast cancer and more than half of the test results are incorrect. However, Switzerland has not banned mammography screenings, they are still part of cancer prevention. Claims that the examination causes the development of cancer and the spread of metastases are also false. The study the post refers to is about cancer detection, not cancer development. The results of the mammographic examination are correctly identified in about 87% of women who have breast cancer, doctors also determine the diagnosis based on other tests.
A post circulating on Facebook claims that they have banned mammography in Switzerland. The paper states that up to 50-60% of positive results from mammography screening are incorrect, and that the screening stimulates tumor growth and the spread of metastases. The post also refers to a study which allegedly showed, based on 690,000 "records", that a large number of healthy women developed breast cancer after a mammographic examination.
The article does not cite any sources or specific authors, so in our text we will base our search on publicly available data and studies.
Mammography
Mammography is a medical examination that helps detect many cases of breast cancer at an early stage, thereby increasing the chance of a cure.
Breast cancer screening is the international standard for early cancer detection. Mammography can detect signs of cancer 2 or 3 years before the patient or doctor can recognize it. In Slovakia, it is recommended that every woman over the age of 40 undergo this examination at least once every two years.
Switzerland has not banned mammography
When searching on news websites or on the official website of the Swiss Federal Office of Public Health, it is not possible to find any information about Switzerland banning mammography, on the contrary, regular completion of this examination is still recommended both in Switzerland and in our country.
In most of the Swiss cantons, a breast cancer screening program is in place, in which all women over the age of 50 can participate. Participation in the examination is voluntary and invited women do not have to participate if they do not want to. The examination is mostly covered by basic health insurance.
Dr. Michelle Wright, director of the Swiss first aid training company HealthFirst Sàrl, explains that every woman who lives in a canton with a screening program receives a written invitation to participate when she turns 50. A woman receives these invitations every 2 years until the age of 70 in some cantons 74 years.
When asked about the situation in Switzerland regarding mammography examinations, the non-profit organization Swiss cancer screening, which raises awareness in the field of cancer prevention, said: "Organized breast cancer screening is still recommended in Switzerland and we have no knowledge of the abolition of mammography screening in Switzerland."
Report of the Swiss Medical Council
The claims in the post are likely based on an older report by the Swiss Medical Council, which concluded that it does not recommend systematic mammography screening. The Swiss Medical Council is a non-governmental organization and its recommendations are not legally binding. The report was criticized by other experts and its conclusions were never implemented.
The Swiss Medical Council issued a report in 2013 stating that it does not recommend systematic mammography screening programs for the early detection of breast cancer. The panel concluded that the effectiveness of mammography is still uncertain and that overdiagnosis and false-positive tests cause harm and that screening programs have an unfavorable cost-effectiveness ratio (.pdf, pp. 52–53).
In response to the new recommendations, a number of prominent Swiss figures, experts and organizations said they considered the report "flawed and misleading" and that it could confuse women and cost them their lives. Moreover, a study published around the same time as the Swiss Medical Council report presented a completely opposite view of breast cancer screening, declaring that its benefits outweigh the harm it could cause.
"There is real disagreement about overdiagnosis, but methods that take into account lead time and underlying incidence trends provide estimates of overdiagnosis that are low and balanced by the mortality benefit," the report says.
The professional journal JAMA Internal Medicine, published by the American Medical Association, responded to the Swiss medical report with an article on systematic screening. The authors of the article state that there is not enough evidence to abolish screening programs.
Mammography results are reliable
Claims that 50 to 60% of positive mammogram results are false are grossly inaccurate. In fact, the sensitivity of mammography is around 87%. This means that mammography results correctly identify about 87% of women who have breast cancer.
Mammographic examination is recommended to be repeated at regular intervals. According to studies, after ten annual mammograms, even with high reliability, the chance of receiving at least one false positive result out of ten is about 50 to 60%.
A study led by the University of California, Davis found that nearly half of all women will experience at least one false-positive mammogram in a decade of annual digital tomosynthesis breast cancer screening. However, the study also acknowledges that early detection of breast cancer through screening mammography is a key strategy to reduce the risk of advanced cancer and death from the disease.
In addition, the first positive mammographic result does not automatically mean that the patient is diagnosed with breast cancer. A positive screening leads to further diagnostic processing, when the patient is called for examination and other tests. When radiologists interpret the results of a mammogram, they try to identify a potential tumor early, and then more targeted mammograms and tests are performed.
The Swiss non-governmental organization Swiss cancer screening states that the mammography results are assessed separately by two radiologists who have undergone specific training and regular continuing education. If a change or abnormality is detected, the radiologists discuss the images with each other and only then come to a conclusion.
Radiologist Dr. Amy Conners of the Mayo Clinic, one of the top cancer clinics in the US, says false-positive mammograms are a normal and expected part of the screening process.
Breast pressure and tissue radiation
The post also claims that during the examination, the breast is compressed by a large weight and then "healthy, highly sensitive mammary gland tissue is bombarded with radioactive radiation."
A mammogram examination involves the irradiation of the breast with X-rays, but the amount of rays is minimal in this case. X-rays that penetrate tissue are weakened. Mammography uses very small doses of radiation - about the level of radiation we receive in a normal life in six months. The risk of harm from this amount of radiation is very low, and experts say the benefits outweigh the risks. In addition, there has never been a known case of breast cancer caused by radiation during mammography.
Each breast is X-rayed twice from different angles. To obtain high-quality images and minimize radiation, the breast is briefly compressed between two plates, which can be uncomfortable or even painful. Experts recommend using a pressure of around 10 kPa, which helps in obtaining high-quality X-ray images and reducing pain. There is no scientific evidence that breast compression causes cancer or that it can cause cancer to spread.
A misinterpreted study
The post also mentions a purported study of 690,000 records that showed that a large number of healthy women developed breast cancer after a mammogram. The post probably refers to a study from 2000, but it significantly misinterprets its conclusions. The study looked at 690,993 women aged 66 to 79 and aimed to see if older women who get screened have a lower risk of metastatic breast cancer.
The study found that women who had mammograms were more likely to have breast cancer detected, not that the mammogram itself could have caused the cancer. These results are consistent with recommendations that mammography is the only recommended screening method to detect early stage breast cancer. The results of the study also state that screening mammography is associated with a reduced risk of detecting metastatic breast cancer in older women.
Conclusion
Switzerland has not banned mammography examinations. Radiation during the examination is not dangerous, it does not cause cancer or the spread of metastases. The post also greatly exaggerates the rate of false positive tests. The study that the post is likely referring to is about increased cancer diagnosis due to mammography screenings, not the development of cancer caused by the screening. Therefore, as part of our cooperation with Facebook, we mark the post as false.
false_claim: Mammography has been banned in Switzerland due to concerns that it can cause breast cancer and that more than half of the test results are incorrect.

content:
La foto del primo ministro polacco davanti a un busto di Stepan Bandera è falsa
Il 28 novembre 2022 su Facebook è stata pubblicata una foto che mostra due uomini di spalle davanti a un busto. L’immagine è accompagnata da questo commento: «Il primo ministro polacco Morawiecki a Kiev ha reso omaggio a Stepan Bandera. “Il ricordo di questo grande guerriero rimarrà per sempre nei nostri cuori. Bandera è sempre stato un grande amico del popolo polacco”, ha dichiarato Morawiecki».
Il contenuto oggetto di analisi utilizza un’immagine alterata per veicolare una notizia falsa.
Il riferimento è al politico nazionalista ucraino Stepan Bandera, che dopo aver collaborato con i nazisti durante la seconda guerra mondiale fu da questi internato come prigioniero politico a causa della sua intenzione di creare uno stato ucraino indipendente, seppur fedele ad Adolf Hitler. Bandera, ucciso nel 1959 da un agente dei servizi segreti sovietici, è stato il leader dell’Upa (esercito insurrezionale ucraino), organizzazione paramilitare che nel 1942 (quando Bandera era detenuto come prigioniero) si macchiò di pulizia etnica ai danni della minoranza polacca ed ebraica nelle regioni occupate dai nazisti della Volinia e della Galizia orientale.
Come hanno ricostruito i colleghi fact-checker di Correctiv, il contenuto oggetto di analisi è stato originariamente pubblicato il 26 novembre 2022 da un canale Telegram in lingua russa che diffonde contenuti di propaganda.
Nella foto originale del busto, pubblicata online dal suo autore nel 2009, non compaiono le due persone di spalle. La statua si trova a Kozivka, un villaggio nell’Ucraina occidentale a ovest di Kiev.
Lo scatto dei due uomini, inserito successivamente su quello con il busto di Bandera, proviene da una fotografia pubblicata il 26 novembre 2022 su Twitter dall’account ufficiale della Cancelleria del Primo ministro della Polonia.
La foto originale mostra il primo ministro polacco Mateusz Morawiecki insieme a un’altra persona mentre rende omaggio a un monumento a Kiev dedicato alle vittime dell’Holodomor, la carestia provocata tra il 1932 e il 1933 dal dittatore sovietico Iosif Stalin in Ucraina, quando ancora faceva parte dell’Unione sovietica.
Precisiamo infine che la dichiarazione su Bandera attribuita nel post oggetto di analisi al primo ministro polacco è priva di qualsiasi riscontro.
Dall’inizio dell’invasione russa dell’Ucraina, su Facta ci siamo occupati in diverse occasioni di contenuti di disinformazione ai danni della Polonia.
Clicca qui per iscriverti alla newsletter gratuita di Facta
Ogni sabato mattina riceverai il meglio del nostro lavoro
Translation:
The photo of the Polish prime minister in front of a bust of Stepan Bandera is fake
On November 28, 2022, a photo was published on Facebook showing two men from behind in front of a bust. The image is accompanied by this comment: «Polish Prime Minister Morawiecki paid tribute to Stepan Bandera in Kiev. “The memory of this great warrior will remain forever in our hearts. Bandera has always been a great friend of the Polish people,” Morawiecki declared.”
The content being analyzed uses an altered image to convey false news.
The reference is to the Ukrainian nationalist politician Stepan Bandera, who after having collaborated with the Nazis during the Second World War was interned by them as a political prisoner due to his intention to create an independent Ukrainian state, albeit loyal to Adolf Hitler. Bandera, killed in 1959 by an agent of the Soviet secret services, was the leader of the UPA (Ukrainian insurrectionary army), a paramilitary organization which in 1942 (when Bandera was held as a prisoner) was guilty of ethnic cleansing against the Polish minority and Jewish in the Nazi-occupied regions of Volhynia and eastern Galicia.
As Correctiv's fact-checker colleagues reconstructed, the content being analyzed was originally published on November 26, 2022 by a Russian-language Telegram channel that spreads propaganda content.
In the original photo of the bust, published online by its author in 2009, the two people do not appear from behind. The statue is located in Kozivka, a village in western Ukraine west of Kiev.
The shot of the two men, inserted later on the one with the Bandera bust, comes from a photograph published on November 26, 2022 on Twitter by the official account of the Chancellery of the Prime Minister of Poland.
The original photo shows Polish Prime Minister Mateusz Morawiecki together with another person while paying homage to a monument in Kiev dedicated to the victims of the Holodomor, the famine caused between 1932 and 1933 by the Soviet dictator Joseph Stalin in Ukraine, when still it was part of the Soviet Union.
Finally, we would like to point out that the statement on Bandera attributed to the Polish Prime Minister in the post under analysis is devoid of any corroboration.
Since the beginning of the Russian invasion of Ukraine, on Facta we have dealt with disinformation content against Poland on several occasions.
Click here to subscribe to Facta's free newsletter
Every Saturday morning you will receive the best of our work
false_claim: An image shows Polish Prime Minister Mateusz Morawiecki at a Bandera monument in Kiev, which has been misrepresented.

content:
En los últimos días están circulando varios contenidos que aseguran que el cantante del grupo ucraniano Kalush Orchestra, ganadores de la edición de 2022 de Eurovisión, habría hecho el saludo romano tras recoger el premio. Los contenidos, que aseguran que es un gesto nazi, contienen imágenes en los que supuestamente se podría observar al músico alzando el brazo. Pero es un bulo: el vídeo se ha recortado para que no se vea que se trata de un saludo al público, y otro ángulo permite ver que no se trata de una referencia nazi con mayor claridad.
En los contenidos que se difunden se pueden leer varias acusaciones de que los miembros de la banda Kalush Orchestra pertenecerían a la ideología nazi, con afirmaciones como que “me quedo con el pvt() nazi (sic)” o “parece que los ucronazis no pudieron aguantar las ganas de levantar la zarpa ni estando observados por televisiones de toda Europa”.
Para sostener este argumento, a los mensajes los acompañan unas imágenes en las que supuestamente se podría observar al cantante del grupo, Oleh Psiuk, realizando el saludo romano tras recoger el premio.
Pero estas imágenes no están completas. Si atendemos a la emisión original realizada por el festival, podemos observar que el gesto es en realidad un saludo al público, y que la mano no está cerrada como en el saludo romano, sino que la palma está abierta. Un gesto que no se aprecia segundos después por la posición de la cámara, que se sitúa de perfil respecto al artista. Además, en el video se aprecia que el brazo está situado en una posición vertical, y no paralela o angulada respecto al suelo, a diferencia del saludo fascista.
En otro plano grabado por un videoaficionado en los mismos instantes, se puede observar con mayor claridad cómo el cantante se dirige hacía el público con la palma de la mano abierta, y que no se trata de ningún saludo de ideología nazi.
Dejen de inventar cosas que no son, aquí claramente se ve que tiene la mano abierta y que nos estaba saludando. https://t.co/c9VYblRhBp pic.twitter.com/Mrpbr0R5Ft
— Danitcita ✨ (@danitcitas) May 15, 2022
Por lo tanto, no es cierto que el cantante de Kalush Orchestra, ganadores de Eurovision 2022, haya hecho el saludo romano. El gesto, que se trata de un saludo al público, ha sido sacado de contexto.
Este no es el único bulo que ha surgido a lo largo de la edición de 2022 del festival de Eurovision. Desde Maldita.es os contamos todas las desinformaciones que están circulando alrededor del evento.
Translation:
In recent days, several contents have been circulating that claim that the singer of the Ukrainian group Kalush Orchestra, winners of the 2022 edition of Eurovision, would have given the Roman salute after collecting the award. The contents, which they claim to be a Nazi gesture, contain images in which the musician could supposedly be seen raising his arm. But it is a hoax: the video has been cropped so that it cannot be seen that it is a greeting to the public, and another angle allows us to see that it is not a Nazi reference more clearly.
In the contents that are disseminated, you can read several accusations that the members of the Kalush Orchestra band belong to the Nazi ideology, with statements such as “I stick with the Nazi pvt() (sic)” or “it seems that the Ucronazis do not "They couldn't resist the urge to raise their paws even when they were watched by television from all over Europe."
To support this argument, the messages are accompanied by images in which the group's singer, Oleh Psiuk, could supposedly be seen performing the Roman salute after collecting the award.
But these images are not complete. If we look at the original broadcast made by the festival, we can see that the gesture is actually a greeting to the public, and that his hand is not closed as in the Roman greeting, but rather his palm is open. A gesture that is not appreciated seconds later due to the position of the camera, which is positioned in profile with respect to the artist. Furthermore, in the video it can be seen that the arm is located in a vertical position, and not parallel or angled with respect to the ground, unlike the fascist salute.
In another shot recorded by a video amateur at the same moments, you can see more clearly how the singer addresses the audience with the palm of his hand open, and that it is not a greeting of Nazi ideology.
Stop inventing things that are not, here you can clearly see that he has his hand open and that he was greeting us. https://t.co/c9VYblRhBp pic.twitter.com/Mrpbr0R5Ft
— Danitcita ✨ (@danitcitas) May 15, 2022
Therefore, it is not true that the singer of Kalush Orchestra, winners of Eurovision 2022, has given the Roman salute. The gesture, which is a greeting to the public, has been taken out of context.
This is not the only hoax that has emerged throughout the 2022 edition of the Eurovision Song Contest. From Maldita.es we tell you all the misinformation that is circulating around the event.
false_claim: The Ukrainian group Kalush Orchestra made a Nazi salute at the Eurovision song contest.

content:
Factcheck: nee, Oekraïense oud-minister van Defensie niet aan de Côte d’Azur gespot
Online circuleert een foto van de ontslagen Oekraïense minister van Defensie Oleksij Rezkinov op een jacht. Sommige socialemediagebruikers zien er een bewijs in dat de oud-minister een luxueus leventje aan de Côte d’Azur leidt. Het gaat echter om een oude foto, die in het Turkse Istanbul is genomen en die in 2020 op Facebook werd geplaatst.
Deze factcheck is uitgevoerd op basis van de beschikbare informatie op de datum van publicatie. Lees hier meer over hoe we werken.
Op 10 september post een Nederlandstalige Facebookgebruiker een foto, met het volgende bijschrift: ‘Reznikov, de Oekraïense minister van Landsverdediging, vorige week ontslagen wegens onder andere een schandaal in de leveringen van maaltijden aan het leger, toert al aan de Côte d’Azur. Mag ik zeggen met ons geld?’ (hier gearchiveerd).
Ook op X (voorheen Twitter) circuleert de bewering (hier gearchiveerd). Een tweet werd ruim 390.000 keer bekeken.
Rezkinov werd begin deze maand ontslagen als minister van Defensie na beschuldigingen van corruptie en persoonlijke verrijking.
Toont de foto Rezkinov kort na zijn ontslag aan de Côte d’Azur?
De kleding van beide personen op de foto doet ons al twijfelen. Ze staan ingeduffeld op het dek van een schip.
We laden de foto op bij Google Lens en voeren een omgekeerde zoekopdracht uit. Zo komen we terecht op een artikel van de Oekraïense nieuwssite 24tv. Daarin lezen we de biografie van Rezkinov, die het in 2020 van Oekraïens staatssecretaris tot minister van Defensie schopte.
In het onderschrift lezen we ‘Rezkinov en zijn bruid Yulia Zorii in Istanboel, onmiddellijk na het huwelijksaanzoek’. Zorii is een Oekraïense televisiepresentatrice. Reznikov en Zorii trouwden op 25 juli 2020. De foto is afkomstig van Rezkinovs Facebookpagina. Daar vinden we de foto inderdaad terug. Rezkinov plaatste de foto online op 14 februari 2020, de dag waarop hij Zorii ten huwelijk vroeg, zoals blijkt uit de bijhorende Facebookpost.
Conclusie
Online circuleert een foto van de ontslagen Oekraïense minister van Defensie Oleksij Rezkinov op een jacht. Sommige socialemediagebruikers zien er een bewijs in dat de oud-minister een luxueus leventje aan de Côte d’Azur leidt. Het gaat echter om een oude foto, die in het Turkse Istanbul werd genomen en in 2020 op Facebook werd geplaatst. We beoordelen het bijschrift bij de foto dan ook als onwaar.
Meer informatie over de factchecks vindt u op de website van Knack.
U vindt onze factchecks ook terug bij deCheckers, samen met betrouwbare factchecks van andere Vlaamse redacties.
Knack is erkend lid van het International Fact-Checking Network (IFCN) en European Fact-Checking Standards Network (EFCSN).
Krasse uitspraak, straf cijfer of dito feit in de actualiteit gezien?
Vul uw vraag in op de website van deCheckers met exacte bronvermelding van het citaat of stuur het naar factcheck@knack.be.
Knack maakt onderdeel uit van Roularta Media Group.
Translation:
Fact check: no, Ukrainian former defense minister not spotted on the Côte d'Azur
A photo of the dismissed Ukrainian Defense Minister Oleksij Rezkinov on a yacht is circulating online. Some social media users see it as proof that the former minister leads a luxurious life on the Côte d'Azur. However, it is an old photo that was taken in Istanbul, Turkey and posted on Facebook in 2020.
This fact check was carried out based on the information available at the date of publication. Read more about how we work here.
On September 10, a Dutch-speaking Facebook user posted a photo with the following caption: 'Reznikov, the Ukrainian Minister of Defense, fired last week due to, among other things, a scandal in the delivery of meals to the army, is already touring the Côte d'Azur. Can I say with our money?' (archived here).
The claim is also circulating on X (formerly Twitter) (archived here). A tweet was viewed more than 390,000 times.
Rezkinov was dismissed as defense minister early this month after allegations of corruption and personal enrichment.
Does the photo show Rezkinov shortly after his dismissal on the Côte d'Azur?
The clothing of both people in the photo already makes us doubt. They are bundled up on the deck of a ship.
We load the photo into Google Lens and perform a reverse search. This brings us to an article from the Ukrainian news site 24tv. In it we read the biography of Rezkinov, who rose from Ukrainian State Secretary to Minister of Defense in 2020.
In the caption we read 'Rezkinov and his bride Yulia Zorii in Istanbul, immediately after the marriage proposal'. Zorii is a Ukrainian television presenter. Reznikov and Zorii got married on July 25, 2020. The photo is from Rezkinov's Facebook page. We indeed find the photo there. Rezkinov posted the photo online on February 14, 2020, the day he proposed to Zorii, as evidenced by the accompanying Facebook post.
Conclusion
A photo of the dismissed Ukrainian Defense Minister Oleksij Rezkinov on a yacht is circulating online. Some social media users see it as proof that the former minister leads a luxurious life on the Côte d'Azur. However, it is an old photo that was taken in Istanbul, Turkey and posted on Facebook in 2020. We therefore rate the caption with the photo as untrue.
More information about the fact checks can be found on the Knack website.
You will also find our fact checks at deCheckers, together with reliable fact checks from other Flemish editors.
Knack is a recognized member of the International Fact-Checking Network (IFCN) and European Fact-Checking Standards Network (EFCSN).
Have you seen a bold statement, penalty or ditto fact in current events?
Complete your question on the deCheckers website with the exact source of the quote or send it to factcheck@knack.be.
Knack is part of Roularta Media Group.
false_claim: A photo of former Ukrainian Defense Minister Reznikov drinking champagne on a yacht was taken after his resignation.

content:
Nein, in Mailand wurde kein Plakat von Selenskyj angebracht, der Geld schnupft
- Dieser Artikel ist älter als ein Jahr.
- Veröffentlicht am 20. April 2023 um 12:18
- Aktualisiert am 20. April 2023 um 12:29
- 5 Minuten Lesezeit
- Von: Paula CABESCU, AFP Rumänien, AFP Deutschland
- Übersetzung: Saladin SALEM
Copyright © AFP 2017-2024. Für die kommerzielle Nutzung dieses Inhalts ist ein Abonnement erforderlich. Klicken Sie hier für weitere Informationen.
Das Video des angeblichen Selenskyj-Plakats wurde dutzende Male auf Facebook und Twitter geteilt. Auf Telegram sahen mehr als hunderttausend Menschen den Clip. Das Video wurde zudem auf Rumänisch, Englisch, Spanisch, Französisch, Niederländisch und Bulgarisch geteilt.
Die Behauptung: "Mitten im Zentrum von Mailand wurde eine Plakatwand mit Zelensky installiert, der Spenden durch seine Nase aufsaugt", heißt es zu einem online kursierenden Video. Zu sehen sind Aufnahmen einer Werbetafel mit Selenskyjs Gesicht vor dem Mailänder Dom. Durch das abgebildete Nasenloch werden Geldscheine in die Tafel gesaugt.
Der ukrainische Präsident Wolodymyr Selenskyj wurde in der Vergangenheit immer wieder zum Ziel von Gerüchten über einen angeblichen Kokain-Konsum, die bereits 2019 während seines Präsidentschaftswahlkampfes auftraten. Seit Beginn des russischen Angriffs auf die Ukraine im Februar 2022, kursieren die Behauptungen erneut und stützen kremlnahe Darstellungen, wonach die ukrainische Regierung eine "Horde von Drogensüchtigen" sei. AFP hat in der Vergangenheit mehrere derartige Behauptungen widerlegt (hier, hier).
Zuletzt widerlegte AFP im Februar 2023 Behauptungen, wonach die Stadt Mailand angeblich die Statue einer Nase mit einer Spur aus weißem Pulver für Selenskyj errichtet habe. User behaupteten dazu, die Statue solle symbolisieren, dass Selenskyj Drogen konsumiere. Tatsächlich handelte es sich dabei aber um eine Kunstinstallation, die den Drogenhandel in Mailand verurteilte und nichts mit dem ukrainischen Präsidenten zu tun hatte.
Ursprung des Videos
Der online verbreitete Clip enthält mehrere Einstellungen verschiedener Perspektiven des Piazza del Duomo in Mailand, direkt vor dem Mailänder Dom. Auf dem Poster Selenskyjs sind die Worte "Spenden für die Ukraine" zu sehen. Das verwendete Bild des ukrainischen Präsidenten scheint aus diesem Artikel der US-Nachrichtenseite "The Hill" zu stammen und zeigt Selenskyj bei einem Besuch in Washington im Dezember 2022.
In einigen Versionen des online zirkulierenden Videos ist zudem ein Wasserzeichen zu sehen, das zu dem russischsprachigen Telegram-Kanal "Omarov Today" führt. Der Kanal teilte den Clip erstmals am 4. April 2023. In der Beschreibung des Beitrags stehen die Worte "ein kleiner Vogel hat mir erzählt" und "Mailand, 3. April".
Der Standort der Plakattafel kann mithilfe einer Suche in Google Maps nachvollzogen werden:
Ein AFP-Reporter besuchte den Aufnahmeort am 13. April 2023 und bestätigte, dass auf der gezeigten Werbetafel zu diesem Zeitpunkt kein Bild des ukrainischen Präsidenten hing. Stattdessen war Werbung für die Milano Art Week zu sehen.
Zuständige Behörden bestreiten Echtheit
AFP erkundigte sich bei mehreren Quellen nach der angeblichen Installation an der Werbetafel.
Elena Santini Nunziati, Sprecherin der Organisation, die das Domgelände verwaltet, erklärte am 13. April 2023 in einer E-Mail gegenüber: "Am Dom oder auf dem Domplatz in Mailand wurden niemals verunglimpfende oder verhöhnende politische Botschaften oder Plakate angebracht." Die fragliche Werbetafel falle zudem in den Zuständigkeitsbereich der Mailänder Stadtverwaltung, so Nunziati. Am unteren Rand der Tafel ist auch das Logo der Stadt zu sehen.
Die Kommunikationsabteilung der Stadt Mailand, der die Werbetafel gehört, teilte AFP am 19. April in einer E-Mail mit, dass das Filmmaterial "kein Originalvideo ist, da kein solches Plakat jemals in den Räumen der Gemeindeverwaltung genehmigt wurde". Dies gelte auch für die Tafel aus dem Video.
AFP befragte auch einen Mitarbeiter eines Restaurants am Rande des Piazza del Duomo, das sich in unmittelbarer Nähe der Werbetafel befindet, zu den Aufnahmen. Dieser bestätigte, die fragliche Werbetafel gut zu kennen, aber die angebliche Installation mit Selenskyj nie gesehen zu haben. Der Mitarbeiter wollte in diesem Artikel nicht namentlich genannt werden.
Video deutet auf Manipulation hin
Die Originalaufnahmen auf dem russischsprachigen Telegram-Kanal beinhalten mehrere Hinweise, die auf eine mögliche Manipulation hindeuten.
Beim Blick auf den Rand des angeblichen Selenskyj-Plakats fällt auf, dass keine Lücke zwischen dem Bild und dem Rahmen zu existieren scheint. Der Rahmen wirft auch keinen Schatten, wie es normalerweise der Fall ist.
Die Aufnahmen des Telegram-Kanals weisen zudem einige Unstimmigkeiten auf. Insbesondere ist sowohl bei Sekunde 16 als auch Sekunde 20 im Hintergrund derselbe Mann zu sehen, der auf die gleiche Weise durch den Bildrand läuft, obwohl die Einstellungen verschiedene Zeitpunkte zeigen sollen.
Nach Angaben der Faktencheck-Organisation Open.online, die das kursierende Video ebenfalls untersuchte, haben auch die Sicherheitskräfte am Mailänder Dom das angebliche Selenskyj-Plakat nie gesehen. Der Domplatz ist zudem umfangreich videoüberwacht, sodass es praktisch unmöglich ist, ein solches Plakat aufzuhängen, ohne bemerkt zu werden.
Der Piazza del Duomo ist einer der am meisten besuchten Orte in Mailand und auch bei Touristen sehr beliebt. Daher wäre zu erwarten, dass eine solche Installation sowohl bei traditionellen Medien als auch in sozialen Netzwerken Aufmerksamkeit erregen würde. AFP konnte jedoch außer dem gefälschten Video keinen Hinweis auf die Existenz der angeblichen Installation finden.
Fazit: Nein, in Mailand wurde keine Werbetafel aufgestellt, die es Menschen erlaubt, Geldscheine durch Selenskyjs Nasenloch zu werfen. Das bestätigten die Mailänder Behörden und ein Beschäftigter vor Ort. Das Video weist zudem Unstimmigkeiten auf, die auf eine Bearbeitung hindeuten.
Translation:
No, there was no poster of Zelensky sniffing money in Milan
- This article is older than a year.
- Published on April 20, 2023 at 12:18 p.m
- Updated April 20, 2023 at 12:29 p.m
- 5 minutes reading time
- By: Paula CABESCU, AFP Romania, AFP Germany
- Translation: Saladin SALEM
Copyright © AFP 2017-2024. Commercial use of this content requires a subscription. Click here for more information.
The video of the alleged Zelensky poster was shared dozens of times on Facebook and Twitter. More than a hundred thousand people saw the clip on Telegram. The video was also shared in Romanian, English, Spanish, French, Dutch and Bulgarian.
The claim: "A billboard has been installed in the middle of the center of Milan with Zelensky sucking up donations through his nose," says a video circulating online. You can see photos of a billboard with Zelenskyj's face in front of the Milan Cathedral. Banknotes are sucked into the board through the nostril shown.
Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky has repeatedly been the target of rumors about alleged cocaine use, which arose during his presidential election campaign in 2019. Since Russia's attack on Ukraine began in February 2022, the claims have been circulating again, supporting pro-Kremlin narratives that the Ukrainian government is a "horde of drug addicts." AFP has debunked several such claims in the past (here, here).
Most recently, in February 2023, AFP refuted claims that the city of Milan had allegedly erected the statue of a nose with a trail of white powder for Zelensky. Users claimed that the statue was meant to symbolize that Zelensky was using drugs. In fact, it was an art installation condemning the drug trade in Milan and had nothing to do with the Ukrainian president.
Origin of the video
The clip, which was distributed online, contains several shots from different perspectives of the Piazza del Duomo in Milan, directly in front of the Milan Cathedral. The words “Donations for Ukraine” can be seen on Zelensky’s poster. The image of the Ukrainian president used appears to come from this article from the US news site "The Hill" and shows Zelensky during a visit to Washington in December 2022.
In some versions of the video circulating online, a watermark can also be seen that leads to the Russian-language Telegram channel "Omarov Today." The channel first shared the clip on April 4, 2023. The post's description includes the words "a little bird told me" and "Milan, April 3."
The location of the billboard can be tracked by searching Google Maps:
An AFP reporter visited the shooting location on April 13, 2023 and confirmed that the billboard shown did not have a picture of the Ukrainian president on it at the time. Instead, there was advertising for Milano Art Week.
The responsible authorities deny its authenticity
AFP asked several sources about the alleged installation on the billboard.
Elena Santini Nunziati, spokeswoman for the organization that manages the cathedral grounds, said in an email on April 13, 2023: "No denigrating or mocking political messages or posters have ever been displayed at the cathedral or in the cathedral square in Milan." The billboard in question also falls under the jurisdiction of the Milan city administration, said Nunziati. The city's logo can also be seen at the bottom of the board.
The communications department of the city of Milan, which owns the billboard, told AFP in an email on April 19 that the footage "is not an original video, as no such poster has ever been authorized on the premises of the municipal administration." This also applies to the board from the video.
AFP also interviewed an employee of a restaurant on the edge of the Piazza del Duomo, which is in close proximity to the billboard, about the footage. He confirmed that he knew the billboard in question well, but had never seen the alleged installation with Zelensky. The employee did not want to be named in this article.
Video suggests manipulation
The original recordings on the Russian-language Telegram channel contain several clues that indicate possible manipulation.
When you look at the edge of the alleged Zelensky poster, you notice that there doesn't seem to be a gap between the picture and the frame. The frame also doesn't cast a shadow, as is usually the case.
The recordings of the Telegram channel also show some inconsistencies. In particular, at both seconds 16 and 20, the same man can be seen in the background walking through the edge of the image in the same way, even though the shots are supposed to show different points in time.
According to the fact-checking organization Open.online, which also investigated the circulating video, the security forces at the Milan Cathedral never saw the alleged Zelensky poster. The cathedral square is also under extensive video surveillance, making it practically impossible to hang such a poster without being noticed.
Piazza del Duomo is one of the most visited places in Milan and is also very popular with tourists. Therefore, it would be expected that such an installation would attract attention from both traditional media and social networks. However, AFP was unable to find any evidence of the existence of the alleged installation other than the fake video.
Conclusion: No, there was no billboard erected in Milan allowing people to throw banknotes through Zelensky's nostril. This was confirmed by the Milan authorities and an employee on site. The video also has inconsistencies that indicate editing.
false_claim: A billboard in Milan displayed Zelensky with a hole in his nose 'sniffing' banknotes.

content:
Sotsiaalmeedias levib väidetav müügileping, mis pidavat tõestama, et Zelenskõiga seotud firma ostis oktoobris Joseph Goebbelsile kuulunud villa Berliini lähedal. Väidetav leping on võltsing ja selle levitaja on väljamõeldud isik.
„Zelensky ostis 8 mln euro eest Goebbelsi villa. Slava ukradina,“ seisab Facebooki grupi Patriootliku Eesti sõbrad - rahvusriigi sõbrad 1. jaanuari postituses.
„Libauudis nr 1? Ukraina president Volodõmõr Zelenskõiga seotud ettevõte ostis väidetavalt Saksamaal Natsi-Saksamaa propagandaministri Joseph Goebbelsi endise villa. Internetti lekkinud ostu-müügi lepingu kohaselt soetas firma Film Heritage Inc. käesoleva aasta oktoobris 8 miljoni euro eest Berliini lähedal asuva Bogensee villa,“ kirjutas portaal Telegram 30. detsembril.
„Uudisteportaalid viitavad ka vallasvara BIM-i haldava kinnisvarabüroo endisele töötajale Sabine Melsile, kes avaldas dokumendi, mis kinnitas, et ettevõte Film Heritage Inc. omandas Bogensee villa,“ kirjutab Telegram.
Esmalt ilmus 24. detsembril 57 jälgijaga Youtube’i kanalil „Sabine Mels“ video pealkirjaga „Zelenskõi ostis kurikuulsa Goebbelsi villa (Bogensee) 8 miljoni euro eest“ („Zelensky purchased infamous Goebbel’s villa (Bogensee) for 8 million Euro“). Kõik kolm selle kasutaja videot on postitatud 24. detsembril ja on seotud „antifašismiga“.
Isik, kes nimetab end Sabine Melsiks, on enda sõnul Berliini linna kinnisvarahaldusettevõtte BIM (Berliner Immobilienmanagement GmbH) endine töötaja. Videos räägib ta Saksa keeles, et tema endine kolleeg BIMist olevat saatnud talle Goebbelsi villa müügilepingu koopia. Väidetavalt ostis villa 2023. aasta oktoobris Ukraina presidendiga seotud offshore-firma Film Heritage Inc.
BIM kinnitas BBC-le, et keegi nimega Sabine Mels pole neil kunagi töötanud.
Saksa keelt emakeelena kõneleja ütles Ukraina faktikontrollimise väljaandele StopFake, et naine räägib videos selge vene aktsendiga.
Sabine Melsi nimelisel ainsal sotsiaalmeediakontol X-is on varastatud profiilipilt. Tegelikult kuulub see USA näitlejale Alyssa Gadsonile. X-is on Sabine Melsi nimeline kasutaja varem teinud postitusi enamasti araabia keeles ja suurem osa jälgijatest on pärit Indiast ja Araabia maadest.
Seega Sabine Mels on väljamõeldud isik ja pole kunagi töötanud BIM-is.
Väidetaval müügilepingu koopial on mitu viga, mis tõendavad, et dokument on võltsitud.
Näiteks on sellelt näha, et tehingu olevat notariaalselt kinnitanud „Dr. Friederike Schulenburg, jurist – notar“. Schulenburg tõesti töötas kunagi notarina BIM-is. Praegu on ta üle 80aastane. Vastavalt Saksamaa föderaalsele notarimäärusele lõpeb notari ametiaeg 70-aastaselt.
Schulenburg töötab enda sõnul endiselt advokaadibüroos, kuid pole saanud notaritööd teha juba üle kümne aasta. Schulenburg kinnitas, et ei vormistanud oktoobris ühtegi müüki.
Schulenburgi sõnul on väidetav müügileping „suhteliselt kohmakalt kokku pandud“. Näiteks on sellele kirjutatud „Ostuleping“ („Kaufvertrag“), kuid sellist pealkirja pole tema sõnul olemaski. Lisaks on puudu pitsat, allkiri ja märge „kinnitatud koopia“. Ka formaalne kujundus ei vasta tema sõnul standarditele.
Pärast Hitleri režiimi kokkuvarisemist oli Bogensee piirkond Nõukogude Liidu kontrolli all ja kinnistu sai punaarmee baasiks. 1946. aastal anti see üle Ida-Saksamaa kommunistlikule noorsooliikumisele. Pärast müüri langemist asus seal sotsiaaltöötajate koolitamise keskus, Berliini politsei kasutas klassiruume konverentside korraldamiseks, rajati lasteaed jne.
Alates 2000. aastast on kinnistu seisnud tühjana ja selle omanik on siiani Berliini omavalitsus. Villa Bogensee pole kellelegi müüdud ega isegi müüki pandud. Seda kinnitas BBC-le BIMi esindaja.
Ka kohalikud poliitikud ütlesid väljaandele T-Online, et arvestades kinnistu ajalugu on kujuteldamatu, et mõni sellel asuv hoone eraldataks ja müüdaks lihtsalt eraviisiliselt maha. Samuti oleks Berliini valitsus sellest avalikult teatanud.
Kinnistu võimalikku müüki suhtutakse kriitiliselt, et see ei satuks paremäärmuslastest Hitleri fännide kätte. 2016. aastal ütles BIM-i juht Birgit Möhring, et hoonel on probleeme kütte ja veega ning fassaad ja katus on halvas seisus. Möhring nimetas kinnistu taastamiseks vajalikke kulutusi põhjendamatuks ja pakkus välja villa lammutamist.
30. detsembril postitas valeväite Zelenskõi väidetava villaostu kohta ka Venemaa Lõuna-Aafrika saatkonna ametlik X-i konto. Seejärel ilmusid samasugused uudised sotsiaalmeedias ja kümnetes Venemaa kanalites, näiteks RIA Novosti, Комсомольская правда ja Sputnik.
Venemaa on varem tootnud arvukaid valeinfo-kampaaniaid Zelenskõi vara ja väidetavate salatehingute kohta. Näiteks levis mõni nädal tagasi valeinfo, et Zelenskõi ostis Floridasse villa ja sai Ameerika kodakondsuse.
Venemaa üks strateegiline narratiiv, mida otseselt toidab valeinfo Goebbelsi villa kohta, on Zelenskõi ja terve Ukraina seostamine natsismiga. Nn „Ukraina denatsifitseerimist“ kasutab Venemaa siiani ettekäändena sõja põhjendamiseks.
Otsus: vale. Võltsitud müügilepinguga levitatakse valet, et Ukraina president Volodõmõr Zelenskõi ostis Berliini lähedal asuva Hitleri propagandaministrile Goebbelsile kuulunud villa. Tegu on otsast lõpuni võltsitud looga, mille eesmärk on laimata Zelenskõit ja levitada läänes Venemaa strateegilisi narratiive.
Translation:
An alleged sales contract is circulating on social media, which purports to prove that a Zelenskyi-related company bought a villa near Berlin that belonged to Joseph Goebbels in October. The purported contract is a forgery and is distributed by a fictitious person.
"Zelensky bought Goebbels' villa for 8 million euros. Slava ukradina," reads the January 1st post of the Facebook group Friends of Patriotic Estonia - Friends of the Nation State.
“No. 1 gossip? A company linked to Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskiy has reportedly bought the former villa of Nazi German Propaganda Minister Joseph Goebbels in Germany. According to the purchase and sale agreement leaked on the Internet, the company Film Heritage Inc. acquired. in October of this year, a villa in Bogensee near Berlin for 8 million euros," the Telegram portal wrote on December 30.
"News portals also refer to Sabine Mels, a former employee of the real estate agency that manages BIM for movable property, who published a document confirming that the company Film Heritage Inc. acquired Bogensee villa," Telegram writes.
On December 24, a video with the title "Zelensky purchased infamous Goebbel's villa (Bogensee) for 8 million Euro" was first published on the YouTube channel "Sabine Mels" with 57 followers. All three of this user's videos were posted on December 24th and are related to "anti-fascism".
The person, who calls herself Sabine Mels, says she is a former employee of BIM (Berliner Immobilienmanagement GmbH), a real estate management company in the city of Berlin. In the video, he says in German that his former colleague from BIM sent him a copy of Goebbels' villa sales contract. The villa was reportedly purchased in October 2023 by Film Heritage Inc., an offshore company linked to the Ukrainian president.
BIM confirmed to the BBC that no one named Sabine Mels had ever worked for them.
A native German speaker told Ukrainian fact-checking publication StopFake that the woman speaks with a distinct Russian accent in the video.
The only social media account on X under the name of Sabine Mels has a stolen profile picture. It actually belongs to US actress Alyssa Gadson. On X, a user named Sabine Mels has previously posted mostly in Arabic, and most of her followers are from India and Arab countries.
So Sabine Mels is a fictitious person and has never worked in BIM.
The purported copy of the contract of sale has several errors which prove that the document is a forgery.
For example, it shows that the transaction was notarized by "Dr. Friederike Schulenburg, lawyer - notary". Schulenburg actually once worked as a notary at BIM. He is now over 80 years old. According to the German Federal Notary Ordinance, the term of office of a notary expires at the age of 70.
According to Schulenburg, he still works at a law firm, but has not been able to do notary work for over ten years. Schulenburg confirmed that it did not close any sales in October.
According to Schulenburg, the alleged sales agreement is "relatively clumsily put together." For example, "Purchase Agreement" ("Kaufvertrag") is written on it, but according to him, such a title does not exist. In addition, the seal, signature and notation "certified copy" are missing. According to him, the formal design also does not meet the standards.
After the fall of Hitler's regime, the Bogensee area was under the control of the Soviet Union and the property became a base for the Red Army. In 1946, it was handed over to the communist youth movement of East Germany. After the fall of the wall, there was a training center for social workers, the Berlin police used classrooms for conferences, a kindergarten was built, etc.
The property has been empty since 2000 and is still owned by the Berlin municipality. Villa Bogensee has not been sold to anyone or even put up for sale. This was confirmed by a BIM representative to the BBC.
Local politicians also told T-Online that given the history of the property, it is unimaginable that any of the buildings on it would be separated and simply sold privately. Also, the Berlin government would have announced this publicly.
The possible sale of the property is viewed critically so that it does not fall into the hands of far-right Hitler fans. In 2016, BIM manager Birgit Möhring said that the building has problems with heating and water, and the facade and roof are in poor condition. Möhring called the expenses necessary to restore the property unjustified and suggested demolishing the villa.
On December 30, the official X account of the Russian embassy in South Africa also posted a false statement about Zelenskyi's alleged purchase of wool. Then similar news appeared on social media and dozens of Russian channels, such as RIA Novosti, Комсомольская правда, and Sputnik.
Russia has previously produced numerous disinformation campaigns about Zelenskyi's assets and alleged secret dealings. For example, a few weeks ago, false information spread that Zelensky bought a villa in Florida and got American citizenship.
One of Russia's strategic narratives, which is directly fueled by the false information about the Goebbels villa, is to associate Zelensky and all of Ukraine with Nazism. The so-called "denazification of Ukraine" is still used by Russia as a pretext to justify the war.
Verdict: False. A fake sales contract spreads the lie that Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky bought a villa near Berlin that belonged to Hitler's propaganda minister Goebbels. It is a completely fake story with the aim of defaming Zelenskyi and spreading Russia's strategic narratives in the West.
false_claim: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky purchased a villa near Berlin that previously belonged to Nazi propaganda minister Joseph Goebbels.

content:
Il Washington Post non ha pubblicato un articolo su Hamas che riceve armi dall’Ucraina
L’11 novembre 2023 è stato pubblicato su Facebook lo screenshot di un presunto articolo del Washington Post intitolato “Weapons supplies from Ukraine to Hamas have tripled over the past month” (in italiano, “Le forniture di armi dall’Ucraina ad Hamas sono triplicate nell’ultimo mese”). Il pezzo, si legge nell’immagine, sarebbe stato scritto da «Chris Moltisanti» e pubblicato dal quotidiano statunitense il 2 novembre 2023.
Lo screenshot è accompagnato da un testo, scritto dall’autore del post, in cui si afferma che sarebbero state confermate «le prime notizie di armi occidentali contrabbandate dall’Ucraina nelle mani di Hamas».
Si tratta di una notizia falsa.
Sul sito del Washington Post non è presente alcun articolo che riporta una simile notizia. Inoltre, non risulta esistere un giornalista che scrive per il quotidiano statunitense chiamato «Chris Moltisanti». Contattato da diversi siti di fact-checking, un portavoce del Washington Post ha confermato che il giornale non ha mai pubblicato l’articolo che compare nello screenshot analizzato e che nessun giornalista di nome «Chris Moltisanti» scrive o collabora con il Washington Post. «Chris Moltisanti» è invece il nome di un personaggio della celebre serie televisiva The Sopranos.
Precisiamo infine che l’informazione secondo cui il gruppo estremista palestinese Hamas possiederebbe armi provenienti dall’Ucraina è ad oggi priva qualsiasi riscontro. Nei comunicati stampa in cui l’esercito israeliano dichiara di aver trovato a Gaza covi di Hamas con armi non è mai stato menzionato il fatto che queste provenissero dall’Ucraina. Inoltre, in un’analisi pubblicata lo scorso 16 ottobre da Reuters su Hamas e la sua forza militare, vengono riportate le parole di Ali Baraka, un alto funzionario del gruppo estremista palestinese, sulla difficoltà nell’importare armi a Gaza. Un problema, continua Baraka, che ha fatto sì che il gruppo abbia sviluppato la capacità di autoprodurre armi.
Translation:
The Washington Post did not publish an article about Hamas receiving weapons from Ukraine
On November 11, 2023, a screenshot of an alleged Washington Post article titled “Weapons supplies from Ukraine to Hamas have tripled over the past month” was published on Facebook in the last month”). The piece, we read in the image, was written by «Chris Moltisanti» and published by the US newspaper on November 2, 2023.
The screenshot is accompanied by a text, written by the author of the post, which states that "the first reports of Western weapons smuggled from Ukraine into the hands of Hamas" have been confirmed.
This is fake news.
There is no article on the Washington Post website reporting similar news. Furthermore, there does not appear to be a journalist who writes for the US newspaper called «Chris Moltisanti». Contacted by several fact-checking sites, a spokesperson for the Washington Post confirmed that the newspaper never published the article that appears in the analyzed screenshot and that no journalist named "Chris Moltisanti" writes or collaborates with the Washington Post. «Chris Moltisanti» is the name of a character from the famous television series The Sopranos.
Finally, we would like to point out that the information according to which the Palestinian extremist group Hamas possesses weapons coming from Ukraine is currently without any confirmation. In the press releases in which the Israeli army claims to have found Hamas hideouts with weapons in Gaza, it was never mentioned that these came from Ukraine. Furthermore, in an analysis published last October 16 by Reuters on Hamas and its military force, the words of Ali Baraka, a senior official of the Palestinian extremist group, on the difficulty in importing weapons to Gaza are reported. A problem, continues Baraka, which has meant that the group has developed the ability to self-produce weapons.
false_claim: The Washington Post published an article about weapons supplies from Ukraine to Hamas.

content:
Pozor na fámy ohľadne údajného úmrtia švédskeho vyšetrovateľa havárie plynovodu Nord Stream
- Tento článok je viac ako rok starý.
- Uverejnené 24. októbra 2022 o 17:34
- Článok prečítate za 7 min
- Autor: Nathan GALLO, AFP Francúzsko
- Článok preložil/-a Robert BARCA
Copyright © AFP 2017-2024. Pre akékoľvek komerčné použitie tohto obsahu je nutné predplatenie našich služieb. Viac informácií zistíte tu.
„Erik Ollsen je mŕtvy Kto je Erik Ollsen? Bol hlavným vyšetrovateľom útoku na nordstream...,“ píše sa v slovenčine v príspevku z ruskej sociálnej siete VKontakte z 9. októbra 2022. Súčasťou príspevku je snímka twitterového príspevku v holandčine, podľa ktorého mal byť Ollsen dokonca zástupcom šéfa švédskej prokuratúry.
Podľa príspevku bol vraj „nájdený doma“, pričom uvádza jeho meno ako „Olsen“. Rôzne verzie tohto tvrdenia uvádzajú meno údajného vyšetrovateľa v rôznych podobách, raz ako Olsen či Ollsen, inokedy ako Olssen, Ulsson či Ollson.
Podľa holandského tweetu aj slovenského používateľa VKontakte bolo príčinou smrti muža údajne bodnutie včelou a jeho telo bolo „v priebehu niekoľkých hodín“ spopolnené.
Podobné príspevky spoločne s holandským tweetom boli zdieľané o deň neskôr aj na Telegramovom kanáli AKWSK, tentokrát s tvrdením, že „Erik Olssen, sef vysetrovacieho vyboru pre sabotaz na NS1 a NS2, je mrtvy“. Rovnaké tvrdenie bolo následne skopírované aj na Facebook, kde ho zdieľalo viac ako 250 používateľov.
Podľa týchto tvrdení bol muž zodpovedný za vyšetrovanie údajnej sabotáže plynovodov Nord Stream 1 a 2 v Baltskom mori, ku ktorej došlo koncom septembra.
26. septembra 2022 došlo na dvoch plynovodoch v Baltskom mori, ktorými sa prepravuje ruský plyn do Nemecka, k štyrom masívnym únikom plynu, ktoré podľa viacerých krajín spôsobili podvodné detonácie. Ruská federácia, ktorá čelí obvineniam z toho, že mala stáť za útokmi, odmietla akúkoľvek zodpovednosť a z týchto útokov obvinila Západ.
Nemecko 1. októbra oznámilo vytvorenie spoločného tímu s Dánskom a Švédskom za účelom vyšetrenia únikov plynu. Dánsko 13. októbra uviedlo, že vyšetrovanie „dobre napreduje“.
Výbuchy plynovodu Nord Stream sa tiež časovo zhodovali s otvorením nového plynovodu z Nórska do Poľska cez Dánsko, ktorého cieľom je znížiť závislosť európskych krajín od ruského plynu.
„Éra dominancie ruského plynu sa končí,“ povedal 27. septembra poľský premiér Mateusz Morawiecki.
Dodávky energie sú hlavnou geopolitickou a hospodárskou otázkou medzi Západom a Ruskom, najmä odkedy Rusko koncom februára podniklo vojenskú inváziu na Ukrajinu.
Podobné tvrdenia o smrti údajného švédskeho vyšetrovateľa Erika Olssena sa rozšírili aj v angličtine, francúzštine, poľštine či nemčine.
Švédske orgány: „O Erikovi Ollsenovi nemáme vedomosť“
Švédske orgány začali vyšetrovať možnú príčinu výbuchov, ktoré zasiahli plynovody Nord Stream 1 a 2 v Baltskom mori. V rámci hľadania a overovania sme však v agentúre AFP nenašli žiadnu zmienku o osobe s menom Erik Ollsen (alebo podobným) v rámci švédskych inštitúcií zodpovedných za vyšetrovanie v tejto veci.
Švédska prokuratúra poverená vyšetrovaním, ktorú sme v rámci AFP kontaktovali, 12. októbra uviedla, že „žiadny prokurátor zodpovedný za prípad [Nord Stream] s menom Erik Olsson nezomrel v dôsledku bodnutia včelou“.
Vo viacerých príspevkoch sa tvrdilo, že príbuzných údajného „zástupcu švédskej prokuratúry“ dokonca kontaktovali „kolegovia“, ktorí im chceli vyjadriť „sústrasť“. Prokuratúra tieto príspevky odmietla a uviedla: „Ide o 'falošné správy'.“
Švédska prokuratúra tiež upozornila, že vyšetrovanie incidentov na plynovodoch Nord Stream v súčasnosti vedie Mats Ljungqvist, ktorý bol citovaný v tejto tlačovej správe zo 6. októbra.
Podľa viacerých príspevkov na sociálnych sieťach vydala vyhlásenie o Ollsenovej smrti štokholmská polícia. V jednom z takýchto príspevkov sa tvrdilo, že polícia „oznámila niektoré podrobnosti o tom, čo sa stalo“, a uviedla, že „Ulssonov [sic] závet“ bol „objavený spoločne so žiadosťou o okamžitú kremáciu v prípade smrti“.
Štokholmská polícia však 12. októbra pre agentúru AFP uviedla, že o tejto osobe „nemá vedomosť“ a „o záležitosti neinformovala“.
Dánska polícia 18. októbra pre agentúru AFP e-mailom uviedla, že „v kodanskej polícii nie je žiadny zamestnanec s menom Erik Ollson (alebo iným podobným menom)“. Dodali, že podľa ich vedomostí toto meno znie švédsky.
Nemecká prokuratúra, ktorú taktiež kontaktovala agentúra AFP, ved odmietla komentovať.
AFP nenašla vo vyhľadávačoch žiadnu relevantnú zmienku o Erikovi Ollsenovi. Iné organizácie, ktoré overujú fakty, dospeli k rovnakým záverom (tu alebo tu).
Pôvod na Telegrame a na ruskej sieti VKontakte
Odkiaľ sa tieto tvrdenia vzali? Vo väčšine príspevkov môžeme tweet v holandčine, ktorý 8. októbra na svojom účte uverejnil istý Remco Van Velzen. Podľa našich zistení tento používateľ pravidelne uverejňuje množstvo proruských informácií o vojne na Ukrajine.
O niekoľko hodín neskôr po zverejnení pôvodného tweetu Van Velzen oznámil, že ho zmazal, pričom pripustil, že neexistuje žiadny dôkaz, že vyšetrovanie viedol „pán Ollson [sic]“. Podľa vlastných slov sa len odvolával na konkrétny príspevok, ktorý bol zverejnený na ruskej sociálnej sieti VKontakte.
Pôvodný príspevok na VKontakte bol zverejnený 6. októbra používateľom zdieľajúcim proruský obsah vo francúzštine. V príspevku sa môžeme dočítať, že istý Olsson, ktorý mal byť podľa tohto príspevku tiež švédsky prokurátor, „sľúbil povedať svetu pravdu o výbuchu plynovodu Nord Stream“ a vraj tiež „obvinil tajné služby z pokusu zmocniť sa kľúčových protokolov pobrežnej stráže o sabotáži“. Autor príspevku obsah z iného ruského príspevku zverejneného 3. októbra z účtu s názvom „ANTIrusofób“, ktorý obsahuje rovnaké prvky a ktorého obsah odvtedy skopírovalo mnoho ďalších používateľov.
Ruský príspevok zasa odkazuje na podobný príspevok na Telegrame z 3. októbra zverejnený na ruskom kanáli podporujúcom inváziu Ukrajiny.
Oba príspevky z VKontakte a Telegramu obsahujú okrem zavádzajúceho textu aj fotografiu muža, ktorý má byť údajne mŕtvy.
AFP však pomocou spätného vyhľadávania obrázkov zistila, že pôvodná fotografia v skutočnosti zachytáva maďarského politika menom Zsolt Borkai, čo môžete vidieť v tomto článku Hungary Today z roku 2019 .
Erik Olsen, nórsky expert na morské ekosystémy, musel v dôsledku fám na svojom Twitteri 11. októbra vysvetľovať, že s údajným švédskym vyšetrovateľom, s ktorým má vraj rovnaké meno, nemá nič spoločné.
Podozrenia zo sabotáže: Obnovenie napätia medzi Ruskom a západnými krajinami
Objavenie obrovských únikov z plynovodov Nord Stream 1 a 2 koncom septembra vyvolalo nárast napätia medzi Ruskom a západnými krajinami na pozadí súčasnej vojny na Ukrajine a vzájomných obvinení zo sabotáže.
Prvé kontroly, ktoré švédske orgány vykonali od začiatku októbra, „posilnili podozrenie zo sabotáže“, pričom „detonácie“ spôsobili „značné škody“, oznámila 6. októbra švédska prokuratúra.
„Vidíme, že v blízkosti plynovodov Nord Stream 1 a 2 vo švédskej výlučnej ekonomickej zóne došlo k detonáciám, ktoré mali za následok značné poškodenie plynovodov,“ uviedol v ten istý deň vo vyhlásení Mats Ljungqvist, špeciálny prokurátor zodpovedný za vyšetrovanie.
„Kontroly na mieste incidentu posilnila podozrenie z plánovanej sabotáže. Na mieste boli zaistené dôkazy, ktoré budú preskúmané,“ dodal.
Rusko čeliace podozreniam, že stojí za výbuchmi, sa bránilo tým, že obvinilo Spojené štáty; tie taktiež odmietli akúkoľvek zodpovednosť. Ruský prezident Vladimir Putin v prejave na energetickom fóre v Moskve označil výbuchy plynovodov za výsledok „medzinárodného terorizmu“.
„Beneficienti sú jasní (...) Pretože (tento incident) posilňuje geopolitický význam zostávajúcich plynových systémov, tých, ktoré prechádzajú cez územie Poľska (...) a Ukrajiny a ktoré Rusko vybudovalo na svoje náklady. Ale aj pre Spojené štáty, ktoré im teraz môžu dodávať energiu za vysoké ceny,“ povedal.
Biely dom zase odmietol obvinenia zo strany Ruska ako „smiešne“. „Všetci vieme, že Rusko dlhodobo šíri dezinformácie a robí to aj v tomto prípade,“ komentovala koncom septembra hovorkyňa Rady Bieleho domu pre národnú bezpečnosť Adrienne Watson.
Úniky plynovodu Nord Stream boli zdrojom aj ďalších nepravdivých informácií a konšpiračných teórií na sociálnych sieťach. Niektorí používatelia napríklad špekulovali o havárii súkromného lietadla nemeckého podnikateľa Petra Griesemanna začiatkom septembra. Podľa týchto tvrdení bola Griesemannova spoločnosť zodpovedná za údržbu turbín Nord Stream. Niektorí používatelia sociálnych médií tiež naznačili, že jeho lietadlo mohlo byť zostrelené. Tieto tvrdenia však nie sú pravdivé a agentúra AFP ich vyvrátila.
Máte tip na správu, ktorú by sme v AFP mohli overiť?
Kontaktujte nás
Translation:
Beware of rumors about the alleged death of a Swedish investigator of the Nord Stream gas pipeline accident
- This article is over a year old.
- Posted on October 24, 2022 at 5:34 pm
- You can read the article in 7 minutes
- By Nathan GALLO, AFP France
- The article was translated by Robert BARCA
Copyright © AFP 2017-2024. Any commercial use of this content requires subscription to our services. You can find more information here.
"Erik Ollsen is dead Who is Erik Ollsen?" He was the main investigator of the attack on Nordstream...," is written in Slovak in a post from the Russian social network VKontakte dated October 9, 2022. The post includes a screenshot of a Twitter post in Dutch, according to which Ollsen was even supposed to be the deputy head of the Swedish prosecutor's office.
He was said to be "found at home," according to the post, listing his name as "Olsen." Different versions of this claim give the name of the alleged investigator in different forms, sometimes as Olsen or Ollsen, other times as Olssen, Ulsson or Ollson.
According to a Dutch tweet and a Slovak VKontakte user, the man's cause of death was allegedly a bee sting and his body was cremated "within a few hours".
Similar posts, along with a Dutch tweet, were shared a day later on the AKWSK Telegram channel, this time with the claim that "Erik Olssen, head of the NS1 and NS2 sabotage investigation committee, is dead." The same claim was subsequently copied on Facebook, where more than 250 users shared it.
According to these claims, the man was responsible for investigating the alleged sabotage of the Nord Stream 1 and 2 gas pipelines in the Baltic Sea, which occurred at the end of September.
On September 26, 2022, four massive gas leaks occurred on two gas pipelines in the Baltic Sea that transport Russian gas to Germany, which, according to several countries, were caused by underwater detonations. The Russian Federation, which faces accusations that it was behind the attacks, has denied any responsibility and blamed the attacks on the West.
On October 1, Germany announced the creation of a joint team with Denmark and Sweden to investigate gas leaks. Denmark said on October 13 that the investigation was "progressing well".
The Nord Stream explosions also coincided with the opening of a new gas pipeline from Norway to Poland via Denmark, which aims to reduce European countries' dependence on Russian gas.
"The era of Russian gas dominance is ending," Polish Prime Minister Mateusz Morawiecki said on September 27.
Energy supplies are a major geopolitical and economic issue between the West and Russia, especially since Russia launched a military invasion of Ukraine in late February.
Similar claims about the death of the alleged Swedish investigator Erik Olssen have also spread in English, French, Polish and German.
Swedish authorities: "We have no knowledge of Erik Ollsen"
Swedish authorities have begun investigating the possible cause of the explosions that hit the Nord Stream 1 and 2 gas pipelines in the Baltic Sea. However, through searching and verification, we have found no mention of a person named Erik Ollsen (or similar) within the Swedish institutions responsible for the investigation in this matter.
The Swedish prosecutor's office in charge of the investigation, contacted by AFP, said on October 12 that "no prosecutor responsible for the [Nord Stream] case named Erik Olsson died as a result of a bee sting".
Several posts claimed that relatives of the alleged "representative of the Swedish prosecutor's office" were even contacted by "colleagues" who wanted to express their "condolences". The prosecutor's office rejected the posts, saying: "This is 'fake news'."
The Swedish prosecutor's office also noted that the investigation into the Nord Stream pipeline incidents is currently being led by Mats Ljungqvist, who was quoted in this October 6 press release.
According to several posts on social networks, the Stockholm police issued a statement about Ollsen's death. One such post claimed that police had "communicated some details of what happened" and said that "Ulsson's [sic] will" had been "discovered along with a request for immediate cremation in the event of death".
However, Stockholm police told AFP on October 12 that they were "not aware" of the person and "did not report the matter".
Danish police told AFP in an email on October 18 that "there is no employee with the name Erik Ollson (or any similar name) in the Copenhagen police". They added that to their knowledge the name sounds Swedish.
The German prosecutor's office, which was also contacted by AFP, refused to comment.
AFP found no relevant mention of Erik Ollsen in search engines. Other fact-checking organizations have reached the same conclusions ( here or here ).
Origin on Telegram and on the Russian VKontakte network
Where did these claims come from? In most of the posts, we can tweet in Dutch, which was posted on October 8 on his account by a certain Remco Van Velzen. According to our findings, this user regularly publishes a lot of pro-Russian information about the war in Ukraine.
Hours later after the original tweet was published, Van Velzen announced that he had deleted it, admitting that there was no evidence that "Mr. Ollson [sic]" was leading the investigation. According to his own words, he was only referring to a specific post that was published on the Russian social network VKontakte.
The original post on VKontakte was published on October 6 by a user sharing pro-Russian content in French. In the post, we can read that a certain Olsson, who according to this post was also supposed to be a Swedish prosecutor, "promised to tell the world the truth about the Nord Stream gas pipeline explosion" and allegedly also "accused the secret services of trying to get hold of key Coast Guard sabotage logs." The author of the post content from another Russian post published on October 3rd from an account called "ANTIrusofob", which contains the same elements and whose content has since been copied by many other users.
The Russian post, in turn, refers to a similar Telegram post from October 3 published on a Russian channel supporting the invasion of Ukraine.
Both posts from VKontakte and Telegram contain, in addition to misleading text, a photo of a man who is supposed to be dead.
However, AFP used a reverse image search to find that the original photo actually captures a Hungarian politician named Zsolt Borkai, which you can see in this 2019 Hungary Today article.
Erik Olsen, a Norwegian expert on marine ecosystems, had to clarify on his Twitter account on October 11th that he had nothing to do with the alleged Swedish investigator, with whom he is said to share the same name.
Suspicions of sabotage: Renewal of tensions between Russia and Western countries
The discovery of huge leaks from the Nord Stream 1 and 2 gas pipelines in late September triggered a rise in tensions between Russia and Western countries against the background of the current war in Ukraine and mutual accusations of sabotage.
The first checks carried out by Swedish authorities since the beginning of October "strengthen the suspicion of sabotage", with "detonations" causing "significant damage", Swedish prosecutors announced on 6 October.
"We see that there have been detonations near the Nord Stream 1 and 2 gas pipelines in Sweden's exclusive economic zone, which have resulted in significant damage to the gas pipelines," Mats Ljungqvist, the special prosecutor in charge of the investigation, said in a statement the same day.
"Checks at the scene of the incident strengthened the suspicion of planned sabotage. Evidence was seized at the scene and will be examined," he added.
Faced with suspicions that it was behind the blasts, Russia has defended itself by blaming the United States; they also denied any responsibility. Speaking at an energy forum in Moscow, Russian President Vladimir Putin called the gas pipeline explosions the result of "international terrorism".
"The beneficiaries are clear (...) Because (this incident) reinforces the geopolitical importance of the remaining gas systems, those that pass through the territory of Poland (...) and Ukraine, and which Russia built at its own expense. But also for the United States, which can now supply them with energy at high prices," he said.
The White House, in turn, dismissed Russia's accusations as "ridiculous." "We all know that Russia has been spreading disinformation for a long time, and it is doing so in this case as well," commented Adrienne Watson, spokeswoman for the White House National Security Council, in late September.
The Nord Stream gas pipeline leaks have also been the source of other false information and conspiracy theories on social networks. For example, some users speculated about the crash of German businessman Peter Griesemann's private plane in early September. According to these claims, Griesemann's company was responsible for the maintenance of the Nord Stream turbines. Some social media users also suggested that his plane may have been shot down. However, these claims are not true and have been refuted by AFP.
Do you have a tip for a report that we at AFP could verify?
Contact us
false_claim: Claims that Erik Olsen, the lead investigator of the Nord Stream gas pipeline sabotage, died before revealing secrets about the investigation.

content:
Questo grafico non dimostra che l’attuale temperatura terrestre è tra le più basse degli ultimi 9.500 anni
Il 9 gennaio 2023 la redazione di Facta.news ha ricevuto una segnalazione riguardante un grafico intitolato “Storia del clima nel corso di 9.500 anni”, realizzato nel 2004 da «R.B. Alley» e che riporta le «anomalie di temperatura in gradi Celsius dal 7.643 a.C. a oggi».
All’interno del grafico vengono sottolineati con il colore rosso alcuni presunti picchi di temperature anomale, segnalate rispettivamente come «Optimum dell’Olocene» (attorno al 5.000 a.C.), «riscaldamento minoico» (1.100 a.C.), «riscaldamento romano» (73 d.C.), «riscaldamento medievale» (1.135 d.C.). L’asse delle ascisse, che riporta il riferimento temporale, si ferma al 1885 e in questo periodo il grafico segnala temperature anomale inferiori alla media, accompagnate dal commento «presunto riscaldamento «senza precedenti» del clima attuale».
All’interno del grafico si legge inoltre che «le temperature globali più recenti sono all’estremità inferiore dell’intervallo storico» e che «l’81,3% delle osservazioni negli ultimi 9.500 anni è superiore alla lettura della temperatura più recente». Il grafico è stato condiviso su Twitter come la prova dell’inesistenza dei cambiamenti climatici.
Si tratta di un grafico fuorviante, che veicola una notizia falsa.
Il grafico oggetto della segnalazione non riassume le anomalie di temperatura registrate negli ultimi 9.500 anni, come si legge su Twitter, ma si basa sulle temperature di un nucleo di ghiaccio della Groenlandia aggregati a partire dal 1988 nell’ambito del Greenland Ice Sheet Project 2 (Gisp2), progetto patrocinato dalla US National Science Foundation. I dati sono raccolti attraverso il carotaggio di una sezione di ghiaccio profonda oltre 3mila metri e nel 2000 sono stati utilizzati all’interno di un articolo scientifico pubblicato dal professor Richard B. Alley, un geoscienziato americano della Pennsylvania State University.
Contattato nel 2010 dai colleghi del New York Times, Alley aveva chiarito che il grafico non può in alcun modo essere rappresentativo del trend riguardante le temperature globali, dal momento che «la temperatura è un record locale e un sito non è il mondo intero» e che per questo motivo è «scientificamente non ragionevole» utilizzare i dati del grafico per negare il riscaldamento globale.
Come avevamo spiegato in un precedente articolo, il riscaldamento globale è un fenomeno di incremento delle temperature medie della superficie terrestre riconducibile all’azione umana e in grado di condizionare fenomeni atmosferici come alluvioni, siccità, desertificazione e scioglimento dei ghiacci. Secondo l’ultimo report pubblicato dall’agenzia federale americana che si occupa di oceanografia, meteorologia e climatologia (Noaa), dal 1880 la temperatura terrestre è aumentata di 0,08 gradi Celsius per decennio, mentre dal 1981 il tasso di riscaldamento ha accelerato, raggiungendo un aumento di 0,18 gradi Celsius per decennio.
Uno studio pubblicato nel 2020 dalla rivista Scientific Data ha rivelato che l’intervallo di tempo più caldo della storia umana, prima dell’industrializzazione, si era verificato circa 6.500 anni fa durante l’Olocene, quando le temperature della superficie terrestre erano state di circa 0,7 gradi Celsius più calde rispetto a quelle del XIX secolo. Le temperature registrate tra il 2011 e il 2019, tuttavia, sono state mediamente di un grado centigrado superiori a quelle del XIX secolo e dunque inequivocabilmente superiori a quelle dell’Olocene.
Questo contenuto di disinformazione è stato verificato anche dai colleghi di Aap e da quelli di Correctiv.
Aiuta facta.news a combattere la disinformazione, segnala i contenuti sospetti via WhatsApp al numero 342-1829 843 oppure clicca qui.
Insieme renderemo Internet un posto più sicuro!
Translation:
This graph does not demonstrate that the current Earth temperature is among the lowest in the last 9,500 years
On January 9, 2023, the editorial staff of Facta.news received a report regarding a graph entitled “History of climate over the course of 9,500 years”, created in 2004 by «R.B. Alley" and which reports the "temperature anomalies in degrees Celsius since 7,643 BC. to this day."
Within the graph, some presumed anomalous temperature peaks are underlined in red, reported respectively as «Holocene Optimum» (around 5,000 BC), «Minoan warming» (1,100 BC), «Roman warming» (73 AD). ), «medieval warming» (1.135 AD). The x-axis, which shows the time reference, stops at 1885 and in this period the graph reports anomalous temperatures below the average, accompanied by the comment "presumed "unprecedented" warming of the current climate".
The graph also states that "the most recent global temperatures are at the lower end of the historical range" and that "81.3% of observations over the last 9,500 years are above the most recent temperature reading." The graph was shared on Twitter as proof of the non-existence of climate change.
This is a misleading graph, which conveys false news.
The graph being reported does not summarize the temperature anomalies recorded over the last 9,500 years, as we read on Twitter, but is based on the temperatures of a Greenland ice core aggregated since 1988 as part of the Greenland Ice Sheet Project 2 ( Gisp2), a project sponsored by the US National Science Foundation. The data was collected through core drilling from a section of ice over 3,000 meters deep and in 2000 was used in a scientific article published by Professor Richard B. Alley, an American geoscientist from Pennsylvania State University.
Contacted in 2010 by colleagues at the New York Times, Alley clarified that the graph cannot in any way be representative of the trend regarding global temperatures, since "the temperature is a local record and a site is not the whole world" and that for this reason it is "scientifically unreasonable" to use the graph data to deny global warming.
As we explained in a previous article, global warming is a phenomenon of increase in the average temperatures of the earth's surface attributable to human action and capable of influencing atmospheric phenomena such as floods, drought, desertification and melting of ice. According to the latest report published by the American federal agency that deals with oceanography, meteorology and climatology (Noaa), since 1880 the earth's temperature has increased by 0.08 degrees Celsius per decade, while since 1981 the rate of warming has accelerated, reaching an increase of 0.18 degrees Celsius per decade.
A study published in 2020 by the journal Scientific Data revealed that the warmest time interval in human history, before industrialization, occurred around 6,500 years ago during the Holocene, when Earth's surface temperatures had been around 0.7 degrees Celsius warmer than in the 19th century.
